Massage means any tactile stimulation of another person, for hire, below the collarbone on the front torso and the shoulder blades on the back torso including, but not limited to, touching, rubbing, probing, scrubbing, bathing, cleaning, rinsing, or otherwise applying hands or other body contact of the masseuse or a mechanical apparatus or appliance to the torso of another to clean, relieve tension or pain, stimulate blood flow, provide pleasurable sensation or for any other purposes. 
Massage parlor means a business with a location in Macon-Bibb County at which any person engages in or offers massage, regardless of the name of the business or the words used to describe the business through signage or advertisement or in filings with the Secretary of State. Massage parlors are subject to regulation by a local government, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(b)(17) and O.C.G.A. § 43-24A-22(a) as amended. 
Masseuse, masseur, massage practitioner, or persons practicing massage means a person who performs or engages in the practice of massage. 
State license means a license to practice massage therapy issued by the board, pursuant to the Act. 
Sec. 7-271. - Requirements and application. 
(a)  Requirements. 
(1)  a.  State license. No person other than a licensed massage therapist shall perform or offer to perform massage in a massage parlor within Macon-Bibb County. 
b.  No license shall be issued to any massage parlor within Macon-Bibb County under this division unless every person who performs or offers to perform massage on its premises is a licensed massage therapist, and it shall be unlawful to operate as a massage parlor unless all such persons are and remain licensed massage therapists. The Macon-Bibb County license of a massage parlor that fails to meet this requirement is subject to revocation. 
(2)  Macon-Bibb County license. No person shall operate a massage parlor without a valid, current, unrevoked, and unsuspended license from Macon-Bibb County, pursuant to this division. 
(3)  Conviction of a crime. No license under this section shall be issued or renewed to any person who shall have been convicted or shall have entered a plea of nolo contendere for any felony within ten (10) years, or two (2) misdemeanors within five (5) years, other than traffic violations, immediately prior to the filing of the application. The term "conviction" shall include an adjudication of guilty or plea of guilty or nolo contendere or the forfeiture of a bond in part or in whole when charged with a crime. Licenses granted to persons who fail to meet this requirement at any time shall be subject to revocation. 
(4)  Age of licensee; education. No person under the age of eighteen (18) shall be issued a license to operate a massage parlor. No license shall be issued to an applicant who does not have a high school diploma or its recognized equivalent. 
(5)  Personal residency; agent. All applicants for licenses under this chapter and all actual owners of parlors for which licenses are sought shall be bona fide residents of Macon-Bibb County at the time of the filing of the applications and shall remain bona fide residents of such county during all times that the licenses and renewals thereof are in effect, or shall name one (1) or more residents in Macon-Bibb County as the agent or representative of the licensee, who shall be responsible for any matter relating to such license and who, at all such times, shall be a bona fide resident of Macon-Bibb County. 
(6)  Corporate residency. All applications for licenses under this chapter by a corporation or other business entity shall name in the application one (1) or more residents in Macon-Bibb County as the agent and representative of the corporation to receive all communications, notices, services of process, or other papers or documents on behalf of the corporation in connection with any matter arising out of or connected with the issuance, holding, suspension, revocation, or other action with respect to any license issued pursuant to this division. The application shall give the mailing address of the person, and the mailing to any such person at such address of any notice required to be given under this chapter or any other law shall be sufficient notice to the corporation. If any such person shall cease to be a resident of Macon-Bibb County, another person shall immediately be appointed, in writing, in his place, and written notice shall be given the department of business and development services, stating the name and address of the new agent. 
(7)  Annual license fee. The annual license fee shall be determined from time to time by the mayor and commission, based upon the reasonable costs of the actual regulatory activity, and listed in a schedule of fees and charges maintained by the Department of Business and Development Services. 
(b)  Application for license. 
(1)  To operate a massage parlor within Macon-Bibb County, the applicant must first make application to the Department of Business and Development Services on a form provided by the Department of Business and Development Services or his designee, and that person, after having fully and truthfully completed such form and paying the prescribed fees and having received a license, shall maintain and operate such business pursuant to the ordinances of Macon-Bibb County and the laws of the state. 
(2)  Upon applying for a license with the Department of Business and Development Services, each applicant shall provide a true and correct copy or original of the state license for each and every massage practitioner, performing or anticipated to perform massage at its location, to the finance officer for inspection and copying. Failure of any massage practitioner to provide his or her state license shall automatically result in the denial of the issuance of a Macon-Bibb County license to the applicant. 
(3)  Subsequent to the Macon-Bibb County license being issued, the licensee shall, in person, furnish to the Department of Business and Development Services or his designee a true and correct copy or original of the state license of each new massage practitioner at the licensee's massage parlor prior to such person's commencing to perform or offering to perform massage at such massage parlor. When any massage practitioner discontinues performing massage at a massage parlor, the licensee shall make the departure known in writing to the Department of Business and Development Services within thirty (30) days of such departure. 
(4)  Each applicant for a license shall make his or her affidavit before the Department of Business and Development Services or his designee, on a form provided by the Department of Business and Development Services, upon oath, swearing or affirming that all persons practicing massage on the premises of his or her massage parlor are licensed massage therapists and that all requirements of this division for a license have been met. 
Sec. 7-272. - License renewal. 
Licenses for massage parlors may be renewed on a calendar year basis, provided that the licensee(s) continue to meet the requirements set out in this division and the requirements of the Act. 
Sec. 7-273. - Registry. 
A registry shall be kept of all persons practicing massage on the premises of such massage parlor, which shall be available for inspection by an agent of Macon-Bibb County during normal hours of business, providing the following information: 
(1)  Legal name and any other name(s) the massage practitioner has been or is known as or by; 
(2)  Current address; 
(3)  State or country of birth; date of birth; 
(4)  Number and expiration date of state license; and 
(5)  Position with the massage parlor or business entity. 
Sec. 7-274. - Posting licenses and rates. 
(a)  Each massage parlor shall post its license obtained pursuant to this division, along with the state license of each masseuse operating on the premises of such parlor, in a conspicuous place in the licensee's place of business and shall keep such licenses there at all times. 
(b)  Price rates for all services shall be prominently posted in the reception area or other conspicuous location available for all prospective customers. No service shall be allowed or permitted that is not prominently posted with its fees in such location. 
Sec. 7-275. - Escort services and adult entertainment prohibited. 
No massage parlor shall act as an escort or dating service. 
Sec. 7-276. - Alcoholic beverages prohibited. 
No alcoholic beverages shall be sold, served, given, dispensed, provided, consumed, or caused or allowed to be sold, served, given, dispensed, provided, consumed by or to any person on the premises of a massage parlor or kept thereon. Alcoholic beverages means and includes all types and kinds of alcohol as defined in the Alcoholic Beverages chapter of this Code of Ordinances. 
Sec. 7-277. - Hours of operation; inspection. 
(a)  Massage parlors shall be open for business only between the hours of 6 a.m. and 11 p.m., inclusive. 
(b)  Any business holding a license issued under this division shall, at any time that the premises are open for business, be open to inspection by a law enforcement officer, the health department, license inspectors, and/or fire department inspectors. 
Sec. 7-278. - Name; place of business; sale, transfer, or change of location. 
No person or business entity granted a location license pursuant to this division shall operate the business under a name not specified in the license nor conduct business at any location or place not specified in the license. No license shall be transferable. Upon the sale or relocation of a massage parlor, the license thereof shall be null and void. 
Sec. 7-279. - Restrictions on minor's presence. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or persons operating a massage parlor to permit persons under eighteen (18) years of age to enter the licensed premises unless such minor is accompanied by a parent or guardian, has the written, notarized permission of the parent or guardian, or has a written prescription from a physician, surgeon, osteopath, or podiatrist who has a valid current license, issued pursuant to Georgia law. 
Sec. 7-280. - Operating requirements. 
(a)  Every portion of the premises of, and all equipment and supplies of, the massage parlor shall be kept clean and shall be operated in a sanitary condition. 
(b)  All employees and masseuses at each massage parlor shall wear clean, nontransparent outer garments, covering the breast, buttocks and genital areas. 
Sec. 7-281. - Revocation, suspensions, violations, and penalties. 
Macon-Bibb County may, upon notice and a hearing for good cause, revoke or suspend or place on probation the license of any massage parlor: 
(1)  That commits or allows any violations of the provisions of this division of the Macon-Bibb County Code; 
(2)  That allows any masseuse, working on the massage parlor's premises, to commit or offer to commit a sexual crime under O.C.G.A. Title 16, Chapter 6; 
(3)  That allows any person to perform or offer massage on the premises who is not a licensed massage therapist; 
(4)  Where the applicant for the massage parlor's license gave false information on the application, in his or her affidavit, or in the massage parlor's registry as required in this division, or fails to update information related to the license to the Department of Business and Development Services as required by this division; or 
(5)  Where the licensee fails at any time to meet the requirements for licensure under this division. 
Any violation of any section of this division shall be punishable as provided in the general penalty section of the Code of Ordinances of Macon-Bibb County. Each day during which said offenses occur shall constitute a separate offense, as shall each separate act constitute a violation. 
Sec. 7-282. - Exemptions. 
(a)  The requirements of this division shall have no application to or effect upon the following persons acting within the scope of their professions: 
(1)  Medical doctors and osteopaths, chiropractors, physical and occupational therapists, podiatrists, acupuncturists, registered or licensed practical nurses, barbers, beauty culturists, and cosmetologists duly licensed to practice in this state pursuant to O.C.G.A. Title 43; 
(2)  Employees of duly licensed nursing and convalescent homes and hospitals; 
(3)  Athletic directors or trainers who are affiliated with an accredited educational institution or a bona fide sports team and whose work is limited to athletic team members. 
(b)  The requirement of subsection 7-271(a)(1)a., of this division, requiring licensure under the Act, shall not apply to persons excluded from state licensure pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 43-24A-19, acting within the scope of their professions. 
Secs. 7-283—7-285. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 12. - MISCELLANEOUS BUSINESSES 

Sec. 7-286. - Carnival and tent shows; permit required; prohibited locations; games tax or fee. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any carnival, circus, tent show, or any other show of like nature, unless they shall first obtain a permit from the Department of Business and Development Services. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any street fair, carnival, or other tent shows to exhibit, or erect any tents, huts or houses for the purpose of exhibiting, on any of the streets, lanes or parks within Macon-Bibb County; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall be construed to make it unlawful to hold such exhibitions or shows, with the permission of the commission. 
(c)  Every circus, carnival company, traveling show, and every other person operating or showing in Macon-Bibb County, whether under auspices of any local organization or not, any so-called game of skill, the operation of which is legal under state laws, and for the playing of which any charge is made or accepted, shall pay to Macon-Bibb County a fee or tax in an amount to be determined from time to time by the commission and listed in the schedule of fees and charges maintained by the Department of Business and Development Services. 
Sec. 7-287. - House moving; permit. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to move, carry or otherwise transport houses, buildings, parts of buildings or other large structures through or across the streets of Macon-Bibb County without first having obtained a permit from the director of the Department of Business and Development Services and approval of the sheriff's department. 
(b)  The director of the Department of Business and Development Services is hereby delegated the duty and responsibility for issuing permits to applicants desiring to use the streets of Macon-Bibb County for moving houses, buildings, parts of buildings or other large objects. 
(c)  The permit required by this section shall constitute an additional requirement to any other requirements in this Code or state law. 
(d)  In determining whether a permit shall be issued, the director of the Department of Business and Development Services and sheriff's department shall take into account the following factors in addition to any other factors as may be necessary to determine whether a proposed moving is in the public interest: 
(1)  The length of time required for the moving; 
(2)  The hours during which the moving is to take place and in particular whether the proposed moving conflicts with heavy traffic patterns; 
(3)  The route of the proposed moving; and 
(4)  The equipment and personnel available and employed for the proposed moving. 
(e)  If the director of the Department of Business and Development Services or sheriff's department determines that the proposed moving of a structure hereunder would create a serious traffic hazard or otherwise be unreasonably dangerous to the public at large, either shall deny the application for a permit as required by this section. Otherwise the director of the Department of Business and Development Services shall approve the application and issue the permit. 
Sec. 7-288. - Fortunetelling, palmistry, phrenology, astrology, clairvoyance, and other kindred practices. 
(a)  No person shall engage in, conduct, or carry on in or upon any premises within Macon-Bibb County fortunetelling, palmistry, phrenology, astrology, clairvoyance, and/or kindred practices unless that person holds a valid unexpired and unrevoked license issued by Macon-Bibb County. 
(b)  The annual license fee shall be determined from time-to-time by the commission based upon the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity, and listed in a schedule of fees and charges maintained by the Department of Business and Development Services. 
(c)  No license under this section shall be issued or renewed to any person who shall have been convicted or shall have entered a plea of nolo contendere for any felony within five (5) years, or two (2) misdemeanors within two (2) years, other than traffic violations, immediately prior to the filing of the application. The term "conviction" shall include an adjudication of guilty or plea of guilty or nolo contendere or the forfeiture of a bond in part or in whole when charged with a crime. 
(d)  Any person desiring to obtain a license under this section to operate within Macon-Bibb County shall make an application to the department of business and development services. The application shall be accompanied by the following: 
(1)  Proof of planning and zoning compliance. 
(2)  Proof of building code compliance. 
(3)  Proof of fire code compliance. 
(4)  The full name, age, residence, present and previous occupations of the applicant. 
(5)  A specific description of the location of the proposed place of business of the applicant. 
(6)  A list of three (3) character references and at least three (3) business references who have known the applicant for a period of at least five (5) years. 
(7)  A list of dates and places of employment for five (5) years prior to date of application. 
(8)  A photograph and fingerprints made by the sheriff's department. 
(9)  A letter of clearance from the U.S. District Court of the Middle District, and a letter of clearance from the Clerk of Bibb County Superior Court, indicating that the applicant does not have any criminal charges currently pending and that the applicant has no convictions from the respective court within five (5) years, excluding traffic offenses. 
(10)  A letter of clearance from the Clerk of the State Court of Bibb County showing that the applicant has no criminal charges pending and no convictions in the past two (2) years, excluding traffic offenses. 
(11)  An affidavit from the applicant stating that the applicant has no criminal charges pending nor any convictions from any other court in the United States that would make the applicant ineligible as provided in section 10-333(b). 
(12)  Any false statement or material misrepresentation in any application hereunder shall be grounds for revocation of any license granted hereunder. 
(e)  Within ten (10) days after receipt of an application as provided for in this section the sheriff's department shall cause an investigation to be made of the applicant and his proposed operations and shall furnish his findings to the Department of Business and Development Services. 
(f)  If, upon investigation, the sheriff's department shall find that the applicant is of good moral character and meets the requirements of this section, the Department of Business and Development Services shall issue a license to the applicant. 
(g)  Any person having or applying for a license hereunder shall meet the standards set forth above and shall be subject to all regulations of this Code. 
(h)  Licenses issued under this section shall not be transferable, and shall be subject to revocation or suspension by the municipal court judge for violation of any of the provisions of this Code or misconduct by the licensee, after reasonable notice and an opportunity to be heard has been given the licensee. 
Sec. 7-289. - Reserved. 
Sec. 7-290. - Motorized vendors. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any motorized vehicle used for the purpose of selling ice cream, candy, soft drinks or other such similar goods from the streets in Macon-Bibb County to carry on that activity without first clearly labeling the vehicle so as to identify the types of goods sold and to further mark the vehicle to warn approaching motorists that sudden stops may be required. 
(b)  All such vehicles are prohibited from ringing bells or using other noise-producing devices in neighborhoods after the hour of 9:00 p.m. 
Sec. 7-291. - Motorized trailer exhibits restricted. 
Motorized trailer exhibits on the streets of Macon-Bibb County are hereby prohibited when such exhibits permit or require contributions or admission charges. 
Secs. 7-292. - Reserved. 
Secs. 7-293. - Reserved. 
Sec. 7-294. - Convenience stores. 
(a)  All persons who own or operate a convenience store are required to ensure that at least seventy-five (75) percent of the window area through which the cash register or transaction area may be seen is free from signage or other obstructions and further must ensure that there is at all times a clear view of the cash register or transaction area along normal lines of sight from the outside of the store through all such window areas. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, the term "convenience store" shall include any small retail store that is stocked to sell primarily prepackaged food items, but may also sell beverages, periodicals, and other household supplies to customers who purchase relatively few items per visit. Such stores may also sell fuel and are often open between the hours of midnight and 6:00 a.m. 
Secs. 7-295—7-330. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 13. - RESERVED 

Secs. 7-331—7-355. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 14. - SELF-SERVICE FUEL STATIONS 

Sec. 7-356. - Self-service fuel pumps and stations. 
In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 36-60-1, it is hereby determined that the operation of self-service motor fuel dispensing pumps will not be injurious to the health or welfare of the citizens and residents of Macon-Bibb County so long as the operation of self-service motor fuel dispensing pumps is carried out in compliance with Chapter 120-3-11 of the Rules and Regulations of the safety fire commissioner of the state and N.F.P.A. 30 pertaining to flammable and combustible liquids, and the further requirements of this division. 
Sec. 7-357. - License application. 
Any person desiring to operate self-service motor fuel dispensing pumps within Macon-Bibb County shall make application to the Department of Business and Development Services for a license on the form prescribed by the chief of the fire prevention bureau and shall pay a license fee or business tax in the amount prescribed by the business license and business tax ordinances of Macon-Bibb County. 
Sec. 7-358. - Issuance; display. 
The chief of the fire prevention bureau shall review the application and if the chief determines that the applicant is in compliance with the rules and regulations of the safety fire commissioner of the state and the requirements of this division, the Department of Business and Development Services shall issue a license to the applicant which shall be posted in a conspicuous location where it may be viewed by authorized representatives of the fire prevention bureau, other authorities and customers. 
Sec. 7-359. - Permitted dispensing devices. 
Approved special dispensing devices such as, but not limited to, remote-controlled pre-pay and post-pay types are permitted at self-service stations. 
Sec. 7-360. - Presence of attendant required; functions. 
All self-service stations shall have at least one qualified attendant on duty while the station is open to the public. The attendant's function shall be to supervise, observe and control the dispensing of and the collection for the various fuels. It shall be the responsibility of the attendant to prevent the dispensing of class 1 liquids into approved containers, and is fitted with a spout or so designed that the contents can be poured without spilling. It shall also be the responsibility of the attendant to control sources of ignition, and to immediately handle accidental spills and fire extinguishers as needed. The attendant or supervisor on duty shall be capable of performing the functions and assuming the responsibilities required in this section. 
Sec. 7-361. - Safety requirements. 
(a)  Emergency controls, excluding main power shutoff switches, shall be installed at a location within twenty (20) feet from the attendant's principal control location, not more than one hundred (100) feet from the dispensers, and shall at all times be accessible to the attendant on duty. Main power shutoff will be located in compliance with state regulations. 
(b)  Instructions for the operation of the dispensers shall be conspicuously posted on either the dispenser or the dispenser island. 
(c)  A list of emergency procedures and instructions shall be conspicuously posted in the immediate vicinity of the attendant's principal control location. 
(d)  The dispensing operation shall at all times be in clear view of the attendant, and the placing or allowing of any obstacle to come between the dispensing operation and the attendant so as to obstruct the attendant's view is prohibited. 
(e)  At all times while class 1 liquids are being dispensed, the attendant shall be required to remain within arm's length distance of the remote control facilities at the principal control location. 
(f)  No self-service station shall be prohibited from installing and no customer at such station shall be prohibited from using hold-open latches on gasoline or diesel fuel pumps available for operation by the customer. However, if hold-open latches are used on pumps operated by the customer, such pumps shall be equipped with a functioning automatic closing device. 
(g)  A voice communications system, such as, but not limited to, an intercom system, so as to allow direct voice communications at all times between the person dispensing gasoline and the attendant shall be required. 
(h)  On each and every dispenser island shall be conspicuously posted in letters at least two (2) inches in height, the following signs: 
(1)  "Warning—It is unlawful to dispense gasoline into any portable container unless the container is constructed of metal or is approved by the Fire Prevention Bureau of Macon-Bibb County"; 
(2)  "No Smoking" signs, four (4) inches in height, one and one-quarter (1¼) inches in width; and 
(3)  Ignition cut off signs. 
(i)  A minimum of six hundred (600) square feet shall be designated for self-service gasoline dispensing area only. This area, if in question, will have proper signs, color coded and the like, to define gasoline dispensing areas. 
(j)  Any establishment possessing a retail packaged to go liquor license or a liquor consumption-on-the-premises license or both shall be ineligible to obtain any self-service fuel licenses. 
(k)  Each license applicant must present an acceptable traffic flow chart for the station area to be licensed for approval of the chart by the Macon-Bibb County Traffic Engineer and the Fire Prevention Bureau. 
(l)  All wiring must be in compliance with the Macon-Bibb County Electrical Code and any state and local laws for such installation. 
Secs. 7-362—7-380. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 15. - SIDEWALK CAFES 

Sec. 7-381. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this division is to provide for regulation of sidewalk cafes operated by qualified restaurants on public sidewalks in the downtown area, and to more fully promote the public interest by contributing to a viable and attractive commercial and pedestrian environment. In recognition thereof, reasonable regulation of sidewalk cafes is necessary to protect the public health, safety, and welfare, and the interest of Macon-Bibb County and the primary use of the public streets and sidewalks by vehicular and pedestrian traffic. 
Sec. 7-381.1. - Qualifications; special permit. 
The use of sidewalks for restaurant tables shall only be permitted incidental to the operation of a qualified, registered restaurant on private property. For purposes of this chapter, a qualified, registered restaurant would be one which derives at least fifty (50) percent of its total annual gross food and beverage sales revenues from the sale of prepared meals or food. A special permit to conduct such use shall be allowed for in the office of the department of business and development services and shall become effective on the date of issuance and shall automatically expire on December 31st of the year of its issuance. A request for the use of sidewalks shall be subject to approval of the urban development authority, compliance with this Code and building code regulations, and all other legal requirements. 
Sec. 7-381.2. - No closing of sidewalk cafes for special events. 
No restaurant, nor sidewalk cafe that is permitted pursuant to this division, shall be ordered closed, or constructively closed, for any street party or similar event in the central business district regardless of street closings related to said parties and events unless specifically ordered by resolution of the mayor and commission. 
Sec. 7-382. - Restrictions on use of sidewalks. 
(a)  In no event shall the uses permitted by this division reduce that portion of any sidewalk customarily used by pedestrians to less than five (5) feet in width. At least a 15-foot setback from the street curbs at street intersection corners shall be maintained. Additionally, contiguous pedestrian flow must be maintained between two (2) or more adjacent sidewalk cafes. 
(b)  Tables and chairs cannot be placed more than ten (10) feet from the front of the building in which the food is prepared, except as provided otherwise in subsection (g). 
(c)  Tables and chairs and all other unsecured fixtures that are not fully secured must be removed from the sidewalk at the close of business of the restaurant and shall be so stored during all nonoperating hours. 
(d)  Macon-Bibb County reserves the right of access to all portions of the sidewalk included in areas permitted for the purposes of sidewalk repair or other necessary purposes. 
(e)  Persons issued permits pursuant to this section shall maintain the sidewalk area in a clean and safe condition. 
(f)  Only the area in front of a restaurant, as defined by projecting its interior width outward perpendicular to the street to a point at which it intersects the roadway, can be used by the restaurant, unless the licensee has a written agreement with adjacent property owners to use part of the sidewalk area in front of his business. Placement of tables and chairs will be permitted in areas more than ten (10) feet from the front of the building only when the permitting authorities determine it is in the best interest of the public to permit such placement. All tables and chairs must be of a design, material, and specification suitable for outside dining. The sidewalk cafe area may be delineated by the use of non-permanent decorative devices such as railings, potted plants, decorative chain fencing or other such fixtures approved by the Urban Development Authority and Macon-Bibb County. The permanent anchoring of railings, fencing, or other fixtures may be approved by the Urban Development Authority and Macon-Bibb County with assurances that the sidewalk will be repaired upon closure of the sidewalk cafe business. Such railing or fencing material shall be approved by the permitting authorities and shall be similar in design, material and construction for all sidewalk cafes. 
(g)  Sidewalk cafes will only be permitted in the CBD-Central Business District Zone as defined by the comprehensive land development resolution for Macon-Bibb County. Actual location approval within said district shall be at the discretion of the Urban Development Authority and Macon-Bibb County. 
(h)  Except as specifically provided in this division, the ownership, operation and maintenance of a sidewalk cafe shall be subject to all applicable laws, ordinances and regulations. 
(i)  The distance requirements of subsection (a) and (b), shall not apply to nonconforming sidewalk café locations that were approved by the Macon-Bibb County Urban Development Authority prior to November 15, 1994. 
Sec. 7-383. - Permit—Procedure. 
(a)  An applicant for a permit under this division shall file his application therefore with the Department of Business and Development Services on forms provided by the Department of Business and Development Services. In addition to the application form, petitioner must submit a site plan of the proposed area and photos or specifications of the proposed furnishings and accessory signage. 
(b)  The Department of Business and Development Services shall refer the application package to the Urban Development Authority, who shall consider the application and conduct a hearing thereon. The Urban Development Authority shall notify by mail the property owners and tenants at the three (3) adjacent business locations on both sides of the proposed sidewalk cafe of the time and place at which such application shall be considered by the authority. 
(c)  Upon approval of the Urban Development Authority, verification by the Department of Business and Development Services or his designee that the applicant is a qualified, registered restaurant operator in good standing at the specified location, payment of appropriate fees, and compliance with all other requirements of this chapter, a permit may be issued by the department of business and development services. 
(d)  Any applicant who shall be refused a permit by the Department of Business and Development Services due to disapproval of his application by the Urban Development Authority shall have ten (10) days from the date of such refusal to appeal to the commission, whose decision shall be final. 
Sec. 7-384. - Same—Insurance prerequisite. 
(a)  No permit shall be issued pursuant to this section, unless the applicant shall furnish to the Department of Business and Development Services evidence of public liability insurance, naming Macon-Bibb County and the Macon-Bibb County Urban Development Authority as co-insured parties and insuring them against any liability resulting from the uses permitted pursuant to this section. The coverage shall not be less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00). 
(b)  No permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall be valid at any time the insurance required by this section is not maintained and evidence of its continuance filed with the Department of Business and Development Services. 
Sec. 7-385. - Same—Revocation. 
The permit may be revoked at any time by written notice to be served by the Department of Business and Development Services on the permittee; such service to be by certified mail or personal service. Upon receipt of such revocation notice, the permittee shall have ten (10) days to appeal such revocation to the commission, whose decision shall be final. 
Sec. 7-386. - Same—Fees. 
An annual fee of one hundred thirty dollars ($130.00) shall be due concurrent with the due date of the business occupation tax of the restaurant and shall be paid to the Department of Business and Development Services. All fees required herein shall be in addition to any other fees or payments required elsewhere in this Code. 
Sec. 7-387. - Same—Refunds and prorations. 
(a)  When the permit fee has been paid during the first half of the calendar year, and the person paying such fee discontinues the business during the first half of the calendar year, the mayor and Department of Business and Development Services may authorize the refunding of one-half of such fee, provided all other fees and taxes owing by such person have been paid. 
(b)  On any new sidewalk cafe permitted by Macon-Bibb County after July first of each year, the permit fee shall be one-half of the amount as set by ordinance. 
DIVISION 15.5. - SIDEWALK FOOD VENDORS 

Sec. 7-388. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this division is to provide for regulation of sidewalk food vending activities in the downtown area and to more fully promote the public interest by contributing to an active and attractive pedestrian environment. In recognition thereof, reasonable regulation of the street and sidewalk vending is necessary to protect public health, safety and welfare and the interest of Macon-Bibb County and the primary use of the public streets and sidewalks for use by vehicular and pedestrian traffic. 
Sec. 7-389. - Permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or association to engage in and carry on the business of food vending upon streets, sidewalks or public ways of Macon-Bibb County embraced within what is known as the fire zone without first having obtained a permit as required by this division; provided, however, that this section shall not prohibit the issuance of temporary permits or licenses issued under other provisions of this Code. 
Sec. 7-390. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases when used in this division shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Department of health means the Macon-Bibb County Board of Health. 
Fire zone means the downtown fire district which is defined as embraced within the following boundaries: 
Beginning at the intersection of Martin Luther King, Jr., Boulevard and Riverside Drive; extending along Riverside Drive to Spring Street; extending along Spring Street and an extension thereof to Hazel Street; extending along Hazel Street to Fifth Street; extending along Fifth Street and Martin Luther King, Jr., Boulevard to Riverside Drive, the beginning point, including both sides of segments of the above streets forming such boundaries. 
Food means a solid food and nonalcoholic beverages allowed to be sold in accordance with this division. 
Public ways means and includes all portions of streets and alleys from property line to property line. 
Push cart means a wheeled vehicle propelled solely by a single human. 
Vending means the act of selling, offering for sale, transferring or offering to transfer to another for pecuniary gain. 
Vendor means any person engaged in the selling or offering for sale, of food or nonalcoholic beverages on the public streets or sidewalks from a push cart. 
Sec. 7-391. - Application requirements. 
The application for a permit for sidewalk food vendors shall be made at the office of the Department of Business and Development Services on a form deemed appropriate by the Department of Business and Development Services. Such application shall include but not be limited to the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of the applicant; 
(2)  The expiration date of the applicant's business license; 
(3)  Type of items to be sold; 
(4)  A valid copy of all necessary permits required by the department of health; 
(5)  A signed statement that the permittee shall hold harmless Macon-Bibb County, its officers and employees and shall indemnify Macon-Bibb County, its officers and employees for any claims for damage to property or injury to persons which may be occasioned by any activity carried on under the terms of the permit. The permittee shall furnish and maintain such public liability, food products liability and property damage insurance as will protect the permittee and Macon-Bibb County from all claims for damage to property or bodily injury, including death, which may arise from operations under the permit or in connection therewith. Such insurance shall provide coverage of not less than a combined single limit of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for each occurrence. Such insurance shall name as an additional insured Macon-Bibb County, its officers and employees, and shall further provide that the policy shall not terminate or be cancelled prior to the completion of the contract without ten (10) days' written notice to the Department of Business and Development Services; 
(6)  A description (including a photograph) of the permittee's push cart; and 
(7)  The proposed location for conducting business, including written approval for each location by the Macon-Bibb County Urban Development Authority. 
Sec. 7-392. - Permit fee. 
A permit fee of one hundred thirty dollars ($130.00) shall be collected prior to the issuance of the permit and annually thereafter. 
Sec. 7-393. - Location selection. 
(a)  The permit location shall be subject to the approval of the Macon-Bibb County Urban Development Authority. 
(b)  No more than two (2) sidewalk food vending permits shall be issued in any one (1) block of any public way within Macon-Bibb County. 
(c)  The use of the permit operating area for sidewalk food vendors must be compatible with the public interest and use of the sidewalk and street areas and public rights-of-way. In making such determination, the Urban Development Authority shall consider the width of the sidewalk, the proximity and location of existing street fixtures, including but not limited to sign posts, lamp posts, benches, phone booths, street trees, as well as the presence of bus stops, truck loading zones, handicapped parking spaces or the like. 
Sec. 7-394. - Restrictions. 
Any person with a valid sidewalk food vending permit issued pursuant to this division shall be subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  All vendors must display, in a prominent and visible manner the permit issued by the Department of Business and Development Service's office under the provisions of this division. 
(2)  The push cart shall not occupy more than thirty (30) square feet of sidewalk space, which shall include the push cart, the operator and a trash receptacle. 
(3)  The size of the push cart shall not exceed four (4) feet, six (6) inches in widths, six (6) feet in length, and five (5) feet in height (excluding canopies or umbrellas). 
(4)  The name of the vendor and/or business shall be displayed on the exterior of the push cart. 
(5)  Vendor shall not hinder the use of any phone booth, mail box, parking meter, fire alarm, fire hydrant or traffic signal controls. 
(6)  Vendor shall obey any lawful order from a law enforcement officer or fire department official during an emergency, parade, street festival or similar event to avoid congestion or obstruction of the sidewalk. 
(7)  No vendor shall make loud noises or use mechanical, audio or noise making devices to advertise his or her product. 
(8)  No push cart shall be left unattended on the public way, nor remain on the sidewalk between midnight and 6:00 a.m. 
(9)  If the vending site is located along the route or within the designated area of a parade, street festival or similar vent, a permit issued under this division shall not entitle a vendor to operate a push cart at the vending site during a parade or street festival or similar event; provided, however, nothing in this division shall prohibit a street vendor from participating in such event with the approval of the sponsor of such event. 
Sec. 7-395. - Permit revocation or denial. 
The municipal court judge shall have the power and authority to evoke, or deny the renewal of any permit applied for or issued under the provisions of this division. Any permit issued under this division may be suspended, revoked or nonrenewed based upon one (1) or more of the following grounds: 
(1)  Upon the cancellation of any health department authority or permit for food or beverage vending. 
(2)  If the vendor violates or fails to meet any of the provisions of this division. 
(3)  If the vendor does not currently have in force an insurance policy in the minimum amount specified in section 7-391(5). 
(4)  If the permit was procured by fraud or false representation of fact. 
Sec. 7-396. - Hearing. 
Such suspension, revocation or nonrenewal shall not take place until after the permittee shall have been afforded a hearing before the municipal court judge. The permittee shall be given at least ten (10) days prior notice before such hearing is held. 
Secs. 7-397—7-405. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 16. - USED AUTO PARTS, SCRAP DEALERS AND PROCESSORS 

Sec. 7-406. - Records required. 
In addition to the requirements of state law, any person engaged in business as a scrap metal processor, as defined in state law at O.C.G.A. § 43-43-1, shall: 
(1)  Keep in his place of business a book upon which should be entered at the time of any purchase all information required by state law; and 
(2)  Require the seller and/or person who delivers such items to positively identify himself by driver's license, military identification, or other photo identification that contains information regarding such person's name, birthdate, sex, race, and address. Such dealers shall also record the license plate number of the vehicle used to deliver the material. When buying autos, such dealers shall also maintain a photocopy of both the seller's and the deliverer's identification for seven (7) days; and 
(3)  Require proof of ownership as evidenced by a title record, bill of sale, or tag receipt before accepting any auto for scrap and shall record the vehicle identification number (VIN) of any auto purchased in the record book required by subsection (1). Such dealers shall notify the sheriff's department of the purchase of such vehicle and shall wait forty-eight (48) hours, from the time notice was provided to the sheriff's department, before demolishing such vehicle for scrap; and 
(4)  Require any seller of material to sign a statement stating that he is the rightful owner of the material sold or is entitled to sell the material. 
Sec. 7-407. - Period for inspection required. 
No scrap purchaser or processor or any person purchasing any of the articles mentioned in this division shall destroy, use or dispose of such articles until seven (7) days after the purchase thereof, but shall keep such articles available for inspection by the sheriff's department or Macon-Bibb County license inspectors. 
Sec. 7-408. - Itinerant scrap purchasers or scrap processors; reports to sheriff. 
(a)  Any itinerant person engaged in purchasing and accepting delivery and paying for materials at the time of purchase of any ferrous and nonferrous items within Macon-Bibb County shall make a written report to the sheriff the day following the date of the purchase and shall show the name of the person from whom the items are purchased, his address and place of business, the value and quantity of the property or material purchased and its kind and quality. 
(b)  Any itinerant person engaged in this business shall register with the sheriff before he shall be authorized to transact business in Macon-Bibb County. It shall be unlawful for any itinerant person who purchases any ferrous and nonferrous items to conceal the name and identity of any person selling such goods, or to enter upon the report a fictitious or false name of any such person. 
Sec. 7-409. - Time for inspection allowed on itinerant scrap purchasers and scrap processors. 
No itinerant person purchasing any ferrous and nonferrous materials referred to shall destroy, use or dispose of such materials until seven (7) days after the purchase thereof, but shall keep such materials available for inspection by the sheriff's department or Macon-Bibb County license inspectors. 
Secs. 7-410—7-425. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 17. - YARD, GARAGE AND PATIO SALES 

Sec. 7-426. - Permit—Required. 
Persons desiring to hold garage, yard, patio or other such sales of used items owned by the seller, when such sales are not held at the residence of one (1) of the participants, shall first obtain a permit from the Department of Business and Development Services. Such permit shall only be issued for sites other than homes, churches and property owned by charitable organizations registered with the state after presentation of a certificate of compliance from the Macon-Bibb County Planning and Zoning Commission and payment of a fee of two dollars and fifty cents ($2.50). The duration of all such sales shall be limited to one (1) 72-hour period. Unless the sale is to be held upon property owned or leased by one (1) of the participants, written permission of the owner or lessee of the property upon which the sale is to be conducted shall be presented to the Department of Business and Development Services prior to the issuance of a permit of such sale. Unless the sale is conducted by a church or other such charitable organization, the name and address of each individual owning items to be sold in the sale shall be listed on the permit and filed in the office of the Department of Business and Development Services. No person shall participate in a sale more than three (3) times in any calendar year for which a permit is required. Permits issued for such churches and charitable organizations shall be issued without charge and shall be signed by an officer of the church or charitable organization. It shall be unlawful for any person obtaining a permit authorized under this section to knowingly make any false or fraudulent statement upon the permit application. 
Sec. 7-427. - Same—Exception. 
No permit shall be required for sales described in the above section if the sale is held upon the premises of a business properly licensed for the sale of such merchandise or for such sales held upon property of the state, such as the state farmer's market. 
Sec. 7-428. - One fee covers all persons. 
One fee of two dollars and fifty cents ($2.50) shall cover all persons involved in any one sale authorized under this division. 
Sec. 7-429. - Violation. 
It shall be a violation of this section for any person to sell any new merchandise or any old merchandise collected or purchased for the purpose of reselling such items during such sale. 
Secs. 7-430—7-450. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 18. - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 7-451. - Findings; public purpose. 
Based on the demonstrated experience of other urban counties and municipalities, including but not limited to Atlanta and Fulton County, Georgia; DeKalb County, Georgia; Orlando, Florida; Orange County, Florida; Indianapolis, Indiana; Los Angeles, California; Beaumont, Texas; Phoenix, Arizona; St. Paul, Minnesota; and Austin, Texas, which experience is found to be relevant to the problems that face Macon-Bibb County, and based upon the documentary evidence and oral testimony presented at the joint city-county hearing conducted by the City of Macon and Bibb County by citizens, a number of whom are familiar with conditions resulting in other localities, and experts, the mayor and commission of Macon-Bibb County take note of the notorious and self-evident conditions and secondary effects attendant to the commercial exploitation of human sexuality, which do not vary greatly among the various communities within our country, particularly the problems of crime, blight, and deterioration which are brought about by the combination of alcohol and live nudity. 
It is the finding of the mayor and commission of Macon-Bibb County that public nudity (either partial or total) in so-called "nude bars" or establishments offering so-called "nude entertainment" or "adult entertainment" in conjunction with the sale or consumption of alcoholic beverages, whether sold on the premises or not, begets criminal behavior and tends to create undesirable community conditions. 
Among the acts of criminal behavior found to be associated with nudity and alcohol are disorderly conduct, prostitution, public indecency and drug trafficking. 
Macon-Bibb County, therefore, finds that it is in the best interest of the health, welfare, safety and morals and preservation of its businesses, neighborhoods, and of churches, schools, and parks to prevent the adverse impacts of adult entertainment establishments. Therefore, Macon-Bibb County finds that licensing and regulations are necessary for any adult entertainment establishment which will not be allowed to serve alcoholic beverages or permit the consumption of alcoholic beverages on their premises. Macon-Bibb County finds that these regulations promote the public welfare by furthering legitimate public and governmental interests, such as reducing criminal activity, protecting against property devaluation and deterioration, and eliminating undesirable community conditions, and that such will not infringe upon the protected constitutional rights of freedom of speech or expression. To that end, this section is hereby adopted. 
Sec. 7-452. - Definitions. 
As used in this division, the following words shall have the meanings as set forth below unless otherwise required by context: 
(1)  Adult entertainer means any person employed by an adult entertainment establishment who appears on the premises totally nude or in such attire to expose his or her specified anatomical areas. For the purposes of this section, adult entertainers include employees as well as independent contractors. 
(2)  Adult entertainment means live entertainment that is characterized by an emphasis on the depiction, display or the featuring of "specified anatomical areas." 
(3)  Adult entertainment establishment means any of the following: 
a.  Any commercial establishment that employs or uses any person live, in any capacity in the sale or service of beverages or food while such person is unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing, so as to expose any portion of his or her specified anatomical areas; 
b.  Any commercial establishment which provides live entertainment where any person appears unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing as to expose any portion of his or her specified anatomical areas as defined herein; 
c.  Any commercial establishment which holds, promotes, sponsors or allows any contest, promotion, special night, event or any other activity where live patrons of the establishment are encouraged or allowed to engage in any of the conduct described in subsection a. and b.; 
d.  An establishment which provides premises where patrons congregate, associate, or consort with employees, performers and/or other patrons or private contractors who display specified anatomical areas in the presence of such patrons. 
However, traditional or live theater as defined herein shall not be included in this definition. 
(4)  Alcoholic beverages means and includes all alcohol, distilled spirits, beer, malt beverage, wine or fortified wine as more specifically defined in the Alcoholic Beverages chapter of this Code. 
(5)  Business establishment means any business within Macon-Bibb County which conducts any trade, occupation, vocation or calling of any kind for gain or profit, directly or indirectly, provided that this shall not include any business, trade and the like licensed by the state unless local government licensing is also allowed by state law, nor shall it include any business operated solely under a franchise granted by Macon-Bibb County. 
(6)  Live means any activity or entertainment which is carried on by actual living persons in the physical presence of the patrons. 
(7)  Minor means any person under eighteen (18) years of age. 
(8)  Operator means the manager or other person principally in charge of an adult entertainment establishment. 
(9)  Person means a human being. 
(10)  Premises means the definite closed or partitioned establishment, whether room, shop or building wherein adult entertainment is performed. 
(11)  Specified anatomical areas means any of the following: 
a.  Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals or pubic region; cleft of the buttocks; or any portion of the female breast encompassed within an area falling below the horizontal line one would have to draw to intercept a point above the top of the areola, or any portion of the areola, or any simulation thereof. This definition shall include the entire lower portion of the human female breast, but shall not include any portion of the cleavage of the human female breast exhibited by a dress, blouse, shirt, leotard, bathing suit, or other wearing apparel, provided the areola is not so exposed. 
b.  Human male genitalia in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
(12)  Specified sexual activities means and includes any of the following: 
a.  The fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttocks, anus or female breasts; 
b.  Sex acts, normal or perverted, actual or simulated, including intercourse, oral copulation or sodomy; 
c.  Masturbation, actual or simulated; 
d.  The displaying of the male or female pubic hair, anus, vulva or genitalia; or 
e.  Excretory functions as part of or in connection with any of the activities set forth in a. through d. above. 
(13)  Traditional or live theater (mainstream performance house) means a theater, concert hall, opera house, museum, educational institution, auditorium or similar establishment, which regularly features live performances, including plays, operas, ballets, concerts or other similar performances, which are not distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on the depiction, display, description, or the featuring of "specified anatomical areas" or "specified sexual activity," in that such depiction, display, description or featuring is incidental to the primary purpose of any performance. Performances and showings are regularly featured when they comprise 85 percent of all performances or showings. "Distinguished or characterized by an emphasis upon" means the dominant or principal theme of the object referenced. For instance, when the phrase refers to performances, which are "distinguished or characterized by an emphasis upon the exhibition or display of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas," the performances so described are those whose dominant or principal character and theme is the exhibition or display of "specified anatomical areas" or "specified sexual activities." 
(14)  Owner, if a sole proprietorship, the proprietor; if a partnership, all partners (excluding limited partners); if a corporation, all officers and persons holding more than fifty (50) percent of the outstanding shares of stock. 
Sec. 7-453. - License required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, association, firm, partnership or corporation to engage in, conduct or carry on, in or upon any premises within Macon-Bibb County, an adult entertainment establishment without a valid adult entertainment establishment license to do so. The issuance of such license shall not be deemed to authorize, condone, or make legal any activity or conduct that is illegal or unlawful under any other section of this Code or the laws of the state or the United States. No license for an adult entertainment establishment shall be issued by Macon-Bibb County if the premises to be used also holds a license to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises. Any premises licensed as an adult entertainment establishment shall not be eligible to apply at any time for a license to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises. The annual license fee for an adult entertainment establishment shall be one thousand three hundred dollars ($1,300.00). 
Sec. 7-454. - On-premise operator required. 
An adult entertainment establishment shall have a designated person(s) to serve as an on-premise operator. The operator(s) shall be principally in charge of the establishment and shall be located on the premises during all operating hours. 
Sec. 7-455. - Employee permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for any adult entertainer to be employed by an adult entertainment establishment without first obtaining a permit issued under the terms of this division. The annual permit fee for an adult entertainer permit shall be sixty-five dollars ($65.00). 
Sec. 7-456. - Admission of minors unlawful. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to allow a person younger than eighteen (18) years of age to enter an adult entertainment establishment. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the operator to ensure that an attendant is stationed at each public entrance to the establishment at all times during the establishment's operating hours. It shall be the duty of the attendant not to allow any person under the age of eighteen (18) years to enter the establishment. It shall be presumed that an attendant knew a person was under the age of eighteen (18) unless such attendant asked for and was furnished: 
(1)  A valid operator's, commercial operator's or chauffeur's driver's license; or 
(2)  A valid personal identification certificate issued by the state department of public safety reflecting that such person is eighteen (18) years of age or older. 
Sec. 7-457. - Adult entertainment establishment employees. 
(a)  An adult entertainment establishment shall not employ any minor in any capacity. No adult entertainer permit shall be issued or renewed for any person who is convicted of a sex-related crime, or drug-related or alcohol-related felony. Any adult entertainer so convicted shall not thereafter be employed by an adult entertainment establishment licensed under this division for a period of five (5) years from the date of such conviction, unless a longer time is ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction. The term "convicted" shall include an adjudication of guilt or plea of guilty or plea of nolo contendere. 
(b)  Before any person may be employed as an adult entertainer, he or she shall file an application for an adult entertainer permit with the Department of Business and Development Services and receive approval by the sheriff. Each applicant shall provide a signed and notarized consent, on forms prescribed by the state crime information center, authorizing the release of the applicant's criminal records to the sheriff's department. The sheriff's department shall have fifteen (15) days to investigate the applicant. If the prospective adult entertainer is found to meet the requirements of this section, upon receipt of the certification by the sheriff, the Department of Business and Development Services shall approve the permit and the prospective adult entertainer may begin working on the licensed premises. If the sheriff does not submit a report within fifteen (15) days of the application, it shall be concluded that the sheriff has no objection to the permit being granted. If approval is denied, the department of business and development services shall provide the applicant with the reason for the denial. 
(c)  No patron, adult entertainer or any other employee of an adult entertainment establishment shall, while on the premises of an adult entertainment establishment, commit the offense of public indecency as defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-6-8. 
(d)  The adult entertainer permit of any employee who violates the laws and regulations of the state or any provision of this division shall be subject to suspension or revocation. 
Sec. 7-458. - Application for license. 
(a)  Any person, association, firm, partnership or corporation desiring to obtain a license to operate an adult entertainment establishment within Macon-Bibb County shall make an application to the Department of Business and Development Services. The application must be made in the name of the adult entertainment establishment and include the names of the operator and each owner as defined in this division. 
(b)  The provisions of this Code on general business licensing shall apply in addition to the provisions of this section: 
(1)  All approved applications for new licenses under this chapter shall be accompanied by a payment in cash or by certified check for a nonrefundable fee, established from time to time by ordinance of Macon-Bibb County to defray, in part, the cost of investigation and report required by this division. 
(2)  The application shall be accompanied by the following: 
a.  Proof of planning and zoning compliance; 
b.  Proof of building code compliance; 
c.  Proof of fire code compliance; 
d.  A legal description of the property upon which the premises are located; 
e.  A current photograph of the operator(s); 
f.  Fingerprints of the operator(s) to be taken by the sheriff's department; 
g.  A letter of clearance from the clerk of federal district court, and a letter of clearance from the clerk of superior court, indicating that the operator as well as all owners do not have any criminal charges currently pending, and that each such individual has no convictions from the respective court in the past ten (10) years; 
h.  A letter of clearance from the Clerk of the State court of Macon-Bibb County showing that the applicant has no criminal charges pending and no convictions in the past two (2) years; 
i.  A personal performance bond payable to Macon-Bibb County conditioned upon the applicant and the applicant's employees of the licensed establishment complying with all laws, ordinances, rules and regulations of Macon-Bibb County governing the issuance and control of adult entertainment establishments and the bond shall remain in force as long as the license and its renewals are valid and subsisting and shall be in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
j.  An affidavit from the publisher of the legal organ of Macon-Bibb County showing that the applicant has caused to be published in such legal organ, once a week for two (2) consecutive weeks, a notice showing the name and address of the applicant, the location for which the license is sought, that the applicant seeks a license for an adult entertainment establishment. 
k.  The application shall also contain a form of oath providing that the information disclosed in the application is true and correct, and providing further that the applicant will abide by, observe and conduct his business according to the rules and regulations prescribed by Macon-Bibb County for adult entertainment establishments. The oath shall be taken by the applicant and the agent in charge of the establishment if different from or additional to the applicant. 
(3)  Any false statement or material misrepresentation in any application hereunder shall be grounds for revocation of any license granted hereunder. 
(4)  A general description of the services and entertainment to be provided. 
(5)  The business, occupation and employment history of each agent or operator for five (5) years immediately preceding the date of application. 
(6)  If any agent or operator has had an adult entertainment establishment license or similar type of licensed denied, revoked or suspended by any other governing authority, then the violations that led to the denial, suspension or revocation as well as the date and disposition of such, including any fine or sentence imposed, and whether or not the terms of the disposition have been completed. 
(7)  If the establishment does or proposes to do business under a trade name, then a copy of the trade name as properly recorded shall be provided. 
(8)  The application shall be signed by the operator or agent. If the owner is a corporation, it additionally shall be signed by the president and attested by the corporate secretary. 
(9)  The operator, agent or owner shall provide a signed and notarized consent, on forms prescribed by the state crime information center, authorizing the release of their criminal records to the sheriff's department. 
(10)  The written consent of a registered agent as provided by section 7-466 shall be provided. 
Sec. 7-459. - Issuance of license to persons with prior convictions prohibited. 
No license under this division shall be issued, renewed or transferred to any person where any individual having interest either as owner, partner, operator, principal stockholder, directly or indirectly, beneficial or absolute, shall have been convicted or shall have taken a plea of nolo contendere within ten (10) years immediately prior to the filing of the application for any felony or conviction of two (2) or more misdemeanors of any state of the United States or any municipal ordinance except traffic violations within two (2) years. The term "conviction" shall include an adjudication of guilt or a plea of guilty or nolo contendere or the forfeiture of a bond in part or in whole when charged with a crime. 
Sec. 7-460. - Application; investigation. 
(a)  Within five (5) days of receipt of the application, the Department of Business and Development Services or his designee shall review the application and send a copy to the sheriff's department or his designee to investigate the character and reputation of each owner and operator. The sheriff shall submit a report within fifteen (15) days to the Department of Business and Development Services. If no report is received, it shall be concluded that there is no objection. 
(b)  The Department of Business and Development Services may deny a license under this division on any of the following grounds: 
(1)  Failure to pay the required fees and taxes; 
(2)  Failure to provide required valid information, documents and the like; 
(3)  False information in the application or attached documents; 
(4)  Failure to pass review by the sheriff; 
(5)  Prior convictions as provided in this chapter; or 
(6)  Failure to meet any other requirements in this chapter for a license of the type applied for. 
(c)  Otherwise, the Department of Business and Development Services shall issue any adult entertainment establishment license provided for in this article. 
Sec. 7-461. - License renewal. 
Licenses for adult entertainment establishments may be renewed on a calendar year basis provided that the licensee(s) continue to meet the requirements set out in this division. 
Sec. 7-462. - Open to inspection. 
Any establishment holding a license issued under this division shall at any time that the premises is open to the public for business, be open to inspection by any officer of the sheriff's department, any license inspector of Macon-Bibb County or fire department inspector of Macon-Bibb County. 
Sec. 7-463. - Consumption; open containers prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person owning or operating a place of business licensed under this division to permit any person to drink any whiskey, wine, beer or other alcoholic beverages upon the premises at any time. It shall be unlawful for any person owning or operating a place of business licensed under this division to permit any glass containing any alcoholic beverage, or any opened or unemptied bottle or other open container of any alcoholic beverage to remain in or on the premises of the place of business at any time. 
Sec. 7-464. - Transfer of licenses. 
(a)  Licenses under this chapter may be transferred to another person, partnership, firm or corporation provided that such person, partnership or corporation makes application to Macon-Bibb County as for a new license and pays any appropriate fees and business or transfer taxes and that person, firm, partnership or corporation otherwise meet the requirements of this chapter for a new license. 
(b)  A transfer of location shall be allowed for any license under this chapter provided the licensee files with the department of business and development services the following on the new location: 
(1)  Proof of planning and zoning compliance; 
(2)  Proof of building code compliance; 
(3)  Proof of fire code compliance; 
(4)  A legal description of the property upon which the new premises are located; 
(5)  Any appropriate location transfer fee or tax; and 
(6)  An affidavit from the publisher of the legal organ of Macon-Bibb County the county showing that the transferor has caused to be published in such legal organ, once a week for two consecutive weeks, a notice showing the name and address of the transferor, the location for which the license is sought, the type of license held. 
(c)  Any transfer allowed under this section may be denied or revoked on the same basis as for an application for license under this chapter. 
Sec. 7-465. - Unlawful operation; declared nuisance. 
Any adult entertainment establishment operated, conducted or maintained contrary to the provisions of this Code shall be and the same is hereby declared to be unlawful and a public nuisance. Macon-Bibb County may, in addition to, or in lieu of prosecuting a criminal action hereunder, commence action(s) or proceeding(s) for the abatement, removal or enjoinment thereof, in a manner provided in the applicable provisions of this Code. 
Sec. 7-466. - Notices; registered agent; jurisdiction. 
(a)  All licensed adult entertainment establishments must have and continuously maintain in Macon-Bibb County a registered agent upon whom any process, notice or demand required or permitted by law or under this division to be served upon the licensee, may be served. This person shall act as registered agent for the operator and each owner collectively. This person must be a resident of Macon-Bibb County. The operator may be appointed as the registered agent if he or she is a resident of Macon-Bibb County. The licensee shall file the name of such agent, along with the written consent of such agent, with the Department of Business and Development Services as part of the license application. By appointing such registered agent, and as a condition of the issuance of a license pursuant to the terms of this division, the licensee agrees that any legal action brought by Macon-Bibb County against the adult entertainment establishment or the licensee (which includes the operator or any owner) to enforce the provisions of this division, may be filed in any court of competent jurisdiction in Macon-Bibb County, Georgia. 
(b)  Any notice required or permitted to be given by the Department of Business and Development Services or any office, division, department or other agency under this division to any licensee, operator or owner of an adult entertainment establishment, may be given by either: 
(1)  Personal delivery or; 
(2)  By certified United States mail addressed to licensee's registered agent at the most recent address specified in the agent's written consent form received by the department of business and development services, or any notice of address change which has been received by the department of business and development services. 
If personally delivered, the notice's effective date shall be the date of delivery. If mailed, the notice's effective date shall be two days after the notice is postmarked. 
Sec. 7-467. - Conditions of adult entertainment establishment approval. 
(a)  All adult entertainment establishments shall be kept in a clean, sanitary condition, and shall be in full compliance with all applicable ordinances and regulations of Macon-Bibb County and the state. 
(b)  The Macon-Bibb County Fire Department shall have the authority to regularly inspect adult entertainment establishments to determine compliance with and enforce all applicable fire regulations. 
(c)  The Macon-Bibb County building inspector or designee shall have the authority to regularly inspect adult entertainment establishments to determine compliance with and enforce all applicable building and other technical codes of Macon-Bibb County. 
(d)  The sheriff's department shall have the authority to periodically inspect adult entertainment establishments to determine compliance with and enforce all provisions of this division or other applicable laws. 
Sec. 7-468. - Prohibited conduct. 
(a)  No owner or operator shall permit any patron, customer, or guest to touch, caress or fondle any specified anatomical area of or any part of the body or clothing of any adult entertainer. No owner or operator shall permit any adult entertainer to bring into contact with any patron, customer or guest, any part of the body or clothing of the adult entertainer. 
(b)  No operator shall permit any patron, customer or guest to touch, caress or fondle any specified anatomical area of any waiter, waitress or any other person who appears on the licensed premises while exposing their specified anatomical areas. 
(c)  All adult entertainers who expose their specified anatomical areas shall conduct their performances in an open area and shall not be permitted to perform in any closed stalls or rooms. 
(d)  All adult entertainers shall remain at least ten (10) feet from any customer or patron at all times, except for those who serve beverages or food to the patrons. 
(e)  All adult entertainment which is licensed and permitted by this division shall be carried on inside a closed building with all windows and doors covered so that the activities carried on inside cannot be viewed from the immediate areas surrounding the outside of the building. 
(f)  No adult entertainer, patron or any other person shall be allowed to engage in any specified sexual activity on the premises of the adult entertainment establishment as defined in this division. 
Sec. 7-469. - Miscellaneous. 
Nothing contained in this division shall be deemed to permit or condone any activity whatsoever which is otherwise found to be obscene, lewd or illegal under any applicable code, regulation or statute which provides any prohibition upon nudity or sexual activity. Further, the activities and uses which are regulated and permitted by this division shall only be allowed if they are not obscene or lewd and not in violation of any other such prohibitions on nudity or sexual activity. This section shall supersede and limit all other provisions of this division. 
Sec. 7-470. - Penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate the terms of this division and any such violation shall be punishable in the municipal court of Macon-Bibb County as a violation of the code of ordinances of Macon-Bibb County under the general penalty section of such code and/or the Charter. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a licensee to permit any conduct prohibited in this division which he knows or has reasonable cause to know is taking place on the premises. Any such conduct by a licensee shall be a violation of this Code and shall be punishable in the municipal court of Macon-Bibb County. Also, upon conviction or plea of nolo contendere, the establishment's license may be revoked or suspended as provided in section 7-3 of this Code. 
DIVISION 19. - COMMERCIAL INDOOR SHOOTING RANGES 

Sec. 7-471. - License required. 
No person shall operate within Macon-Bibb County any commercial indoor shooting range unless such person shall have first procured an appropriate license from the Department of Business and Development Services. 
Sec. 7-472. - Residency required. 
(a)  All applicants for a license under this division shall be bona fide residents of Macon-Bibb County at the time of the filing of the application and shall remain bona fide residents of Macon-Bibb County during all times that the licenses and the renewals thereof are in effect or such applicant shall name one (1) or more residents in Macon-Bibb County as the agent or representative of the licensee, who shall be responsible for any matter relating to such license and who, at all such times, shall be a bona fide resident of Macon-Bibb County. 
(b)  All applicants for licenses under this division by a partnership or corporation shall name in the application one or more residents in Macon-Bibb County as the agent(s) or representative of the corporation to receive all communications, notices, services of process or other papers or documents on behalf of the corporation in connection with the issuance holding, suspension, revocation, or other action with respect to any Macon-Bibb County license. The application shall give the mailing address of the person and the mailing to any such person at such address of any notice required to be given under this section or any other law shall be sufficient notice to the partnership or corporation.
