If any such person shall cease to be a resident of the county, another person shall be immediately appointed in writing in his place and written notice shall be given to the Department of Business and Development Services stating the name and address of the new agent. 
Sec. 7-473. - Preliminary approval required. 
All applicants shall be approved or disapproved by the Department of Business and Development Services as a condition to action thereon in issuance of a license by the department of business and development services. If the sheriff determines that the application is not in order, in view, of the requirements of federal or state law or this Code or any sheriff's department investigation, the department of business and development services shall then notify the applicant of the reason for not issuing the license to the applicant. 
Sec. 7-474. - Issuance to persons with prior convictions prohibited. 
No license under this division shall be issued, renewed or transferred to any person where any individual having any interest either as owner, partner, principal stockholder, directly or indirectly, beneficial or absolute, shall have been convicted or shall have entered a plea of nolo contendere for any felony within five (5) years, or two (2) misdemeanors in the past two (2) years, other than traffic violations, immediately prior to the filing of the application. The term "conviction" shall include an adjudication of guilty or plea of guilty or nolo contendere or the forfeiture of a bond in part or in whole when charged with a crime. 
Sec. 7-475. - Grounds for denial. 
The Department of Business and Development Services may deny a license under this section on any of the following grounds: 
(1)  Failure to pay required fees and taxes; 
(2)  Failure to provide valid information, documents and the like; 
(3)  False information in the application or attached documents; 
(4)  Failure to pass review by the sheriff; 
(5)  Improper residency of applicant, owner or registered agents; 
(6)  Prior convictions as provided in this division; and 
(7)  Failure to meet any other requirements in this section for a license of the class applied for. 
Sec. 7-476. - License procedure. 
Indoor shooting ranges shall, prior to the commencement of business, obtain a license upon application to the office of the Department of Business and Development Services and payment of an annual license fee which shall be determined from time to time by the mayor and commission based upon the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity and listed in a schedule of fees and charges maintained by the Department of Business and Development Services. 
Sec. 7-477. - Liability insurance required. 
Each application for a license issued under this division shall be accompanied by evidence that the applicant has obtained a general liability insurance policy in an amount not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00). Such insurance policy shall remain in full force and effect during the term of the license. Such insurance policy shall contain a clause requiring the insurer to immediately notify Macon-Bibb County if, for any reason, coverage under the policy terminates. The proof of insurance required by this section shall be furnished to Macon-Bibb County upon each renewal of the license. Additionally, the licensee shall furnish to the department of business and development services or his designee proof of insurance when requested to do so. 
Sec. 7-478. - Certified instructors required. 
The owner or operator of an indoor shooting range shall have on the premises at all times during range operation an individual certified as a firearm or range instructor by the National Rifle Association or the Georgia Peace Officers Standards and Training (P.O.S.T.) Council. 
Sec. 7-479. - Minimum specifications. 
The applicant for a license under this division shall, before the license is issued, provide certification by the manufacturer of the range equipment that such equipment meets or exceeds the specifications hereinafter set forth, along with certification by the installer that the equipment has been properly installed. The minimum specifications are as follows: 
(1)  Range; minimum specifications. 
a.  The bullet trap shall be designed for use of all handgun ammunition, all shot shell ammunition, including slugs and .22 rim fire rifle ammunition as well as soft point rifle and machine gun ammunition with muzzle velocities and energies under two thousand (2,000) feet per second and/or two thousand two hundred (2,200) foot pounds, respectively. Use of armor piercing ammunition is prohibited. 
b.  The bullet trap for each shooting position shall be constructed of three (3) five-sixteenths-inch thick armor 46 alloy impact plates of 400 to 440 BHN hardness arranged so that the trailing edge of the lowest plate covers the leading edge of the next highest plate. Use of a single continuous impact plate is prohibited. The continuous line of the impact plates shall extend upward at a mean angle not greater than forty (40) degrees from the horizontal plane to a height of ninety-two (92) inches. The bullet trap shall be designed to direct all impacted bullets upward into the deceleration chamber so that spent lead projectiles are directed to the collection chamber at the foot of the bullet trap. All impact plates shall be interchangeable and reversible. Bullet trap sidewall plates shall be fabricated from 10-gauge hot roll steel. There shall be no external bolts exposed to gunfire. The bullet trap shall be so constructed that no gap exists between the ceiling slope and the scrolls which could result in a bullet escaping the trap. 
c.  The air foil lead recovery plates and deceleration chamber shall be fabricated from one-quarter-inch thick armor alloy plates with a hardness of 340 to 380 BHN. 
d.  A rubber/granular composite bullet trap or equivalent shall be used for rifle fire. 
(2)  Rifle bullet trap minimum specifications. The rifle bullet trap shall be designed to withstand the following types of ammunition: 
a.  Commercially loaded handgun ammunition not exceeding a muzzle velocity of three thousand five hundred (3,500) feet per second and a bullet weight of 300 grains. 
b.  Commercially loaded rifle ammunition not exceeding a muzzle velocity of 3,500 feet per second and a bullet weight of three hundred (300) grains. 
c.  Commercially loaded shotgun ammunition not to exceed a muzzle velocity of one thousand five hundred sixty (1,560) feet per second and a bullet weight of one and one-quarter (1¼) ounce. 
(3)  Shooting stall; minimum specifications. The wall of each shooting stall shall be designed to effective stop a .44 caliber magnum bullet fired at point blank range. 
(4)  Range ceiling minimum specifications. The range ceiling shall be designed to provide full ballistic protection from rounds fired from floor level to the top of the stall. The design shall be such that bullets so fired cannot escape through the ceiling. The ceiling shall be constructed of four (4) feet by four (4) feet panels of one-half-inch thick plywood, reinforced by four (4) feet by four (4) feet 10-gauge hot-rolled steel sheets. 
(5)  Wall minimum specifications. The wall shall be constructed using eight-inch number grade concrete blocks. It shall extend from the rear of the bullet trap to a point at least four (4) feet past the shooting stall and shall have a minimum height of eight (8) feet. 
Sec. 7-480. - Hours of operation. 
An indoor shooting range licensed under this division shall limit its operation to the hours between 7:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. daily. 
DIVISION 20. - DOOR-TO-DOOR COMMERCIAL SOLICITATION 

Sec. 7-481. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this division is to protect the citizens of Macon-Bibb County from criminal activity, abusive conduct, unwelcome disturbance, and disruption of privacy in their homes, and to otherwise preserve the public health, safety, and welfare by regulating door-to-door commercial solicitation. 
Sec. 7-482. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except when the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Person means a natural person, corporation, trust, partnership, incorporated or unincorporated association, or any other legal entity. 
Solicitation means going upon the premises of any private residence in Macon-Bibb County, not having been invited by the owner, tenant, or occupant thereof, for any one (1) or more of the following purposes, if such purpose is primarily commercial: 
(1)  Selling, or taking orders for future delivery of, goods, merchandise, wares, or other items of value; 
(2)  Selling, or taking orders for future performance of, services; 
(3)  Requesting the contribution of funds, property, or anything of value or the pledge of any type of future donation; or 
(4)  Distributing handbills, leaflets, or fliers. 
Except as provided by section 7-490, nothing within this division shall be interpreted to prohibit or restrict persons from going door-to-door for the primary purpose of disseminating religious, political, social, or other ideological beliefs. 
Sec. 7-483. - Permit required; duration; nontransferable. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in solicitation in Macon-Bibb County without first obtaining a permit from the Department of Business and Development Services. Any person claiming exemption from the permit fee, shall demonstrate proof of exemption at the time of application. 
(b)  A permit issued under this division shall be valid for not more than sixty (60) days. 
(c)  No permit issued under this division shall be transferred to any other person. 
Sec. 7-484. - Application; fee; bond; procedures. 
(a)  Any person desiring a permit to engage in solicitation in Macon-Bibb County must file an application with the Department of Business and Development Services on a form prescribed by Macon-Bibb County and containing the following information: 
(1)  The applicant's full legal name; 
(2)  Any and all other names under which the applicant has or does conduct business, or to which the applicant will officially answer; 
(3)  Full address of the applicant's permanent residence; 
(4)  The applicant's telephone number and any business telephone number or other telephone number where the applicant can be reached; 
(5)  The full legal name and address of any and all business operations owned, managed, or operated by applicant, or by which the applicant is employed, or which the applicant represents; 
(6)  Name, address, and relationship to the applicant of all persons who may engage in solicitation on behalf of the applicant; 
(7)  The nature and location of employment of the applicant during the preceding 12 months; 
(8)  A brief description of the nature, character, quality, and price of the goods, wares, merchandise, services, or other items of value that are to be offered by the applicant; 
(9)  A description of the planned solicitation activities, including the dates during which the applicant intends to conduct business; 
(10)  A statement of whether the planned solicitation activities will require cash deposits or taking orders for cash on delivery purchases (C.O.D.) or a contract of agreement to finance the sale of any goods, services, or merchandise for future delivery, or services to be performed in the future; 
(11)  A physical description of the applicant (hair color, eye color, height, weight, any distinguishing features, and the like). 
(12)  If employed, credentials establishing the exact relationship of the applicant with the employer; 
(13)  The applicant's driver's license or other government-issued photo identification card; 
(14)  The license plate number; registration information; vehicle identification number; and year, make and model of any motor vehicle to be used in conjunction with the planned solicitation; 
(15)  A statement as to whether the applicant was convicted of or plead nolo contendere to any felony, misdemeanor, or local ordinance violation, and if so, the location, date, and nature of the offense and the penalty assessed; 
(16)  A statement by the applicant authorizing Macon-Bibb County to perform criminal background searches, criminal history investigations, and personal character investigations of the applicant; 
(17)  The name of any and all municipalities, counties, or other locations where the applicant has conducted solicitation or similar activities in the two (2) years immediately preceding the date of the Macon-Bibb County application; and 
(18)  Proof of any other required license or permit from Macon-Bibb County, including from the judge of the Macon-Bibb County Probate Court pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 43-32-1. 
(b)  All applications shall be accompanied by the fee established by the mayor and commission as it may be amended from time to time. 
(c)  All applicants whose solicitation activities require cash deposits or taking orders for cash on delivery purchases (C.O.D.) or who require a contract of agreement to finance the sale of any goods, services, or merchandise for future delivery, or for services to be performed in the future, shall deposit with the Department of Business and Development Services a good and sufficient bond payable to Macon-Bibb County and conditioned to pay Macon-Bibb County, or anyone else suing on the bond, for injuries or damages received on account of dishonest, fraudulent, or improper conduct in the administration of the business so permitted. The amount of the bond shall be the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) and shall be given for each fiscal year. The bond shall provide that any person or persons injured by the dishonest, fraudulent or improper conduct of the business may sue on the bond for their own use and any recovery shall be payable to the person. 
(d)  Upon receipt of an application, fee, and any bond required by this division, the business license office will determine if the application is complete. An application will be considered complete if all required information is provided. If the business license office determines that an application is incomplete, the applicant shall be notified and afforded an opportunity to submit the missing information. If the application is complete, the business license office shall order an investigation, including criminal background checks, to verify the information provided within the application. After receiving a complete application and background investigation, the business license office shall issue the permit unless grounds exist for denying the application under section 7-485, in which case the application shall be denied and the applicant may appeal in accordance with section 7-488. 
Sec. 7-485. - Ineligibility. 
The following shall be grounds for denying a permit under this division: 
(1)  The failure of an applicant to demonstrate proof of having obtained any other required license or permit from Macon-Bibb County, including and license or permit required from the Macon-Bibb County probate judge; 
(2)  The failure of an applicant to provide truthful and complete information as requested by Macon-Bibb County as part of the application process; 
(3)  The failure of the applicant to sign the permit application; 
(4)  The failure of the applicant to pay the required fee at the time of application; 
(5)  The failure of the applicant to furnish Macon-Bibb County any required bond at the time of application; 
(6)  A conviction within the past five (5) years of the date of application for any violation of any federal or state statute or regulation or of any local ordinance that adversely reflects upon the person's ability to conduct solicitation activities in a legal, honest, and professional manner. Such violations include, but are not limited to, burglary, theft, larceny, swindling, fraud, unlawful business practices, and any form of actual or threatened physical harm against another person; or 
(7)  The revocation within the past five (5) years of any permit issued to the applicant pursuant to this division. 
Sec. 7-486. - Identification badge. 
At the same time the permit is issued, Macon-Bibb County shall issue the permittee an identification badge, which shall be worn by the permittee at all times while engaged in solicitation activities in Macon-Bibb County. It shall be unlawful for any person other than the permittee to use or wear such badge. 
Sec. 7-487. - Revocation. 
The following shall be grounds for revoking a permit issued under this division: 
(1)  Any of the reasons listed in section 7-485 as grounds for denying an application, including any convictions or complaints or other disqualifying circumstances that occurred either before, on or after the date the permit was issued; 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement made in the course of solicitation activities; 
(3)  Any violation of this division; or 
(4)  Conducting a business of soliciting in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety, or, general welfare of the public. 
Sec. 7-488. - Appeal of denial or revocation. 
(a)  If an application is denied or if a permit is revoked, the applicant or permittee, as the case may be, shall be notified in writing. The notice shall set forth the particular grounds for such decision and inform the permittee of the right to appeal. The notice shall be delivered in person or by mail to the permittee's last known residential address on file with the Department of Business and Development Services. 
(b)  An applicant or permittee wishing to contest such action, shall, within ten (10) days after the issuance of the notice, deliver to the county manager a written request for a hearing. 
(c)  If a written request for a hearing to contest the action is delivered to the county manager within the time limitations imposed in subsection (b), the county manager shall cause notice to be served upon the person contesting the action in person or by mail, requiring such person to appear before the municipal court judge to show cause why the permit should have been granted or not revoked, as the case may be. 
(d)  The hearing shall not be held sooner than five (5) business days from the mailing of the notice, and the notice shall specify the date, time, and place of the hearing. The municipal court judge shall notify the applicant or permittee of his or her decision within a reasonable time after the hearing in the same manner as provided herein for service of notice of the hearing. If the judge upholds the decision, no rebate shall be made on any portion of the permit fee. 
Sec. 7-489. - Prohibited times and days for solicitation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit in Macon-Bibb County between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit in Macon-Bibb County on Sunday or any federal or state holiday. 
Sec. 7-490. - Exclusion by placard. 
It shall be unlawful to enter upon the premises of another for the purpose of solicitation, whether for commercial or noncommercial purposes, when the property is posted with a sign or placard prominently placed at the entrance to the property stating "No Soliciting" or other comparable statement. 
Sec. 7-491. - Request to leave premises. 
Any person soliciting shall immediately leave the premises upon request of the owner or occupant. 
Sec. 7-492. - Permit carried upon person and produced upon demand. 
(a)  Any person engaging in solicitation or canvassing must clearly and affirmatively state to the person being solicited at the initial contact and at all subsequent contacts, the following: 
(1)  The identity of the solicitor; 
(2)  The legal name of the person represented by the solicitor; 
(3)  The purpose of the solicitation; 
(4)  The type of goods or services being offered for sale and the method of distribution, if applicable; and 
(b)  Any person engaging in solicitation in Macon-Bibb County must at all times maintain upon his or her person a legible copy of the permit issued by Macon-Bibb County. The permit must be produced for review and inspection upon demand of any person. 
Sec. 7-493. - Receipts. 
(a)  Every solicitor shall, upon request, provide written receipts to persons to which or from which the solicitor has: 
(1)  Sold, or taken orders for, the purchase of goods, merchandise, wares, or other items of value, or for services performed or to be performed in the future; and/or 
(2)  Obtained a contribution or donation of funds, property, or anything of value, or obtained a pledge for any type of future contribution or donation. 
(b)  The receipt shall reflect: 
(1)  The name and business address of the solicitor; 
(2)  If different from the solicitor, the name and address of the person for whom the solicitation was made; 
(3)  The name and address of the person solicited; 
(4)  The nature of the items sold or ordered and the amount thereof; and 
(5)  The amount of the contribution or donation or pledge for future contribution or donation and the intended uses thereof. 
Sec. 7-494. - Penalty. 
Any person who violates any provision of this division shall be guilty of an offense and shall be subject to the maximum punishment under the Macon-Bibb County Charter or Code general penalty provision. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during which a violation occurs or continues. 
DIVISION 21. - BUSINESS INCUBATORS 

Sec. 7-495. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Business incubatee means a young entrepreneurial company (whether a sole proprietorship or any business entity recognized under state law) who is being assisted by a business incubator through the provision of an array of business-support resources and services, including, but not limited to, affordable physical spaces (which are for office use only), shared offices, common services, financial assistance, marketing support, coaching, and networking connections. 
Business incubator means an organization designed to accelerate the growth and success of business incubatees through an array of business-support resources and services, including, but not limited to, affordable physical spaces (which are for office use only), shared offices, common services, financial assistance, marketing support, coaching, and networking connections. 
Sec. 7-496. - License required for business incubators. 
(a)  No person or entity shall operate within Macon-Bibb County any business incubator unless such person or entity shall have first procured a business incubator license from the department of Macon-Bibb County. 
(b)  To be eligible for a new or renewal business incubator license, an applicant must present evidence to the business licensing office that the applicant is either a registered not-for-profit organization or that at least seventy-five (75) percent of the applicant's gross income is derived from rents and fees charged to business incubatees. 
Sec. 7-497. - Special license required for business incubatees. 
For the first two (2) years in which it is engaged in business, a business incubatee shall be eligible for a special incubate rate of half of the administrative fee for an occupational tax certificate. Incubatees will be subject to all other applicable privilege licenses associated with the nature of the business. To receive such special rate, a business incubatee must provide the department of business and development services with written evidence that it meets the requirements of this Code at the time such business applies for its occupation tax certificate. 
Sec. 7-498. - Planning and zoning compliance for business incubators. 
A business incubator shall comply with the applicable planning and zoning requirements. 
Sec. 7-499. - Application of planning and zoning requirements to business incubatees. 
A business incubatee need not submit proof of its planning and zoning compliance, and will not be inspected for planning and zoning compliance, if: 
(1)  The business incubatee is being assisted by a business incubator through the provision of a physical space (which is for office use only); and 
(2)  It has already been determined that the business incubator is complying with the applicable planning and zoning requirements. 
Sec. 7-500. - Building code compliance for business incubators. 
A business incubator shall comply with the applicable building codes. 
Sec. 7-501. - Application of building code requirements to business incubatees. 
A business incubatee need not submit proof of its building code compliance, and will not be inspected for building code compliance, if: 
(1)  The business incubatee is being assisted by a business incubator through the provision of physical space (which is for office use only); and 
(2)  It has already been determined that the business incubator is complying with the applicable building codes. 
Sec. 7-502. - Fire code compliance for business incubators. 
A business incubator shall comply with the applicable fire code. 
Sec. 7-503. - Application of fire code requirements to business incubatees. 
A business incubatee need not submit proof of its fire code compliance, and will not be inspected for fire code compliance, if: 
(1)  The business incubatee is being assisted by a business incubator through the provision of a physical space (which is for office use only); and 
(2)  It has already been determined that the business incubator is complying with the applicable fire code. 
DIVISION 22. - COIN OPERATED AMUSEMENT MACHINES 

Sec. 7-504. - Short title. 
This division shall be known as the "Macon-Bibb County Coin Operated Amusement Machine Ordinance." 
Sec. 7-505. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Bona fide coin operated amusement machine shall have the same definition as found in O.C.G.A. § 50-27-70. 
Business location means the entire office or area of the business in any one location owned or leased by the same proprietor or proprietors where the lessor or lessors allow the space to be used for business purposes. 
Location owner or location operator means an owner or operator of a business where one or more bona fide coin operated amusement machines are available for commercial use and play by the public, or shall have the same definition as found in O.C.G.A. § 50-27-70, should that definition differ. 
Class B machine shall have the same definition as found in O.C.G.A. § 50-27-70. 
Operator means any person, individual, firm, company, association, corporation, or other business entity who exhibits, displays, or permits to be exhibited or displayed, in a place of business other than his own, any bona fide coin operated amusement machine in this state, or shall have the same definition as found in O.C.G.A. § 50-27-70, should that definition differ. 
Owner means any person, individual, firm, company, association, corporation, or other business entity owning any bona fide coin operated amusement machine in this state or shall have the same definition as found in O.C.G.A. § 50-27-70, should that definition differ. 
Sec. 7-506. - Prohibition on class B devices. 
Location owners and location operators are prohibited from offering more than six (6) class B machines at one (1) business location within Macon-Bibb County. 
Sec. 7-507. - Location owner and location operator notice. 
The owner and/or possessor of each bona fide coin operated amusement machine that rewards the player exclusively as described in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(d) with a machine located within the jurisdiction of Macon-Bibb County is required to inform the location owner and/or location operator of each business location in which one of the machine owner's machines is located of the prohibitions and penalties set out in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(e), (f), and (g). 
Sec. 7-508. - Employee notice. 
The location owner and/or location operator of each business location which offers to the public the use of a bona fide coin operated amusement machines which rewards the player exclusively as described in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(d) with a machine located within the jurisdiction of Macon-Bibb County is required to inform all employees of that business in which one of the machine is located of the prohibitions and penalties set out in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(e), (f), and (g). 
Sec. 7-509. - License suspension and revocation; penalties. 
(a)  Macon-Bibb County may suspend or revoke the license of any location owner or location operator to manufacture, distribute, or sell alcoholic beverages in Macon-Bibb County, or any other license granted by Macon-Bibb County, as a penalty for the conviction of the location owner or location operator of a violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(e), (f), or (g) or for violation of one or more provisions of this division. Violation of any provision of this division may also be punished in accordance with the general penalty section of this Code. 
(b)  Macon-Bibb County may suspend or revoke the license of any location owner or location operator of any other license granted by Macon-Bibb County as a penalty for the conviction of the location owner or location operator of a violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(e), (f), or (g). 
(c)  The suspension or revocation of licenses under this section, or other penalties imposed, shall be in accordance with the following guidelines of due process: 
(1)  No license shall be suspended or revoked pursuant to this section except for due cause and after hearing and upon prior three-day written notice to the holder of the license of the time, place and purpose of the hearing and a statement of the charges upon which the hearing shall be held, unless such hearing has been waived pursuant to stipulation as provided under subpart (8) of this subsection. Such notice shall provide the reasons for the suspension or revocation sought and shall be mailed or delivered to the holder of the license. 
(2)  The term "due cause" for the purposes of this section shall include, but not be limited to: 
a.  Violation by the location owner or location operator of any provision of this division; and/or 
b.  Conviction of the location owner or location operator of a violation of subsection (e), (f), or (g) of O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35. 
(3)  Notice of suspension or revocation proceedings shall be served on the person named as licensee in the application. Notice shall be in writing. The notice may be served personally or by first class mail. If by mail, the notice shall be addressed to the licensee at its address as provided by the licensee to Macon-Bibb County. The burden shall be on the licensee to provide notice, in writing, of any change of address for service of notices and process. In the case of service by mail of any notice required by this chapter, the service is complete at the time of deposit in the United States Postal Service. 
(4)  The hearing shall be conducted by a judge of the municipal court of Macon-Bibb County. 
(5)  Hearings shall be only as formal as necessary to preserve order and shall be compatible with the principles of justice. Macon-Bibb County shall bear the burden of proving by a preponderance of the evidence that due cause exists to suspend or revoke the license. At the hearing the licensee shall have the right to represent itself or be represented by counsel, may cross examine all witnesses offered by Macon-Bibb County, and may call witnesses and present evidence in its own behalf. Formal rules of evidence shall not apply to hearings under this section, although the judge shall have the right to exclude evidence which carries no indicia of reliability. All testimony shall be offered under oath or affirmation. 
(6)  The judge shall make his final determination within ten (10) business days of the completion of the hearing. The decision shall be placed in writing and contain the judge's findings of fact, conclusions of law, and decision as to sanction, if any. Such sanction may include one (1) or more of the following: revocation of the license, suspension of the license for no more than twelve (12) months, imposition of a probationary period not to exceed twelve (12) months, and/or a civil monetary penalty as provided in the general penalty section of the Macon-Bibb County charter or code. Progressive sanctions, depending on the severity of the violation, are encouraged but not required. Where the remaining term of the license is less than twelve (12) months, imposition of suspension or probation for a period in excess of the term of the existing license shall be applied to any renewal license. A subsequent violation within a probationary period shall be cause for revocation and/or denial of license renewal. A total of three (3) separate and unrelated violations within twenty-four (24) months, whether or not within a probationary period, shall be grounds for permanent revocation. 
(7)  The judge's decision shall be personally served or mailed by certified mail, return receipt requested to the licensee and his attorney, with a copy to the Macon-Bibb County attorney, within ten (10) business days of the close of the hearing. The decision of the judge shall constitute final action by Macon-Bibb County, subject to review upon petition for certiorari to the superior court. 
(8)  Upon receipt of notice of adverse action against the licensee under this section, the licensee may waive its right to a hearing and stipulate to a sanction, as recommended by the mayor, in consultation with the sheriff. Any stipulation entered under this subsection shall be in writing, signed by the licensee, and non-appealable. 
Sec. 7-510. - Monthly reports; gross receipts. 
(a)  A location owner or location operator subject to O.C.G.A. § 50-27-84(c) is hereby required to provide a copy of the monthly verified report required by such code section to the commission. Such report shall indicate the monthly gross retail receipts for each business location located in Macon-Bibb County and shall be due by the 21st day of each month, subsequent to the month in which the sales have taken place. Macon-Bibb County shall be entitled to conduct an annual audit of such reports and the location owner or location operator shall make its books reasonably available for such purpose upon request of the tax commissioner. 
(b)  No location owner or location operator may derive more than fifty (50) percent of such location owner's or location operator's monthly gross retail receipts for this business location in which the class B machines are situated from such class B machines. 
Sec. 7-511. - Posting of signs. 
Any location owner or location operator with a business location within Macon-Bibb County which offers to the public one or more bona fide coin operated amusement machines is hereby required to post prominently a notice, in the vicinity of such coin operated amusement machines, including the following or substantially similar language: 
GEORGIA LAW PROHIBITS PAYMENT OR RECEIPT OF MONEY FOR WINNING A GAME OR GAMES ON THIS AMUSEMENT MACHINE; PAYMENT OR RECEIPT OF MONEY FOR FREE REPLAYS WON ON THIS AMUSEMENT MACHINE; PAYMENT OR RECEIPT OF MONEY FOR ANY MERCHANDISE, PRIZE, TOY, GIFT CERTIFICATE, OR NOVELTY WON ON THIS AMUSEMENT MACHINE; OR A WARDING ANY MERCHANDISE, PRIZE, TOY, GIFT CERTIFICATE, OR NOVELTY OF A VALUE EXCEEDING $5.00 FOR A SINGLE PLAY ON THIS MACHINE. 
Any such notice shall be at least 11.5 inches by 17.5 inches in size. Words and letters shall be in bold print and shall be at least one (1) centimeter in size. 
Sec. 7-512. - Minimum distance requirements. 
Any business location which offers to the public one (1) or more bona fide coin operated amusement machines may not be located within one hundred (100) yards of any church building, within two hundred (200) yards of any school building, educational building, school grounds or college campus, within one hundred (100) yards of any alcoholic treatment center, or within one hundred (100) yards of any housing authority property. 
Sec. 7-513. - Disclosure of machine owner. 
Any location owner or location operator seeking to locate a business within the jurisdiction of Macon-Bibb County and offer to the public one (1) or more bona fide coin operated amusement machines must first submit in writing the name, physical address and mailing address of the owner of the bona fide coin operated amusement machine to the tax commissioner before any occupational tax certificate or license granted by Macon-Bibb County is issued or renewed. 
Sec. 7-514. - Location of machines. 
Any location owner or location operator who offers to the public one (1) or more bona fide coin operated amusement machines is required as a condition of doing business in the jurisdiction of Macon-Bibb County to locate each and every bona fide coin operated amusement machine in plain view and accessible to any person who is at the business location. 
Sec. 7-515. - Posting of privilege license or occupation tax certificate. 
Any location owner or location operator who offers to the public one or more bona fide coin operated amusement machines is required as a condition of doing business in the jurisdiction of Macon-Bibb County to post its privilege license and/or occupation tax certificate, whichever it is required by this code to obtain, in a conspicuous place in the location owner or location operator's place of business at which such machine(s) is offered and leave it there at all times. 
Chapter 8 - CEMETERIES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Burials. 
It shall be unlawful for any undertaker or any other person to bury or cause to be buried, or to in any manner aid or assist in the burial of the dead body of any human being in any cemetery or location in Macon-Bibb County other than an authorized public cemetery or a private cemetery established and approved pursuant to this chapter. 
Sec. 8-2. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Cemetery means any land or structure in this state dedicated to and used or intended to be used for interment of human remains. It may be either a burial park for earth interments or a mausoleum for vault or crypt interments or a combination of one or more thereof. 
EPD means the Georgia Department of Natural Resources Environmental Protection Division. 
FEMA means the Federal Emergency Management Agency. 
Marker means a small individual memorial placed at either the head or foot of a grave. This is sometimes referred to as a headstone or footstone. 
Sec. 8-3. - Authority of Macon-Bibb County Engineer. 
The Macon-Bibb County Engineer shall be responsible for issuing permits and ensuring that the requirements of this article are satisfied. Other than maintaining in his office an original of the plat of survey of each cemetery and maintaining an inventory of cemeteries in Macon-Bibb County, the Macon-Bibb County Engineer and Macon-Bibb County shall have no responsibility or duty to supervise the operation of any such cemetery. 
Sec. 8-4. - Records. 
The Macon-Bibb County engineer shall maintain a record and inventory of the locations of all cemeteries established and permitted pursuant to this article. 
Sec. 8-5. - Enforcement officers. 
All law enforcement agencies, officers, certified peace officers, and/or officials of the state, or any code enforcement officer, are hereby authorized, empowered, and directed to enforce compliance with this article. 
Sec. 8-6. - Penalties for violation of article. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a cemetery in Macon-Bibb County unless done so in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(1)  Violators of the provisions of this chapter may be punished for any violation of this chapter not already a violation of the laws of the state up to six months in jail and a fine of $1,000.00, or both, each day's violation constituting a separate offense. 
(2)  In addition to any other remedy provided in this article, Macon-Bibb County may seek injunctive relief to cease and remove any violations of this article in the appropriate court against the appropriate person or entity. 
(3)  Any violation of this article is hereby deemed to be a continuing nuisance and may be abated by an application for injunction or other proceedings allowed by law in the appropriate court. 
Sec. 8-7. - Operation. 
It shall be the sole responsibility and duty of the owner, creator, trust or other legal entity which shall own, supervise or have control of a cemetery to ensure that the same shall not at any time constitute a health hazard or constitute a nuisance. The owner, creator, trust or other legal entity, which shall own, supervise or have control of a cemetery shall have the right and responsibility of creating rules and regulations necessary to or appropriate for the operation of such cemetery. 
Sec. 8-8. - Creation of nuisances. 
No owner, creator, trust or other legal entity which shall own, supervise or have control of a cemetery shall allow such cemetery to accumulate weeds, trash, junk, filth, or other unsanitary or unsafe conditions so as to create a public health hazard or a general nuisance to those persons residing in the vicinity. 
Secs. 8-9—8-28. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SPECIFIC REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 8-29. - Permits. 
No cemetery shall be allowed in Macon-Bibb County without the owner, creator, trust or other legal entity having first applied for and obtained from the Macon-Bibb County Engineer, a permit approving the operation thereof. In addition to any other requirements set forth in this chapter, no permit will be granted without compliance with the following: 
(1)  Survey. A plat of survey of the cemetery prepared by a state-registered land surveyor shall be submitted to the Macon-Bibb County Engineer along with the application. Upon approval of the survey by the Macon-Bibb County Engineer, the applicant shall file, or cause to have filed, two signed original copies of the survey with the superior court clerk for recording. 
(2)  Minimum area. No cemetery shall be approved unless the survey provided for in this chapter indicates that the cemetery contains not less than two acres to be utilized for burial space. 
(3)  Land use compatibility. The location of the proposed cemetery is to be compatible with adjacent land uses, existing or proposed highways and any other elements or factors deemed by Macon-Bibb County to affect the public health, safety and welfare of the inhabitants of the area surrounding the proposed location, including but not limited to the effect on aquifers, wells and ground water, the potential for pollution of nearby streams, lakes and other waters and the suitability of the soil composition for such use. Under no circumstances shall a cemetery be allowed within 1,000 feet from any known well, aquifer, lake or stream which in the determination of EPD requires a stream buffer. 
(4)  Buffer area. The proposed location must contain a buffer area that is landscaped with trees and/or shrubbery on all sides of the site that is identified on the survey and is not less than ten feet in width. 
(5)  Flood prohibition. No cemetery shall lie in whole or in part within a floodplain and certification of the same must be provided upon the survey shown on the latest FEMA flood maps. 
(6)  Identification of boundaries. The boundaries of the proposed cemetery must be clearly marked and delineated by concrete or metal pins or other permanent means of identification. No burials shall be permitted within 500 feet of adjacent property lines. 
(7)  Ingress and egress. Adequate access, ingress and egress to and from the cemetery must be available by public road or private drive. 
Sec. 8-30. - Additional requirements. 
(a)  Fencing shall be installed around the perimeter of the cemetery of sufficient height and strength to keep dogs and wild animals from accessing the cemetery. 
(b)  Any land disturbances in the construction of a cemetery must be subject to all sediment erosion and ground water run-off requirements applicable to other development projects as set forth in the ordinances and regulations of Macon-Bibb County, Georgia. 
(c)  All graves must be marked with an appropriate marker as defined herein that will allow law enforcement authorities to locate graves if necessary for any lawful purposes after interment. 
(d)  All cemeteries shall be subject to the requirements of state law and regulations in effect or as they may exist in the future with regard to perpetual care, reinterment of remains and any such other conditions as may require remediation. 
(e)  All human remains shall be buried in a leak-proof casket or vault to protect against contamination of ground water, wells, and aquifers. 
(f)  No human remains shall be buried less than the depth that is customarily used in the funeral industry in Georgia and in accordance with minimum standards for interment as may be adopted by the Secretary of State. 
(g)  Remains of persons who die from communicable diseases must be buried by and under the supervision of a licensed funeral director in accordance with the rules and regulations of the State Funeral Service Board. 
(h)  Human remains must be buried before they begin to decompose as evidenced by odor, or create a danger to the health, safety and welfare of others. 
Sec. 8-31. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  It shall be a violation of this chapter to willfully disturb, destroy, deface, mutilate, remove, excavate or expose a burial place without first obtaining a permit pursuant to O.C.G.A. Title 36, Chapter 72 (O.C.G.A. § 36-72-1 et seq.), or as amended from time to time, and following the requirements of this chapter. 
(b)  It shall be a violation of this chapter to fail to report the discovery of human remains or to notify the local authority of the disturbance of a burial ground. 
(c)  It shall be a violation of this chapter should any person or entity seeking a permit to disturb a burial place pursuant to O.C.G.A. Title 36, Chapter 72 (O.C.G.A. § 36-72-1 et seq.), as amended from time to time, not follow the provisions of this chapter. 
(d)  It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person or entity to fail to comply with the provisions of an approved permit. 
Sec. 8-32. - Health department approval. 
The approval of the proposed cemetery must be obtained from the Macon-Bibb County Health Department and submitted with the application. 
Sec. 8-33. - Appeal from denial. 
Appeals from the denial of a permit authorized by this chapter shall be to the Commission of Macon-Bibb County. 
Sec. 8-34. - Exemption. 
Any cemetery which as of the effective date of this chapter has received all necessary state, local and federal permits, has otherwise met all legal requirements to operate, is fully operational and is lawfully receiving human remains for burial, shall be exempt from the requirements of this chapter. 
Secs. 8-35—8-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PUBLIC CEMETERIES 

Sec. 8-50. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Board of health means the Macon-Bibb County Board of Health. 
Department means the department of parks and recreation. 
Director means the director of parks and recreation. 
Secretary or chairman means of the health board. 
Sec. 8-51. - Responsibilities of Department of Parks and Recreation. 
The department of parks and recreation shall take charge of Macon-Bibb County burial grounds and keep the buildings, fences and other appurtenances thereto belonging in proper order and condition, shall be always ready to receive verbal or written application for interments on the said ground, and make, without delay, all interments so applied for. 
Sec. 8-52. - Removal of trees. 
The director of the department of parks and recreation, with approval of the mayor, shall have the right and power to have removed from any owner's lot any tree deemed unsafe and likely to injure any of the improvements in the cemetery. 
Sec. 8-53. - Records. 
(a)  The department of parks and recreation shall keep a cemetery record book of all deaths and burials in Macon-Bibb cemeteries showing names and ages and in which cemetery each person was buried. 
(b)  The department shall also keep a book of record on all material received for carrying on the work in the Macon-Bibb County-owned cemeteries stating the account name, amount and kind of material received and the purposes for which it was used. 
(c)  The department shall also keep a book of record and make true entries therein of all charges made and fees collected for work or material by and for the Macon-Bibb County-owned cemeteries. 
(d)  The department shall render to the mayor, through the county manager, a monthly report on these records. 
Sec. 8-54. - Burial permits. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for anyone, other than the department of parks and recreation, to bury any person dying within Macon-Bibb County in any of Macon-Bibb County cemeteries, without first obtaining a burial permit from the secretary of the board of health. The secretary shall not be authorized to furnish a burial permit without a certificate from the attending physician setting forth the cause of death, provided that there was a physician in attendance. In case there was no physician in attendance, then the secretary shall comply with the requirements applying to the department under similar circumstances. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the department or any other person to bury any person dying beyond the Macon-Bibb County borders in any of the Macon-Bibb County cemeteries, without first obtaining a burial permit from the secretary of the board of health, nor shall the secretary issue a permit unless there is pasted on the box containing the corpse a certificate from the attending physician giving the full name of the deceased, the date of death and the disease causing death. The secretary shall keep a record of all such cases. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for the department to bury any person dying within Macon-Bibb County in any of the Macon-Bibb County cemeteries, without first obtaining from the attending physician, provided there was one, a certificate setting forth cause of death, which certificate shall accompany the order for the grave. The superintendent shall record or cause to be recorded in the secretary's office, the certificate, subject to the inspection of all concerned. In all cases where there was no physician in attendance, the such case shall be at once reported by the superintendent to the chairman of the board of health, who will issue the burial permit, first making due investigation as to the cause of the death, to the end that the mortuary records of the board of health may be complete. 
Sec. 8-55. - Burial of paupers. 
The director of the Department of Parks and Recreation shall bury all paupers, when so directed by the mayor, or in the mayor's absence, the county manager. 
Sec. 8-56. - Graves. 
The Department of Parks and Recreation shall inter all bodies in graves of not less than four feet in depth, when walled up, or four and one-half feet otherwise, or in a vault. In no case shall a body be permitted to remain aboveground enclosed with brick or other materials. Piles of earth, brick, mortar beds, or rubbish of any kind shall not remain on the ground longer than 24 hours after an interment or the completion of any work incident to a burial. 
Sec. 8-57. - Interments and removal of bodies. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to inter a body in any of the Macon-Bibb County cemeteries, or remove a body which has been or shall hereafter be interred, in any of the cemeteries, from its place of interment, without the authorization of the director. 
Sec. 8-58. - Disinterments. 
The body of any person buried in any cemetery in Macon-Bibb County shall not be disinterred without first obtaining a permit so to do from the board of health or from the chairman thereof. 
Sec. 8-59. - Duties of undertakers. 
It shall be unlawful for any undertaker or any other person in Macon-Bibb County to furnish a coffin in which to bury anyone who may have died in Macon-Bibb County and is to be buried within or beyond the border of Macon-Bibb County, unless the application for the coffin is accompanied by the permit of the board of health, and that permit alone is authority for the director to bury the body for which the permit is given. 
Sec. 8-60. - Plan of lots. 
The director of the department of parks and recreation shall keep a plan of the grounds of Macon-Bibb County cemeteries for public inspection, which shall be furnished to the public, with all the lots and ranges properly numbered, and with the names of the owners. The director shall see that numbers are kept on all lots. Any lot that may be sold, if the terms are not complied with, shall, if not occupied, revert again to the control of the Macon-Bibb County, or if occupied in part, the remaining portion may be again disposed of by Macon-Bibb County. 
Sec. 8-61. - Lots for public institutions. 
Lots of suitable sizes may be set apart by the director for the use of public institutions. Ranges shall also be laid out for the burial of strangers and others who may not purchase lots. 
Sec. 8-62. - Proceeds from sale of lots. 
The money collected from the sale of lots shall be paid to the director of finance, who shall faithfully keep a correct account of all receipts and disbursements. 
Sec. 8-63. - Purchase by nonresidents. 
Persons living outside of Macon-Bibb County may purchase lots on the same terms and conditions as resident citizens. 
Sec. 8-64. - Collection of fees. 
The department of parks and recreation shall collect all cemetery fees as are appropriate according to the schedule of cemetery fees adopted in the department regulations. 
Sec. 8-65. - Acceptance of fees prohibited. 
No employee of Macon-Bibb County shall receive any compensation for cleaning lots, but all fees collected by the department for cleaning private lots shall be promptly paid into the Macon-Bibb County treasury. 
Sec. 8-66. - Receipts. 
The department of parks and recreation shall be required to give receipts for all fees, lots sold, work done on lots, for building foundations for monuments, or for any kind of work done by Macon-Bibb County in Macon-Bibb County-owned cemeteries. The stubs of these receipts shall show each amount received, from whom, and for what purpose and the like. These stubs shall be numbered from one, consecutively, and shall correspond with the monthly itemized reports sent to the mayor. All funds received by the department shall be paid weekly into the Macon-Bibb County treasury. 
Sec. 8-67. - Defacing monuments. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to mutilate or in any manner deface a monument, fence or other enclosure in the cemeteries, or dig up, remove or destroy any shrubbery or trees in the Macon-Bibb County cemeteries, or upon the reserved land around any of the cemeteries, except with permission of the director. 
Sec. 8-68. - Gathering flowers prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to break down or gather any wild or cultivated flowers in any cemetery, and it shall be the duty of the director to inform persons visiting the grounds of the existence of this section, and report all violations that come to his knowledge. 
Sec. 8-69. - Climbing fences; exit through gates required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to pass over any fence or any part of the enclosure around any Macon-Bibb County cemetery, or to go out from any Macon-Bibb County cemetery on the river by boat, or to pass through a Macon-Bibb County cemetery in any way other than by the gates. 
Sec. 8-70. - Times of admittance. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to remain in any of the Macon-Bibb County cemeteries after sundown, nor shall anyone be allowed to enter therein before sunup. 
Chapter 9 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 9-1. - Establishment; Mission statement. 
(a)  The Macon-Bibb County Emergency Management Agency is established as the civil defense and emergency management organization of Macon-Bibb County and its jurisdiction is the entire geographic area of Macon-Bibb County. 
(b)  The mission of the Macon-Bibb County Emergency Management Agency is coordination of contingency planning for carrying out all emergency functions, other than functions for which military forces are primarily responsible, to prevent, minimize and repair injury and damage resulting from emergencies or disasters, or imminent threat thereof, of manmade or natural origin, caused by enemy attack, sabotage, civil disturbances, fire, flood, earthquake, wind, storm, wave action, oil spill, other water contaminations, or hazardous materials accidents or incidents, requiring emergency action to avert danger or damage, epidemic, air contamination, blight, drought, infestation, explosion, riot or other hostile action, to include terroristic activities or other causes. These functions include, without limitation, firefighting services; law enforcement services; medical and health services; rescue; engineering; warning services; communications; defense from radiological, chemical and other special weapons; evacuation of persons from stricken areas; emergency welfare services; emergency transportation; plant protection; temporary restoration of public utility services and other functions related to civilian protection, together with all other activities necessary or incidental to the preparation for and carrying out of the foregoing functions. 
Sec. 9-2. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Building contractor means any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity engaging in, undertaking or carrying on any business consisting of or relating to building construction, repair, renovation or making improvements to real property including dwellings, homes, buildings, structures, or fixtures attached thereto. 
Curfew means a regulation requiring the withdrawal from any person not otherwise exempt from this chapter from appearing in certain public areas during specified hours. 
Doing business means any building contractor who has or operates an office, agency, project site or place of business whether permanently, temporarily, periodically, or otherwise, that provides the following activities in the limits of the Macon-Bibb County expressly including but not limited to the construction, renovation or repair of dwellings or buildings or the making of improvements to real property or any fixtures attached thereto. 
Emergency means a condition resulting from enemy attack, rioting or natural disaster which cannot be handled by normal operating personnel and facilities. 
Emergency management volunteer means any person who serves without compensation in the emergency management organization. 
Exempt individuals means, unless otherwise specified in the resolution implementing the curfew, those individuals engaged in the provision of designated, essential services, such as fire, law enforcement, emergency medical services and hospital services, military services, and utility emergency repairs. The resolution may, in the discretion of the governing authority, also exempt regular employees of local industries traveling to and from their jobs with appropriate identification, news media employees, and building and repair contractors, properly registered according to section 9-10 performing activities related to construction, repair, renovation or improvement of buildings and other structures damaged during the disaster or emergency. 
Fees means any fee or rate charged by the Macon-Bibb County for building permits, land disturbance permits, zoning applications, special land use permits, temporary land use permits, and other fees relating to the reconstruction, repair and clean-up of areas impacted by the disaster or emergency. "Fees" shall not include those fees collected by Macon-Bibb County on behalf of the federal or state government or those fees charged by Macon-Bibb County pursuant to a federal or state statute or regulation. 
Natural disaster means any condition seriously affecting or threatening public health, welfare or security as a result of a severe fire, explosion, flood, tornado, hurricane, electrical failure or similar natural or accidental cause, and which is beyond the control of public or private agencies ordinarily responsible for the control or relief of such conditions. 
Overcharging means charging prices for goods, materials, services, or housing which are substantially in excess of the customary charges or in applicable cases substantially in excess of the supplier's or provider's costs for such goods, materials, services or housing. The existence of overcharging shall be presumed from a substantial increase in the price at which the goods, materials, services, or housing was offered in the usual course of business immediately prior to the onset of the emergency, but shall not include increases in costs to the supplier directly attributable to higher costs of materials, supplies, and labor costs resulting from the emergency. 
State of emergency means, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3(5), a condition declared by the governor when, in his judgment, the threat or actual occurrence of a disaster is of sufficient severity and magnitude as to warrant extraordinary efforts in preventing or alleviating the damage, loss, hardship, or suffering threatened or caused thereby. 
Subsequent recovery period means that period during which the disaster continues to cause disruptions in the disaster area, but shall not exceed three (3) months after the emergency declaration has been terminated by the governor. 
Temporary dwelling means any mobile or easily movable home, trailer, recreational vehicle or structure not otherwise permitted by the zoning regulations in a particular zoning district. 
Sec. 9-3. - Emergency powers. 
In the event of manmade or natural disaster, rioting, actual enemy attack upon the United States or any other emergency which may affect lives and property, the mayor may announce to the public and the members of the commission that the emergency operations plan has been activated. Thereafter, the mayor shall keep the commissioners informed as to the status of the emergency and any related matters. The mayor may present the commission with emergency ordinances that are necessary or incidental to the carrying out of emergency management functions. 
Sec. 9-4. - Emergency management and disaster control plan. 
A comprehensive emergency management and disaster control plan for Macon-Bibb County shall be adopted by resolution of the commission and approved by the mayor. In preparation of this plan as it pertains to Macon-Bibb County organizations, the services, equipment, facilities and personnel of all existing departments and agencies shall be utilized to the fullest extent possible. When approved, it shall be the duty of all departments and agencies to perform the functions and duties assigned by the plan and to maintain their portion of the plan in a constant state of readiness at all times. 
Sec. 9-5. - Emergency management and disaster control fund. 
An emergency management and disaster control fund is hereby created, and any money as shall be appropriated from time to time for the carrying out of the purposes of this chapter shall be deposited in the fund. Except during a state of emergency as declared by the mayor, the money shall be disbursed in the usual manner for the disbursement of Macon-Bibb County funds. In the event of a declaration of a state of emergency, the mayor may disburse funds within his discretion and without the signature or counter-signature of any officer; provided, however, that the mayor shall be limited to the amount appropriated and set aside in the emergency management and disaster fund. 
Sec. 9-6. - Volunteers. 
All persons, other than officers and employees of Macon-Bibb County, performing emergency functions pursuant to this chapter, shall serve without compensation under the direction of the emergency management director. Volunteers shall serve with immunity to liability under O.C.G.A. § 51-1-29. 
Sec. 9-7. - Violations; falsely displaying emblem. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter, or any person wearing, carrying or displaying any emblem or insignia or other means of identification as a member of the emergency management agency without authority of the proper official shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter. 
Sec. 9-8. - Building contractor registration required. 
No person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity shall engage in, undertake or carry on any business in whole or in part within the limits of Macon-Bibb County during a state of emergency, or the subsequent recovery period consisting of or relating to building, constructing, repairing, renovating or making improvements to real property including dwellings, homes, buildings, structures, or fixtures attached thereto without having registered the name of the business with the department of business development services and having paid fees as provided by this chapter. 
(1)  Certification. The building contractor shall, under oath, provide the department of building development services with a statement describing the general nature of the business to be conducted and give true and correct information as may be called for on the registration form, application or certificate provided by Macon-Bibb County. 
(2)  Registration fees. Building contractor registration fees are hereby fixed under the terms and conditions of this chapter at fifty dollars ($50.00) per annum. Registration fees shall be paid in full at the time of issuance of the registration certification. 
(3)  Transferability. Each certification issued under this chapter is granted to, and shall be accepted by, the building contractor under the condition that the same is not transferable and after issuance no such certification shall be transferred by Macon-Bibb County or the building contractor to another individual or entity. 
(4)  Display of registration certification. Each certification issued hereunder shall be posted conspicuously by the building contractor in the place of business of the building contractor or shall be carried on his person or vehicle used in such business. Such certification shall be exhibited to any authorized enforcement officer when so requested. 
(5)  Revocation; suspension. Each certification granted under this chapter is a mere permit to engage in the business only so long as said business is conducted in a lawful manner. The Macon-Bibb County Commission hereby reserves the right to revoke or suspend any certification granted hereunder, if the building contractor, or the building contractor's agent or employee acting within the scope of his employment, violates this chapter or any other city, county, state or federal law. If after issuance of a certification, Macon-Bibb County desires to revoke such certification, written notice thereof shall be given to the building contractor, which notice shall specify the violation with which the building contractor is charged and a date, time and place at which a hearing in municipal court shall be held with regard to the violation. The building contractor shall have an opportunity to be heard at such hearing, shall have the right to be represented by counsel, and shall have the right to introduce and submit evidence in opposition to such revocation. 
(6)  Effective date; expiration. The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all building contractors doing business within the geographic limits of Macon-Bibb County on that date and doing business on any date thereafter. However, this chapter and any certification issued pursuant to it shall be operative only during the period of a declared state of emergency and any subsequent recovery periods. 
Sec. 9-9. - Curfew. 
(a)  Institution of curfew. 
(1)  Upon the declaration of a state of emergency by the governor, or upon the determination by the Macon-Bibb County Commission, or its designee, of the existence of an emergency or disaster, the commission, its designee or the emergency interim successor may adopt a resolution instituting a curfew when it is determined necessary to protect and safeguard the people and property of Macon-Bibb County. 
(2)  All of the territory of Macon-Bibb County shall be subject to the terms of the curfew, unless otherwise specified in the resolution. 
(3)  The resolution instituting the curfew shall include the dates and hours that the curfew shall be in effect. 
(b)  Prohibition. It shall be prohibited for any person, other than exempt individuals, to appear in public in the territory subject to the curfew, including but not limited to, streets, highways, alleys, sidewalks, vacant lots, parks, public buildings or any other public places in all or a delineated part of the geographic limits of Macon-Bibb County during the stated hours of the curfew. 
Sec. 9-10. - Authority to waive or suspend ordinances, procedures, other formalities, and fees structures. 
(a)  Meetings. Upon proclamation by the appropriate state official of an emergency or disaster of manmade or natural causes or enemy attack impending on or affecting Georgia or the United States, pursuant to section 19(e)(1) of the charter of Macon-Bibb County, the mayor, the mayor pro tempore, or a majority of the commissioners may convene to enact an emergency ordinance to provide, among other things, that the affairs and business of Macon-Bibb County may be conducted at places other than the regular or usual place thereof, within or outside of Macon-Bibb County, when it is not prudent, expedient or possible to conduct business at the regular location. When such emergency ordinance is passed and meetings occur outside of Macon-Bibb County, all actions taken by the commission shall be as valid and binding as if performed within Macon-Bibb County. 
(b)  Purchasing and public works contracts. Upon the declaration of a state of emergency by the governor, or upon the determination by the Macon-Bibb County Commission, or its designee, of the existence of an emergency or disaster, the commission, its designee or the emergency interim successor may make emergency procurements pursuant to the provisions related to emergency procurement of the Macon-Bibb County Code of Ordinances and may contract for public works without letting such contract out to the lowest, responsible bidder and without advertising and posting notification of such contract for four weeks; provided, however, that any public works contract entered into pursuant to this subsection shall be entered on the minutes of the commission as soon as practical and the nature of the emergency described therein. 
(c)  Code enforcement. Upon the declaration of a state of emergency by the governor, or upon the determination by the Macon-Bibb County Commission, or its designee, of the existence of an emergency or disaster, the commission, its designee or the emergency interim successor may temporarily suspend the enforcement of the Code of Ordinances of Macon-Bibb County, or any portion thereof, where: 
(1)  The emergency or disaster is of such nature that immediate action outside this Code is required; 
(2)  Such suspension is consistent with the protection of the public health, safety and welfare; and 
(3)  Such suspension is not inconsistent with any federal or state statutes or regulations. 
(d)  Fees. Upon the declaration of a state of emergency by the governor, or upon the determination by the Macon-Bibb County Commission, or its designee, of the existence of an emergency or disaster, the commission, its designee or the emergency interim successor may temporarily reduce or suspend any permit fees, application fees or other rate structures as necessary to encourage the rebuilding of the area impacted by the disaster or emergency. 
(e)  Temporary dwellings. Upon the declaration of a state of emergency by the governor, or upon the determination by the Macon-Bibb County Commission, or its designee, of the existence of an emergency or disaster, the commission, its designee or the emergency interim successor may issue temporary permits for mobile home, trailer, recreational vehicle or other temporary dwelling structures in any zoning district while the primary dwelling is being repaired provided that such temporary dwellings are designed by an engineer and the plans are approved by the Macon-Bibb County Health Department and the Macon-Bibb County Department of Business Development Services. The temporary permit shall not exceed six (6) months in duration. In the case of continuing hardship and in the discretion of the governing authority or its designee, the permit may be extended for a period for an additional six (6) months. Upon expiration of the temporary permit or an extension, the temporary dwelling shall be removed. 
Sec. 9-11. - Overcharging for goods, materials, services and housing during state of emergency prohibited. 
In order to preserve, protect, or sustain the life, health, or safety of persons or their property, it shall be unlawful during the duration of a state of emergency or subsequent recovery period in which Macon-Bibb County has been designated as a disaster area, for any person, firm, or corporation located or doing business therein to overcharge for any goods, materials, services or housing sold within Macon-Bibb County. 
Sec. 9-12. - Penalties. 
Violation of any provision of this chapter, upon conviction, shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per violation and/or imprisonment not to exceed sixty (60) days. For purposes of enforcing the provisions of section 9-8, each day a building contractor does business within Macon-Bibb County without complying with this ordinance shall constitute a separate offense. 
Chapter 10 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION 

Sec. 10-1. - State Fire Marshall Rules and Regulations adopted. 
(a)  The State Fire Marshal Rules and Regulations shall be adopted, by reference hereto and incorporated herein as if fully stated, as required by Title 25 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. Such rules and regulations are published at Ga. Comp. R. and Regs. 120-3-3 et seq. 
(b)  As required by Title 25 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated all existing buildings in Macon-Bibb County, except single family dwellings shall be inspected by the Bureau of Fire Prevention. 
(c)  The Bureau of Fire Prevention in the Macon-Bibb County Fire Department is hereby vested with full authority and power to enforce the provisions of the Fire Prevention Code. The chief and members of that bureau are authorized to administer the provisions of the Fire Prevention Code, and to make inspections and to take such action as is necessary, proper and convenient to cause violators of the code to be punished, including the initiation of proceedings in a court of proper jurisdiction whether by summons, citation, warrant or otherwise. 
Sec. 10-2. - Fire Prevention Code adopted. 
(a)  The 2012 edition of the International Fire Prevention Code (IFC) is here by adopted in its entirety, including appendixes A, B, C, D, E, and F, and incorporated herein by reference, and shall be enforced by the Bureau of Fire Prevention. The provisions of the 2012 IFC shall supersede any override any conflicting provisions of existing ordinances or resolutions adopted by the City of Macon, Bibb County, or Macon-Bibb County, but only to the extent where such provisions directly conflict with each other. 
(b)  The 2012 IFC, together with all non-conflicting ordinances previously adopted by the City of Macon or Bibb County governing fire safety shall be known as the Macon-Bibb County Fire Prevention Code, copies of which shall be on file and open for public inspection in the office of the Clerk of Macon-Bibb County. Copies of the Macon-Bibb County Fire Prevention Code shall also be on file and open for inspection in the office of the chief of the Macon-Bibb County Fire Department and the director of the office of the Bureau of Fire Prevention. 
(c)  Violations of any provision of this chapter shall be punished as provided in the Charter and ordinances of Macon-Bibb County for violation of the ordinances of Macon-Bibb County. 
Sec. 10-2.1. - Amendments to Standard Fire Prevention Code. 
(a)  The 2012 International Fire Code, as adopted in section 10-2, is here by amended as by inserting the following definitions in Chapter 2, Section 202: 
Fire District shall mean all those areas within the boundaries of Macon-Bibb County. 
Fire Code Official shall mean the Fire Chief or his/her designee 
(b)  Chapter 3, Section 304.1.1 of the 2012 International Fire Code, as adopted in section 10-2, is here by amended by inserting at the end of the paragraph the following exception: 
"Exception: Land comprising acreage of natural growth may only need safeguarding by cutting fire breaks of sufficient width." 
Sec. 10-3. - Life Safety Code adopted. 
(a)  The 2012 edition of the Life Safety Code, recommended by the National Fire Protection Association, is here by adopted by referenced and incorporated herein for enforcement in Macon-Bibb County by the Bureau of Fire Prevention. Up to date copies of the Life Safety Code shall be maintained at the office of the clerk of Macon-Bibb County, the office of the fire chief, and the office of the Bureau of Fire Prevention. 
(b)  Any provision of the Macon-Bibb County Fire Prevention Code which is in conflict with the Life Safety Code shall be controlling over the conflicting provisions of the Life Safety Code. 
(c)  Deletions and additions to, or adoption of the latest edition of or supplements to this code chapter may be adopted by resolution of the Macon-Bibb County Commission, provided that copies of such changes are placed on file with the office of the Clerk of Macon-Bibb County, the office of the fire chief, and the office of the Bureau of Fire Prevention. 
Sec. 10-4. - Powers and duties of fire chief. 
The fire chief shall: 
(1)  See to the proper and speedy extinguishment of fires which may endanger life or property within Macon-Bibb County; 
(2)  Enforce all regulations of the department and administrative directives of the mayor; 
(3)  Have supreme and absolute command at the scene of a fire over the endangered property, the general area surrounding the property, and all public safety personnel present at such fire, including law enforcement personnel; 
(4)  Issue a report each year in writing to the county manager for presentation to the mayor and to the commissioners on all fires attended by the fire department in the preceding year, with causes thereof, if ascertainable, and the number and description of any buildings destroyed, persons injured and all fire related deaths; 
(5)  Investigate all fires to determine if arson was involved;
