(6)  Examine, in general, all buildings, except single family dwellings, throughout Macon-Bibb County in order to become familiar with the construction and class of business carried on, the class of goods on each floor and whether the goods are highly combustible or noncombustible, to see that entrances, stairways, halls and exits are accessible, to learn the most expedient manner of attack in the case of fire, to make any other observations as may serve the interest of the department, and to make a note of each inspection in a book or other form of record provided for that purpose. A copy of this record shall be kept at each fire station and all members of the department shall familiarize themselves with it; and 
(7)  Have the power to evacuate any buildings or area necessary for the protection of human life during a threat of a bomb, fire, explosion, or similar hazardous condition. 
Sec. 10-5. - Oath of office. 
(a)  Before any fire officers shall assume the duties of office, each shall take substantially the following oath: 
"I do solemnly swear or affirm that I will faithfully perform all the duties of my office, and that I will faithfully observe all the rules, orders and regulations of the department. I further swear or affirm that I will obey all laws of Macon-Bibb County, the State of Georgia, and any other state, or the United States of America." 
(b)  This oath shall be administered by the fire chief, assistant chief or the mayor. 
Sec. 10-6. - Reports of insurance adjusters. 
Each fire insurance adjuster shall be required to file a report with the fire chief upon settling a fire loss of one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more, within ten (10) days following the settlement, and the report shall show the cause of the fire loss, amount of loss, amount of insurance carried by the insured, the amount of settlement and amount of salvage recovery value. 
Sec. 10-7. - Using or tampering with fire hydrants. 
No person shall use water from or tamper with any fire hydrant of Macon-Bibb County, except with the written approval of the fire chief. 
Sec. 10-8. - Obstructing fire stations. 
No person shall obstruct in any manner the entrance to any fire station house. 
Sec. 10-9. - Solicitations. 
(a)  Solicitations, subscription paper circulation, sales of tickets for entertainment, raffles and the like are prohibited in or around fire department facilities except by written permission from the fire chief. 
(b)  Officers and employees of the fire department shall not solicit subscriptions or attempt to sell anything to persons outside the department while on duty, for company or other purposes, without written permission of the fire chief. 
Sec. 10-10. - Downtown fire district. 
There is hereby recreated and re-established a downtown fire district which is defined as embraced within the following boundaries: 
Beginning at the intersection of Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard and Riverside Drive; extending along Riverside Drive to Spring Street; extending along Spring Street and an extension thereof to Hazel Street; extending along Hazel Street to Fifth Street; extending along Fifth Street and Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard to Riverside Drive, the beginning point, including both sides of segments of the above streets forming such boundaries. 
Sec. 10-11. - Requirements for water mains and fire hydrants in developments. 
(a)  All new residential and commercial developments within Macon-Bibb County shall make adequate provisions for water mains and fire hydrants in compliance with the standards adopted pursuant to this section. The purpose of this section is to ensure that an adequate water supply is available throughout Macon-Bibb County to protect our citizens from the dangers of fire. 
(b)  The following words, where used in this section, shall be deemed to have the following meanings: 
(1)  Residential development shall include, but not be limited to, single-family subdivisions, apartments, condominiums, cooperatives, and zero lot line units. 
(2)  Commercial development means any development related to or connected with trade or commerce. 
(c)  The fire chief is authorized to adopt written standards concerning the installation and maintenance of a system of adequate water mains and fire hydrants throughout Macon-Bibb County. A copy of these standards so adopted by the fire chief shall be kept on file for public inspection and copying at all times in the office of the Macon-Bibb County clerk, the fire chief's office, and the Bureau of Fire Prevention. 
(d)  All developers must submit, in advance, to the Bureau of Fire Prevention a set of detailed plans showing the placement of the proposed mains and hydrants, type of materials to be used, size of proposed mains, nearest existing water mains and hydrants, and all other necessary details of the fire hydrant system. Such plan shall bear the seal of a registered engineer and a certification by the engineer that the plans comply with these regulations. All developers shall be required to post an adequate financial guarantee, which is acceptable to the fire chief to insure the completion of the fire hydrant system. Before construction of the fire hydrant system will be allowed, the fire chief shall have reviewed and approved the plans. 
(e)  These plans shall also be submitted, prior to construction, to the Macon-Bibb County Water and Sewer Authority for a review and approval that an adequate water supply exists for the project. An adequate water supply shall be deemed to exist if there is a water main of sufficient size within five hundred (500) feet of the property line of the proposed development. 
(f)  During installation of the fire hydrant system by the developer, the Department of Business Development Services and the Bureau of Fire Protection will conduct inspections and the building official shall approve that portion of the system on private property. It shall be the duty of the contractor installing the fire hydrant system to call the Department of Business Development Services and Bureau of Fire Prevention for inspections before each section of the system is covered over. 
(g)  No certificates of occupancy may be issued by the building official in such development until such certification of completion of the fire hydrant system has been issued by the building official and accepted by the fire official. Furthermore, the water and sewer authority shall not provide water service to the water mains on private property in such development until such certification of completion has been issued. 
(h)  Also, no streets within the development may be accepted for public maintenance by the Macon-Bibb County engineer until the certification of completion has been issued. 
(i)  The fire chief may waive or modify the provisions of these standards if the Macon-Bibb County Water and Sewer Authority cannot certify that an adequate water supply is available. 
(j)  Any new development which involves a substantial modification of an existing part of Macon-Bibb County's fire hydrant system shall also be required to comply with the standards which are adopted pursuant to this section. 
Sec. 10-12. - Smoking in bed prohibited; signs. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, while an occupant of a hotel, rooming house, tourist court or other commercial establishment in which room accommodations are furnished for hire, to smoke any cigarette, cigar, pipe or other device used for the burning of tobacco or other substance, while such person is in bed. 
(b)  Every operator of a hotel, rooming house, tourist court or other commercial establishment in which rooming accommodations are furnished for hire shall post in a prominent place, in each room let for hire a copy of this section, and cause such notice to be so posted continuously. 
Sec. 10-13. - Parking in fire lane. 
It shall be unlawful to park a motor vehicle in a posted fire lane. Law enforcement officers and members of the Bureau of Fire Prevention of the Fire Department may issue citations for violations of this section. 
Sec. 10-14. - Security gates. 
Security gates shall be constructed only with the approval of the fire chief and only if they comply with following provisions: 
(1)  Plans describing the gate width and type of emergency entrance for fire vehicles shall be submitted to the fire department for review and approval; 
(2)  Changes in the security code must be immediately reported to the fire department; 
(3)  All security gates installed must comply at all times with Section 503.6 of the 2012 International Fire Code; 
Sec. 10-15. - Burn permits. 
It shall be unlawful to engage in any type of outdoor burning without the prior approval of the Bureau of Fire Prevention. 
Sec. 10-16. - Emergency contact telephone numbers. 
(a)  All businesses shall submit to the fire department an emergency contact list of persons to be notified in case of after hour emergencies. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a designated emergency contact person to refuse to respond to an emergency when so notified by the fire department or law enforcement personnel. 
(c)  All changes in designated contact persons or contact information shall be immediately reported to the Bureau of Fire Prevention. 
Chapter 11 - FLOOD DAMAGE PREVENTION 
ARTICLE I. - STATUTORY AUTHORIZATION, FINDINGS, PURPOSE, AND OBJECTIVES 

Sec. 11-1. - Authorization and findings of fact. 
Article IX, Section II of the Constitution of the State of Georgia and O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20(a) have delegated the responsibility to local governmental units to adopt regulations designed to promote the public healthy, safety, and general welfare of its citizenry. Therefore, the Macon-Bibb County Commission, does ordain as follows: 
(1)  The flood hazard areas of Macon-Bibb County, Georgia are subject to periodic inundation which results in loss of life and property, health and safety hazards, disruption of commerce and governmental services, extraordinary public expenditures for flood relief and protection, and impairment of the trot base, all of which adversely affect the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(2)  These flood losses are caused by the occupancy in flood hazard areas of uses vulnerable to floods, which are inadequately elevated, flood-proofed, or otherwise unprotected from flood damages, and by the cumulative effect of obstructions in floodplains causing increases in flood heights and velocities. 
Sec. 11-2. - Statement of purpose. 
It is the purpose of this chapter to promote the public health, safety and general welfare and to minimize public and private losses due to flood conditions in specific areas by provisions designed to: 
(1)  Require that uses vulnerable to floods, including facilities, which serve such uses, be protected against flood damage at the time of initial construction; 
(2)  Restrict or prohibit uses which are dangerous to health, safety and property due to water or erosion hazards, or which increase flood heights, velocities, or erosion; 
(3)  Control filling, grading, dredging and other development which may increase flood damage or erosion, and; 
(4)  Prevent or regulate the construction of flood barriers which will unnaturally divert flood waters or which may increase flood hazards to other lands; 
(5)  Control the alteration of natural floodplains, stream channels, and natural protective barriers, which are involved in the accommodation of floodwaters. 
Sec. 11-3. - Objectives. 
The objectives of this ordinance are: 
(1)  To protect human life and health; 
(2)  To minimize damage to public facilities and utilities such as water and gas mains, electric, telephone and sewer lines, streets and bridges located in floodplains; 
(3)  To help maintain a stable tax base by providing for the sound use and development of flood prone areas in such a manner as to minimize flood blight areas; 
(4)  To minimize expenditure of public money for costly flood control projects; 
(5)  To minimize the need for rescue and relief efforts associated with flooding and generally undertaken at the expense of the general public; 
(6)  To minimize prolonged business interruptions; and 
(7)  To insure that potential homebuyers are notified that property is in a flood area. 
Sec. 11-4. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 11-5. - Lands to which this chapter applies. 
This chapter shall apply to all Areas of Special Flood Hazard within Macon-Bibb County. 
Sec. 11-6. - Basis for area of special flood hazard. 
The Areas of Special Flood Hazard identified by the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) in its most recently available flood elevation data provided in the Flood Insurance Study (FIS) and the Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM) for the consolidate government of Macon-Bibb County, Georgia, as prepared and revised by FEMA. The accompanying maps and other supporting data, including any revisions thereto, are hereby adopted by reference, declared to be part of this ordinance, and shall have the same force and effect as if fully set forth in this ordinance. 
Areas of Special Flood Hazard may also include those areas known to have flooded historically or defined through standard engineering analysis by governmental agencies or private parties but not yet incorporated in a FIS or FIRM. 
The repository for public inspection of the Flood Insurance Study (FIS), Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM), and any accompanying maps and other supporting data, including any revisions thereto, are located in the office of the Macon-Bibb County engineer. 
( Ord. of 6-6-2017(2), § 1 ) 
Sec. 11-7. - Establishment of development permit. 
A development permit shall be required in conformance with the provisions of this chapter PRIOR to the commencement of any development activities. 
Sec. 11-8. - Compliance. 
No structure or land shall hereafter be located, extended, converted or altered without full compliance with the terms of this chapter and other applicable regulations. 
Sec. 11-9. - Abrogation and greater restrictions. 
This chapter is not intended to repeal, abrogate, or impair any existing ordinance, easements, covenants, or deed restrictions. However, where this chapter and another conflict or overlap, whichever imposes the more stringent restrictions shall prevail. 
Sec. 11-10. - Interpretation. 
In the interpretation and application of this chapter all provisions shall be: 
(1)  Considered as minimum requirements; 
(2)  Liberally construed in favor of the governing body; and 
(3)  Deemed neither to limit nor repeal any other powers granted under state statutes. 
Sec. 11-11. - Warning and disclaimer of liability. 
The degree of flood protection required by this chapter is considered reasonable for regulatory purposes and is based on scientific and engineering considerations. Larger floods can and will occur; flood heights may be increased by man-made or natural causes. This chapter does not imply that land outside the Areas of Special Flood Hazard or uses permitted within such areas will be free from flooding or flood damages. This chapter shall not create liability on the part of Macon-Bibb County or by any officer or employee thereof for any flood damages that result from reliance on this chapter or any administrative decision lawfully made hereunder. 
Sec. 11-12. - Penalties for violation. 
Failure to comply with the provisions of this ordinance or with any of its requirements, including conditions and safeguards established in connection with grants of variance or special exceptions shall constitute a violation. Trial of such violations shall be brought in the Municipal Court of Macon-Bibb County but the case may be removed to the State Court of Macon-Bibb County upon the motion of either party or upon motion of the judge of Municipal Court. Any person, firm or corporation who violates this ordinance or fails to comply with any of its requirements shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable by fines not exceed to five hundred dollars ($500.00) per violation and/or jail time not to exceed thirty (30) days per violation. Nothing herein contained shall prevent Macon-Bibb County from taking such other lawful actions as is necessary to prevent or remedy any violation. 
( Ord. No. O-15-0032, § 1, 7-21-2015 ; Ord. No. O-16-0048, § 1, 6-21-2016 ) 
Secs. 11-13, 11-14. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 11-15. - Designation of chapter administrator. 
The Macon-Bibb County Engineer is hereby appointed to administer and implement the provisions of this chapter. Any reference to the Macon-Bibb County Engineer includes his authorized representatives. 
Sec. 11-16. - Permit procedures. 
Application for a development permit, which shall be accompanied with a fifty dollar ($50.00) application fee, shall be made to the Macon-Bibb County Engineer on forms furnished by the community PRIOR to any development activities, and may include, but not be limited to the following: plans in duplicate drawn to scale showing the elevations of the area in question and the nature, location, dimensions, of existing or proposed structures, earthen fill placement, storage of materials or equipment, and drainage facilities. 
Specifically, the following information is required: 
(1)  Application stage 
a.  Elevation in relation to mean sea level of the lowest floor, including basement, of all structures; 
b.  Elevation in relation to mean sea level to which any non-residential structure will be flood-proofed; 
c.  Design certification from a registered professional engineer or architect that any proposed non-residential flood-proofed structure will meet the flood-proofing criteria of Section 11-21(2); 
d.  Description of the extent to which any watercourse will be altered or relocated as a result of a proposed development; and 
(2)  Construction stage 
For all new construction and substantial improvements, the permit holder shall provide to the administrator an as-built certification of the regulatory floor elevation or flood-proofing level immediately after the lowest floor or flood proofing is completed. Any lowest floor certification made relative to mean sea level shall be prepared by or under the direct supervision of a registered land surveyor or professional engineer and certified by same. When flood proofing is utilized for non-residential structures, said certification shall be prepared by or under the direct supervision of a professional engineer or architect and certified by same. 
Any work undertaken prior to submission of these certifications shall be at the permit holder's risk. 
The Macon-Bibb County Engineer shall review the above referenced certification data submitted. Deficiencies detected by such review shall be corrected by the permit holder immediately and prior to further progressive work being allowed to proceed. Failure to submit certification or failure to make said corrections required herein, shall be cause to issue a stop-work order for the project. 
Sec. 11-17. - Duties and responsibilities of the administrator. 
Duties of the Macon-Bibb County Engineer shall include, but shall not be limited to: 
(1)  Review proposed development to assure that the permit requirements of this ordinance have been satisfied. 
(2)  Advise permittee that additional federal or state permits maybe required, and if specific federal or state permit requirements are known, require that copies of such permits be provided and maintained on file with the Floodplain Development permit. 
(3)  Review all permit applications to determine whether proposed building sites will be reasonably safe from flooding. 
(4)  When base flood elevation data or floodway data have not been provided in accordance with section 11-6, then the Macon-Bibb County Engineer shall obtain, review and reasonably utilize any base flood elevation and floodway data available from federal, state or other sources in order to administer the flood hazard reduction provisions of Article IV. 
(5)  Review and record the actual elevation in relation to mean sea level (or highest adjacent grade) of the lowest floor, including basement, of all new or substantially improved structures in accordance with Section 11-16(2). 
(6)  Review and record the actual elevation, in relation to mean sea level to which any new or substantially improved structures have been flood-proofed, in accordance with Section 11-16(2). 
(7)  When flood-proofing is utilized for a structure, the Macon-Bibb County Engineer shall obtain certification of design criteria from a registered professional engineer or architect in accordance with Sections 11-16(1)(c) and Sections 11-21(2) or 11-23(2). 
(8)  Make substantial damage determinations following a flood event or any other event that causes damage to structures in flood hazard areas. 
(9)  Notify adjacent communities and the Georgia Department of Natural Resources prior to any alteration or relocation of a watercourse and submit evidence of such notification to the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA). 
(10)  For any altered or relocated watercourse, submit engineering data/analysis within six (6) months to the FEMA to ensure accuracy of community flood maps through the Letter of Map Revision process. Assure flood carrying capacity of any altered or relocated watercourse is maintained. 
(11)  Where interpretation is needed as to the exact location of boundaries of the Areas of Special Flood Hazard (for example, where there appears to be a conflict between a mapped boundary and actual field conditions) the Macon-Bibb County Engineer shall make the necessary interpretation. Any person contesting the location of the boundary shall be given a reasonable opportunity to appeal the interpretation as provided in this ordinance. 
(12)  All records pertaining to the provisions of this chapter shall be maintained in the office of the Macon-Bibb County Engineer and shall be open for public inspection. 
(13)  Whenever in this section, a verification is required by the Macon-Bibb County Engineer, he may rely upon a certification by an engineer or surveyor registered in the State of Georgia. 
Secs. 11-18, 11-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FLOOD HAZARD REDUCTION 

Sec. 11-20. - General standards. 
In ALL Areas of Special Flood Hazard the following provisions are required: 
(1)  New construction and substantial improvements of existing structures shall be anchored to prevent flotation, collapse or lateral movement of the structure; 
(2)  New construction and substantial improvements of existing structures shall be constructed with materials and utility equipment resistant to flood damage; 
(3)  New construction or substantial improvements of existing structures shall be constructed by methods and practices that minimize flood damage; 
(4)  Elevated buildings. All new construction or substantial improvements of existing structures that include ANY fully enclosed area located below the lowest floor formed by foundation and other exterior walls shall be designed so as to be an unfinished or flood resistant enclosure. The enclosure shall be designed to equalize hydrostatic flood forces on exterior walls by allowing for the automatic entry and exit of floodwater. 
(a)  Designs for complying with this requirement must either be certified by a professional engineer or architect or meet the following minimum criteria: 
(i)  Provide a minimum of two openings having a total net area of not less than one-square-inch for every square foot of enclosed area subject to flooding; 
(ii)  The bottom of all openings shall be no higher than one-foot above grade; and 
(iii)  Openings may be equipped with screens, louvers, valves or other coverings or devices provided they permit the automatic flow of floodwater in both directions. 
(b)  So as not to violate the "Lowest Floor" criteria of this chapter, the unfinished or flood resistant enclosure shall only be used for parking of vehicles, limited storage of maintenance equipment used in connection with the premises, or entry to the elevated area, and 
(c)  The interior portion of such enclosed area shall not be partitioned or finished into separate rooms. 
(5)  All heating and air conditioning equipment and components (including ductwork), all electrical, ventilation, plumbing, and other service facilities shall be designed and/or located so as to prevent water from entering or accumulating within the components during conditions of flooding. 
(6)  Manufactured homes shall be anchored to prevent flotation, collapse, or lateral movement. Methods of anchoring may include, but are not limited to, use of over-the-top or frame ties to ground anchors. This standard shall be in addition to and consistent with applicable state requirements for resisting wind forces. 
(7)  New and replacement water supply systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of flood waters into the system; 
(8)  New and replacement sanitary sewage systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of flood waters into the systems and discharges from the systems into flood waters; 
(9)  On-site waste disposal systems shall be located and constructed to avoid impairment to them or contamination from them during flooding; 
(10)  Any alteration, repair, reconstruction or improvement to a structure which is not compliant with the provisions of this chapter, shall be undertaken only if the non-conformity is not furthered, extended or replaced; and 
(11)  Any alteration, repair, reconstruction or improvements to a structure which is in compliance with the provisions of this chapter, shall meet the requirements of "new construction" as contained in this chapter. 
Sec. 11-21. - Specific standards. 
In ALL Areas of Special Flood Hazard the following provisions are required: 
(1)  New construction and/or substantial improvements. Where base flood elevation data are available, new construction and/or substantial improvement of any structure or manufactured home shall have the lowest floor, including basement, elevated no lower than two (2) feet above the base flood elevation. Should solid foundation perimeter walls be used to elevate a structure, openings sufficient to facilitate equalization of flood hydrostatic forces on both sides of exterior walls shall be provided in accordance with standards of Section 11-20(4), "Elevated Buildings". 
(a)  All heating and air conditioning equipment and components (including ductwork), all electrical, ventilation, plumbing, and other service facilities shall be elevated at or above one (1) foot above the base flood elevation. 
(2)  Residential construction. New construction and/or the substantial improvement of any structure located in A1-30, AE, or AH zones, may be flood-proofed in lieu of elevation. The structure, together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities, must be designed to be water tight to two (2) foot above the base flood elevation, with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water, and structural components having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads and the effect of buoyancy. A registered professional engineer or architect shall certify that the design and methods of construction are in accordance with accepted standards of practice for meeting the provisions above, and shall provide such certification to the official as set forth above and in Section 11-17(6). 
(3)  Standards for manufactured homes and recreational vehicles. Where base flood elevation data are available: 
(a)  All manufactured homes placed and/or substantially improved on: 
(1)  Individual lots or parcels, 
(2)  In new and/or substantially improved manufactured home parks or subdivisions, 
(3)  In expansions to existing manufactured home parks or subdivisions, or 
(4)  On a site in an existing manufactured home park or subdivision where a manufactured home has incurred "substantial damage" as the result of a flood, must meet all the requirements for new construction, including elevation and anchoring. 
(b)  Manufactured homes placed and/or substantially improved in an existing manufactured home park or subdivision may be elevated so that either: 
(i)  The lowest floor of the manufactured home is elevated no lower than two (2) feet above the level of the base flood elevation, or 
(ii)  The manufactured home chassis is elevated and supported by reinforced piers (or other foundation elements of at least an equivalent strength) of no less than 36 inches in height above grade. 
(c)  All manufactured homes must be securely anchored to an adequately anchored foundation system to resist flotation, collapse and lateral movement. (Ref. Section 11-20(6) above) 
(d)  All recreational vehicles placed on sites must either: 
(i)  Be on the site for fewer than 180 consecutive days; 
(ii)  Be fully licensed and ready for highway use, (a recreational vehicle is ready for highway use if it is licensed, on its wheels or jacking system, attached to the site only by quick disconnect type utilities and security devices, and has no permanently attached structures or additions); or 
(iii)  The recreational vehicle must meet all the requirements for "New Construction", including the anchoring and elevation requirements of Section 11-21(3)(a)(c), above. 
(4)  Floodway. Located within Areas of Special Flood Hazard established in Section 11-6, are areas designated as floodways. A floodway may be an extremely hazardous area due to velocity floodwaters, debris or erosion potential. In addition, the area must remain free of encroachment in order to allow for the discharge of the base flood without increased flood heights. Therefore, the following provisions shall apply: 
a.  Encroachments are prohibited, including earthen fill, new construction, substantial improvements or other development within the regulatory floodway. Development may be permitted however, provided it is demonstrated through hydrologic and hydraulic analyses performed in accordance with standard engineering practice that the encroachment shall not result in any increase in flood levels or floodway widths during a base flood discharge. A registered professional engineer must provide supporting technical data and certification thereof. 
b.  ONLY if Section 11-21(4)(a) above is satisfied, then any new construction or substantial improvement shall comply with all other applicable flood hazard reduction provisions of Article IV. 
Sec. 11-22. - Building standards for streams without established base flood elevations and/or floodway (A-zones). 
Located within the Areas of Special Flood Hazard established in Section 11-6, where streams exist but no base flood data have been provided (A-zones), or where base flood data have been provided but a floodway has not been delineated, the following provisions apply: 
(1)  When base flood elevation data or floodway data have not been provided in accordance with Section 11-6, then the Macon-Bibb County Engineer shall obtain, review, and reasonably utilize any scientific or historic base flood elevation and floodway data available from a federal, state, or other source, in order to administer the flood hazard reduction provisions of Article IV. Only if data are not available from these sources, then the following provisions (2 & 3) shall apply: 
(2)  No encroachments, including structures or fill material, shall be located within an area equal to the width of the stream or 20 feet, whichever is greater, measured from the top of the stream bank, unless certification by a registered professional engineer is provided demonstrating that such encroachment shall not result in more than a one (1) foot increase in flood levels during the occurrence of the base flood discharge. 
(3)  In special flood hazard areas without base flood elevation data, new construction and substantial improvements of existing structures shall have the lowest floor of the lowest enclosed area (including basement) elevated no less than three (3) feet above the highest adjacent grade at the building site. (NOTE: Require the lowest floor to be elevated two (2) feet above the estimated base flood elevation in A-Zone areas where a Limited Detail Study has been completed). Openings sufficient to facilitate the- unimpeded movements of floodwaters shall be provided in accordance with standards of Section 11-20(4) "Elevated Buildings". 
a.  All heating and air conditioning equipment and components (including ductwork), all electrical, ventilation, plumbing, and other service facilities shall be elevated no less than three (3) feet above the highest adjacent grade at the building site. 
The County Engineer shall certify the lowest floor elevation level and the record shall become a permanent part of the permit file. 
Sec. 11-22.1. - Standards for areas of special flood hazard (Zones AE) with established base flood elevations without designated floodways. 
Located within the areas of special flood hazard established in article II, where streams with base flood elevations are provided but no floodways have been designated, (Zones AE) the following provisions apply: 
(1)  No encroachments, including fill material, new structures or substantial improvements shall be located within areas of special flood hazard, unless certification by a registered professional engineer is provided demonstrating that the cumulative effect of the proposed development, when combined with all other existing and anticipated development, will not increase the water surface elevation of the base flood more than one-foot at any point within the community. The engineering certification should be supported by technical data that conforms to standard hydraulic engineering principles. 
(2)  New construction or substantial improvements of buildings shall be elevated or flood-proofed to elevations established in accordance with Article IV, subsection (b) [section 11-30]. 
Sec. 11-23. - Standards for areas of shallow flooding (AO zones). 
Areas of special flood hazard established in Section 11-6, may include designated "AO" shallow flooding areas. These areas have base flood depths of one to three (1' — 3') feet above ground, with no clearly defined channel. The following provisions apply: 
(1)  All new construction and substantial improvements of residential and non-residential structures shall have the lowest floor, including basement, elevated to the flood depth number specified on the Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM), above the highest adjacent grade. If no flood depth number is specified, the lowest floor, including basement, shall be elevated at least three (3) feet above the highest adjacent grade. Openings sufficient to facilitate the unimpeded movements of flood waters shall be provided in accordance with standards of section 11-20(4), "Elevated Buildings". 
The County Engineer shall certify the lowest floor elevation level and the record shall become a permanent part of the permit file. 
(2)  New construction or the substantial improvement of a non-residential structure may be flood-proofed in lieu of elevation. The structure, together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities, must be designed to be water tight to the specified FIRM flood level plus two (2) feet, above highest adjacent grade, with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water, and structural components having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads and the effect of buoyancy. A registered professional engineer or architect shall certify that the design and methods of construction are in accordance with accepted standards of practice for meeting the provisions above, and shall provide such certification to the official as set forth above and as required in Section 11-16(1)(c) and (2). 
(3)  Drainage paths shall be provided to guide floodwater around and away from any proposed structure. 
Sec. 11-24. - Standards for subdivisions. 
(1)  All subdivision and/or development proposals shall be consistent with the need to minimize flood damage; 
(2)  All subdivision and/or development proposals shall have public utilities and facilities such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems located and constructed to minimize flood damage; 
(3)  All subdivision and/or development proposals shall have adequate drainage provided to reduce exposure to flood hazards; and 
(4)  For subdivisions and/or developments greater than fifty (50) lots or five (5) acres, whichever is less, base flood elevation data shall be provided for subdivision and all other proposed development, including manufactured home parks and subdivisions. Any changes or revisions to the flood data adopted herein and shown on the FIRM shall be submitted to FEMA for review as a Conditional Letter of Map Revision (CLOMR) or conditional letter of map amendment (CLOMA), whichever is applicable. Upon completion of the project, the developer is responsible for submitting the "as-built" data to FEMA in order to obtain the final LOMR. 
Sec. 11-25. - Standards for critical facilities. 
(1)  Critical facilities shall not be located in the 100-year floodplain or the 500-year floodplain. 
(2)  All ingress and egress from any critical facility must be protected to the 500-year flood elevation. 
ARTICLE V. - VARIANCES 

Sec. 11-26. - Variance procedures and conditions. 
(A)  The commission shall hear and decide requests for appeals or variance from the requirements of this chapter. 
(B)  The board shall hear and decide appeals when it is alleged an error in any requirement, decision, or determination is made by the Macon-Bibb County Engineer in the enforcement or administration of this chapter. 
(C)  Any person aggrieved by the decision of the commission may appeal such decision to the Superior Court of Bibb County, as provided in O.C.G.A. § 5-4-1. 
(D)  Variances may be issued for the repair or rehabilitation of Historic Structures upon a determination that the proposed repair or rehabilitation will not preclude the structure's continued designation as a historic structure and the variance is the minimum to preserve the historic character and design of the structure. 
(E)  Variances may be issued for development necessary for the conduct of a functionally dependent use, provided the criteria of this article are met, no reasonable alternative exists, and the development is protected by methods that minimize flood damage during the base flood and create no additional threats to public safety. 
(F)  Variances shall not be issued within any designated floodway if ANY increase in flood levels during the base flood discharge would result. 
(G)  In reviewing such requests, the Macon-Bibb County Commission shall consider all technical evaluations, relevant factors, and all standards specified in this and other sections of this ordinance. 
(H)  Conditions for variances. 
(1)  A variance shall be issued ONLY when there is: 
(i)  A finding of good and sufficient cause, 
(ii)  A determination that failure to grant the variance would result in exceptional hardship, and 
(iii)  A determination that the granting of a variance will not result in increased flood heights, additional threats to public safety, extraordinary public expense, create nuisance, cause fraud on or victimization of the public, or conflict with existing local laws or ordinances. 
(2)  The provisions of this chapter are minimum standards for flood loss reduction; therefore any deviation from the standards must be weighed carefully. Variances shall only be issued upon a determination that the variance is the minimum necessary, considering the flood hazard, to afford relief; and, in the instance of a Historic Structure, a determination that the variance is the minimum necessary so as not to destroy the historic character and design of the building. 
(3)  Any applicant to whom a variance is granted shall be given written notice specifying the difference between the base flood elevation and the elevation of the proposed lowest floor and stating that the cost of flood insurance will be commensurate with the increased risk to life and property resulting from the reduced lowest floor elevation. 
(4)  The Macon-Bibb County Engineer shall maintain the records of all appeal actions and report any variances to the Federal Emergency Management Agency upon request. 
(I)  Upon consideration of the factors listed above and the purposes of this chapter, the Macon-Bibb County Commission may attach such conditions to the granting of variances as it deems necessary to further the purposes of this ordinance. 
Secs. 11-27—11-29. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - DEFINITIONS 

Sec. 11-30. - Definitions. 
Unless specifically defined in this section, words or phrases used in this chapter shall be interpreted so as to give them the meaning they have in common usage and to give this section its most reasonable application. 
"Accessory Structure" means a structure having minimal value and used for parking, storage and other non-habitable uses, such as garages, carports, storage sheds, pole barns, hay sheds and the like. 
"Addition (to an existing building)" means any walled and roofed expansion to the perimeter of a building in which the addition is connected by a common load-bearing wall other than a firewall. Any walled and roofed addition, which is connected by a firewall or is separated by an independent perimeter load-bearing wall, shall be considered "New Construction". 
"Appeal" means a request for a review of the Macon-Bibb County Engineer's interpretation of any provision of this chapter or a request for a variance. 
"Area of shallow flooding" means a designated AO or AH zone on a community's Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM) with base flood depths from one to three feet, and/or where a clearly defined channel does not exist, where the path of flooding is unpredictable and indeterminate, and where velocity flow may be evident. 
"Area of special flood hazard" is the land in the floodplain within a community subject to a one percent or greater chance of flooding in any given year. In the absence of official designation by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, Areas of Special Flood Hazard shall be those designated by the local community and referenced in Section 11-6. 
"Base flood" means the flood having a one percent chance of being equaled or exceeded in any given year. 
"Base flood elevation" means the computed elevation to which floodwater is anticipated to rise during the base flood. Base Flood Elevations (BFEs) are shown on Flood Insurance Rate Maps (FIRMs) and on the flood profiles. 
"Basement" means that portion of a building having its floor sub grade (below ground level) on all sides. 
"Building" means any structure built for support, shelter, or enclosure for any occupancy or storage. 
"Critical Facility" means any public or private facility, which, if flooded, would create an added dimension to the disaster or would increase the hazard to life and health. Critical facilities include: 
(a)  structures or facilities that produce, use, or store highly volatile, flammable, explosive, toxic, or water-reactive materials; 
(b)  hospitals and nursing homes, and housing for the elderly, which are likely to contain occupants who may not be sufficiently mobile to avoid the loss of life or injury during flood and storm events; 
(c)  emergency operation centers or data storage centers which contain records or services that may become lost or inoperative during flood and storm events; and 
(d)  generating plants, and other principal points of utility lines. 
"Development" means any man-made change to improved or unimproved real estate, including, but not limited to, buildings or other structures, mining, dredging, filling, grading, paving, excavating, drilling operations, and storage of materials or equipment. 
"Elevated building" means a non-basement building built to have the lowest floor of the lowest enclosed area elevated above the ground level by means of fill, solid foundation perimeter walls, pilings, columns, piers, or shear walls adequately anchored so as not to impair the structural integrity of the building during a base flood event. 
"Existing construction" means any structure for which the "start of construction" commenced before August 17, 1979. 
"Existing Manufactured Home Park or Subdivision" means a manufactured home park or subdivision for which the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed (including at a minimum the installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and final site grading or the pouring of concrete pads) is completed before August 17, 1979. 
"Expansion to an existing manufactured home park or subdivision" means the preparation of additional sites by the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed, including the installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site grading or the pouring of concrete pads. 
"Flood" or "flooding" means a general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from: 
(a)  the overflow of inland or tidal waters; or 
(b)  the unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source. 
"Flood Hazard Boundary Map (FHBM)" means an official map of a community, issued by the Federal Insurance Administration, where the boundaries of areas of special flood hazard have been defined as Zone A. 
"Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM)" means the official map of Macon-Bibb County, Georgia, on which FEMA has delineated both the special hazard areas and the risk premium zones applicable to Macon-Bibb County, Georgia, as made available and amended by FEMA. 
"Flood Insurance Study (FIS)" means the compilation and presentation of flood risk data for specific watercourses, lakes, and coastal flood hazard areas within Macon-Bibb County, Georgia, as made available and amended by FEMA. 
"Floodplain" means any land area susceptible to flooding. 
"Flood proofing" means any combination of structural and non-structural additions, changes, or adjustments to structures, which reduce or eliminate flood damage to real estate or improved real property, water and sanitary facilities, structures and their contents. 
"Floodway" means the channel of a river or other watercourse and the adjacent land areas that must be reserved in order to discharge the base flood without cumulatively increasing the water surface elevation more than a designated height. 
"Functionally dependent facility" means a facility which cannot be used for its intended purpose unless it is located or carried out in close proximity to water, such as a docking or port facility necessary for the loading and unloading of cargo or passengers, shipbuilding, ship repair, or seafood processing facilities. The term does not include long-term storage, manufacture, sales, or service facilities. 
"Freeboard" means a factor of safety usually expressed in feet above a flood level for purposes of floodplain management. "Freeboard" tends to compensate for the many unknown factors that could contribute to flood heights greater than the height calculated for a selected size flood and floodway conditions, such as wave action, bridge openings, and the hydrological effect of urbanization of the watershed. 
"Highest adjacent grade" means the highest natural elevation of the ground surface, prior to construction, adjacent to the proposed foundation of a building. 
"Historic Structure" means any structure that is: 
(a)  Listed individually in the National Register of Historic Places (a listing maintained by the U.S. Department of Interior) or preliminarily determined by the Secretary of the Interior as meeting the requirements for individual listing on the National Register; 
(b)  Certified or preliminarily determined by the Secretary of the Interior as contributing to the historical significance of a registered historic district or a district preliminarily determined by the Secretary to qualify as a registered historic district; 
(c)  Individually listed on a state inventory of historic places and determined as eligible by states with historic preservation programs which have been approved by the Secretary of the Interior; or 
(d)  Individually listed on a local inventory of historic places and determined as eligible by communities with historic preservation programs that have been certified either: 
(1)  By an approved state program as determined by the Secretary of the Interior, or 
(2)  Directly by the Secretary of the Interior in states without approved programs. 
"Lowest floor" means the lowest floor of the lowest enclosed area, including basement, i.e., top of slab in concrete slab construction or top of wood flooring in wood frame construction. An unfinished or flood resistant enclosure, used solely for parking of vehicles, building access, or storage, in an area other than a basement, is not considered a building's lowest floor, provided that such enclosure is not built so as to render the structure in violation of other provisions of this Code. 
"Manufactured home" means a building, transportable in one or more sections, built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities. The term also includes park trailers, travel trailers, and similar transportable structures placed on a site for 180 consecutive days or longer and intended to be improved property. 
"Manufactured Home Park or Subdivision" means a parcel (or continuous parcels) of land divided into two (2) or more manufactured home lots for rent or sale. 
"Mean Sea Level" means the average height of the sea for all stages of the tide. It is used as a reference for establishing various elevations within the floodplain. For purposes of this chapter, the term is synonymous with National Geodetic Vertical Datum (NGVD). 
"National Geodetic Vertical Datum (NGVD)" as corrected in 1929 is a vertical control used as a reference for establishing varying elevations within the floodplain. 
"New construction" means any structure (see definition) for which the "start of construction" commenced on or after August 17, 1979 and includes any subsequent improvements to the structure. 
"New manufactured home park or subdivision" means a manufactured home park or subdivision for which the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed (including at a minimum, the installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site grading or the pouring of concrete pads) is completed on or after August 17, 1979. 
"North American Vertical Datum (NAVD)" as corrected in 1988 is a vertical control used as a reference for establishing varying elevations within the floodplain. 
"Recreational vehicle" means a vehicle, which is: 
(a)  built on a single chassis; 
(b)  four hundred (400) square feet or less when measured at the largest horizontal projection; 
(c)  designed to be self-propelled or permanently towable by a light duty truck; and 
(d)  designed primarily not for use as a permanent dwelling but as temporary living quarters for recreational, camping, travel, or seasonal use. 
"Start of construction" means the date the development permit was issued, provided the actual start of construction, repair, reconstruction, or improvement was within 180 days of the permit date. The actual start means the first placement of permanent construction of the structure such as the pouring of slabs or footings, installation of piles, construction of columns, or any work beyond the stage of excavation, and includes the placement of a manufactured home on a foundation. Permanent construction does not include initial land preparation, such as clearing, grading and filling; nor does it include the installation of streets and/or walkways; nor does it include excavation for a basement, footings, piers or foundations or the erection of temporary forms; nor does it include the installation on the property of buildings appurtenant to the permitted structure, such as garages or sheds not occupied as dwelling units or part of the main structure. (NOTE: accessory structures are NOT exempt from any ordinance requirements) For a substantial improvement, the actual start of construction means the first alteration of any wall, ceiling, floor, or other structural part of a building, whether or not that alteration affects the external dimensions of the building. 
"Structure" means a walled and roofed building that is principally above ground, a manufactured home, a gas or liquid storage tank or other man-made facilities or infrastructures. 
"Substantial damage" means damage of any origin sustained by a structure whereby the cost of restoring the structure to its before damaged condition would equal or exceed fifty (50) percent of the market value of the structure before the damage occurred. 
"Substantial improvement" means any reconstruction, rehabilitation, addition, or other improvement of a structure, the cost of which equals or exceeds fifty percent (50%) of the market value of the structure before the "start of construction" of the improvement. This term includes structures which have incurred "substantial damage," regardless of the actual repair work performed. The term does not, however, include either: 
1.  Any project for improvement of a structure to correct existing violations of state or local health, sanitary, or safety code specifications which have been identified by the local code enforcement official and which are the minimum necessary to assure safe living conditions or 
2.  Any alterations of a "historic structure," provided that the alteration will not preclude the structure's continued designation as a "historic structure." 
Floodplain management requirements for new construction apply to substantial improvements. Increased Cost of Compliance (ICC) coverage does not apply to substantial improvements unless a structure is substantially damaged due to flooding. 
"Substantially improved existing manufactured home parks or subdivisions" is where the repair, reconstruction, rehabilitation or improvement of the streets, utilities and pads equals or exceeds 50 percent of the value of the streets, utilities and pads before the repair, reconstruction or improvement commenced. 
"Variance" is a grant of relief from the requirements of this chapter, which permits construction in a manner otherwise prohibited by this chapter. 
"Violation" means the failure of a structure or other development to be fully compliant with the community's floodplain management regulations. A structure or other development without the elevation certificate, or other certifications, or other evidence of compliance required by this chapter is presumed to be in violation until such time as that documentation is provided. 
( Ord. No. O-16-0048, § 2, 6-21-2016 ; Ord. of 6-6-2017(2), § 2 ) 
Sec. 11-31. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SEVERABILITY 

Sec. 11-32. - Severability. 
If any section, clause, sentence, or phrase of this chapter is held to be invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, then said holding shall in no way effect the validity of the remaining portions of this ordinance. 
Chapter 12 - HEALTH AND SANITATION 
ARTICLE I. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 12-1. - Title of resolution. 
This Chapter shall be known as the Macon-Bibb County Sanitary Code (hereinafter "Chapter"). 
Sec. 12-2. - Construction of chapter. 
This Chapter shall be liberally construed so as to protect the health of citizens of the Macon-Bibb County. Terms that are not defined in this Chapter shall be given their ordinary signification unless a special meaning is attached to them in the trade or business to which the chapter section applies. Headings are provided throughout this Chapter for the purposes of convenience and assistance with regard to use of this Chapter. Headings do not necessarily reference all items addressed in the particular section which follows that heading. 
Sec. 12-3. - Gender and number. 
The masculine includes the feminine and neuter. The singular number includes the plural, and the plural the singular. 
Sec. 12-4. - Definitions. 
The following definitions shall apply in this Chapter, unless the context clearly requires a different meaning: 
Board means the Macon-Bibb County Board of Health (or any successor to that board). 
Health department means the Macon-Bibb County Health Department (or any successor to that department) or any employee or representative thereof acting within the scope of his authority. 
Person includes any individual, firm, partnership, business, trust, corporation, municipal corporation, company, estate, or unincorporated association. 
State department means the Georgia Department of Public Health (or any successor to that department) or any employee or representative thereof acting within the scope of his authority. 
Sec. 12-5. - Permits not transferable. 
Permits issued by the health department shall not be transferable with respect to persons or locations. 
Sec. 12-6. - Transfer of premises violating health standards. 
No person who has been ordered by the health department to correct an unsatisfactory health condition which exists in violation of this Chapter on premises he owns or controls shall sell, lease or in any way transfer his interest in the premises or in a business conducted on the premises unless he first corrects the unsatisfactory condition in accordance with the requirements of this Chapter. 
Sec. 12-7. - Effect of partial invalidity. 
If any provision of this Chapter, or the application thereof to any person or circumstances, is held invalid, the remainder of this Chapter, or the application of such provision to other persons or circumstances, shall not be affected thereby. 
Secs. 12-8—12-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SEWAGE AND SEWERAGE SYSTEMS 

Sec. 12-21. - Adoption of state-wide laws. 
(a)  Pursuant to 1997 Georgia Law page 708, 710, as amended, and O.C.G.A. § 31-3-5(b), the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 31-2A-11 are adopted and made a part of this Chapter. Further, the applicable rules and regulations (including the rules and regulations for On-Site Sewage Management Systems, Chapter 290-5-26, and the manual for On-Site Sewage Management), as amended, promulgated by the state department pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 31-2A-11 are hereby adopted for enforcement in this Chapter. 
(b)  The following sections of this article are in addition to the statute and rules and regulations referenced above. The rules and regulations of the state department contain minimum requirements which will be enforced in Macon-Bibb County; however, this article may contain provisions which are more stringent than the requirements of the state department, and these more stringent standards will be enforced by the health department and the City of Macon and Bibb County. To the extent any sections of this article are less restrictive or would authorize violations of the statute or rules and regulations, the statute and rules and regulations shall govern. 
Sec. 12-22. - Condemned on-site sewerage system. 
The health department may condemn any on-site sewerage system which it finds so constructed, operated or maintained as to menace health, and may post on or near the system signs stating that the system has been condemned and is unsafe for use. No person shall operate or use for sewage disposal purposes an on-site sewerage system which has been so condemned. 
Sec. 12-23. - Connecting sewerage system to storm sewer prohibited. 
No person shall connect a sewerage system so that sewage flows into a storm water sewer or into a drain intended exclusively for storm water. No person shall operate or use for sewage disposal purposes a sewerage system which has been so connected in violation of this section. 
Sec. 12-24. - Maintenance of on-site sewerage system. 
The owner and occupant of a house or building shall be responsible for regular maintenance and servicing of an on-site sewerage system servicing the house or building so that the system is maintained in proper working order. 
Sec. 12-25. - Prohibition of discharge of sewage onto ground or into water. 
No person shall discharge sewage onto the surface of the ground or discharge it in a way that permits it to come to the surface of the ground. No person shall discharge sewage into a stream or a body of water. 
Sec. 12-26. - Sanitary sewage disposal system required. 
The owner of every building designed or regularly used for human habitation or congregation shall provide on the premises a sanitary method of sewage disposal for the exclusive use of the persons who regularly use the building and/or of transient members of the public. For such buildings constructed after the adoption of this Chapter and for buildings serviced by on-site systems which fail after the adoption of this Chapter, the owner shall satisfy this requirement by providing connections to a public sewerage system if a public sewerage system is within 200 feet of the property upon which the building is located, or, if a public sewerage system is not so available, by providing an on-site sewerage system. 
Sec. 12-27. - Individual connections to on-site sewerage system. 
No person shall connect the plumbing system of a house or building to an on-site sewerage system except by a direct and individual connection. 
Sec. 12-28. - Responsibility of owner for maintenance of laterals. 
The owner of a house or building from which sewage is carried by a house connection to a public or to an on-site sewerage system shall maintain the house connection in good repair and operating condition. Whenever two or more houses or buildings use the same house connection, each owner shall be individually responsible for the repair of the lateral but may exact contributions from the other owners. 
Sec. 12-29. - General prohibition on use of pit privy. 
No person shall own, operate or construct a pit privy on property where water under pressure exists or is available. 
Sec. 12-30. - Sewage removal permit. 
No person shall remove, transport or dispose of any sewage sludge by portable or mobile container unless he has an unrevoked permit from the health department authorizing him to do so. A permit shall be issued only to a person who is to use equipment that will not permit spillage or exposure of sewage to the outside air and whose equipment also conforms to the following specifications: 
(a)  The container or tank shall hold a volume of at least 1,000 gallons. 
(b)  The pump shall be capable of handling all particles of sewage and sewage sludge, including grease and caked sludge, and shall be capable of lifting such materials to a height of 15 feet. 
(c)  The tank discharge valve shall be so located and placed that it will empty the entire contents of the tank. Said value shall be equipped with a discharge hose at least 20 feet in length. 
(d)  A manhole shall be provided in the top of the container or tank. 
(e)  All equipment shall be maintained in good operating condition and the exterior of such equipment shall be kept clean at all times. 
The firm name, address and permit number of the holder of a sewage removal permit shall at all times be prominently displayed on the side of the vehicle which carries the container or tank. 
The permit may be temporarily suspended by the health department if the holder violates any of the terms of this Chapter, and it may be revoked upon serious or repeated violations after a hearing by the board. 
Sec. 12-31. - Disposal of sewage. 
A holder of a sewage removal permit shall dispose of sewage sludge at a sewage treatment plant. 
Sec. 12-32. - Construction bond. 
No person shall construct, modify or repair or enter into a contract for the construction, modification or repairing of an on-site sewage system until he furnishes to the health department a guaranty bond in the amount of $10,000.00, executed by a licensed bonding company, for the faithful observance of the applicable requirements of this Chapter and conditioned to protect the rights and property of any other person for whom such construction, modification or repairing may be done. A person who constructs, modifies or repairs an on-site sewerage system on premises which he owns and occupies or will occupy immediately upon completion of such work need not comply with this requirement. 
Secs. 12-33—12-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WATER SUPPLIES 

Sec. 12-50. - Adoption of state-wide laws. 
Pursuant to 1985 Georgia Law, the provisions of the Well Water Standards Act of 1985, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-120 et seq., are adopted and made part of this Chapter. Further, the applicable rules and regulations, as adopted by the state department pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 12-5-120 et seq., are hereby adopted for enforcement in this Chapter. 
Sec. 12-51. - Definitions. 
The following definitions shall apply in this case, unless the context clearly requires a different meaning: 
Private water supply means a non-public water well and/or an Individual water well, as those terms are defined in the Water Well Standards Act of 1985, as amended. This definition shall include springs which serve up to 15 water service connections or regularly serves an average of up to 25 people for 60 days per year. 
Safe water means water that meets the requirements of the Georgia Primary Drinking Regulations, as defined in the Georgia Safe Drinking Water Act of 1977 (O.C.G.A. § 12-5-170 et seq.) as amended. 
All words used in this Chapter which are defined in the Water Well Standards Act of 1985, as amended, and/or the Georgia Safe Drinking Water Act of 1977, as amended, shall have the same meaning in this Chapter as stated in those acts. 
Sec. 12-52. - Safe water required. 
The owner of a private water supply shall furnish only safe water for human consumption or for domestic use and shall protect same from pollution. 
Sec. 12-53. - Power to condemn. 
The health department shall have authority to condemn a private water supply if it finds the water unsafe. No person shall operate a condemned private water supply or knowingly use water from it for human consumption or domestic purposes. 
Sec. 12-54. - Location of wells. 
(a)  The location of a well cannot be within a designated flood plain area. 
(b)  No well shall be located within the foundation walls of a dwelling, barn, or any structure other than a pump house. 
(c)  All wells shall be located at a distance greater than these distances from the following objects: 
(1)  Watertight sealed sewer or drain-line—10 feet. 
(2)  Septic tank—50 feet. 
(3)  Seepage pit—100 feet. 
(4)  Septic tank absorption field—100 feet. 
(5)  Open abandoned well—100 feet. 
(6)  Surface water—100 feet. 
(7)  Buildings, homes or structures where chemical treatment to soil has been applied—100 feet. 
(8)  Animal houses and fowl enclosures—100 feet. 
(9)  Lot lines—10 feet. 
(10)  Pit privies—100 feet. 
Sec. 12-55. - Depth of wells. 
No person operating a water system shall obtain water for the system from a well supplied by a water bearing formation less than 20 feet below the natural ground surface. 
Sec. 12-56. - Construction and protection of wells. 
(a)  The construction of a well shall meet the requirements as specified in the Well Water Standards Act of 1985, as amended. 
(b)  Protection of individual and non-public wells from external surface contamination shall be effected by the following: 
(1)  Grouting of annular space at least ten feet below ground; 
(2)  A concrete slab at least four inches, thick, sloping away from the casing for a distance of at least two feet. in all directions; 
(3)  Casing pipe extending at least 12 inches, above the concrete slab; 
(4)  A water tight sanitary seal enclosing the drop pipe entrance into the casing; 
(5)  A screened or insect-proof vent pipe installed on the casing head; and 
(6)  Further sealing as necessary to prohibit insect and water entrance into the well. 
Sec. 12-57. - Springs. 
A spring used or intended for use as a source of a private water supply shall meet the following requirements. 
(a)  The spring shall be enclosed in walls made of water tight concrete or other durable water tight material. The walls shall extend sufficiently far into the earth to protect the water collecting within the enclosure from pollution. 
(b)  The bottom of the enclosure shall be covered with a layer of clean sand at least four inches thick. 
(c)  An overlapping (shoe-box top) water tight cover shall be placed over the walls or a water proof concrete slab shall be placed over and sealed to the walls. 
(d)  A water quality pipe shall be sealed in a water proof manner into one of the walls of the enclosure. This pipe shall penetrate the wall in such a manner as to allow water in the enclosure to flow to the outside. Water shall not be dipped from the enclosure by hand, cup, bucket or other receptacle. 
(e)  The overflow shall be discharged into a concrete or masonry box or splash block and shall be conducted through an impervious drain a distance of at least 30 feet from the spring. 
(f)  A diversion ditch shall be constructed so as to surround the spring on the uphill side in such a manner that all surface water shall be diverted away from the spring. 
Sec. 12-58. - New construction or repair of a water system-necessity of disinfecting system. 
No water system or part thereof shall be used after construction, installation, repair or cleaning, until it has been disinfected. 
Sec. 12-59. - Cross connections and back flow connections. 
A cross connection or back flow connection between a system supplying water for human consumption or domestic use and any drain, sewer, pipe, tank, sump, vat or other structure containing liquids, chemicals, unsafe water, sewage or any other unsafe matter, is prohibited, unless the connection is so installed and protected by an air gap as to prevent such liquids, chemicals, water, sewage or other matter from entering the safe water system. Cross connections made from nonpotable water for emergency fire protection must be eliminated after the emergency, and the water supply systems disinfected before human consumption resumes. 
Sec. 12-60. - Well drillers—License and bond. 
Anyone engaged in the business of constructing water wells shall be in compliance with license and bond provisions and all other sections of the Well Water Standards Act of 1985, as amended, and any rules and regulations adopted thereunder. 
Sec. 12-61. - Macon-Bibb County registration. 
No person shall construct or modify or enter into a contract for the construction or modification of a well, nor shall he undertake construction of a well until he has registered his name and address in a document maintained for that purpose by the health department at its office. 
Sec. 12-62. - Permits. 
No person shall begin to construct a well until he has received a written permit from the health department authorizing the drilling of that particular well. This permit will serve as intent to drill said well. 
Sec. 12-63. - Property owner well construction. 
Nothing in this Chapter shall be construed to require licensure of a person constructing a well on his own property for use in a single family residence which is his residence or for use only for farm or irrigation purposes. Said well must produce no more than 25,000 gallons per day. 
Sec. 12-64. - Property owner permit and construction requirements. 
An individual property owner desiring to construct his own well must obtain a permit prior to start of construction in accordance with Section 12-62. Construction or abandonment of the well must meet the legal requirements provided in the Well Water Standards Act of 1985, as amended, and this Chapter. 
Sec. 12-65. - Abandoned and condemned wells. 
The owner of a well no longer used as a source of water shall fill it or cause it to be filled with material suitable to protect the water-bearing formations from pollution in accordance with the applicable requirements and recommendations of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources, Environmental Protection Division. 
Secs. 12-66—12-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CARNIVALS AND ITINERANT MEETINGS 

Sec. 12-71. - Definitions. 
The following definitions apply in this Chapter unless the context clearly requires a different meaning: 
Carnival means a carnival, circus, side show, medicine show, carousel, tent show, menagerie, wild west show, street party, fair, arts and crafts festival, food festival, food cook-off event, any combination of these, or other entertainment, except those held regularly in a theater, at an athletic field, or in establishments permitted under article V of this Chapter. 
Itinerant meeting means a gathering open to the public and held in the open air or in a tent or other temporary structure. This shall not apply to such gatherings of less than six consecutive hours duration. 
Sec. 12-72. - Permit. 
(a)  No person shall locate, establish, set up or operate a carnival or an itinerant meeting unless he has an unrevoked and unexpired permit from the health department authorizing him to do so. The application for such a permit shall be submitted in writing a minimum of 30 days prior to the event and shall contain (in so far as applicable) the following information: 
(1)  Proposed site; 
(2)  Estimated area to be occupied; 
(3)  Number of persons traveling with or employed by the carnival or itinerant meeting; 
(4)  Number of animals carried; 
(5)  Number of days proposed site to be occupied; 
(6)  Number of itinerant restaurants to be established; 
(7)  Number of food handling employees; 
(8)  General layout of food vendors; 
(9)  Location of water and sewer utilities; 
(10)  Any other information the health department may require. 
(b)  This permit may be temporarily suspended by the health department if the holder violates any of the terms of this article, and it may be revoked upon serious or repeated violations after a hearing by the board, or the appropriate committee thereof. 
Sec. 12-73. - Water supply. 
No person operating a carnival or an itinerant meeting shall use, for any purpose, water, other than safe water, from a public water supply or a private water supply as provided in article III of this Chapter. 
Sec. 12-74. - Sewage disposal. 
No person shall operate a carnival or an itinerant meeting unless he conforms to the regulations governing sewage disposal as provided in article II of this Chapter. Toilet facilities on the premises shall be provided in compliance with the minimum requirements published by and on file with the health department. If portable toilets are used, the operator of the carnival or itinerant meeting shall, before abandoning the site, have the portable toilets removed. 
Sec. 12-75. - Restaurants. 
Restaurants operated in conjunction with a carnival or itinerant meeting shall be maintained as provided in article V of this Chapter. 
Sec. 12-76. - Refuse. 
Carnival and itinerant meeting operators shall store or cause to be stored all garbage, waste grease/oil and other refuse in watertight containers with tight fitting lids until disposed of as provided in accordance with the applicable provisions of this Chapter. Upon termination of their stay at each location, carnival and itinerant meeting operators shall place the premises in a neat and clean condition. 
Secs. 12-77—12-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - EATING AND DRINKING ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 12-91. - Adoption of state-wide laws. 
(a)  The provisions of Chapter 290-5-14, as amended, of the State Department's Rules and Regulations are adopted and made a part of this Chapter. 
(b)  The following sections of this article are in addition to the State Department's Rules and Regulations. The provisions of the state department's rules and regulations contain minimum requirements which will be enforced in Macon-Bibb County; however, this article may contain certain provisions which are more stringent than the requirements of the state department, and these more stringent standards will be enforced by the health department in Macon-Bibb County. To the extent any sections of this article are less restrictive or would authorize violations of these rules and regulations, the rules and regulations shall govern. 
Sec. 12-92. - Catering permit. 
Any eating or drinking establishment which engages in catering as governed by article X of this Chapter, shall obtain a catering permit under the provisions of that article. 
Sec. 12-93. - Sanitary facilities and controls—Water supply. 
(a)  If equipment to sanitize with hot water is to be utilized, the minimum sanitizing temperature of hot water to the three compartment sink and the hot water sanitizing dish machine shall be 170 degrees and 180 degrees Fahrenheit respectively at the manifold outlet of these fixtures. 
(b)  The minimum temperature of hot water for cleaning shall be 130 degrees Fahrenheit regardless of the type of sanitizing fixtures used. 
Sec. 12-94. - Sanitary facilities and controls—Toilet facilities. 
In addition to the provisions of Chapter 290-5-14.07(4)(a) of the State Department Rules and Regulations, access to toilet facilities by patrons or the public through a food preparation, utensil washing, food storage, or service area is prohibited for all establishments permitted after the effective date of this Chapter. 
Sec. 12-95. - Sanitary facilities and controls—Lavatory facilities. 
In addition to the provisions of Chapter 290-5-14.07 of the State Department Rules and Regulations, the hot water temperature at lavatories shall not exceed 110 degrees Fahrenheit. 
Sec. 12-96. - Posting of permit and inspection sheet. 
In addition to the provisions of Chapter 290-5-14.02 and .11 of the State Department Rules and Regulations, permit and inspection sheets must be posted, as near the main entrance as is practicable, in such a manner as they are readable by the general public and in such a manner as the entire document is fully displayed. 
Sec. 12-97. - Sealed concrete floors. 
In addition to the provisions of chapter 290-5-14.08(1)(a), concrete floors which are sealed in a manner intended to comply with the State Department Rules and Regulations shall be sealed with a sealant which shall be durable for a minimum of one-year and such floors shall be resealed annually. 
Sec. 12-98. - Suspension or revocation of permits. 
The health department shall have the power and authority to suspend or revoke permits for failure to comply with the provisions of this article. When an application for a permit is denied or the permit previously granted is to be suspended or revoked, the applicant or holder thereof shall be afforded notice and hearing as provided in O.C.G.A. Title 31, Chapter 5, Article 1. If an application is denied or a permit is suspended or revoked, the applicant or holder of the permit must be notified in writing, specifically stating any and all reasons why the action was taken. The purpose of these procedures is to state the minimum actions to be taken to fulfill the obligation of the health department in assuring compliance with the regulations when the continued operation of a restaurant presents a substantial and imminent health hazard to the public or when a food service establishment is in flagrant or continuing violation of this Chapter. Suspension is effective upon service of a written notice thereof, and food service must cease immediately. The notice must state the basis for the suspension and advise the permit holder of the right to a preliminary hearing on request within eight working hours. If requested, the preliminary hearing will be held by an experienced supervisory level employee of the health department not directly involved in the suspension. The rules of evidence will not apply, but both the health department and the permit holder may present witnesses, records and argument.
