The hearing official will be authorized immediately to rescind or modify the suspension or to continue the suspension with or without conditions. If the suspension is not rescinded, the permit holder will have the right, upon written request, to an evidentiary hearing. If a hearing is not requested, upon correction of all violations, owner may request an inspection to reinstate permit. The health department shall perform such a reinspection on the next health department business day following the date of its receipt of the request. 
Secs. 12-99—12-110. - Reserved 
ARTICLE VI. - RESERVED[1] 

Footnotes:

Secs. 12-111—12-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PEST CONTROL 

Sec. 12-131. - Definitions. 
The following definitions apply in this article unless the context clearly requires a different meaning: 
Occupant means a person who uses or occupies a building structure, whether as owner or tenant. A tenant who uses a part of a building structure shall be deemed the occupant of that part of which he has actual or constructive possession. The owner, agent, or other person having custody or control of a building structure shall be deemed occupant of the part that is vacant. 
Owner includes the agent operating and managing the building structure as well as the legal owner. 
Rat harborage means a place that provides shelter or protection for rats and favorable conditions for their breeding. 
Tire is defined as a hollow ring, made of rubber or other material, which is designed for placement on the wheel or rim of a motor vehicle to facilitate its operation. In this article, the word applies to used or discarded tires. 
Sec. 12-132. - Duty of occupant of a building to keep it rat-free. 
The owner and occupant of a building shall maintain it in a rat-free condition. 
Sec. 12-133. - Notice to eradicate rats. 
Whenever the health department finds that a premises is infested with rats, the health department shall notify the owner and occupant of the building in writing of that condition and state the time allowed for the eradication of the rats. The time allowed shall not be less than 15 days. 
Sec. 12-134. - Power of the health department to eradicate rats. 
If the owner or occupant fails to eradicate the rats within the time allowed, the health department may cause the rats to be eradicated and charge the cost to the owner or occupant. The cost of eradicating the rats shall constitute a lien on property. 
Sec. 12-135. - Mosquito control. 
No person owning or occupying premises shall cause or permit thereon any standing or flowing water in which mosquitoes breed or are likely to breed unless the water has been effectively treated by one or more of the following methods: 
(a)  Screening with 16 mesh wire netting or with material approved by the health department; 
(b)  Application of mosquito larvicide every 30 days; 
(c)  Keeping free of vegetative growth and stocking with mosquito larvae-destroying fish; 
(d)  Complete emptying and drying or cleaning of water containers every seven days; or 
(e)  Any other method the health department approves after taking into consideration: 
(1)  Distance from the nearest habitation; 
(2)  Direction and velocity of prevailing winds; 
(3)  Population within flight range of mosquitoes under local conditions; and 
(4)  Species of mosquitoes found to be breeding. 
Sec. 12-136. - Artificially created water detention facilities. 
Artificially created water detention facilities shall be maintained by the owner so as not to promote or facilitate the breeding and harborage of mosquitoes. 
Sec. 12-137. - Fly control. 
No person who owns or occupies premises shall permit thereon any storage, accumulation or stockpiling of manure or other organic-type fertilizer, or of any materials in which flies are breeding unless the same is treated with a residual-type fly larvicide in such a manner that the breeding of flies is effectively and in fact halted. 
Sec. 12-138. - Outside or uncovered storage of used or discarded tires prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person in charge or control of any property within the area of Macon-Bibb County, whether as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee, agent or otherwise, to store or permit the storage of used or discarded tires in the open or in an uncovered condition. 
Sec. 12-139. - Covered storage of used or discarded tires prohibited; exception. 
It shall be unlawful for any person in charge or control of any property within the area of Macon-Bibb County, whether as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee, or agent or otherwise, to store or permit the storage of used or discarded tires in a covered area unless the same is protected from the elements and prior to storage, all water has been drained therefrom. 
Sec. 12-140. - New storage. 
Any person desiring to store more than 25 used or discarded tires on property in Macon-Bibb County shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  All used or discarded tires must be stored dry to prevent mosquito breeding. 
(2)  Upon request, owner/occupant shall demonstrate to the health department how the intended storage will thereafter prevent the accumulation of water in the stored tires. 
Sec. 12-141. - Application to existing storage site of used or discarded tires. 
The owners or occupants of existing storage sites of used or discarded tires shall, immediately upon the passage of the ordinance comply with the standards therein set forth; provided, however, that the owners or occupants of existing sites shall be allowed a period of six months in which to bring existing storage into compliance with the provisions of this article. 
Sec. 12-142. - Planning and zoning regulations unaffected. 
Nothing herein contained shall be deemed to authorize any outside storage when it is prohibited by regulations of the Macon-Bibb County Planning and Zoning Commission. 
Secs. 12-143—12-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - SWIMMING POOLS 

Sec. 12-161. - Definitions. 
Public swimming pool. Any structure, chamber, or tank containing an artificial body of water used by the public for swimming, diving, wading, recreation, or therapy, together with buildings, appurtenances, and equipment used in connection with the body of water, regardless of whether a fee is charged for its use. The term includes municipal, school, hotel, or motel pools and any pool to which access is granted in exchange for payment of a daily fee. The term shall also include pools and spas operated by or serving camps, churches, day care centers, group home facilities of 12 or more clients, institutions, parks, state agencies, subdivisions, apartment complexes, country clubs, condominiums, mobile home parks, recreational vehicle parks, associations, health clubs, special purpose pools, and recreational water park attractions. 
Closed pool. A pool, including all areas within the pool enclosure, that is inaccessible to bathers by closing and securing all entry points into the pool enclosure, and is posted "Pool Closed" at each entry point, "as ordered by the health department." 
Sec. 12-162. - Adoption of state-wide laws. 
The applicable provisions of the State Department's Rules and Regulations regarding swimming pools are adopted and made a part of this Chapter, except that the definition stated in Section 12-161 shall be utilized as the definition of public swimming pool wherever it appears in the State Department's Rules and Regulations. If the State Department has issued no rules and regulations regarding swimming pools at the time of the adoption of this Chapter, then the provisions of the previous sanitation codes for the City of Macon and Bibb County shall continue in force and effect until such time as the State Department adopts rules and regulations regarding swimming pools. 
Secs. 12-163—12-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - TOURIST ACCOMMODATIONS 

Sec. 12-181. - Adoption of state law. 
The provisions of Chapter 290-5-18, as amended, of the State Department's Rules and Regulations are adopted and made a part of this Chapter. 
Secs. 12-182—12-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - CATERING ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 12-201. - Definitions. 
The following definitions apply in this Chapter unless the context clearly requires a different meaning: 
Caterer means any person who prepares and/or serves food at any remote location, including, but not limited to, wedding receptions, graduations, anniversaries or other functions by whatever name called. 
Full caterer means a person or establishment permitted under article V of this Chapter but who is also a caterer. 
Limited caterer means a person or establishment that is not permitted under article V of this Chapter but who performs as a caterer. 
Employee means any person who handles food or drink during preparation or serving, or who comes in contact with eating or drinking utensils, or who assists in a room where food or drink is prepared or served. 
Utensils means kitchenware, tableware, glassware, cutlery, containers, serviceware, or other equipment with which food or drink have contact during storage, preparation or serving. 
Sec. 12-202. - Permits. 
No person shall prepare or serve food as a caterer at any location, unless he has a valid catering permit issued by the health department under the terms of this Chapter which authorizes him to do so in the manner which he intends. This permit shall be posted where it is readily visible to all patrons. 
Sec. 12-203. - Approval of proposed catering operations. 
No person shall construct or modify or enter into a contract to construct or modify a kitchen for use in catering until plans and specifications, including a description of the location and a generalized menu of types of foods to be offered, have been submitted to the health department and approved by it as complying with the requirements of this Chapter. 
Sec. 12-204. - Sanitation requirements for full caterers. 
(a)  Every full caterer must meet the requirements set forth in article V of this Chapter and the State of Georgia Food Service Rules and Regulations set forth in Chapter 290-5-14, as amended. 
(b)  In addition to those requirements the following shall also apply to full caterers: 
(1)  Transport vehicle(s). The transport vehicle(s) must be constructed so as to be easily cleanable. Any vehicles used to transport food or food service equipment must be kept clean and in good repair to eliminate any possible contamination of the food or equipment being transported. 
(2)  Temperature maintenance equipment. Adequate portable equipment must be available to maintain proper, accepted temperatures of all potentially hazardous foods during transport and service. 
(3)  Hand washing at point of service. Acceptable hand wash facilities must be available at the site of service. If a typical hand sink supplied with hot and cold water through a mixing faucet and proper supplies, soap and sanitary towels are not available, the caterer must provide a temporary hand wash setup approved by the Health Department. Such a temporary setup will consist of: 
a.  A closed container of warm water equipped with a spigot; 
b.  A container to capture the wastewater; and 
c.  Sanitary towels and hand soap. 
Sec. 12-205. - Limitations upon limited caterers. 
(a)  The following limitations are imposed upon operations by limited caterers. Limited caterers must: 
(1)  Purchase food from an approved source. 
(2)  Have food delivered directly to the point of service. 
(3)  Use disposable tableware and serviceware, or use tableware and serviceware provided by the client. 
(4)  Keep invoices documenting the sources of food served at catered events. 
(5)  Keep a listing of all events catered which shall reflect the client name, menu, and phone number of the client. 
(6)  Provide a signed statement of the owner or manager of the caterer acknowledging the limitations contained in this Chapter upon limited caterers and further acknowledging that any catering activity beyond these limitations shall first require that the caterer obtain a permit to act as a full caterer. 
(b)  Limited caterers shall be subject to quarterly verification with regard to the type of services which they are performing and the sources of food which they are serving. 
Sec. 12-206. - Suspension or revocation of permits. 
The health department shall have the power and authority to suspend or revoke permits for failure to comply with the provisions of this article. When an application for a permit is denied or the permit previously granted is to be suspended or revoked, the applicant or holder thereof shall be afforded notice and hearing as provided in O.C.G.A. Title 31, Chapter 5, Article 1. If an application is denied or a permit is suspended or revoked, the applicant or holder of the permit must be notified in writing, specifically stating any and all reasons why the action was taken. The purpose of these procedures is to state the minimum actions to be taken to fulfill the obligation of the health department in assuring compliance with the regulations when the continued operation of a caterer presents a substantial and imminent health hazard to the public or when a caterer is in flagrant or continuing violation of this Chapter. Suspension is effective upon service of a written notice thereof, and catering must cease immediately. The notice must state the basis for the suspension and advise the permit holder of the right to a preliminary hearing on request within eight working hours. If requested, the preliminary hearing will be held by an experienced supervisory level employee of the health department not directly involved in the suspension. The rules of evidence will not apply, but both the health department and the permit holder may present witnesses, records and argument. The hearing official will be authorized immediately to rescind or modify the suspension or to continue the suspension with or without conditions. If the suspension is not rescinded, the permit holder will have the right on request to an evidentiary hearing. If a hearing is not requested, upon correction of all violations, owner may request an inspection to reinstate permit. The health department shall perform such a reinspection on the next health department business day following the date of its receipt of the request. 
Secs. 12-207—12-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - KEEPING OF ANIMALS 

Sec. 12-221. - Definitions. 
The following definitions apply in this chapter unless the context clearly requires a different meaning: 
Farm animal includes, but is not limited to, cattle, horses, ponies, donkeys, mules, goats, sheep, swine, rabbits, and pet Vietnamese pot-bellied pigs. 
Domestic animals shall include, but is not limited to, dogs and cats. 
Fowl shall include birds of any kind, excluding birds of the psittacine family. 
Swine means any of the various animals that constitute the family of Suidae; however, for the purposes of this Chapter, "swine" shall not include pet Vietnamese pot-bellied pigs. 
Sec. 12-222. - Distance of animals from dwelling house or business establishment of another. 
(a)  No person shall raise, keep or permit to be raised or kept on the premises that he owns or controls any farm animal or fowl unless each part of the premises to which such an animal or fowl has access is at least 100 feet from the nearest property line; however, this minimum distance from the property line can be reduced for so long as no part of the premises to which such an animal or fowl has access is less than 100 feet from the nearest occupied dwelling house or business establishment of another person. 
(b)  No person shall raise, keep or permit to raise or be kept on the premises that he owns or controls any swine, unless each part of the premises to which such swine has access is at least 300 feet from the nearest property line; however, this minimum distance from the property line can be reduced for so long as no part of the premises to which such swine has access is less than 300 feet from the nearest occupied dwelling house or business establishment of another person. 
Sec. 12-223. - Condition of stables, coops, cages, pens or other shelters. 
The condition of stables, coups, cages, pens or other shelters for farm animals, domestic animals, and fowl must be maintained as follows: 
(a)  Stables, coops, cages, pens or other shelters must be: 
(1)  Cleaned at least once each day; 
(2)  Sprayed on the walls and ceilings every month with residual insecticide approved by the health department; and 
(3)  Well drained. 
(b)  Droppings must be disposed of at least once every four days by: 
a.  Scattering on a field or lawn in a manner approved by the health department for animals other than domestic animals; 
b.  Sealing in a container or plastic bag and placing for collection by Macon-Bibb County; 
c.  Sealing in a container or plastic bag and placing for collection by a collection agency authorized by the health department; or 
d.  Disposal at a Macon-Bibb County sanitary landfill or at a sanitary landfill permitted by the State of Georgia. 
Sec. 12-224. - Number of farm animals. 
No person shall raise, keep or permit to be raised or kept on premises which he owns or controls more than one farm animal without written authorization from the board, unless the premises is part of a bona fide farm. If authorization is granted, such individual shall continue to be obligated to comply with all provisions contained the above sections. 
Sec. 12-225. - Exception. 
The limitations contained in this article with regard to minimum distance requirements and number of animals to be kept shall not apply to the keeping of animals for a period not to exceed ten days at stock yards, fairs, or other temporary animal displays. 
Secs. 12-226—12-240. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - GENERAL ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES 

Sec. 12-241. - Acts or conditions endangering health prohibited. 
No person shall commit any act that creates a substantial or unreasonable risk of injury to the health of any person. No person shall maintain or permit to be maintained on premises he owns or controls any condition that injures the health of any person or creates a substantial or unreasonable risk of injury to the health of any person. 
Sec. 12-242. - Annoyances that are not threats to health. 
The health department shall not attempt to correct conditions which, because of their odor, sound or appearance, may annoy persons on nearby premises or members of the public, if in the judgment of the health department the conditions have no substantial relation to health or the spread of disease. 
Sec. 12-243. - Health department's authority to post signs on rental housing. 
Upon violation of any provision of this Chapter relating to sanitation of rented housing, the health department shall have authority to post a conspicuous sign on the premises advising that the premises must not be occupied for dwelling purposes. No person other than the health department shall remove or deface a sign posted under the authority of this section. 
Sec. 12-244. - Authority to enter, inspect, condemn, confiscate, quarantine, take samples and collect specimens. 
The authority of the health department shall include authority to: 
(1)  Enter properties, establishments, carnivals and other operations subject to this Chapter; 
(2)  Inspect properties establishments, carnivals and other operations subject to this Chapter; 
(3)  Condemn and confiscate food, milk, water and other substances the condition of which may endanger health or which violates the requirements for labeling as established by this Chapter; 
(4)  Quarantine persons or premises to prevent the spread of infectious disease; 
(5)  Take samples of food, milk, water or other substances the condition of which may affect health or sanitation and require any person who has such substance in his possession or under his control to furnish samples; and 
(6)  Go on the premises of any person to inspect and/or secure such samples and to capture specimen insects, rodents or other pests, or to determine whether health, sanitation, garbage or plumbing regulations are being observed. 
Sec. 12-245. - Lien—Correction of menace to public health. 
Whenever the health department has determined that a private sewerage system is constructed, operated or maintained so as to constitute a menace to public health or that a violation of this Chapter is occurring so as to constitute a menace to public health, and after the health department has notified the owner of the premises of the existence of this condition and the steps necessary to correct it, the health department is authorized, if the condition has not been remedied within 15 days after notice mailed to the owner of the premises or to his resident agent, to have the necessary installation, repair or modification made. The cost of the work shall be borne by the owner and shall be a lien upon the property involved. This remedy is intended to be cumulative and not to relieve the owner of such penalties as may be applicable under the provisions of this Chapter. 
Sec. 12-246. - Authority to institute legal proceedings. 
The health department shall have power to institute and maintain whatever legal proceedings are necessary or appropriate to enforce compliance with the provisions of this Chapter, including the power to seek injunctive relief. 
Sec. 12-247. - Suspension or revocation of permits; hearings. 
(a)  The health department shall have the power and authority to suspend or revoke permits for failure to comply with the provisions of this article. When an application for a permit is denied or the permit previously granted is to be suspended or revoked, the applicant or holder thereof shall be afforded notice and hearing as provided in O.C.G.A. Title 31, Chapter 5, Article 1. If an application is denied or a permit is suspended or revoked, the applicant or holder of the permit must be notified in writing, specifically stating any and all reasons why the action was taken. The purpose of these procedures is to state the minimum actions to be taken to fulfill the obligation of the health department in assuring compliance with the regulations when the continued operation of an entity permitted under this Chapter presents a substantial and imminent health hazard to the public or when the entity is in flagrant or continuing violation of this Chapter. Suspension is effective upon service of a written notice thereof, and the entity's violative activity must cease immediately. The notice must state the basis for the suspension and advise the permit holder of the right to a preliminary hearing on request within eight (8) working hours. If requested, the preliminary hearing will be held by an experienced supervisory level employee of the health department not directly involved in the suspension. The rules of evidence will not apply, but both the health department and the permit holder may present witnesses, records and argument. The hearing official will be authorized immediately to rescind or modify the suspension or to continue the suspension with or without conditions. If the suspension is not rescinded, the permit holder will have the right on request to an evidentiary hearing. If a hearing is not requested, upon correction of all violations, owner may request an inspection to reinstate permit. The health department shall perform such a reinspection on the next health department business day following the date of its receipt of the request. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in this Chapter, hearings by the board shall be held upon the written request of any person who may be aggrieved by any action or order of the health department issued to or against him in connection with the enforcement of this Chapter. Hearings shall be held as promptly as possible and in no event more than thirty (30) days following receipt of the request by the health department. The board of health, upon completion of the hearing, shall within three days issue a final order in the matter. A person aggrieved by any such final order may secure review thereof by appeal to the Superior Court of Bibb County as provided by Georgia law. 
Sec. 12-248. - Powers of health director. 
The director of the health department shall have the power, whenever in his judgment Macon-Bibb County is threatened by an epidemic of communicable disease, to issue or cause to be issued such orders or regulations as he may deem effective and necessary to prevent and halt the spread of such disease. Said orders or regulations shall remain in full force and effect until revoked or modified by the said health director and no person shall fail or refuse to obey such orders or regulations. 
Sec. 12-249. - Penalties. 
Any person who violates, disobeys or disregards a provision of this Chapter or a lawful order of the health department or board shall, upon conviction in the municipal court or state court of Macon-Bibb County, be liable for a penalty not to exceed $300.00, 60 days in jail, or both, for each separate offense. Each day a provision of this Chapter or a lawful order of the health department is violated, disobeyed or disregarded shall constitute a separate offense. 
Sec. 12-250. - Failure to pay fines or fees. 
For the purpose of defraying all or part of the costs of administration of this Chapter and applicable federal and state laws and regulations, the health department may establish a schedule of fees payable upon submission of the application for a permit and for the annual, semi-annual, or other inspections associated with any permit granted by the health department. Failure to pay by the established deadline any fines imposed for violations of this Chapter or fees imposed by this Chapter or fees otherwise set for the issuance or continuance of a permit issued by the health department shall be cause for denial, suspension or revocation of any permit or application for a permit. 
Chapter 13 - MOBILE HOMES AND MOBILE HOME PARKS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - Penalty. 
Any person who shall do any act prohibited hereby or shall fail to do any act required hereby shall be deemed to be guilty of a violation hereof and, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided by Section 1-6. Each separate day's violation shall be deemed to be a separate offense. 
Secs. 13-2—13-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MOBILE HOMES 

Sec. 13-21. - Findings, purpose and intent. 
Macon-Bibb County finds that promotion and maintenance of property values within the area that formerly comprised unincorporated Bibb County and the health and general welfare of the citizens of Macon-Bibb County are furthered when standards for the condition of structures, including manufactured homes, mobile homes and pre-owned manufactured homes, are established and enforced. 
The purposes and intent of the commission in enacting Sections 13-21 through 13-35 are as follows, and to these ends the said regulations are hereby adopted: 
(1)  To advance the fundamental goal of protecting the health, safety, welfare and morals of the citizens of Macon-Bibb County. 
(2)  To provide for standards, conditions, and an inspection program for manufactured homes, mobile homes or pre-owned manufactured homes which are initially located or relocated within the area that formerly comprised unincorporated Bibb County pursuant to the authority of the Constitution of the state and O.C.G.A. § 8-12-70 et seq.; and 
(3)  To comply with the General Assembly of the State of Georgia in its declaration that no county shall impose any health or safety standards or conditions based upon the age or date of manufacture of a manufactured home. 
Sec. 13-22. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of sections 13-21 through 13-35, the following words, terms and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them: 
Applicant means any person seeking to initially locate or relocate any manufactured home, mobile home, or pre-owned manufactured home in that area of Macon-Bibb County that formerly comprised unincorporated Bibb County. 
Board of tax assessors means the board of tax assessors heretofore established by joint ordinance and resolution of the City of Macon and Bibb County on May 6, 1969. 
Building inspector means the director of the Macon-Bibb County Business Development Services Department. 
Certificate of occupancy means a document issued by the department of business development services for Macon-Bibb County certifying that a pre-owned manufactured home is in compliance with applicable requirements set forth by this article, and indicating it to be in a condition suitable for residential occupancy. 
Guarantee of condition bond means a surety bond to guarantee that the affidavit and photographs required by this article reasonably portray or represent the existing condition of the pre-owned manufactured home proposed for relocation. In lieu of the bond, a cash deposit may be deposited with the county. 
Install means to construct a foundation system and to place or erect a manufactured home on such foundation system. Such term includes, without limitation, supporting, blocking, leveling, securing, or anchoring such manufactured home and connecting multiple or expandable sections of such manufactured home. 
Jurisdiction means that area of Macon-Bibb County that formerly comprised unincorporated Bibb County. 
Manufactured home means a structure, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length or, when erected on site, is 320 or more square feet and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities and includes the plumbing, heating, air-conditioning, and electrical systems contained therein; except that such term shall include any structure which meets all the requirements of this chapter except the size requirements and with respect to which the manufacturer voluntarily files a certification required by the secretary of housing and urban development and complies with the standards established under the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974, 42 U.S.C. § 5401 et seq. 
Mobile home means a structure, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length or, when erected on site, is 320 or more square feet and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities and includes the plumbing, heating, air-conditioning, and electrical systems contained therein. 
Mobile or manufactured home park means a subdivision of plots designed for siting of mobile homes wherein plots are generally leased to owners of manufactured and mobile homes and may include utilities, parking space, access to utility roads and other amenities. 
Pre-owned manufactured home means any manufactured home that has been previously used as a residential dwelling and has been titled. 
Sec. 13-22.1. - Conditions. 
All pre-owned manufactured homes located within the jurisdiction shall bear a label certifying that it was constructed in compliance with the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974, 42 U.S.C. § 5401 et seq. (the HUD Code) and shall be installed in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 8-2-160 et seq. 
Sec. 13-23. - Permitting, inspection, certificate of occupancy and fees. 
(a)  Permit required. A permit shall be required to initially locate or relocate a manufactured home, mobile home, or pre-owned manufactured home within the jurisdiction, if such mobile home is to be used as a residence by the owner thereof, as a residence for other persons, or for any other purpose. 
(b)  A manufactured home, mobile home, or pre-owned manufactured home which is located within the jurisdiction may not be relocated within the territorial boundaries of Macon-Bibb County without first obtaining a permit from the Board of Tax Assessors authorizing such relocation. 
(c)  No person shall hereafter initially locate any manufactured home, mobile home, or pre-owned manufactured home within the jurisdiction without having made application for and obtained a permit as provided by this Chapter. 
(d)  No person shall occupy any manufactured home, mobile home, or pre-owned manufactured home as a residence, nor permit any other person to occupy the same as a residence unless a permit has first been obtained as provided by this Chapter. 
(e)  Application for the required permit shall be made to the Board of Tax Assessors. All permits shall be issued within ten days of receipt of the items listed in subsections (f)(1)—(5). 
(f)  To obtain a permit, applicants shall provide the following items to the Board of Tax Assessors: 
(1)  Proof that all state and county taxes theretofore accruing and payable with respect to such manufactured home, mobile home or pre-owned manufactured home have in fact been paid; and if the home which is to be located or relocated within any portion of Macon-Bibb County that lies within the limits of any municipality therein, then proof that all applicable municipal taxes have been paid; 
(2)  An affidavit signed by the applicant that the manufactured home, mobile home, or pre-owned manufactured home meets the health and safety standards required by this article; 
(3)  Photographs of the interior and exterior of any pre-owned manufactured home providing evidence that said home meets the minimum health and safety standards of Section 13-24. 
(4)  A $200.00 refundable cash deposit; and 
(5)  The permit and inspection fee required by subsection (i) of this section. 
(g)  Inspection. Upon receipt of a permit, applicants may initially locate or relocate the manufactured home, mobile home, or pre-owned manufactured home on a residential site for the purposes of inspection. Applicant shall arrange for an inspection to be held once the installation of the manufactured home, mobile home, or pre-owned manufactured home is complete. 
(h)  Certificate of occupancy. A certificate of occupancy shall be issued to the applicant at such time that the Board of Tax Assessors certifies that the requirements of this chapter have been met and the Department of Business Development services for Macon-Bibb County certifies that all requirements for issuance of a certificate of occupancy have been met. 
(i)  Fees for permit and/or inspection. Each application for a permit required by this chapter shall be accompanied by a permit fee of $5.00, which shall be paid to the Board of Tax Assessors before such permit shall be issued. For applications for location or relocation of any pre-owned manufactured home, an additional inspection fee of $30.00 shall also accompany the permit application. These fees will cover the cost to Macon-Bibb County to process the permit application and to inspect any pre-owned manufactured home. The inspection fee shall cover an initial inspection and one follow-up inspection. The applicant shall be charged $15.00 for each additional follow-up inspection that may be necessary. All sums collected by the Board of Tax Assessors pursuant to this Chapter shall be covered into the Macon-Bibb County treasury. 
(j)  Alternative inspection. At the request of the applicant, the Board of Tax Assessors may, at their discretion, inspect a pre-owned manufactured home prior to its being relocated if the home is then located at another site within the jurisdiction. 
Sec. 13-24. - Minimum health and safety standards. 
All manufactured homes, mobile homes, and pre-owned manufactured homes shall comply with the following before being issued a certificate of occupancy by the department of business development services for Macon-Bibb County: 
(1)  HUD Code. Every manufactured home, mobile home, and pre-owned manufactured home located within the jurisdiction shall be in compliance with the Federal Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act, 42 U.S.C. § 5401-5445 (the HUD Code) and shall not have been altered in such a way that the home no longer meets the HUD Code. 
(2)  Interior condition. Every floor, interior wall, and ceiling of any manufactured home, mobile home, or pre-owned manufactured home shall be in sound condition. Doors and windows shall be operable, watertight and in good working condition. The floor system shall be in sound condition and free of warping, holes, water damage, or deterioration. 
(3)  Exterior condition. The exterior of all manufactured homes, mobile homes, or pre-owned manufactured homes shall be free of loose or rotting boards or timbers and any other conditions that might admit rain or moisture to the interior portions of the walls or to occupied spaces. The exterior siding shall be free of rot and rust. Roofs shall be structurally sound and have no obvious defects that might admit rain or cause moisture to collect on the interior portion of the home. 
(4)  Sanitary facilities. Every plumbing fixture, water, and waste pipe of any manufactured home, mobile home, or pre-owned manufactured home shall be in a sanitary working condition when properly connected, and shall be free from leaks and obstructions. Each home shall contain a kitchen sink. Each bathroom shall contain a lavatory and water closet. At least one bathroom shall contain a tub and/or shower facilities. Each of these fixtures shall be checked upon being connected to ensure that they are in good working condition. 
(5)  Heating systems. Heating shall be safe and in working condition. Un-vented heaters shall be prohibited. 
(6)  Electrical systems. Electrical systems (switches, receptacles, fixtures, etc.) shall be properly installed in working condition. Distribution panels shall be in compliance with the approved listing, complete with required breakers, with all unused openings covered with solid covers approved and listed for that purpose. The home shall be subject to an electrical continuity test to assure that all metallic parts are properly bonded. 
(7)  Hot water supply. Each home shall contain a water heater in safe and working condition. 
(8)  Egress windows. Each bedroom of any manufactured home, mobile home, or pre-owned manufactured home shall have at least one operable window of sufficient size to allow egress if necessary. 
(9)  Ventilation. The kitchen in the home shall have at least one operating window or other ventilation device. 
(10)  Smoke detectors. Each manufactured home, mobile home, or pre-owned manufactured home shall contain one operable battery-powered smoke detector in each bedroom and in the kitchen, which must be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations. 
Sec. 13-25. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Permanent connection to utilities shall not be approved until the Department of Business Development Services has issued a certificate of occupancy. 
(b)  The owner of any manufactured home, mobile home, or pre-owned manufactured home not in compliance upon a third inspection shall have his or her permit revoked and shall be required to remove the home from the jurisdiction at his or her own expense. 
(c)  The cash deposit will be forfeited after 90 days from the date of inspection, unless all conditions and standards are met prior to the end of the 90 days or an extension of time has been issued in writing by the building inspector. 
Sec. 13-26. - Reports by dealers. 
All dealers in mobile homes shall furnish to the joint board of tax assessors a list of all mobile homes in their possession, whether owned by them or not, on January 1 of each calendar year. 
Sec. 13-27. - Decal. 
Any owner of a manufactured home, mobile home or pre-owned manufactured home who has made application for the initial location or relocation of such home and whose application meets the qualifications of this chapter shall be issued a permit and shall likewise be issued a decal. The decal to be issued with a permit authorizing initial location of a manufactured home, mobile home or pre-owned manufactured home within the jurisdiction shall be green in color and shall be affixed to the home at all times it is being used as a residence within the confines of Macon-Bibb County. The decal issued with the permit authorizing relocation of a manufactured home, mobile home, or pre-owned manufactured home shall be red in color and shall be affixed to the home at all times such home is being transported within the confines of the state. Such decals shall be designed in such manner and affixed to mobile homes in such manner as to cause them to be easily visible for inspection. 
Sec. 13-28. - Forms. 
The Board of Tax Assessors is hereby authorized and empowered, subject to the specific provisions of this chapter, to prescribe application, permit and decal forms and thereafter to alter and change the same. 
Sec. 13-29. - Planning and zoning commission. 
(a)  The Board of Tax Assessors shall periodically, but at least monthly, furnish to the Macon-Bibb County Planning and Zoning Commission a list of all permits issued by the board for the location or relocation of any manufactured home, mobile home or pre-owned manufactured home. 
(b)  The issuance of any permit under the provisions of this article shall in no wise be construed as superseding the requirement for the location of manufactured homes, mobile homes, or pre-owned manufactured homes as the same may be contained within appropriate resolutions or other actions of the Macon-Bibb County Planning and Zoning Commission, and the issuance of a permit under the provisions of this article shall not prohibit the planning and zoning commission from requiring a relocation of the manufactured home, mobile home, or pre-owned manufactured home to a place where such home is permitted by the regulations of the Macon-Bibb County Planning and Zoning Commission. In such case, the owner of such home shall apply for and obtain a permit for such relocation as if such relocation were the result of his own initiative. 
(c)  Nothing contained in this chapter shall be deemed to amend or supersede any regulation of the Macon-Bibb County Planning and Zoning Commission with respect to manufactured homes, mobile homes, pre-owned manufactured homes, or any relocatable homes. 
Sec. 13-30. - Notification of tax assessors. 
Whenever a permit authorizing the relocation of a manufactured home, mobile home, or pre-owned manufactured home is issued and such home is to be relocated within the confines of another county in the state, the board of tax assessors shall notify the tax assessors of such other county of the date of the issuance of such permit. 
ARTICLE III. - MOBILE HOME PARKS 

Sec. 13-31. - Location in mobile home park. 
No owner or operator of a mobile or manufactured home park shall permit any manufactured home, mobile home or pre-owned manufactured home to be located or relocated within the confines of such park for residential use unless the permit required by Article II shall have been obtained. No owner or operator of any mobile or manufactured home park shall permit any manufactured home, mobile home, or pre-owned manufactured home presently located within the limits of such park owned or operated by him to remain in such park after the date of this article unless a permit authorizing such continued location as required by Article II shall have been obtained. 
Sec. 13-32. - Records—Operator to maintain. 
Every operator of a mobile or manufactured home park within the limits of the jurisdiction shall maintain records showing the given name and last name of each adult occupant of any manufactured home or mobile home located within the mobile or manufactured home park so operated, and such operator shall maintain such records in a current manner so that at all times such records shall accurately reflect the name of each such actual adult occupant. 
Sec. 13-33. - Same—Description. 
The records required by Section 13-32 may be maintained in one or more alternative fashions, as follows: 
(1)  If the mobile or manufactured home park has an office located at the site of the park, the records prescribed may be maintained in such office, provided that the records shall be available for reference by any person legitimately entitled thereto including, but not limited to, law enforcement officers, 24 hours a day. 
(2)  If the mobile or manufactured home park does not have an office open 24 hours a day, then and in such event, the records required hereby shall be maintained in the office of the sheriff of the county. 
(3)  The records need not be maintained in any particular form so long as they disclose the information required hereby. The records may consist of a plat of the mobile or manufactured home park showing the lots by number upon which are listed the names of the adults occupying such lot, or the records may consist of a list of the names of the occupants of the mobile or manufactured home park alphabetically with an indication of the lot number upon which the manufactured home or mobile home occupied by them may be found or it may be a listing of lots by number showing the names of the adult occupants thereof. At a minimum, however, the records shall be such as will enable one inspecting them to determine the given and last names of every adult occupant of every mobile or manufactured home in the park with a reference to the number of the lot upon which the manufactured home or mobile home occupied by them is located. 
Sec. 13-34. - Lot numbers. 
To make the provisions of this article effective, every operator of every mobile or manufactured home park within the limits of Macon-Bibb County shall devise a system of numbering the lots in the mobile or manufactured home park operated by him in such manner that the lots are consecutively numbered in such fashion as will permit one seeking the location of a lot to find it with relative ease, and through means of a sign on each lot or other similar device, each lot shall be identified by number so that a person traversing the thoroughfares of the mobile or manufactured home park by automobile will be able to identify any lot by number. 
Sec. 13-35. - Other records to be maintained; disposition. 
In addition to the records required to be kept by this article, each operator of a mobile, or manufactured home park within Macon-Bibb County shall maintain records showing, as of January 1 in each calendar year, the name of the owner of each manufactured home or mobile home located in the mobile home or manufactured home park under the control of such operator, together with a brief description of the manufactured home or mobile home and the lot on which the same is located. Not later than January 15 in each calendar year, each operator of a mobile or manufactured home park required to maintain the records described in this section shall mail a true copy hereof to the county tax commissioner and a copy to the Macon-Bibb County Board of Tax Assessors. 
Chapter 14 - MUNICIPAL COURT 

Sec. 14-1. - Judges and judicial authority. 
(a)  The chief municipal judge may propose written regulations, or amendments thereto, to organize and operate the municipal court in the most efficient manner reasonably possible consistent with state law, the Uniform Rules of Municipal Court approved by the Georgia Supreme Court, the Charter and this Code. 
(b)  All municipal judges shall be members in good standing of the state bar. 
(c)  The chief judge shall not maintain a private practice of law. 
Sec. 14-2. - Jurisdiction. 
(a)  The Municipal Court shall have the authority to try any case of alleged violation of any provision of this Code committed within Macon-Bibb County, unless otherwise provided in this Code, and, after conviction, punish any person found to be in violation as alleged. 
(b)  The Municipal Court may likewise try, convict and punish any person for violation of any state law where jurisdiction has been granted or allowed by general state law or the Charter. 
(c)  Every person charged with a violation in Macon-Bibb County of any other state law may be brought before the municipal judge as soon as is reasonably possible for a finding of probable cause, and upon such a finding the person shall be bound over for prosecution by the state. 
(d)  The Municipal Court shall also have any other powers and duties allowed under state law for such courts. 
Sec. 14-3. - Summons; notice to appear; subpoena; failure to appear. 
(a)  Any person charged with a violation of this Code or any state law under the jurisdiction of the Municipal Court and who has been served with a written summons, citation or notice to appear before the municipal judge at a given time, place and date shall be required to so appear and, upon failure to so appear, the municipal judge may order that person's immediate arrest for an appearance before the judge on a day and time certain to show cause why the person should not be held in contempt and on the original charges. 
(b)  Any person who may be able to provide evidence of any kind on a matter before the Municipal Court and who has been served by any law enforcement officer with a written subpoena issued by the court clerk or a municipal judge which orders the person to be present at the municipal court and testify at a given time, place and date shall be required to be present and, upon failure to be present, may be held in contempt of court and the municipal judge may order that person's immediate arrest for an appearance before the judge on contempt charges. 
Sec. 14-4. - Court sessions; opening announcement. 
(a)  A regular session of the Municipal Court shall be held each week at a fixed hour of a fixed day or days, as may be determined by the chief municipal judge, provided that the chief municipal judge proposes a specific schedule of court sessions in a written regulation that is approved pursuant to this chapter. Notwithstanding the above, any session may be dispensed with when there is no business pending in the court or no cases are ready for trial. 
(b)  The general form of opening announcement may contain the following: 
(1)  A command that attention by all is required; 
(2)  The name of the court; 
(3)  A declaration that court is in session; and 
(4)  The name of the judge presiding. 
Sec. 14-5. - Special sessions. 
The chief municipal judge may order special sessions when, in his judgment, it is necessary, or there is urgent cause for the trial of accused persons, before the next regular sitting of the court. The necessity or urgency of the cause shall be presumed from the fact of a session being held. All defendants shall have at least six (6) hours' notice of the session. 
Sec. 14-6. - Law enforcement attendance. 
It shall be the duty of the Sheriff, or some sworn member of the Office of Sheriff designated by the Sheriff, to attend each session of the court to act as court liaison officer. It shall be the duty of each deputy making the arrest or having knowledge of the case for or against the defendant, to attend the trial of any person brought before the Municipal Court. 
Sec. 14-7. - Appearance bond; procedure for accepting. 
Offenses against the ordinances of Macon-Bibb County shall be bailable as follows: 
(1)  The arresting officer, Sheriff, a municipal judge, or any other officer designated by the Sheriff, may accept bond of the accused payable to Macon-Bibb County conditioned upon the appearance of the accused at the next session or any subsequent session of the Municipal Court as stated in the bond, to answer the charge. 
(2)  The bond shall be in writing in an amount established in a schedule adopted by the chief municipal judge and approved by the mayor. 
(3)  In lieu of an appearance bond, a person arrested for violation of a Macon-Bibb County ordinance may be released on his own recognizance or may deposit, his driver's license with the arresting officer, the Sheriff or a municipal judge if, in any of these officials' determinations, the person will appear at the time set for the court appearance in view of the following considerations: 
a.  The seriousness of the offense charged; 
b.  The penalty provided by law; 
c.  The number of charges pending against the defendant; 
d.  The criminal record of the defendant; 
e.  The residence of the defendant and the length of time of residence; 
f.  The defendant's age; 
g.  Marital status and number of children; 
h.  Residency of the relatives of the defendant; 
i.  Employment of defendant (by whom, nature of work and how long employed); 
j.  Former employment; 
k.  Amount of earnings; 
l.  The defendant's character, reputation and previous criminal history; 
m.  The defendant's mental condition; and 
n.  Whether the defendant has membership in any clubs or societies; church affiliation and other things which could show that he is a responsible member of the community with established community ties. 
(4)  Any person released under subsection (3) above shall receive a receipt for any driver's license deposited or, if released on the person's own recognizance, shall sign and receive a copy of the citation or ticket describing the violation for which the person was arrested. 
(5)  All persons arrested or notified by citation or ticket of parking violations shall be released on their own recognizance. 
(6)  All sureties who sign bonds for the release of principals for offenses against Macon-Bibb County shall at all times be governed and comply with O.C.G.A. § 17-6-1 et seq. 
(7)  Any person engaged in the bonding business that fails to deposit the required bond amount into the court registry after a bond forfeiture has occurred, as required by O.C.G.A. § 17-6-71 shall be summoned to the Municipal Court, after having been given ten (10) days' notice, to show cause why their privilege of signing bonds for municipal offenses should not be suspended by the court. 
Sec. 14-8. - Continuance of cases. 
Continuances shall be made only for good cause shown. Prior to the scheduled court appearance the Clerk of Court or the presiding judge may grant continuations of a case. 
Sec. 14-9. - Forfeiture of witness and appearance bonds. 
(a)  The presiding municipal judge shall call the case in its regular order, and, if the accused or any subpoenaed witness is not in court and does not answer the call, and if no good and sufficient reason is given for the nonappearance, the judge shall enter on the docket where the case is stated, "bond forfeited," or similar words, if there was any bond or cash posted, and issue an arrest warrant for that person, in the judge's discretion. 
(b)  Upon forfeiture of any bond, the cash deposited as security shall be paid to Macon-Bibb County treasury, and it shall become the property of Macon-Bibb County. 
(c)  Upon the forfeiture of any bond signed by a person as surety, Macon-Bibb County may collect the sum as delinquent revenues are collected. 
(d)  Each bond forfeited under the terms of this section, unless extended by the court for good cause shown, shall be due and payable six (6) months from the date that said bond is forfeited. If any forfeiture is not paid within thirty (30) days of the due date for payment of such forfeiture, Macon-Bibb County will no longer accept any bonds signed by the same person acting as the surety on the forfeited bond. 
Sec. 14-10. - Acceptance of pleas. 
Before accepting a plea to an offense charged, the court shall in all cases, in language which the defendant can understand, inform the defendant of the nature of the charge and the penalty which may be imposed upon conviction. 
Sec. 14-11. - Pleas. 
(a)  The defendant shall enter one of the following pleas: 
(1)  Guilty; 
(2)  Not guilty; 
(3)  Nolo contendere (with the permission of the court); or 
(4)  A former judgment of conviction or acquittal of the offense charged. 
(b)  If the defendant refuses to enter a plea, the court shall enter a plea of not guilty and set the case down for trial. 
Sec. 14-12. - Fines; collections; payment in advance of court date. 
(a)  For fines that may be due by any defendant, collection may be made by Macon-Bibb County as for delinquent taxes due Macon-Bibb County. 
(b)  Persons charged with violations of this Code may, prior to the time for their court appearance, plead guilty in writing and pay to Macon-Bibb County as their fine the amount set as the appearance bond for the offense charged, except as may be provided otherwise in the appearance bond schedule. 
Sec. 14-13. - Appearance of complaining witnesses; bond. 
(a)  A material or complaining witness in any contested prosecution shall appear at the session at which the prosecution is docketed. The prosecution may be dismissed if the material witness fails to appear. 
(b)  Any person who has been subpoenaed as a witness before the Municipal Court, may, in the discretion of the Sheriff, be required to give bond or be released on their own recognizance with good security or a cash bond or collateral, conditioned to appear and testify before the municipal court in the case in which the witness has been subpoenaed. 
Sec. 14-14. - Rules of evidence. 
The general rules of evidence applicable to the Superior Court of Bibb County shall be applicable in the trial of all cases in the Municipal Court. 
Sec. 14-15. - Judgment and sentences. 
Upon a judgment or plea of guilty the court shall impose sentence. The court may: 
(1)  Impose a fine, with or without a commitment for compulsory work, confinement or both; 
(2)  Commit the defendant to confinement, compulsory work or both; 
(3)  Suspend the execution of the sentence in whole or in part; or 
(4)  Defer the execution of the sentence or any portion or portions thereof to one or more fixed dates in the future. 
Sec. 14-16. - Court costs—Collection. 
(a)  The Municipal Court may collect costs in cases involving violations of the penal statutes of the state in the same manner as are now provided by law in cases where criminal warrants are issued, and proceeding thereon had before a magistrate. 
(b)  In all cases in the Municipal Court involving a violation of the penal statutes of the state, where the accused is bound over to the Superior Court or the State Court of Bibb County to await trial, Macon-Bibb County shall be allowed costs in the same amounts as is provided by general state law for a magistrate. 
(c)  Such costs shall be collected and paid to Macon-Bibb County in the same manner and at the same time as costs are now collected and paid by the State court of Bibb County to the Sheriff, clerk, and solicitor of the state court for the benefit of Macon-Bibb County and the board of education of Macon-Bibb County; provided, however, that the insolvent cost bill of Macon-Bibb County shall participate in the distribution of fines and forfeitures arising only in cases committed from the Municipal Court. 
Sec. 14-17. - Prosecuting attorney of Municipal Court. 
The Office of Solicitor-General for Bibb County will prosecute criminal cases in Municipal Court. Code violations that are civil in nature will be prosecuted by the County Attorney's Office. Any prosecutors are authorized to file, at their election, accusations as charging instruments in Municipal Court. 
Sec. 14-18. - Municipal court clerk. 
The office of municipal court clerk is hereby established in and for Macon-Bibb County. The office of the municipal court clerk shall be composed of the municipal court clerk who shall serve as the department head and such other employees as may be necessary. The municipal court clerk, under the direction of the mayor, shall be responsible for the administration, supervision, and control of the office of the municipal court clerk. The duties of the municipal court clerk shall be as follows: 
(1)  Assist the municipal court judge in the operation of the municipal court by maintaining a court calendar and records on all cases before the court, including arrests, subpoenas, case dispositions, bonds and the like; 
(2)  Prepare the budgeting and fiscal reports and documents as may be necessary and proper for the operation and maintenance of the municipal court; 
(3)  Collect and compile data, including cases filed and disposed of, and information on the expenditures and receipts of the municipal court; 
(4)  Enforce all regulations of the office and administrative directives of the mayor; 
(5)  Issue any witness subpoena necessary; 
(6)  Attend, or have a designee attend, every session of the municipal court and perform any clerical duties necessary during the session; and 
(7)  Otherwise assist the municipal court judge in administration of the municipal court. 
( Ord. No. O-16-0001, § 1, 1-5-2016 ) 
Chapter 15 - NUISANCES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 15-1. - Conditions constituting nuisance. 
The following conditions are hereby declared to constitute nuisances when any of them endangers the health, welfare or good order of the community and shall be abated, although this section shall not be construed to be limiting with regard to its enumeration of nuisances: 
(1)  Stagnant water on premises. 
(2)  Any dead or decaying matter, weeds, vegetation, or any fruit, vegetable, animal or rodent, upon premises, which is odorous or capable of causing disease or annoyance to the inhabitants of Macon-Bibb County. 
(3)  The generation of smoke or fumes in sufficient amounts to cause odor or annoyance to the inhabitants of Macon-Bibb County. 
(4)  The pollution of public water or the injection of matter into the sewerage system which would be damaging thereto. 
(5)  Maintaining a dangerous or diseased animal or fowl. 
(6)  Obstruction of a public street, highway or sidewalk without a permit. 
(6.1)  Playing basketball or other sports in the street. 
(6.2)  Placement of basketball goals or other sports equipment in the street or sidewalk, or adjacent to the street in such a manner that use of such equipment as placed will cause persons to play in the street. 
(7)  Loud or unusual noises which are detrimental or annoying to the public, including without limiting the foregoing, unusual loud disturbances in or around churches or multiple-family complexes such as loud music and other activities in swimming pool and clubhouse areas, and any noises in violation of Article II. 
(8)  All walls, trees, and buildings that may endanger persons or property. 
(9)  Any business or building where illegal activities are habitually and commonly conducted in such a manner as to reasonably suggest that the owner or operator of the business or building was aware of the illegal activities and failed to reasonably attempt to prevent such activities. 
(10)  Unused iceboxes, refrigerators and the like unless the doors, latches or locks thereof are removed. 
(11)  All rubbish, litter, or debris, including but not limited to combustible and noncombustible waste materials, garbage, wood, coal, coke, paper, rags, cartons, boxes, excelsior, rubber, leather, tree branches, yard trimmings, tin cans, metals, mineral matter, glass, crockery, and the residue from burning such items that may endanger the health, welfare, good order, or beauty of the community. 
(12)  Shrubbery or tree limbs on private property which protrude or hang so as to obstruct the safe passage of pedestrians or motor vehicles. This section shall not apply to the removal of fallen trees, dead trees, shrubbery, bushes, etc. on private property where such do not protrude into the pedestrian/motor vehicle passageway. 
(13)  Any method of human excretion disposal that does not conform to the provisions of local ordinances, or state or federal law. 
(14)  The abandonment of living animals on any property in Macon-Bibb County. 
(15)  Allowing any dog not on a leash, not under restraint, to run loose on the property or premises of another without permission of the owner of the property or the owner of the animal being in possession thereof. 
(16)  Riding off-road vehicles on public roads or upon property of another without permission of the property owner. 
(17)  Maintaining noisome odors in violation of Section 15-10 of this Chapter. 
(18)  Any other condition constituting a nuisance under state law. 
Sec. 15-2. - Nuisance prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, individual, firm, corporation, association, partnership or other entity to cause, permit, maintain, or allow the creation or maintenance, of a nuisance, as defined or more specifically described in this chapter. 
Sec. 15-3. - Complaint of nuisance. 
(a)  Any official or inhabitant of Macon-Bibb County may direct a complaint of nuisance to the Sheriff's Office. Any complaint of nuisance shall be investigated by the sheriff's office and may be placed on either the municipal court or state court docket for a hearing upon the basis of the investigation. The Sheriff's Office may forward such complaints to the appropriate office for investigation and placement on the court docket. 
(b)  After five days' notice to both the complainant and the owner, agent in control of, or tenant in possession of the property involved, the municipal court or state court shall hold a hearing on the complaint. Upon finding that a nuisance in violation of this chapter does exist, the court shall issue an order and notice to abate nuisance to the owner, agent in control of, or tenant in possession of the property, stating that a nuisance has been found to exist and that the nuisance must be abated within so many hours or days as the judge shall deem reasonable, having consideration for the nature of the nuisance and its effect on the public. 
(c)  The Macon-Bibb County Engineer, animal control officers, building and license inspectors, health inspectors, public works inspectors, and the fire prevention bureau of the fire department of the county may also receive complaints, investigate the same, and may place on the court docket such complaints in the same manner as the sheriff or sheriff's deputies. 
Sec. 15-4. - Order and notice to abate. 
Whenever a nuisance in violation of this chapter is found to exist within the jurisdiction of Macon-Bibb County, the municipal court or state court shall issue a written order and notice to abate to the owner, agent in control of, or tenant in possession of the property upon which such nuisance exists or upon the person causing or maintaining the nuisance, to abate the nuisance. 
Sec. 15-5. - Contents of order and notice to abate. 
The order and notice to abate nuisance issued by the municipal court or state court under the provisions of this chapter shall contain the following: 
(1)  A statement that a nuisance in violation of this chapter has been found to exist on the property involved; 
(2)  An order to abate the nuisance, which shall be reasonable under the circumstances, given the nature of the nuisance, its effect on the public, and the immediacy of the need for corrective action; 
(3)  The location of the nuisance, if the nuisance is stationary; 
(4)  A description of what constitutes the nuisance; and 
(5)  A statement of acts necessary to abate the nuisance. 
Sec. 15-6. - Abatement by Macon-Bibb County. 
(a)  In any case where the owner, agent in control of, or tenant in possession of the property cannot be served with notice, or where the nature of the nuisance is such that, in the opinion of the municipal court judge or state court judge, the nuisance must be immediately abated, the judge may issue an order to the appropriate office directing the nuisance to be abated. 
(b)  The office receiving such order of abatement, in such case, shall keep a record of the expenses and cost of abating said nuisance, and the costs shall be billed against the owner, agent in control of, or tenant in possession of the property for collection as for Macon-Bibb County revenues generally and shall become a lien on the property of such persons. 
Sec. 15-7. - Compliance with other laws; conflicting provisions. 
(a)  The provisions of all other applicable Macon-Bibb County, state, and federal laws shall apply. This chapter shall not be construed or interpreted to repeal or to be in conflict with any other provisions of this Code relating to nuisance, including but not limited to Chapter 15, Nuisances and Chapter 22, Article III, Litter Control. 
(b)  The procedures for enforcement and abatement under this chapter shall be independent of those procedures for enforcement and abatement delineated in Chapter 15, Nuisances and Chapter 22, Article III, Litter Control. 
(c)  If any provision of this chapter is in genuine conflict with any state or federal law or requirement, the conflict shall be resolved in accordance with law. 
Sec. 15-8. - Penalties. 
Any person who violates an order of the municipal court or state court to abate a nuisance after the initial hearing and issuance of an order and notice to abate provided for above shall be punished as provided in the general penalty section of this Code. 
Sec. 15-9. - Mayor may abate nuisance per se. 
Nothing contained in this chapter shall prevent the mayor from, summarily and without notice ordering the abatement of or abating any nuisance that is a nuisance per se in the law or where the case is an urgent one and the health and safety of the public or a portion thereof is in imminent danger, and the mayor is hereby authorized to exercise such authority in conformance with state law. 
Sec. 15-10. - Noisome odors prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any owner or individual in control of any property within the boundaries of Macon-Bibb County to: 
(1)  Allow the accumulation of animal body wastes; 
(2)  Boil offal, bone, fat, tallow; 
(3)  Manufacture glue, varnish or oil; 
(4)  Make lamp black, turpentine or tar; 
(5)  Render or dry out dead animals; or 
(6)  Conduct any other activity, business or trade not specifically enumerated in this Code whereby noisome stenches and odors arise, or noxious gases are generated or circulated within Macon-Bibb County. 
Sec. 15-11. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WEEDS, DEBRIS AND INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLES 

Sec. 15-12. - Definitions. 
The following terms, as used in this division shall have the following meanings: 
Building means any structure that encloses a space used for sheltering any occupancy. 
Debris, for the purpose of this division, shall include residue from the burning of wood, coal, or other combustible material, as well as paper, rags, cartons, boxes, wood, rubber, leather, fallen, broken or destroyed trees or tree limbs or other material or objects not a part of the land and constituting a health or safety hazard. 
Inoperable motor vehicles means any motor vehicle as defined herein which is in a state of disrepair, wrecked, dismantled, inoperative, abandoned or discarded. The term inoperable shall include a motor vehicle that is incapable of being moved under its own power. 
Lot, for the purposes of this division, shall mean one (1) or any one or more of several contiguous parcels of land making up a block, measured and set apart for use or occupancy. 
Motor vehicle means any vehicle which is self-propelled and designated to travel along the ground and shall include, but not be limited to, automobiles, buses, motorbikes, motorcycles, motorscooters, trucks, tractors, go carts, golf carts, campers and trailers. 
Weeds shall be defined as all objectionable growth, including weeds and grasses which serve as a breeding place for mosquitoes and other unhealthy or undesirable insects, or as a refuge for snakes, rats or other rodents, or that create a fire or traffic hazard or provide a hiding place for persons. Provided, however, that flowers, shrubbery, trees and other growth used as a part of landscaping shall not be included in this definition. 
Wooded areas shall be defined as those portions of lots consisting of a dense growth of trees, which exceed three (3) inches in diameter. 
Sec. 15-13. - Weeds, debris, inoperable motor vehicles; prohibition; exception. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the occupant of any lot of land or premises in Macon-Bibb County, or the owner of any lot of land or premises in Macon-Bibb County, or any agent or representative of such owner or occupant, to permit or maintain on such lot the growth thereon of objectionable weeds, the accumulation of debris or the harborage of inoperable motor vehicles, as defined in this division, which distracts from the community aesthetics, and endangers the public health, safety or welfare. The following conditions shall constitute a nuisance as it relates to the growth of objectionable weeds: 
(1)  Any lot on which a residential structure is built shall be deemed a nuisance if the growth of weeds as defined herein is twelve (12) inches or more in height. 
(2)  Any vacant lot located within a residential district or area shall be deemed a nuisance if the growth of weeds as defined herein exceeds eighteen (18) inches or more in height. 
(3)  Any lot or property other than those described above shall be deemed a nuisance if the growth of weeds as defined herein exceeds eighteen (18) inches in height. 
Exception: For the purpose of this division, wooded areas as defined herein shall be exempt from the above requirements and agricultural areas as defined in O.C.G.A. § 41-1-7 shall also be exempt. 
(b)  This division defines and establishes procedures for abating inoperable motor vehicles. For definitions and enforcement procedures pertaining to abandoned vehicles, refer to Article III. 
Sec. 15-14. - Notice of violations. 
(a)  When any objectionable condition as defined in section 15-1 is being permitted or maintained on any lot of land or premises in Macon-Bibb County in violation of section 15-1, the Director of Business Development Services or the Director of Economic and Community Development, as applicable, or their designee (the "official"), shall notify in writing the occupant of such lot, or the owner thereof or their agents or representatives, that the conditions existing upon the property constitute a nuisance, and setting forth the actions to be taken to eliminate the objectionable conditions within fifteen (15) days or within thirty (30) days if the property is zoned industrial or exceeds two (2) acres in size. Failure of the owner or occupant to eliminate the conditions constituting a nuisance within the allotted time period, shall constitute an offense of this Code. An official may grant a written extension upon a showing of reasonable cause, not to exceed an additional fifteen (15) days. Upon the expiration of the fifteen (15) days plus any extension, if any, the official shall issue a summons so charging the party notified and requiring such party to appear in the municipal court or state court for a hearing at a given time, place and date. 
(b)  Notices shall be in writing and delivered in person or by certified mail to the occupant and/or owner or its agents or representatives. If the official, following due diligence, is unable to serve such notice, the official shall cause such notice to be published once a week for two (2) consecutive weeks in the news publication of general distribution of the court, prior to taking any steps to abate said nuisance and prior to the running of the fifteen (15) day period for abatement of the nuisance. 
(c)  Any department, agency or individual charged with the enforcement of these regulations shall establish procedures for the tracking, monitoring and the enforcement thereof not inconsistent with these regulations. 
Sec. 15-15. - Summary abatement. 
In all cases where the owner, occupant or agent of a lot cannot be found, or if found and notified, neglects or refuses to abate said nuisance within the time specified by court order or fails to appear in court when summoned, it shall be lawful for Macon-Bibb County to abate the same and remove the objectionable conditions from the property. In such cases, the official shall notify the public works director who shall cause the nuisance to be abated and the objectionable conditions to be removed from the property and shall assess the costs associated with said removal and charge all costs thereof to the owner or representative. Said costs may constitute a lien against the property and be collected pursuant to section 26-2. Provided, however, that this shall not preclude other remedies available to the official for abating said nuisance or Macon-Bibb County's use of other legal means of collecting the cost therefor. 
Sec. 15-16. - Complaint, trial, order, failure to comply, assessment, collection. 
(a)  When it becomes necessary to summons an owner or occupant of lands subject to the provisions of this division, said summons shall be in the form of a written complaint in the municipal or state court setting forth, particularly, the nature and location of the nuisance and the identity of the person complained against. If the court determines that the conditions do in fact constitute a nuisance, the court shall issue an order specifying the time within which such nuisance must be abated. In addition, the court may impose a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the offense of failure to abate the nuisance within the period provided for in section 15-14 if the court determines that the owner or occupant unreasonably failed to abate the nuisance during that time period or prior to the court hearing. 
(b)  The failure of the owner or occupant to comply with the court's order to abate the nuisance shall constitute an offense and shall subject the person to prosecution and penalties as provided in the general penalty section of this Code, including: 
(1)  Fines not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) per violation. 
(2)  Imprisonment, not to exceed fifty (50) days. 
(3)  Community service to be performed with any private, non-profit community service organization or any public agency willing to participate and approved by municipal court or any other court ordering the abatement. Violators shall not be used for any purpose resulting in private gain to any person, except in accordance with state law. The role of Macon-Bibb County in the supervision of violators performing community service shall be a governmental function. 
(4)  Any or all of these penalties in the discretion of the judge. 
(5)  Payment of the cost of abatement incurred by the public works or other department of Macon-Bibb County, upon order of the court. 
DIVISION 3. - OBSTRUCTIONS TO CROSS-VISIBILITY 

Sec. 15-17. - Obstructions to cross-visibility at intersections deemed nuisance; abatement procedures. 
(a)  In order to promote and conserve the public health and safety and pursuant to the police powers of Macon-Bibb County and the power to prevent and abate public nuisances as conferred upon Macon-Bibb County by the laws of the State of Georgia, it is hereby declared to be a public nuisance for a person owning and/or having the legal control of any land within the corporate limits of Macon-Bibb County to maintain or permit upon any such land any fence, sign, billboard, shrubbery, bush, tree, mailbox or other object, or any combination thereof, which obstructs the view of motorists using any street or approach to any street intersection so as to constitute a traffic hazard or a condition dangerous to the public safety. 
(b)  The restrictions set forth in this section shall apply to both of the following triangles of land: 
(1)  That triangle bounded by the curb edges (or edges of pavement where there is no curb), measured along the curb edge (or edge of pavement where there is no curb) twenty (20) feet from the midpoint of the radius of the curb edge (or edge of pavement where there is no curb) in each direction and the diagonal line connecting the further ends of such twenty-foot lengths; and
