It shall be unlawful for the holder of a deed under power to fail to record such deed, as required by O.C.G.A. § 44-14-160, with the Clerk of Superior Court within ninety (90) days of a foreclosure sale of real property located within Macon-Bibb County. For each day the deed is unrecorded after the ninetieth day following the foreclosure sale, the holder of such unrecorded deeds under power for real property located within Macon-Bibb County shall be subject to a fine of ten dollars ($10.00) per day. Each day after the ninetieth day following the foreclosure sale that such deeds remain unrecorded shall be a separate violation of this section. Each individual deed under power that remains unrecorded shall be a separate violation of this section. 
Sec. 16-41. - Driving, parking of motor vehicles in public parks. 
(a)  In order to regulate the driving and parking of motor vehicles in public parks in Macon-Bibb County, it is hereby provided that it shall be unlawful for any person to drive or park any motor vehicle of any kind at any time in any public park in Macon-Bibb County, except upon any streets, roadways and parking areas as may be constructed therein for the driving and parking of motor vehicles. 
(b)  A person driving or parking a motor vehicle in a public park as part of, or in connection with, an officially sanctioned festival or special event, or after having obtained written permission from the government department or agency operating the public park prominently displayed on the vehicle, shall not be a violation of this section. 
(c)  A person convicted of an offense of this section shall be punished by a fine of no less than two hundred ten dollars ($210.00). 
Sec. 16-42. - Reserved. 
Sec. 16-43. - Pedestrian, wheelchair, and powered mobility device violations of traffic rules and regulations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for a pedestrian or a person in a wheelchair or a powered mobility device to violate any provision of the Uniform Rules of the Road, codified at O.C.G.A. § 40-6-90 et seq. or Chapter 28, Traffic and Parking. 
(b)  For the first violation of this section, or sections 28-32 through 28-34, in a period of two (2) years, a person found or pleading guilty shall be punishable by a maximum penalty of a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00), provided that the municipal court judge may exercise his discretion in levying fines based upon the circumstances surrounding the violation. For subsequent violations within a two-year period, the maximum penalty shall be a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per violation. 
(c)  Subsection (b) shall not apply to violations of O.C.G.A. § 40-6-95 or any other violation relating to a pedestrian under the influence of alcohol or drugs. 
(d)  Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-6-320, it shall not be a violation of this section for a person using a motorized wheelchair, also known as an electric personal assistive mobility device or as a powered mobility device, from operating such a device on a roadway with a speed limit of thirty-five (35) miles per hour or less, or in a separately striped bicycle lane, in the same direction of travel authorized for motor vehicle traffic on that roadway. 
Chapter 17 - PARKS AND RECREATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 17-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Board of health means the Macon-Bibb County board of health. 
Department means the department of parks and recreation. 
Director means the director of parks and recreation. 
Secretary or chairman means the secretary or chairman of the health board. 
Sec. 17-2. - Schedule of rates for use of golf courses required; location. 
(a)  A schedule of rates shall be established in the proper department regulations for the use and rental of any Macon-Bibb County golf courses. 
(b)  A copy of these rate schedules shall be kept on file and available to interested parties at the office of the Clerk of Commission as well as at the manager's office of each such facility. 
Sec. 17-3. - Commission to approve change in recreation areas; notice. 
No park, playground or other recreation area, owned by Macon-Bibb County, may be reduced in size, altered in any manner or diverted from its present use without the prior approval of the commission given at a regular meeting. No action may be taken by the commission upon any request or proposal to reduce in size, alter or divert from its present use any such park, playground or other recreation area until notice of the request or proposal has been published once a week for two consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in Macon-Bibb County. The form and contents of the notice shall be that specified by the commission. The Clerk of Commission shall be charged with the responsibility of causing the notice to be published and the cost of publication shall be borne by Macon-Bibb County. 
Sec. 17-4. - Prohibited hours. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, other than authorized personnel of Macon-Bibb County, to be present on the premises any public park or recreation facility in Macon-Bibb County at any time from 12:00 midnight to 6:00 a.m. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person other than authorized personnel of Macon-Bibb County to be on the premises of any public playground in Macon-Bibb County at any time from 10:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. during the period of May 1 through October 31, and from 7:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. during the period from November 1 of any year through April 30 of the succeeding year. 
(c)  The prohibition stated above shall not apply to school playgrounds which are under the control of the county board of education or to any public park or playground in Macon-Bibb County where activities are being conducted by or under the sponsorship of the Macon-Bibb County recreation department or to Central City Park during the period of the of an approved festival, fair, or carnival. 
Sec. 17-5. - Youth sports events. 
The director of the parks and recreation department shall propose written regulations, or amendments thereto, governing youth sports events on Macon-Bibb County property, including, but not limited to the establishment of a code of conduct, a leadership training program, and a youths sports conduct committee. Regulations are subject to mayor and commission approval in accordance with the administration chapter of this Code. 
Sec. 17-6. - Tobesofkee recreation area exceptions. 
The provisions of this article shall not apply to the Tobesofkee Recreation Area whenever the specific provisions of article III are in conflict with this article. 
Sec. 17-7. - Prohibited activities with regard to park and recreation areas. 
The following activities are prohibited in any Macon-Bibb County park or recreation area: 
(1)  Climb or lie upon any tree, shrub, fence, statue, monument, art, or fountain which has not been expressly designated for that purpose. 
(2)  Enter or leave any park except through established entrances or exits and within established time periods. 
(3)  Gain or attempt to gain admittance to any park or facility in any park where a charge is made, without paying that charge. 
(4)  Use any area for changing clothing, other than an area designated for that purpose. 
(5)  Disregard the notices, prohibitions or directions on any park sign. 
(6)  Disobey the lawful order of a law enforcement officer. 
(7)  Place or display any sign or advertisement, except that this rule shall not apply to any signs or advertisements regarding any County sponsored or County authorized program, festival, or other event that occurs in the park. Signs or advertisements regarding County sponsored or County authorized programs, festivals or other events may be placed or displayed only with written permission by the Director of Recreation and Director of Parks & Beautification or their individual designee, and only at the locations and during the times authorized in writing by the Director of Recreation and Director of Parks & Beautification or their respective designee. 
(8)  Play, practice or otherwise participate in any game, sport or other recreational activity that is destructive to the lawn, plants, walls, road, or other infrastructure of a park, except at or upon places designated for that game, sport or recreational activity. 
(9)  Knowingly, or through reckless behavior, destroy or damage the lawn, plants, walls, road, or other infrastructure of a park, except by written permission from the Director of Recreation and Director of Parks & Beautification, or their respective designee. 
(10)  Drive stakes, posts, poles or any other device or dig holes for the purpose of securing stakes, posts, poles or any other device for any reason, including to erect a tent, stage or other structure, except by written permission from the Director of Recreation and Director of Parks & Beautification or their respective designee. 
(11)  Bring in, erect, or permit a minor child in one's custody to bring in and/or erect any inflatable amusements, amusements requiring water, or any amusements requiring an independent power source, except during permitted special events and festivals. This rule shall not apply to County pools and lakes where inflatables such as floats, tubes, water wings, etc. shall be permissible. For purposes of this subsection, inflatable amusements shall not include balls or balloons, and amusements requiring water shall not include water pistols. 
(12)  Bring in and abandon any animal in a park, including but not limited to cats, ducks, raccoons, opossums, fish and dogs, without the written permission of the Director of Recreation and Director of Parks & Beautification or their respective designee. 
( Ord. No. O-16-0093, § 1, 8-16-2016 ) 
Sec. 17-8. - Rosa Parks Square. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, to consume, sell and/or use any alcoholic beverage in Rosa Parks Square at any time, provided, however, that these prohibitions shall not become effective until the completion of Poplar Street Commons. Rosa Parks Square shall be designated as place of reflection for purposes of honoring Rosa Park's legacy upon completion of Poplar Street Commons, provided, however, that community concerts, dance classes, movie nights, and other community related activities shall continue to be allowed. The existing monuments, memorials, and historical markers located in Rosa Parks Square shall not be relocated or moved without the approval of the Macon-Bibb County Commission. 
( Ord. of 7-5-2017(1), § 1 ) 
Editor's note— Ord. of 7-5-2017(1), § 1 , set out provisions for use herein as § 17-7. Inasmuch as § 17-7 existed at the time of codification, those provisions have been included herein as § 17-8. 
Secs. 17-9—17-29. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TREE PRESERVATION, PROTECTION AND REPLACEMENT 

Sec. 17-30. - Purpose and intent. 
(a)  Purpose. It is the purpose of this article to promote and protect the public health, safety, the environment, and general welfare by providing for the regulation of the planting, maintenance, and removal of trees on Macon-Bibb County-owned property and public rights-of-way within the limits of Macon-Bibb County. 
(b)  Intent. It is the intent of the mayor and the commission that the terms of this article shall be construed so as to promote: 
(1)  The planting, maintenance, restoration, and survival of desirable trees within the public rights-of-way and on Macon-Bibb County-owned property within Macon-Bibb County; and 
(2)  The protection of community residents from personal injury and property damage, and the protection of the Macon-Bibb County from property damage, caused or threatened by the improper planting, maintenance, or removal of trees located in the public rights-of-way and on Macon-Bibb County-owned property. 
(3)  An increase in holding capacity of water in the land, the reduction of air pollutants and carbon monoxide levels in the air, the minimization of increased temperature on lands with tree cover, the aesthetic qualities of the community, the maintenance or increase of property values, the prevention of siltation of the rivers, canals, ditches, and other waterways, the aesthetic quality provided by the natural tree cover on tracts of land being converted to urban development, and the prevention of soil erosion. 
Sec. 17-31. - Jurisdiction. 
The provisions of this article shall apply to all public rights-of-way, and Macon-Bibb County-owned property within the limits of Macon-Bibb County. 
Sec. 17-32. - Definitions. 
As used within this article, the following terms shall have the meanings set forth in this section: 
Arboricultural Specifications and Standards of Practice for Macon-Bibb County (hereinafter, "Arboricultural Specifications Manual, or abbreviated as, ASM") means the ASM is a manual prepared by the Forester pursuant to this article containing regulations and standards for the planting, maintenance, protection, and removal of trees upon the public rights-of-way and Macon-Bibb County-owned property. 
Caliper means the diameter or thickness of the main stem of a young tree or sapling as measured at six inches above the ground level. This measurement is used for nursery grown trees having a diameter of four inches or less. 
Clearing means the removal of woody vegetation of two inches diameter or greater. 
Diameter means the diameter or width of the main stem of a tree as measured four and one-half feet above the natural grade at the base of a tree. Whenever a branch, split in the main trunk, limb, defect or abnormal swelling of the trunk occurs at this height, the diameter shall be measured at the nearest point above or below four and one-half feet at which a normal diameter occurs. 
Drip line means a vertical line extending from the outer surface of a tree's branch tips down to the ground. 
Forester means the agent of Macon-Bibb County who is responsible for the administration of these standards and having the primary responsibilities of administration and enforcement of the Macon-Bibb County Tree Preservation, Protection, and Replacement Ordinance. 
Imminent danger means an appearance of threatened and impending injury or loss of property as would put a reasonable and prudent man to his instant defense. 
Land disturbing activity means excavation or construction work within the drip line of any tree in or upon any public property and/or change in natural drainage, excavation of any ditches, tunnels, trenches or laying of any drive within the root protection zone of any tree having all or any portion of its trunk in or upon any Macon-Bibb County property. 
Macon-Bibb County-owned property means property within the limits of Macon-Bibb County or Macon-Bibb County-owned property, and 
(1)  Owned by Macon-Bibb County in fee simple absolute, or 
(2)  Implied or expressly delegated or dedicated to the public for present or future use for purposes of vehicular or pedestrian traffic, or for public easements. 
Person means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or organization of any kind, including public utilities and governmental entities. 
Protective barrier means the minimum tree protection device shall be as described in the ASM. 
Property owner means the record owner or contract purchaser of any parcel of land. 
Responsible person means the person who removes a tree from Macon-Bibb County-owned property or a public right-of-way which must be replaced and maintained pursuant to section 17-35. 
Specimen tree means a tree which has been determined by the forester to be of high value because of its type, size, age or other professional criteria, and has been so designated in the official records of Macon-Bibb County. 
Tree means any self-supporting woody perennial plant which has a trunk diameter of two inches or more when measured at a point six inches above the ground level and which normally attains an overall height of at least ten feet at maturity, usually with one main stem or trunk, but may have multiple trunks at the base, and many branches which contains lignin (wood) in the stems and limbs. 
Tree protection zone means the area surrounding a preserved or planted tree that is essential to that tree's health and survival, protected within the guidelines of this article, and is regulated and illustrated by the ASM. 
Tree commission means the entity created and described in section 17-33. 
Sec. 17-33. - Tree commission; establishment; composition; appointment of members; duties. 
(a)  The establishment, composition, and appointment of members. There shall be created a commission to be known and designated as the "tree commission" composed of fourteen (14) people. Seven (7) of said members shall be appointed by the mayor with the confirmation of the commission. Of the seven (7) members appointed by the mayor, one (1) shall be a representative of any of the historic districts of Macon, three (3) shall be citizens at large, one (1) shall be a contractor or developer, and two (2) shall be persons professionally trained in the field(s) such as urban forestry/arboriculture, botany, horticulture, or landscape architecture. The eighth member shall be the director of the department of parks and beautification, or his or her designee, who shall be an ex-officio member; the ninth member shall be the forester who shall be an ex-officio member; the tenth member shall be a member of the state forestry commission, or a designee, who shall be an ex-officio member; the eleventh member shall be the director of the Keep Macon-Bibb Beautiful Commission, or a designee, who shall be an ex-officio member; the twelfth member shall be a representative of the Georgia Power Company who shall be an ex-officio member; the thirteenth member shall be the director of the county extension service, or a designee, who shall be an ex-officio member; and the fourteenth member shall be the director of the Macon-Bibb County planning and zoning commission, or a designee, who shall be an ex-officio member. No ex-officio member shall have the right to vote on commission matters. All members of the commission shall serve without pay. The seven (7) members appointed by the mayor shall be appointed as follows: two (2) for two (2) years, three (3) for three (3) years, and two (2) for four (4) years, and shall serve until their successors are duly appointed and confirmed by council. Successors to those members appointed by the mayor shall thereafter be appointed for terms of four (4) years. Vacancies caused by death, resignation, or otherwise, shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as the original appointments are made. The mayor may recommend removal or replacement of a member of the commission for nonperformance of duty. 
Nonperformance of duty is defined herein to mean three consecutive unexcused absences from commission meetings. 
(b)  Duties of the tree commission. The duties of said "tree commission" shall be as follows: 
(1)  To study the problems and determine the needs of Macon-Bibb County in connection with its tree planting, maintenance and removal programs and the urban forestry management plan. 
(2)  The tree commission shall provide consultation and assistance to the forester on any matter pertaining to the "Macon-Bibb County Tree Preservation, Protection, and Replacement Ordinance" and its enforcement. The topics under which this advice and consultation may be given may include, but are not limited to, any of the following: 
a.  Amendments to the Macon-Bibb County Tree Preservation, Protection, and Replacement Ordinance, and alterations or revisions to the ASM and alterations or revisions of the urban forestry management plan; 
b.  Policy concerning selection, planting, maintenance, and removal of trees within Macon-Bibb County, on Macon-Bibb County-owned property or public rights-of-way; 
c.  Establishment of educational and informational programs to encourage proper maintenance of trees. 
(3)  The tree commission, upon receipt of a written appeal from any person who disagrees with a decision of the forester shall hear all issues of the disputes which arise between the forester and any such person whenever those issues involve matters of the interpretation or enforcement of the ASM, the urban forestry management plan, or of the interpretation or enforcement of this article. The decision of a majority of the appointed members of the tree commission with regard to such dispute shall be final. Any person who disagrees with the decision of the tree commission may appeal said decision to municipal court as set forth in section 17-41. 
(4)  To assist the administration of Macon-Bibb County, as well as the commission members and citizens of Macon-Bibb County, in the dissemination of news and information regarding the protection, maintenance, removal and planting of trees on Macon-Bibb County-owned property or public rights-of-way, and to make such recommendations from time to time to the mayor and commission as to desirable legislation concerning the tree program and activities for Macon-Bibb County. 
(5)  To provide at least quarterly meetings and special meetings at which the subject of trees may be discussed by a quorum of the members of the commission, officers, and personnel of Macon-Bibb County, and all other persons interested in the tree program. 
(6)  That within a reasonable time after the appointment of said commission and the approval of the members thereof, upon call of the mayor, said commission shall meet and organize by the election of a chairperson and the appointment of a secretary. The said commission shall then provide for the adoption of rules and procedures and for the holding of regular and special meetings as said commission shall deem advisable and necessary in order to perform the duties set forth. 
(7)  To assist the planning and zoning commission in the enforcement of regulations and procedures adopted by the planning and zoning commission for the purpose of regulating trees on private property. The provisions of this article shall not be binding on or affect the commission's regulations and procedures. 
( Ord. of 2-21-2017(1), § 1 ) 
Sec. 17-34. - Forester; duties; authority. 
(a)  Duties. 
(1)  The forester is hereby charged with the duty to enforce this section. 
(2)  The forester, with the assistance of the tree commission, shall develop, and each subsequent year, update, the urban forestry management plan. The plan shall outline the urban forestry program activities for a minimum of the next five (5) years. This plan shall describe the urban forestry activities to be undertaken by Macon-Bibb County, the reasons for those activities, the possible funding source(s), the means of accomplishing the activities, the alternatives available to Macon-Bibb County to fund or accomplish the activities, the projected date of completion, and the impact if the activities are not completed. Activities may include but are not limited to street tree inventory, planting, tree removal, personnel training, beautification projects, and educational projects. 
(3)  The forester, with the assistance of the tree commission, shall develop and periodically review and revise, as necessary, the ASM. This manual shall contain regulations and standards for the planting, maintenance, tree protection zones, and removal of trees upon Macon-Bibb County-owned property, and the public rights-of-way. 
(4)  The forester shall cause the urban forestry management plan and the ASM, and all revisions and amendment to it, to be published and promulgated and shall cause one (1) copy of the ASM, and all revisions and amendments to it, to be available for public inspection at the office of the county clerk. Notice that such information is available for public inspection shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation within Macon-Bibb County at least one (1) weekday of each of four (4) consecutive weeks immediately following the initial availability of the ASM, or revisions or amendments thereto. The ASM, and any revisions and amendments thereto, shall become effective upon approval by the mayor and commission. The most recent version of the ASM used by the City of Macon shall remain in effect until such time as a new ASM is adopted by the commission. The ASM, once passed by the commission, becomes effective upon the mayor signing the same. Copies shall also be made available to the Macon-Bibb County planning and zoning commission and engineering department of Macon-Bibb County. 
(5)  The forester shall maintain on file in the office of the Clerk of Commission for any interested persons, copies of the tree ordinance, information about the activities of the tree commission, copies of the ASM, and copies of the urban forestry management plan. 
(6)  The forester shall administer the urban forestry management plan, the Macon-Bibb County Tree Preservation, Protection, and Replacement Ordinance, and the provisions of the ASM. 
(7)  The forester shall perform whatever acts are necessary, including the planting and maintenance of trees and the removal of undesirable trees located on public rights-of-way or Macon-Bibb County-owned property to conform to the urban forestry management plan, the ASM, and this article. Pursuant to this duty, the forester, in accordance with normal Macon-Bibb County procedures regarding contracts, may arrange contractual agreements. 
(8)  The forester shall review and issue a written decision on all requests for tree removal as are required by this chapter. The forester shall obtain, as a condition precedent to the issuance of an approval, the written plan and agreement of each person who applies that he or she will comply with the requirements of this chapter, the urban forestry management plan, and the tree replacement requirements. The plan and agreement shall include a completion date. The forester shall have the right to inspect all work performed in public rights-of-way or Macon-Bibb County-owned property. 
(9)  The forester shall establish a program of public information and education that will encourage the planting, maintenance, protection, or removal of trees on private property in furtherance of the goals of the urban forestry management plan. 
(10)  The forester shall assist the Macon-Bibb County planning and zoning commission on any actions affecting the planting, maintenance, protection, or removal of trees in Macon-Bibb County under the commission's jurisdiction. 
(11)  No person shall unreasonably hinder, prevent, delay, or interfere with the forester or his agents while engaged in the execution or enforcement of this article. 
(b)  Jurisdiction. The forester shall have the authority to regulate the protection, maintenance, removal and planting of trees on streets, parks, public places and other tree protection zones, on public rights-of-way and Macon-Bibb County-owned property within the limits or on any Macon-Bibb County-owned property. Such authority shall include the assurance that this article is enforced and the issuance of citations for the violation of these provisions. 
Sec. 17-35. - General protection and regulation of trees on Macon-Bibb County-owned property and public rights-of-way. 
(a)  Prior to any land disturbing activity within the tree protection zone, as defined in section 17-32, a person who owns property adjacent to Macon-Bibb County-owned property or the public rights-of-way shall obtain approval of the forester. The property owner shall consult with and obtain approval from the forester prior to removing, transporting, destroying, breaking, cutting, spraying, defacing, or otherwise disturbing any tree located on adjacent Macon-Bibb County-owned property or in the tree protection zone. The forester shall respond to such request as expeditiously as possible, but in any event within sixty (60) days. If the forester has not responded within sixty (60) days, the forester will be presumed to have approved such request, unless otherwise informed. The property owner shall not allow any gaseous, liquid, chemical or solid substance which is harmful to trees to come into contact with, set fire to, or burn any tree on the adjacent Macon-Bibb County-owned property or any adjacent public rights-of-way. 
(b)  No person shall cut, damage, carve, top, attach or place any rope, wire, sign, poster, handbill, or any other thing on any tree or woody shrubs growing in the public right-of-way or on Macon-Bibb County-owned property without consulting and obtaining approval from the forester. 
(c)  No person shall directly or indirectly place stone, cement, or any substance in or about the tree(s) growing in public rights-of-way or on Macon-Bibb County-owned property which will impede the free entrance of water or air to the root system of such trees without consulting and obtaining approval from the forester. 
(d)  No person shall attach or place any rope, wire, sign, poster, handbill, or any other thing on any tree or woody shrub growing in the public right-of-way or on Macon-Bibb County-owned property without consulting and obtaining approval from the forester. 
(e)  All actions required to preserve and protect trees, and to prevent soil erosion affected by this chapter shall be performed in accordance with the Arboricultural Specifications and Standards of Practice Manual, or ASM. 
(f)  This section shall not be interpreted to prohibit Macon-Bibb County, utility companies (such as gas, electricity, cable, and telephone) and such other service providers from constructing and maintaining easements, safe clearances and/or rights-of-way for utility lines. All utilities and service providers shall notify the forester in writing of any land-disturbing activity affecting trees covered by this article prior to conducting such activity, except in cases of an emergency. All companies, suppliers and/or agencies removing trees shall execute an agreement recognizing the need to minimize the cutting, trimming or removal of trees which do not frustrate or substantially interfere with the supply of service. 
(g)  The forester's permission must be obtained prior to planting any trees in public rights-of-way or on any Macon-Bibb County-owned property. Certain types of trees are inappropriate for planting along public rights-of-way. Trees placed on such property without the permission of the forester shall be subject to removal at the expense of the person who planted such trees. 
Sec. 17-36. - Tree replacement requirements. 
(a)  Street rights-of-way trees that are in sound condition but are to be removed to facilitate construction of driveways, utilities, curbs, sidewalks, or street widening must be replaced using the caliper and/or diameter as the replacement factor as specified in the ASM. Upon the removal of each tree, whether approved by request or unlawful, this article requires mitigation for trees removed with replacement trees of equal value and at least two-inch caliper. The aggregate or combined caliper inches of replacement trees shall equal the total diameter inches (dbh) of the tree(s) removed. Where the forester cannot determine the dbh because of prior removal of a tree, the forester shall determine the dbh in accordance with the latest revision of "Estimating DBH from stump diameter for 15 Southern Species" as published by the U.S. Forestry Service. Where the species removed is not included in the above publication, the forester shall select a species closest to the type removed. 
(b)  Any person responsible for replacing removed tree(s) shall also be responsible for maintaining the health of all replacement trees for a period of one (1) year from the date of planting. The person shall replace any tree that dies during this time period. 
(c)  Any person who violates the tree replacement requirements or who fails to comply shall be charged the cost of replacement of said tree or at least five hundred dollars ($500.00), whichever is greater. The replacement value of trees shall be determined in accordance with the latest revision of "Guide for Plant Appraisal" as published by the International Society of Arboriculture. 
(d)  Replacement tree species and number shall be determined by the forester. Replacement shall be reasonably confined to the area from which Macon-Bibb County's tree was removed. Acceptable replacement could include planting on public rights-of-way, Macon-Bibb County-owned property, or private property with the approval of the forester. 
(e)  Where the forester has determined that irreparable damage has occurred to tree(s) on public rights-of-way, on Macon-Bibb County owned property or within a tree protection zone, the tree(s) must be removed and replaced by the responsible person(s) in accordance with the tree replacement requirements. 
Sec. 17-37. - Public nuisances. 
(a)  The following are hereby declared public nuisances under this article: any tree or portion thereof whether located on Macon-Bibb County-owned property, public rights-of-way or on private property which: 
(1)  By reason of location or condition constitutes an imminent danger to the health, safety, or welfare of the general public; 
(2)  Obstructs the free passage of pedestrian or vehicular traffic or which obstructs a street light or street sign; 
(3)  Dangerously obstructs the view of motorists as such may be determined by the traffic engineer pursuant to this article. 
(b)  Right to inspect. The forester shall have the authority to enter onto private property whereon there is located a tree or portions thereof, that is reasonably suspected to pose an imminent danger or a public nuisance. 
(c)  Abatement. All nuisances described within this article shall be abated pursuant to nuisance chapter of this Code. When a dead or diseased tree which is alleged to constitute a nuisance is brought to the attention of the forester, the forester, in his or her discretion, may submit a written opinion to the director of the parks and recreation department or the director the department of business development services, whichever department has appropriate code enforcement jurisdiction over the property upon which such nuisance is located. Upon receiving a written opinion from the forester that any tree or part thereof is a nuisance, the director, or his or her designee, shall commence nuisance abatement proceedings pursuant to the nuisance chapter of this Code. In such cases where danger to the public is imminent, the director shall have the right, but not the obligation, to enter the property and abate the nuisance. 
Sec. 17-38. - Notice, violation and civil penalty. 
(a)  If any person violates this article or fails to comply with any provision of this article, the forester, or his designee, shall notify the person of the violation in writing. Said notice shall be delivered in person or by certified mail. The notice shall set forth the actions to be taken to correct the violation within fifteen (15) days. Failure of any person to correct the violation shall constitute an offense of this code. The forester may grant a written extension not to exceed sixty (60) days. Any person who disagrees with the finding of the forester may, prior to the expiration of the fifteen (15) period, or any extension, file a written appeal with the tree commission. An appeal shall be considered filed if delivered in person or certified mail to the tree commission. 
(b)  If the person notified fails to correct the violation or file an appeal with the tree commission within the allowable time period, the forester shall issue a summons so charging the person notified and requiring such person to appear in court for a hearing at a given time, place and date. Said summons shall be in the form of a written complaint setting forth the violation and the identity of the person complained against. Said summons shall be delivered in person or by certified mail. Municipal court, state court, and magistrate court shall have concurrent jurisdiction over violations of this article. 
(c)  If the court determines that the person summoned did violate this chapter, the court shall order mitigation as prescribed by subsection (d). In addition to mitigation, the court may impose a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation of the article. Each day during which any violation of the provisions of this article shall occur or continue shall be a separate violation. 
(d)  If, as the result of the violation of any provision of this article, the injury, mutilation, or death of a tree located on Macon-Bibb County-owned property or public rights-of-way is caused, the cost of repair or replacement of such tree shall be borne by the party in violation. The replacement value of trees and shrubs shall be determined in accordance with the tree replacement requirements. 
Sec. 17-39. - Emergencies. 
In case of official emergencies, such as windstorms, ice storms, or other disasters, the requirements of this division shall be waived so that the requirements of this article would in no way hinder private or public work to restore order in Macon-Bibb County. This work shall follow maintenance standards as outlined by the forester. 
Sec. 17-40. - Moving large objects. 
No person shall move any building or other large object which may injure trees or parts thereof in public rights-of-way or on Macon-Bibb County-owned property, without first having obtained the approval of the forester. 
Sec. 17-41. - Appeals. 
An appeal of a decision of the tree commission shall be taken to the municipal court. The municipal court, upon receipt of an appeal, shall have the authority and duty to consider and act upon the application. 
Secs. 17-42—17-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TOBESOFKEE RECREATION AREA 

Sec. 17-50. - Established. 
There is hereby established the "Tobesofkee Recreation Area," which is defined to mean that geographical area of Macon-Bibb County, title to which was acquired by the Bibb County pursuant to an agreement with the United States of America for the Tobesofkee project, including, but not limited to, the lake area, recreational areas, the dam, easements and other rights in land and property acquired for the project. 
Sec. 17-51. - Manager. 
There shall be a Manager of the Tobesofkee Recreation Area who shall be a representative of the governing authority of Macon-Bibb County to operate, maintain and supervise the Tobesofkee Recreation Area, and to enforce the regulations hereby enacted, together with such other regulations as may hereafter be adopted. The Manager shall serve at the pleasure of the Director of Parks and Recreation, and shall have such compensation and other emoluments as from time to time shall be fixed. He or she shall make statistical and progress reports to the governing authority as it shall direct with respect to the operation of the Tobesofkee Recreation Area, and shall account to the governing authority for all sums collected as fees or charges as well as for other public funds coming into his or her hands, at such intervals and in such manner as the governing authority may from time to time determine. He or she and his or her assistants and employees who handle public funds shall give such bond payable to Macon-Bibb County as from time to time shall be required. He or she may from time to time delegate duties to rangers and other recreation area personnel as he or she may determine. 
Sec. 17-52. - Violations of regulations. 
The Tobesofkee Recreation Area is hereby declared to be closed to any person or member of the public who violates the regulations specified in Article I of this Chapter. 
Sec. 17-53. - Penalty for violations. 
Any person who does any act prohibited by this article or who fails to do any act required by this article shall be deemed guilty of an offense and punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), by sentence to work on the streets or public works for a period not exceeding sixty (60) days or imprisonment for a term not exceeding fifty (50) days, any or all of these penalties in the discretion of the judge. Municipal court, state court, and magistrate court shall have concurrent jurisdiction over violations of this article. 
Sec. 17-54. - Annual permit; when available; privileges obtained. 
(a)  The governing authority of Macon-Bibb County may from time to time establish a fee and costs for the issuance of annual permits. 
(b)  Persons desiring to purchase an annual permit may do so upon payment of the fee currently in effect plus $1.00 as administrative costs subject to the following terms: 
(1)  Purchase of an annual permit will entitle the holder thereof, the holder's spouse, minor children and children over the age of 18 who reside with their parents and who are students or who are not wage earners to access to the parks and the lake in the Tobesofkee Recreation Area for general purposes. 
(2)  For the fee of $1.00, only one card per family will be issued. Upon payment of $2.00 per card, up to two additional cards may be issued to members of the immediate family of the person who purchased the initial card, but no card will be issued to any person under the age of 16 years. Each card shall show the name of the person to whom issued and shall contain such other information as the park superintendent may determine to be appropriate to provide a reasonable identification. 
(3)  Payment of the fee does not entitle the holder to engage in commercial activity. 
(4)  An annual permit will be valid for a period of 12 months without any limitation as to the number of days during the 12-month period upon which it may be used unless the same is previously revoked. 
(5)  Notwithstanding the preceding paragraph, annual permits will not be recognized as valid unless the bearer has on his or her person a driver's license or other document to demonstrate that the bearer and persons in the bearer's company are persons who are authorized to make use of the annual permit. 
(6)  The annual permit may be revoked for violation of the rules and regulations pertaining to the Lake Tobesofkee Recreation Area. 
(7)  In addition to the foregoing, the following rules and regulations apply to property abutting the 369-foot line around the Lake Tobesofkee Recreation Area or otherwise abutting property of Macon-Bibb County around the lake and to the owners of such property: 
a.  Persons who own property abutting the aforesaid 369-foot contour line on Macon-Bibb County property and who maintain docks or boathouses, either or both, below the 369-foot contour line or on Macon-Bibb County property are required, in addition to procuring the construction permit otherwise required, to obtain an annual permit as a condition to the construction and to the continued use of the area below the 369-foot contour line or Macon-Bibb County property for such docks or boathouses, either or both, and to pay the fee for such permit. 
b.  Such annual permits shall, upon payment of the fee prescribed therefore, be valid for a period of 12 months from the date of purchase and each such property owner shall, on or before such expiration date, renew such permit by paying the annual fee then currently prescribed so that permits will be continuously in force. 
c.  Any property owner who fails or refuses to renew the annual permit and pay the fee therefor as prescribed in this section on or before the due date therefore, shall be deemed delinquent and such fee shall thereupon bear interest at the rate of one percent per month or fraction thereof from its due date until paid. 
d.  In the event any property owner shall fail to pay the Macon-Bibb County the fee for the annual permit, such fee being hereby levied, within 90 days from its due date, then and in such event, the tax commissioner shall issue in the name of said board an execution against such delinquent property owner for the amount due and unpaid together with all costs thereon which costs are hereby fixed at $10.00, and each execution shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month or fraction thereof, the fraction of a month being charged as a full month. 
e.  The execution so issued shall bind and be a lien upon all real property of such delinquent property owner abutting the 369-foot contour line around the Lake Tobesofkee Recreation Area and shall be a special lien superior to all other liens except liens for ad valorem taxes upon such property. Such execution shall be collectible and defenses thereto may be made in the manner provided by law with respect to ad valorem taxes. 
f.  In the event a property owner has failed to pay the fees hereby levied for annual permits for two consecutive calendar years, and the second of such fees shall been delinquent for 12 months, Macon-Bibb County shall notify, by certified mail, return receipt requested, the property owner of such delinquency, and such notice shall contain a statement to the effect that the property owner is directed to remove the dock, boathouse, and other improvements placed upon the property at such property owner's expense within a period of 30 days from the date of such notice which shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested. If the property owner fails to remove such improvements within such 30-day period, Macon-Bibb County may remove the same, and charge the cost thereof to the property owner. The cost of such removal shall be evidenced by an execution to be issued by the commission which execution shall have the same rank, dignity and lien upon the real property of the owner abutting Macon-Bibb County property as that provided above for annual permit fees. 
g.  Liability for payment of the annual permit fees shall not be affected or abated by a change in ownership of property abutting the 369-foot contour line or otherwise abutting Macon-Bibb County property, but each purchaser of such property is hereby charged with notice that is such purchaser's responsibility to pay any accumulated an unpaid annual permit fees which may have accrued prior to his or her purchase of the property. The property so purchased shall be subject to the same lien as that above described, it being the intent hereof that a purchaser of property shall have the same obligations with respect to the payment of annual permit fees as such purchaser would have with the payment of ad valorem taxes. 
Sec. 17-55. - Docks, boathouses and seawalls. 
(a)  Definitions. 
Boathouse, as used in this article, a boathouse is an enclosed structure along the shoreline in which a boat is kept. 
Dock, as used in this article, a dock means a wooden-decked structure, supported on piles and used to give passengers access to vessels. 
(b)  General. Any proposed land disturbance above the 360-foot contour line (normal water elevation) within 25 feet of said line may require a buffer variance. The determination as to whether or not a buffer variance will be required is to be made by the state department of natural resources, environmental protection division or it's designee. This includes the construction of docks, boat launching facilities and seawalls. (O.C.G.A. § 12-7-1, DNR/EPD Rules and Regulations 391-3-7.) 
Persons who at the time of application thereof own property abutting 369-foot contour line of the Lake Tobesofkee Recreation Area and who hold current, valid, permits as described in section 17-54 and this section may construct a dock and/or boathouse at the 360-foot contour level upon the following conditions. 
(c)  Application. 
(1)  A person desiring to construct a dock or boathouse, either or both shall first make application to the Manager of the Tobesofkee Recreation Area on application forms provided by the same. In addition to the following, the applicant shall submit information prescribed by the Tobesofkee Recreation Area and the department of business development services. 
a.  A statement of the proposed location and length of a dock or boathouse as well as the height thereof which may not exceed the length and height hereinafter specified. 
b.  The plans and specifications by which the dock or boathouse, either or both are to be constructed shall be in such reasonable detail as may be prescribed by the department of business development services and shall be such as to make adequate provision for the safety of those using the dock or boathouse. 
(2)  Upon receipt of the application, plans and specifications by the Manager of Tobesofkee Recreation Area who shall forward same said documents to the Macon-Bibb County engineering Department; and they shall examine the same and visit the proposed site with the applicant. If they find that the application does not meet the location requirements or other requirements herein specified; they shall reject the same, stating in writing the reasons why it was rejected. 
(3)  Once the application is approved by the Macon-Bibb County engineering department, the applicant shall be forwarded to the business development services who shall examine the same together with the accompanying plans and specifications for compliance with applicable construction codes enforced in Macon-Bibb County. The department of business development services shall confer with the applicant if after the examination additional details or information is necessary to assure that the completed structure if built in accordance therewith will comply with such codes. Once the department approves the application, a construction permit shall be issued subject to fees as prescribed by the department of business development services and in accordance with the department's administrative procedures. 
(d)  Requirements. 
(1)  Any such dock or boathouse shall be located in front of the property or the person desiring to construct the same at a point which would place the entire structure between the sidelines of his or her property if such sidelines were extended to the nearest points on the 360-foot contour line and intersected with such contour line as nearly as possible at right angles. 
(2)  A dock or boathouse shall not be constructed where there is less than 100 feet of frontage at the 360-foot contour line. The shoreline will be measured from pin to pin. 
(3)  Docks or boathouses may have located thereon an enclosed area for recreational purposes, provided that it not exceed the maximum allotted boathouse dimensions. The total structure, including pilings, dock, boathouse and roof, shall extend no higher than 20 feet above the 360-foot contour line. Except for the installation of one water line to aid in the cleaning of fish and for similar purposes, there shall be no plumbing installed. Such area shall not be used for sleeping quarters or other human habitation, nor shall it contain bath or toilet facilities. No additional enclosed boathouses will be permitted. Open-sided boathouses will be permitted as long as they meet all other requirements and specification as set forth herein. Only one enclosed storage area may be located on open-sided boathouses. 
(4)  No dock shall be constructed any longer than is necessary to reach from the 360-foot contour line to a horizontal length of 40 feet, nor longer than is necessary to reach a ten-foot depth of water vertically, whichever is the shorter distance. As an additional limitation, no dock shall be constructed in such manner as to occupy in length or breadth more than 25 percent of the width of a slough or cove. 
(5)  Flotation docks and boathouses are not permitted. 
(6)  Whenever an existing dock or boathouse is to be replaced (or remodeled or repaired to an extent which exceeds in cost 50 percent of the value thereof), a new application shall be made in accordance with the procedures established in this section and such replacement, remodeling or reconstruction shall not occur until such time as all required approvals have been obtained. Existing boathouses may be repaired or replaced but not expanded. If an enclosed boathouse is torn down, destroyed or removed for any reason, any replacement shall be constructed in accordance with all current regulations and requirements of this section. 
(7)  If construction is not substantially commenced within six months after the final approval of an application, whether the same be for a new dock or boathouse, either or both, or for the repair, replacement or reconstruction of either or both, the permit shall expire, and the applicant shall not proceed until after having filed a new application and obtained approval thereof as provided in subsection (b). 
(8)  The annual permit required under section 17-54 and issued under the provisions of this section shall remain from its date as long as the dock and/or boathouse are properly constructed and maintained in a safe and presentable condition and for so long as the holder thereof is the owner of the property which enabled him to apply for the permit in the first instance. A permit issued under the provisions of this subsection will be transferred to a successor in title of such abutting land if there are no changes in the conditions which permitted the initial authorization and so long as the dock and/or boathouse are maintained in a presentable and safe condition. 
(9)  It shall be the responsibility of the owner to maintain docks and boathouses in a safe condition. All docks and boathouses are subject to periodic inspections by representatives of Tobesofkee Recreation Area. If a structure is found to be dilapidated or unsafe, the department of business development services shall be notified to inspect the same and to notify the responsible party of any repairs needed for continued use of the dock or boathouse. Failure to comply with such directions shall be grounds for revocation of the permit. 
(10)  Nevertheless it is a condition of the issuance of the permit that the holder thereof, or his or her successor in title, will nevertheless remove at his or her sole cost and expense any dock or boathouse and restore the area to its original condition upon 60 days written notice from the director of the department of business development services. This provision is made in view of the fact that the location of the dock and/or boathouse are upon public property and the owner of the abutting property acquires no vested right to continue to use and occupy such public property. 
(11)  Any person holding a permit for the construction, replacement, reconstruction or repair of a dock or boathouse shall be deemed to have a agreed to comply with all reasonable rules and regulations now or hereafter promulgated by Macon-Bibb County and the directions of the Manager of the Tobesofkee Recreation Area and the department of business development services with respect to the construction, maintenance or use of such dock or boathouse as well as with respect to the use of the lake or other areas of the Tobesofkee Recreation Area. 
(12)  No recreation area constructed in connection with a dock or boathouse shall at any time be used for human habitation. Recreational uses which generate noise, odors or other practices which constitute a nuisance shall be grounds for revocation of the permit herein granted and for ordering the owner to remove the facility. 
(13)  Reserved. 
(14)  The terms "owner," "responsible party," "applicant," "holder of the permit" and similar words and phrases shall be construed to mean the person owning private property abutting the 369-foot contour line and the Tobesofkee Recreation Area, and are not intended to import any ownership by anyone of the area between the 360- and 369-foot contour lines. "Owner" also designated the person for compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(15)  Any person aggrieved by action of the Manager, Tobesofkee Recreation Area, or the department of business development services under the provisions of this section may appeal in writing to the commission within 30 days after receipt of such written notice of a decision of either official and the commission shall hold a hearing upon the appeal at which the appellant shall be entitled to be present and present evidence to support the appeal. The decision of the commission on the appeal shall be final. 
(16)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, and notwithstanding any limitation in the building code of Macon-Bibb County, the department of business development services is constituted as the agency for the enforcement of the Tobesofkee regulations to the extent that they relate to electrical installations to and from docks and boathouses and as they relate to regulations respecting the potable water systems for docks and boathouses. The director of the department of business development services, or his or her designee, is hereby vested with full authority and power to enforce the provisions of the building code including the power to issue summonses or citations for violations of such codes. The director, or his or her designee, is hereby authorized to administer the provisions of the building code, to make inspections and to take such action as necessary, proper and convenient to cause violators of the code to be punished. 
(e)  Specific requirements for docks or boathouses. 
(1)  Only one boat dock or boathouse is permitted on each lot. Permanent structures shall be a minimum of 15 feet from side property lines. 
(2)  Boat docks or boathouses shall extend no further than 40 feet from the 360-foot contour line. A shorter length may be required where a narrow cove is involved or if the dock would extend in front of an adjacent lot. Under no circumstances will a dock be permitted where access of adjacent property owners would be limited. Overall concerns for safety shall dictate the location and length of docks which will be approved by the Lake Tobesofkee Manager or his or her designated agent. 
(3)  Docks shall be stationary. (No floating docks will be permitted.) 
(4)  Docks or boathouses shall comply with the following: 
a.  Maximum of six-foot wide cat walk. 
b.  Maximum platform size shall be 12 feet by 20 feet. 
c.  If a dock (walkway) and boathouse are constructed as a single unit the width shall be no greater than 30 feet. 
d.  Maximum interior dimension of the boathouse shall be 24 feet by 26 feet. 
e.  Maximum extension into the lake is 40 feet. 
f.  Maximum roof height is 20 feet above the 360-foot contour line (normal elevation). 
g.  Minimum size of water line is one-inch and must be used only for cleaning fish. 
h.  No sanitary plumbing is permitted, nor can recreation area be used for sleeping purposes or human habitation. 
(5)  Boat lifts attached to docks must be approved prior to installation. A maximum of two full-sized boat lifts will be allowed per dock as long as the overall length is within the required guidelines and is approved by the Manager of the Tobesofkee Recreation Area or his or her designee. The boat lift cannot be placed closer than 15 feet from the adjoining property line. Each full-sized lift may have a matching canopy frame. The frame must be dome-shaped. No pitch frame canopy will be allowed. The color and type of material must be approved by the Manager of the Tobesofkee Recreation Area or his or her designee prior to installation. Natural colors are recommended (dark blue or dark green). 
(6)  Personal watercraft (PWC) ramps must be approved prior to installation. A maximum of two PWC ramps may be attached to a dock or boathouse as long as the overall length is within the required guidelines and is approved by the Manager of the Tobesofkee Recreation Area or his or her designee. The PWC ramp may be constructed of wood or high-density polyethylene and must be maintained in a safe and presentable condition. 
(f)  Requirements for seawalls. Persons who at the time of application thereof own property abutting the 369-foot contour line of the Tobesofkee Recreation Area and who hold current, valid permits as described in section 17-54 may construct a seawall at the 360-foot contour level upon the following conditions: The construction of a new seawall may require a buffer variance permit from the department of natural resources, environmental protection division. 
(1)  A person desiring to construct a seawall shall first make application to the Manager of the Tobesofkee Recreation Area. In addition to the following, the applicant shall submit information prescribed by the Tobesofkee Recreation Area and the department of business development services. 
(2)  Seawall construction will require proper erosion and sedimentation controls. After completion of the seawall and until the vegetative buffer is restored, a silt fence must be installed and maintained just behind the new seawall at ground level. 
(3)  Seawall construction plans should show the following: 
a.  The length of shoreline to be fronted by the seawall. 
b.  The type of foundation to be installed and depth below ground level. 
c.  The type of materials to be used for construction of the seawall. 
d.  The height of the seawall should be no higher than necessary to stabilize shoreline. 
(4)  The distance between the proposed seawall and the existing shoreline shall not exceed two feet. 
(5)  The location of the proposed seawall must be staked at 25-foot intervals in order for inspectors to assure the original contour is adhered to as close as possible. For very irregular shoreline, stakes shall be no more than ten feet apart. 
(6)  Creosote timbers are prohibited for new seawall construction. 
Any variance from the requirements as set forth in this section must be approved by the commission. 
Sec. 17-56. - Launching facilities and community boat docks to serve subdivisions and apartments. 
Where there are subdivisions or apartment properties whose boundaries abut the 369-foot contour line at Lake Tobesofkee, the property owners' association of the subdivision or the apartment owner or a tenants' association may make application to the commission for approval to construct boat launching facilities and/or community boat docks. In determining whether a permit will be granted, the commission shall be authorized to take into account all relevant facts affecting the lake, the revenues derived therefrom, impact on other property owners, as well as other relevant considerations. If approved, board launching facilities and/or community boat docks may be established under the following conditions: 
(1)  The applicant shall be fully responsible for the maintenance of the boat-launching facilities and/or community boat docks and preservation of safety and cleanliness. 
(2)  The applicant agrees to abide by all rules and regulations as set forth by this Code and the Manager of the Tobesofkee Recreation Area. 
(3)  Upon failure of the applicant or successor to maintain the facility or boat dock in a clean, safe and aesthetically satisfactory condition, the permit may be revoked by Macon-Bibb County. 
(4)  In determining whether to issue a permit, the governing authority may take into consideration this entire article, and particularly subsection 17-55(d)(10). 
(5)  Approval of such a facility and/or boat dock and its subsequent operation by the applicant or a successor to the applicant shall entitle the residents of the subdivision or apartment complex to use the lake for swimming, fishing, boating or skiing purposes but only if such users hold a current valid annual permit as described in subsection 17-54(b). 
Sec. 17-57. - Rights granted to property owners; reservations. 
(a)  Persons owning property abutting the 369-foot contour line around Lake Tobesofkee are hereby authorized to use so much of the Tobesofkee Park property as lies between the 369-foot contour line and the 360-foot contour line and between the sidelines of the property of such persons which would exist if the property line began at the present terminus of such property lines at the 369-foot contour line and extended to the 360-foot contour line so that such extended side property lines would intersect with the 360-foot contour line at the nearest point so that such extended sideline will be the shortest distance between the 369-foot contour line and 360-foot contour line. If, by reason of physical circumstances such as land contours, the application of the foregoing rule would deny a person owning property abutting the 369-foot contour line reasonable access to the 360-foot contour line, or would otherwise produce a manifest absurdity, the Manager of the Tobesofkee Recreation Area is authorized, with due consideration to the effects on adjoining property owners, to specify how the sidelines of the property of such owner will be extended so as to afford some access to the 360-foot contour line. However, in order to construct a dock or boathouse there must be a minimum width of 100 feet of water frontage at the 360-foot contour line. 
(b)  The use and occupancy which may be made by abutting property owners shall be in common with that of the general public and shall be such as is afforded to the public with respect to other Macon-Bibb County property and rights-of-way. 
(c)  Notwithstanding, Macon-Bibb County reserves the full and complete right to flood at will such area, and to install therein public utilities, including, but not limited to, water and sewer lines and to maintain the same or to permit the Macon-Bibb County water and sewerage authority to do so. Macon-Bibb County further reserves full right to make such use of the area as it shall deem necessary or convenient in the maintenance of the lake itself. 
(d)  Macon-Bibb County shall have no liability to property owners or third parties by any use made of the above-described area by owners of abutting property. 
(e)  Nothing in this section shall be construed as granting any right to cut trees, dig ditches, channels or otherwise make cuts, fill, excavate or otherwise alter the natural elevation or to erect and maintain fences in the area below the 369-foot contour line, but on the contrary, all of such activities are specifically prohibited except with the specific approval of Macon-Bibb County after written application therefor giving adequate justification; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall be deemed to require the removal of any fences which were in existence and which were used for the enclosure of cattle at the time the Tobesofkee Recreation Area was acquired by Bibb County; and, provided further, that if at any time the land formerly used for the grazing of cattle has changed in its use, then and at that time, the fences shall be removed and shall not thereafter be maintained. 
(f)  Tree removal. 
(1)  To protect the vegetative buffer surrounding the lake, the removal of any trees with a diameter of more than three inches is prohibited without prior written approval of the commission. 
(2)  Native ornamental trees such as dogwoods, magnolias, flowering fruit trees, etc. of any size, may not be removed without prior written approval of the commission. 
(3)  Tree removal requests must include a tree survey performed by a registered forester, professional landscape architect or arborist, which shows all trees in the proposed area, the specific trees to be removed, the total number of trees to be removed, the value of the trees to be removed and the process by which they will be removed. 
(4)  If tree removal involves significant earth disturbance, proper erosion and sedimentation controls must be followed, including installing a silt fence to protect the shoreline and re-vegetative plan. 
(5)  All portions of the tree/s (limbs, stumps, etc.) must be properly removed from the lot. Dumping, burying, or otherwise disposing of any portion of the tree on Macon-Bibb County property, lease lots, or lake is prohibited. 
(g)  Dredging. 
(1)  Dredging will be permitted up to 500 cubic yards per lot. Greater amounts will require approval from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and additional agencies. 
(2)  Dredging plans must be submitted and approved before work begins. A dredging permit must be obtained prior to any dredging activity. 
(3)  By obtaining a dredging permit from Macon-Bibb County the permittee agrees to: 
a.  Abide by all governmental rules, laws, regulations, directives and statutes. 
b.  Acquire all necessary governmental permits or licenses, which may include, but shall not be limited to, a soil distributing activity permit. 
(4)  Applicants must provide the volume of material to be removed. A qualified engineer or surveyor should determine this information (especially for large projects over 100 cubic yards). An estimate sheet is to be attached to the permit request. 
(5)  Removal of original lake bottom is prohibited. The sole purpose for dredging is to remove silt or sedimentation that has accumulated over time. 
(6)  The material removed from the lake shall be disposed of in upland area so as to avoid re-entry into the lake. 
(h)  Macon-Bibb County grants only such use of the area described in this section as it may lawfully grant. 
Sec. 17-58. - No vested interests. 
No person shall have or acquire any rights in land or any vested interest to the continuance of any access permit or a permit for the construction and maintenance of a dock or boathouse nor to the continuance of these regulations in their present form. This provision is necessary for the protection of the public property and all permits for any such purposes are expressly made subject to this section. 
Sec. 17-59. - Authority vested in superintendent, rangers and staff. 
In addition to such other powers and authority as they may have, the superintendent of the Lake Tobesofkee Recreation Area, the rangers and other members of the staff (including, but not limited to, lifeguards) are hereby expressly authorized and empowered to issue citations to person violating any of the rules and regulations of the Lake Tobesofkee Recreation Area contained in this Code. Immediately after issuing the citation, the person issuing the same shall forward a copy to the appropriate prosecuting official of Macon-Bibb County for appropriate further action. Municipal court, state court, and magistrate court shall have concurrent jurisdiction over violations of this article. 
Sec. 17-60. - Rules and regulations. 
(a)  The rules and regulations applicable to the Lake Tobesofkee Recreation Area are as follows: 
General. 
(1)  The cardinal rule of conduct for all persons utilizing the Lake Tobesofkee Recreation Area ("the area") is that of common courtesy and respect for the rights of others. Most problems can be avoided if this rule is recognized. 
(2)  No person may be admitted to or use the facilities of Lake Tobesofkee without payment of the appropriate fee. Evidence of fee payment shall be retained by every person admitted on a daily basis and shall be produced upon request of area personnel or other authorized individual. 
(3)  All persons using the Tobesofkee Recreation Area are expected to comply with all of the laws of the state regulating parks, recreation areas, camping, boating, skiing and fishing, as well as with the applicable rules of the state department of natural resources and of Macon-Bibb County. 
(4)  Hunting, trapping or otherwise pursuing or catching any wildlife within the Tobesofkee Recreation Area is strictly prohibited. 
(5)  Persons having boats in the water at the marina and at the apartment complexes on the lake must possess a current valid annual permit. All boats entering the marina for the purpose of boating will be required to purchase tickets at a gate house prior to entry, or must be the holder of a current annual permit. 
(6)  All children under 16 years of age must wear a helmet when riding a bicycle anywhere inside parks. 
(7)  Claystone and Arrowhead Parks open at 6:00 a.m. and close at 9:30 p.m. throughout the year. Sandy Beach Park hours vary from time to time according to the season. Area office hours are from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. Sandy Beach Waterpark shall operate 8:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. Monday through Sunday during the water park season which shall be from Memorial Day weekend through Labor Day weekend. 
(8)  Off-road vehicles (ATVs, dirt bikes, go carts, motorized scooters, etc.) are prohibited. Golf carts are likewise prohibited with the exception of those utilized by disabled individuals and displaying a valid handicap sticker. 
(9)  The possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages within the Tobesofkee Recreation Area is prohibited, except under special circumstances approved by the commission and within areas designated by the Manager. 
(10)  Discharge of any firearm within the Tobesofkee Recreation Area shall be unlawful, unless express written permission for such has been authorized by the commission. 
(11)  Possession of any explosive substance, including fireworks, within the Tobesofkee Recreation Area shall be unlawful unless express written permission for such has been authorized by the commission. 
(12)  Motorized vehicles may be operated only upon designated roadways and shall be parked only in officially designated areas. 
(13)  No person shall drive any motor vehicle of any character on the roadways of the Tobesofkee Recreation Area at a speed greater than 15 miles per hour. 
(14)  Pets are not permitted within the Tobesofkee Recreation Area unless on a leash. Under no circumstances are pets permitted on beach areas. 
(15)  The Macon-Bibb County boat ramp docks are to be used only for assistance in launching or removing boats from the water. Use of the boat ramp dock for sunbathing and the placing thereon of lawn chairs and other equipment are prohibited. 
(16)  No person, firm or corporation shall deposit within the Tobesofkee Recreation Area in any of the parks below the 369-foot contour line any dirt, rock, debris or waste matter whether it is solid waste matter, garbage, human waste or other material, which might contaminate the ground or the lake. All waste matter shall be disposed of in approved facilities. 
(17)  Every person shall at all times obey and comply with directions given by all official regulatory signs posted within the area. 
(18)  Utilization of the Tobesofkee Recreation Area and its facilities is at the risk of the user. Macon-Bibb County assumes no responsibility for injury to persons or property arising from the utilization of the Tobesofkee Recreation Area. 
(19)  Persons wishing to utilize a picnic shelter may reserve a shelter in advance by contacting the area office and paying a reservation fee. Shelters not reserved in advance are available on a first come, first serve basis. Payment of a shelter reservation fee does not entitle anyone to enter the park free of charge. Each person desiring to enter the park shall pay the regular admission fee. 
Camping. 
(20)  Campsites may be reserved by contacting the area office. 
(21)  Camping in areas other than designated camping areas is prohibited unless express, written authorization of the Manager is obtained. 
(22)  Payment of camping fees entitles the authorized persons to make use of campsites, beaches, and other facilities not requiring any other additional fees. Payment of camping fees covers admission to other site parks in addition to the one in which the paying parties are camping. 
(23)  Persons desiring to camp must pay camping fees in advance and obtain a permit from the gate stations; however, campers entering after 10:00 p.m. and prior to 6:00 a.m. may camp for the night, provided camping and other fees are paid not later than 9:00 am. on the morning immediately following entry. 
(24)  Check out time for camping is 12:00 noon. Campers remaining after 12:00 noon on any day will be charged for an additional day's camping. 
(25)  Camping is limited to 14 consecutive nights at any one site. After 14 consecutive nights, campers and the unit (RV, camper, trailer, etc.) must move to another site designated by the Manager (Waterfront sites in Arrowhead Park and the pull-through sites in Claystone Park are not included). Campers may stay a total of seven nights within a 30-night period at the waterfront sites in Arrowhead Park and pull-through sites at Claystone Park. After a total of seven nights during any 30-night period, campers and the unit (RV, camper, trailer, etc.) must vacate these sites for 30 consecutive nights before re-occupying any one of these sites. 
(26)  Campers who bring boats must pay the daily boat fee regardless of whether the boat is in the water or at a designated parking area. Boats and boat trailers shall not be parked at the campsites. 
(27)  Visitors to any occupied campsite must pay the general admission fee required of all persons. Issuance of a camping permit does not entitle visitors to enter the park area free of charge. 
(28)  Tent camping is permitted in RV sites. Camping occupancy is limited to one camping unit; (RV, pop-up, trailer or family tent) and one additional small tent per campsite. Each campsite is permitted two additional vehicles. Tent camping is not permitted in pull-through and sewer access sites. 
(29)  The use of major electrical appliances such as, but not limited to, refrigerators, washing machines, ice makers, and so forth is not permitted outside any camping unit (RV, pop-up, trailer, or tent). 
(30)  Camp fires are permitted only in designated areas and only when supervised by adults. 
(31)  Persons desiring to arrange for group camping should consult the area office in advance of applicable rules. 
(32)  Loud, boisterous conduct, including playing radios or other sound-producing devices at loud levels, is prohibited. Disorderly conduct, drunkenness, or obscene language is prohibited. 
(33)  Oversized vehicles such as tractor trailer trucks, automotive wreckers, etc., shall not be parked at camp sites. This prohibition does not apply to motor homes used for camping. 
(34)  Persons registering to camp must be 21 years of age or older. 
(35)  After 9:00 p.m. all children under 16 years of age must be accompanied by an adult unless they are at their campsite. Parents shall be responsible for the actions of their children. 
(36)  Pets are allowed in the campground if kept on a leash and attended at all times. Unleashed pets and those whose behavior disturbs other campers must be removed from the park by the owner. Under no circumstances are pets permitted on beach areas. 
Fishing, boating and skiing. 
(37)  Except as provided in subsection (43), fishing, boating and skiing are authorized only for those people who hold a current day's ticket or a current annual permit in their possession. 
(38)  Fishermen, boaters, and skiers are cautioned to comply with all state and local regulations respecting those activities. 
(39)  Persons desiring to night fish after park hours must purchase tickets before park gates close, or have a current annual permit. 
(40)  Fishing is prohibited in swimming areas when the lake is open to swimmers. 
(41)  Fishing from public boat docks when boats are present is prohibited. 
(42)  Skiers and operators of boats towing skiers must exercise due care for the safety and welfare of others. Skiing in lake coves is specifically prohibited. 
(43)  Persons 65 years of age or older may fish without payment of an admission fee, provided they have obtained a senior citizen's pass at the area office. 
(44)  For the present, no limitation is placed upon the horsepower of motors. However, Macon-Bibb County reserves the right to place limits on the size of motorboat motors should the commission determine that to be in the public interest. 
(45)  All fishermen must carry licenses, as required by the state. 
(46)  No trout lines, set hooks, baskets, nets, jugs, or any type of commercial fishing gear shall be permitted. Cast nets and landing nets may be used in compliance with state laws.
