(47)  Fishing from bridges, right-of-way of roads and boat ramp docks is prohibited. 
(48)  No vessel, including sail boards, shall be permitted to enter any swimming area or any area designated as a no boat area. 
Swimming. 
(49)  Swimming at all park sites must be confined to areas designated for that purpose. 
(50)  Diving or jumping from public docks and bridges is prohibited. 
(51)  Swimming is permitted during daylight hours only. Persons choosing to swim when lifeguards are not on duty do so at their own risk. 
(52)  Scuba diving in Lake Tobesofkee is prohibited unless the express written permission of the Manager is obtained. 
(b)  Official copies of these rules and regulations are maintained in the office of the Clerk of Commission and the office of the Manager of the Tobesofkee Recreation Area. 
(c)  If any provision of this section is in genuine conflict with any state or federal law or requirement, the conflict shall be resolved in accordance with law. 
( Ord. of 6-20-2017(2) ) 
Chapter 18 - PERSONNEL 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Statement of policy. 
It is the policy of Macon-Bibb County Government to provide equal employment opportunity to all qualified persons; to prohibit discrimination in employment because of race, color, religion, age, disability, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, veteran's status or national origin; and to promote the full realization of equal employment opportunity through a positive, continuing program in each department and agency of the Macon-Bibb County Government. The policy of equal opportunity applies to every aspect of County employment, policy and practice. 
( Ord. No. O-15-0015, § 1, 3-17-2015 ) 
Sec. 18-2. - Definitions. 
As used in this Article, the following terms have the following meanings: 
(1)  "Applicant" means any person considered or who requests to be considered for employment by Macon-Bibb County. 
(2)  "County agency" means any office, department, agency, board or commission of Macon-Bibb County. 
(3)  "Employee" means all persons engaged in the operation or conduct of any business, whether as owner, any member of owner's family, partner, associate, agent, manager, or representative, and any and all other persons engaged or employed in said business. 
(4)  "Employment" means any occupation, vocation, job, work for pay or employment, including temporary or seasonal work, contracted work, contingent work and work through the services of a temporary or other employment agency. "Employment" shall not, for the purposes of this chapter, include membership in any law enforcement agency. 
(5)  "Conviction" means any sentence arising from a verdict or plea of guilty or nolo contendere, including a sentence of incarceration, a suspended sentence, a sentence of probation or a sentence of unconditional discharge. 
(6)  "Inquiry" means any direct or indirect conduct intended to gather information, using any mode of communication. 
(7)  "Interview" means any direct contact by the employer with the applicant, whether in person or by telephone, to discuss the employment being sought or the applicant's qualifications. 
( Ord. No. O-15-0015, § 1, 3-17-2015 ) 
Sec. 18-3. - Ban-the-box. 
In connection with printed and/or on-line employment application forms of Macon-Bibb County, it shall be an unlawful discriminatory practice for them to contain a "box" or inquiry regarding an applicant's prior criminal history. 
( Ord. No. O-15-0015, § 1, 3-17-2015 ) 
Sec. 18-4. - Unlawful discriminatory practice—Ex-offenders. 
To prohibit unfair discrimination against persons previously convicted of one or more criminal offenses: 
(a)  In connection with the licensing or employment of any person, it shall be an unlawful discriminatory practice for Macon-Bibb County to make any inquiry regarding or to require any person to disclose or reveal any criminal conviction(s) during the application process. The application process shall begin when the applicant inquires about the employment being sought and shall end when an employer has accepted an employment application. 
(b)  It shall further be an unlawful discriminatory practice for Macon-Bibb County to make any inquiry regarding, or to require any person to disclose or reveal any criminal convictions against such person before the first interview. 
(c)  Prior to an applicant being selected for hire with Macon-Bibb County, a background check and drug test is required for consideration of employment. 
( Ord. No. O-15-0015, § 1, 3-17-2015 ) 
Sec. 18-5. - Adverse employment decision—ex-offenders. 
Once the applicant has been deemed qualified for the position for which he/she applied, Macon-Bibb County may then inquire into the applicant's criminal history. If Macon-Bibb County makes an adverse employment decision, including, but not limited to, the refusal, rescission, or revocation of a conditional offer of employment, or termination of employment, after the criminal history inquiry is conducted, Macon-Bibb County shall within a reasonable period of time, not to exceed thirty (30) days: 
(a)  Notify the applicant of the adverse employment decision; and 
(b)  Provide the applicant with a photocopy of the results of the criminal inquiry, indicating the particular conviction(s) that relate(s) to the position's responsibilities. 
( Ord. No. O-15-0015, § 1, 3-17-2015 ) 
Sec. 18-6. - Dissemination of criminal history. 
Any information obtained by Macon-Bibb County that pertains to an applicant's criminal history: 
(a)  Shall remain confidential; 
(b)  Shall only be shared with individuals that have a need to know the contents for the purpose of evaluating candidates or employees in a manner consistent with this section, except as dictated by law; 
(c)  Shall not be used, distributed, or disseminated by Macon-Bibb County for any use other than those permitted under this policy; and 
(d)  Shall not be used, distributed, or disseminated by Macon-Bibb County to any other entity or individual, except as dictated by state or federal law. 
( Ord. No. O-15-0015, § 1, 3-17-2015 ) 
Sec. 18-7. - Exemptions. 
Macon-Bibb County hiring for positions where certain convictions or violations are a bar to employment in that position under state or federal law, including but not limited to positions that involve work with children and positions in law enforcement, shall not be constrained at any time from asking questions about those convictions or violations. Furthermore, positions with the Macon-Bibb County Fire Department shall also be exempt from the provisions of this Article. 
( Ord. No. O-15-0015, § 1, 3-17-2015 ) 
Secs. 18-8—18-31. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SOCIAL SECURITY AND RETIREMENT 

Sec. 18-32. - Social security authorization. 
It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of Macon-Bibb County to extend at the earliest date possible under the agreement entered into by the state and the Federal Social Security Administration, to the appropriate employees and officials thereof, and its instrumentalities, not excluded by law or by this division, the benefits of the system of old age and survivors insurance as authorized by the federal social security act, the state enabling act, and amendments thereto. In pursuance of such policy, and for that purpose, Macon-Bibb County shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws and regulations. 
Sec. 18-33. - Agreements authorized. 
The mayor is hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the employees' retirement system of the state for coverage of such employees and officials as provided for in section 18-32, to include any employees, namely, who are ineligible for membership in Macon-Bibb County's officers' and employees' pension plan, that are in positions covered by a public retirement system, in the manner by such law provided. 
Sec. 18-34. - Employee contributions. 
Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees and officials for the purpose provided for in section 18-32 are hereby authorized to be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the state agency. 
Sec. 18-35. - Macon-Bibb County contributions. 
There shall be appropriated from general funds such amounts at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations for employer's contributions, administrative expenses, and such funds shall be paid over to the state employees' retirement system in accordance with regulations established by such agency. 
Sec. 18-36. - Records. 
Macon-Bibb County shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
Sec. 18-37. - Exclusions. 
There is hereby excluded from this division any authority to make any agreement with respect to any position, or any employee or official not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
Sec. 18-38. - Future authorizations. 
All future authorizations or adoptions of new provisions of the federal social security act, the appropriate state enabling act thereunder, and any new state and federal laws or regulations thereunder, may be adopted by a resolution of the commission. 
Secs. 18-39—18-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE DEPARTMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-56. - Applications for employment; investigation and examination of applicants; qualifications; list of qualified applicants. 
(a)  Receipt of application. The department of human resources shall receive all applications for employment with the fire departments on Macon-Bibb County employment application forms, regardless of whether a vacancy exists at the time of application. 
(b)  Investigation, physical examination. The director, department of human resources, shall cause to be made a thorough investigation of the character, experience, background and physical fitness, including a physical condition test, of all applicants, which investigation shall include but not be limited to an investigation of police record, all previous employment, reputation in neighborhood of past and present places of residence, personal habits, military record, educational background and any other pertinent statement or statements contained in the application for employment. 
(c)  Minimum education, age and personal qualifications. All applicants for employment with the fire department shall have at least a high school education or its equivalent recognized by the state department of education, or, in the case of firefighter applicants, the adult basic learning examination, form A, level III may be substituted for a high school education or equivalency. Applicants receiving a required certified learning level on the examination will be acceptable for further employment processing. Applications may be accepted from any legal resident of the United States. However, all personnel governed by this chapter must live within a twenty-six-mile radius of the city hall to meet emergency reaction times when they arise. A statement must be signed by each applicant that he or she understands and will comply with this requirement. Certificates will be maintained by the chief or the department of human resources. All applicants must also be a minimum age requirements of 18 years for the fire department. 
(d)  Rejection of application. In addition to the requirements of subsection (c) above, an applicant shall be denied employment hereunder for failure to meet any of the following requirements; or be denied reapplication for failure to meet the following requirements unless reapplication is made within the established time limits and the failure is of a nature that it can be corrected: 
(1)  Have a valid state driver's license; 
(2)  Not have been convicted for an offense under state or federal law for which the applicant could have served any time in confinement; 
(3)  Not have committed five (5) or more traffic offenses in the last twelve (12) months for which a fine of over twenty-five dollars ($25.00) was imposed; 
(4)  Be certified by a police department polygraph operator as satisfactorily answering a standard list of required questions; 
(5)  Not have been dishonorably discharged from the armed services; 
(6)  Pass a human resources department administered physical condition test, provided the test has an adverse impact factor for the qualifying of female applicants; 
(7)  Not have been dismissed from public service for cause; 
(8)  Not have made a false statement of fact or attempted fraud or deception in his or her application or other required documents; 
(10)  Have passed the physical examination required in subsection (b) above; and 
(11)  Pass the assessment center evaluation examination. 
(e)  Examination procedure. The examinations shall be used to determine the fitness of applicants and may be written, oral, physical or in the form of a demonstration of skill or any combination of these and shall be of a character to fairly test and determine the relative fitness and ability of applicants to perform the actual duties of the class or position to which they seek appointment. 
(f)  Fire applicants. The Fire Civil Service Board shall review the application and all information and records on each initial applicant. The Fire Civil Service Board will certify to the chief those applicants who meet the employment standards and are eligible for further consideration together with written findings on any applicant who is not recommended. The chief of the department will make the final decision. 
(g)  List of qualified applicants to be kept. All applicants who have successfully passed the requirements to become a firefighter will be listed in alphabetical order. A list of such applicants will be certified by the director of human resources and furnished to the chief. 
(h)  Selection from list. Whenever vacancies occur in either the fire department, the chief concerned shall select the number needed from the list and submit the names to the mayor for approval to employ. 
( Ord. No. O-14-0036, § 1, 6-17-2014 ) 
Sec. 18-57. - Training program; probationary period. 
(a)  Duration, course of training. After selection for employment with the fire department, the person shall then undergo prescribed training. The course of training shall be determined and approved by the chief. 
(b)  Unsatisfactory performance by trainee. Any trainee whose performance is unsatisfactory during the aforesaid training period shall be brought before the chief and after explanation of the deficiency in question by the training officer, the chief shall determine whether the trainee shall be retained in the training program or dismissed. 
(c)  Assignment to duty. Upon satisfactory completion of the required training program, trainees shall be sworn to faithfully perform their duties by the chief and shall be assigned to duty on a probationary status. 
(d)  Duration of probationary status. After the completion of three hundred sixty-five (365) days of satisfactory probationary service, probationary employees shall be eligible to be promoted to nonprobationary status by official action of the mayor, as classified career employees of their respective departments; provided, however, that the chief may, with the approval of the mayor, extent the probationary service of an employee for a period not to exceed one hundred eighty (180) days if such action is deemed to be in the best interest of Macon-Bibb County and the employee. 
Sec. 18-58. - Performance evaluation. 
(a)  Anniversary performance evaluation. All classified career employees of the fire departments shall be rated on performance no less than once each year on the anniversary date of employment. 
(b)  Performance rating forms. The performance rating forms used shall be those approved by the chief and the director, department of human resources. 
(c)  Trainees. Trainees shall be given a written performance evaluation report by the department training officer at the end of their initial training period. This report shall be signed by the trainee and made a part of his personnel records. 
(d)  Probationary employees. Probationary employees shall be given a written performance evaluation at the end of three (3), six (6) and nine (9) months. Following satisfactory completion of their probationary period they shall be given a full year's performance evaluation on their anniversary date. 
(e)  Nonprobationary employees. Nonprobationary employees shall receive a yearly performance evaluation on their anniversary date. 
(f)  Rating by immediate supervisor. Each person shall be rated by his immediate supervisor in the chain of command, and shall be endorsed by the next three (3) supervisors in the chain of command. A failure of any endorsing supervisor to agree with the evaluating supervisor's evaluation shall automatically place the performance evaluation in an appeal status. 
(g)  Evaluator. Each evaluator shall be a minimum of one rank higher than the person rated and each endorser shall be at least one rank higher than the first and subsequent endorser. 
(h)  Transferred employees. Employees transferred from one (1) supervisor to another shall be rated by the releasing supervisor on an interim rating form approved by the chief when the releasing supervisor has supervised the employee thirty (30) or more work days. This evaluation shall be signed by the employee and made available to the new supervisor. 
(i)  Criteria for promotion. To be eligible to stand for any promotion examination or to qualify for promotion from a promotion register, an employee must have been rated as competent or better on his or her last annual performance evaluation, with the preceding annual performance evaluation rated at no less than satisfactory. 
Sec. 18-59. - Performance evaluation appeal. 
(a)  No appeal shall be permitted when the evaluator and subsequent endorsers agree on the evaluation. 
(b)  If one (1) endorser out of three (3) disagrees with the evaluator's evaluation, the employee's evaluation shall automatically be appealed to an evaluation appeal committee. 
(c)  The evaluation appeal committee shall be made up of a nonvoting presiding officer, who shall be the director, department of personnel or a designee of the director, and two senior officers, two (2) sergeants, and one (1) private, none of whom have been directly associated with the appealing officer. The voting members of the committee shall be appointed by the mayor or county manager. 
(d)  The evaluation appeal committee has the right to request appearances of other employees who have knowledge of the appealing employee's performance. The decision of the committee shall be forwarded to the chief for review and concurrence or nonconcurrence. 
(e)  In the event of nonconcurrence with a recommended evaluation change the original evaluation shall be retained. There shall be no appeal of the chief's decision. 
Sec. 18-60. - Declaration of position vacancy. 
Subject to the requirements of Sec. 18-77(e)(1), the chief of the fire department shall fill vacated positions above the entry level positions from the appropriate promotional registry, or post for examination the vacant positions within thirty (30) calendar days of the occurrence of the vacancy, or shall recommend to the mayor that the vacated position be abolished and removed from the authorized budgeted organization. 
( Ord. No. O-14-0036, § 2, 6-17-2014 ) 
Sec. 18-61. - Reemployment of members; entitlement to seniority point credit. 
Members of the fire department whose employment is terminated for any reason shall be eligible for reemployment only upon qualification and selection as provided in this chapter for new members and upon reemployment such members shall not be entitled for seniority point credit for promotion purposes for the time served prior to the date of reemployment. 
Sec. 18-62. - Maintenance of position. 
(a)  Physical examination. The chief of the fire department or the mayor may require any member of the department rated as a classified career employee to take a thorough physical examination if deemed necessary. Such examination shall be conducted by a physician selected by the mayor for conducting the examination and the cost shall be borne by Macon-Bibb County. The employee required to take such physical examination shall present a certificate from the examining physician stating whether or not the employee is physically able to fulfill the duties of his position with the department. If the employee is ruled physically unable to perform his duties, the following actions may be taken as appropriate: 
(1)  Placement on accrued sick leave pending clearance by a physician to return to work; 
(2)  Retirement under the disability retirement feature of the pension plan upon committee approval; 
(3)  Early retirement; or 
(4)  Termination. 
(b)  Program of study. All levels of supervisors in the fire department shall maintain a program of study in fire department management and operational fields in accordance with the minimum recommended standards established by resolution of the commission. 
(c)  Physical fitness standards. 
(1)  Applicants for employment in the fire department must meet the established minimum physical standards for the job classification for which they apply. As a condition of continued employment, all classified career employees in the fire department must meet the established minimum physical standards for their particular classification. 
(2)  The fire chief, in conjunction with a physician, shall have the authority to formulate and establish the appropriate minimum physical standards for each particular job description within the department. Such standards shall bear a reasonable relationship to the requirements of the particular job. 
(3)  The minimum standards of fitness shall be applied equally to all applicants or employees within a particular job description. 
(4)  Physical fitness training program. 
a.  If a classified career employee of the fire department fails to pass the minimum fitness standard for his particular job description, he or she shall be given an opportunity to participate in a physical fitness program for the purpose of meeting the minimum physical fitness standard for his or her job qualification. If such an employee does not meet the minimum physical fitness standard within a prescribed time limit, the chief shall take appropriate disciplinary action unless such employee is unable to meet such standards because of a medical condition verified to exist and being of a correctable temporary nature. 
b.  It shall be the responsibility of a physician and a physical conditioning specialist to suggest the appropriate physical fitness training program for the employee. The chief in conjunction with a physician and a physical conditioning specialist shall determine the length of time, not to exceed one-year, within which the employee must bring himself up to the applicable minimum physical standards. 
c.  At all times, it shall be within the authority of the chief to take necessary and reasonable disciplinary measures to ensure that the physical fitness standard is met and maintained. 
Sec. 18-63. - Fire department service required. 
Service requirements indicated for positions below shall be required before any member of the fire department is eligible for promotion to such position: 
(1)  A minimum of twelve (12) years' service with a recognized paid fire department shall be required before any person shall be eligible to be appointed chief or assistant chief of the fire department. A bachelor's degree in fire sciences, chemistry or a related field shall constitute two (2) years' experience. An associate degree in fire sciences, chemistry or a related field shall constitute one (1) years' experience. 
(2)  Firefighters above the rank of sergeant with a minimum of ten (10) years' service in the Macon-Bibb County fire department are eligible for appointment to the positions of battalion chief, training director or fire prevention director. A bachelor's degree in fire sciences, chemistry or a related field shall constitute two (2) years' experience. An associate degree in fire sciences, chemistry or a related field shall constitute one (1) years' experience. 
(3)  Lieutenants with a minimum of ten (10) years' service with the Macon-Bibb County fire department who have served at least one (1) year as lieutenant shall be eligible for promotion to captain. A bachelor's degree in fire sciences, chemistry or a related field shall constitute two (2) years' experience. An associate degree in fire sciences, chemistry or a related field shall constitute one (1) years' experience. 
(4)  Sergeants with a minimum of eight (8) years' service with the Macon-Bibb County fire department who have served at least one (1) year as sergeant shall be eligible for promotion to the position of lieutenant. A bachelor's degree in fire sciences, chemistry or a related field shall constitute two (2) years' experience. An associate degree in fire sciences, chemistry or a related field shall constitute one (1) years' experience. 
(5)  Privates with a minimum of six (6) years' non-probationary service with the Macon-Bibb County fire department and minimum of two (2) years of emergency apparatus driving experience with the department shall be eligible for promotion to the position of sergeant. A bachelor's degree in fire sciences, chemistry or a related field shall constitute two (2) years' experience. An associate degree in fire sciences, chemistry or a related field shall constitute one (1) years experience. 
( Ord. No. O-14-0036, § 3, 6-17-2014 ) 
Secs. 18-64—18-69. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FIRE CIVIL SERVICE SYSTEM 

Sec. 18-70. - Definitions. 
The following terms, when used herein in connection with the Macon-Bibb County Fire Civil Service System, shall have the following meanings unless the context clearly requires otherwise: 
(1)  Board means the Macon-Bibb County Fire Civil Service Board. 
(2)  Secretary means the Secretary of the Macon-Bibb County Fire Civil Service Board. 
(3)  Appointing authority means the Fire Chief of Macon-Bibb County or any person lawfully serving as Fire Chief of Macon-Bibb County. 
(4)  Macon-Bibb County Commission means the Mayor and Nine (9) Commissioners of Macon-Bibb County. 
(5)  Position means any office or place of employment as a firefighter in the service of Macon-Bibb County, Georgia, and any office or place of employment of the Fire Chief of Macon-Bibb County, except those offices and positions placed in the unclassified service as set forth in subsection (a) of Sec. 18-75. 
(6)  Classified employee means any employee holding a position in the classified service. 
(7)  Public hearings means an opportunity given after public notice of at least five days for any person or persons to appear and be heard on the matter involved. 
( Ord. No. O-14-0036, § 4, 6-17-2014 ) 
Sec. 18-71. - Changes in system. 
The Macon-Bibb County Commission shall have authority to enact laws changing, altering, or abolishing the Macon-Bibb County Fire Civil Service System herein established and to provide additions, exceptions, or exemptions to the Macon-Bibb County Fire Civil Service System herein established. The Macon-Bibb County Commission may at any time remove the Fire Department of Macon-Bibb County from the Civil Service System herein created. 
( Ord. No. O-14-0036, § 4, 6-17-2014 ) 
Sec. 18-72. - Created. 
A fire civil service system is created as follows. 
( Ord. No. O-14-0036, § 4, 6-17-2014 ) 
Sec. 18-73. - Status of incumbents. 
Any person holding a permanent position as a firefighter in the Macon-Bibb County Fire Department on the effective date of this Macon-Bibb County Fire Civil Service System shall continue to hold such position subject to the provisions herein and shall be deemed to be qualified for such employment and shall be entitled to receive a regular permanent appointment in accordance with the provisions herein. 
( Ord. No. O-14-0036, § 4, 6-17-2014 ) 
Sec. 18-74. - Penalties. 
Any person who shall be convicted of willfully or corruptly violating any of the provisions herein shall be punished as provided in Sec. 1-6; and if such convicted person be in the classified service, he or she shall be dismissed therefrom, at the discretion of the Mayor, and shall not be eligible for reemployment, reinstatement, or reappointment for a period of three years from date of such conviction. 
( Ord. No. O-14-0036, § 4, 6-17-2014 ) 
Sec. 18-75. - Unclassified service and classified service. 
(a)  The unclassified service shall consist of the following: 
(1)  Any person serving as Fire Chief of Macon-Bibb County. 
(2)  Any person serving in the appointed position of Assistant Fire Chief of Macon-Bibb County. 
(3)  Any person serving in the appointed position of Battalion Chief and/or Division Director. 
(4)  Any person serving in the appointed position of Educator, Instructor, and/or Coordinator for any division of the Macon-Bibb County Fire Department. 
(5)  Any person serving in the appointed position of Fire Inspector. 
(6)  Any person who does not receive regular compensation from Macon-Bibb County funds, directly or indirectly. 
(7)  Clerical, maintenance, and custodial personnel. 
(b)  The classified service shall consist of all offices and positions of employment as a firefighter in the service of Macon-Bibb County and serving under the direction of the Fire Chief of Macon-Bibb County, and all offices and positions of employment in the service of the Fire Department of Macon-Bibb County, except those offices and positions placed in the unclassified service as set forth above in subsection (a) of Sec. 18-75. 
( Ord. No. O-14-0036, § 4, 6-17-2014 ) 
Sec. 18-76. - Oaths. 
The board and all sworn employees shall take the oath of office as prescribed by law for their respective positions. 
( Ord. No. O-14-0036, § 4, 6-17-2014 ) 
Sec. 18-77. - Fire civil service board created. 
(a)  There is hereby created and established the Macon-Bibb County Fire Civil Service Board which shall consist of five members who shall have been residents of Macon-Bibb County for two years or more. The members of the Macon-Bibb County Civil Service Board shall be appointed by the Mayor and approved by the Commission and shall serve a four year term. The members shall annually elect one of their members as chairman of the board and one member as vice-chairman. Three members of the board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. Vacancies in the office of said board created by death, resignation, or otherwise shall be filled for the unexpired term by an appointment of the Mayor with the approval of the Commission. No member of the board shall be a current employee of Macon-Bibb County. Members of the board shall be limited to two consecutive full terms of office on the board. Filling more than one-half of an unexpired term of office shall constitute a full term of office. 
(b)  Members of the board are subject to removal at any time by the Mayor. 
(c)  The members of the board shall serve without compensation, except that the Commission may authorize payment to members on a per diem basis for the time actually devoted to the business of the board. 
(d)  The board shall keep its office and shall hold its meetings in the Macon-Bibb County Human Resources Department, and all of said meetings shall be open to the public. The board shall hold regular meetings at least once every three months, and as often in addition thereto as the board may provide. 
(e)  It shall be the duty of the board as a body: 
(1)  To review, including orally interviewing, and pass judgment upon whether the qualifications of initial applicants and promotional candidates match the requirements of the Position. The interview shall consist of personal meeting with the applicants or candidates to evaluate their training, experience, and personal qualifications. If it is determined by the board that an applicant's or candidate's qualifications match the requirements of the Position, the board shall designate the applicant or candidate as qualified for the Position. The applicant or candidate shall then be eligible for consideration by the appointing authority in accordance with Sec. 18-79 of this Chapter. 
(2)  To adopt, rescind, and amend rules and regulations for the administration of the process and procedures of the board for interviewing and passing judgment upon the qualifications of applicants and candidates for promotion after providing reasonable notice and a public hearing during which the Macon-Bibb County Commission, appointing authority, and the classified employees shall be afforded every opportunity to be heard. 
(3)  To keep minutes of its own meeting and such other records as the board may deem necessary. 
(4)  To examine and approve or modify the annual report prepared by the secretary and submit such report to the Commission on or before July 1 of each year transmitting therewith any suggestions it may approve for the more effectual accomplishment of the purpose of this fire civil service system; and to supervise generally the work of the secretary in the administration of the provisions of this system. 
( Ord. No. O-14-0036, § 4, 6-17-2014 ; Ord. of 4-19-2016(1), § 1 ; Ord. No. O-16-0043, § 1, 4-19-2016 ) 
Sec. 18-78. - Secretary. 
(a)  The Human Resources Director of Macon-Bibb County or such person's designee shall serve as secretary. 
(b)  The Commission shall provide adequate facilities and quarters for the board and the secretary to store records and to administer the provisions of this fire civil service system. 
(c)  The secretary shall receive no additional compensation for service on behalf of the board unless such shall be provided by the Commission. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of the secretary: 
(1)  To attend meetings of the board, to act as its secretary and to record its official actions. 
(2)  To assist the board in administering the civil service system. 
(3)  To establish and maintain a roster of all officers and employees in the employ of Macon-Bibb County Fire Department who are covered by this system, showing for each such person the date of appointment, the title of position or positions held, the initial rate of compensation and all changes thereof, and such other data as deemed desirable and pertinent. 
(4)  To present to the board all matters filed with him for the board's consideration, including providing the board with the names and personnel files of all eligible applicants and candidates for promotion. 
(5)  To provide to the appointing authority the results of the board's review of the eligible applicants and candidates for promotion. 
( Ord. No. O-14-0036, § 4, 6-17-2014 ) 
Sec. 18-79. - Appointing authority. 
After receiving the results of the Civil Service Board's review, the appointing authority may use whatever evaluative tools he or she deems necessary or proper, to include validated written tests and/or assessment centers, to further evaluate the eligible applicants and candidates for promotion. The appointing authority shall have final authority to hire and/or promote eligible applicants and candidates using the Uniform Selection Criteria format. 
( Ord. No. O-14-0036, § 4, 6-17-2014 ) 
Sec. 18-80. - Transfers. 
The appointing authority may, at any time, transfer any classified employee under his jurisdiction, from one position to another in the same classification. 
( Ord. No. O-14-0036, § 4, 6-17-2014 ) 
Sec. 18-81. - Demotions. 
The appointing authority may, in accordance with any personnel policies adopted for employees of Macon-Bibb County by the Macon-Bibb County Commission, demote a classified employee under the appointing authority's jurisdiction from a position in one class to a position in a lower class. Any appointing authority may also, in accordance with the personnel policies adopted for employees of Macon-Bibb County by the Macon-Bibb County Commission, suspend, terminate, or otherwise discipline a classified employee without the need to consult with the Board. 
( Ord. No. O-14-0036, § 4, 6-17-2014 ) 
Sec. 18-82. - Personnel policies and general orders. 
Except as specifically provided for or exempted in this Chapter, the appointing authority and all classified employees shall be subject to provisions of all Macon-Bibb County personnel policies adopted by the Macon-Bibb County Commission, including but not limited to disciplinary policies and procedures contained therein, and all General Orders and rules and regulations adopted by the Macon Bibb County Fire Department. If the provisions of this Chapter conflict with the provisions of any Macon-Bibb County personnel policies or any Macon-Bibb County Fire Department General Orders or the department's rules and regulations, the provisions of the Chapter shall govern. 
( Ord. No. O-14-0036, § 4, 6-17-2014 ) 
Secs. 18-83—18-139. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ACCIDENT AND INCIDENT REPORTING 

Sec. 18-140. - Purpose. 
It is the purpose of this article to describe a comprehensive system of reporting incidents, accidents and other occurrences which involve or may involve Macon-Bibb County employees or vehicles, either or both, or which may be observed by Macon-Bibb County employees in the course of their employment. 
Sec. 18-141. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Accident means an undesired event that results in physical harm to a person or damage to property whether or not the event is a "pure accident," or is attributable to negligence on the part of one or more persons. 
Incident means an event which occurs or is observed by Macon-Bibb County personnel while engaged on Macon-Bibb County business and which is one which is unexpected and is outside the normal course of events, and in the happening of which Macon-Bibb County has or may reasonably be expected to have more than a casual interest. 
Occurrence means an all-encompassing term which includes any event, whether or not resulting in known damage or a known personal injury, whether or not involving motor vehicles belonging to Macon-Bibb County and whether or not resulting in known damage to Macon-Bibb County property or personal injury to Macon-Bibb County employees or others, but involves Macon-Bibb County personnel or property, or an activity in which Macon-Bibb County has or may have an interest. 
Sec. 18-142. - Reports—When required. 
(a)  Whenever an accident, incident or occurrence is observed by one or more Macon-Bibb County employees, the same shall be reported in writing as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  If the accident, incident or occurrence is observed by only one Macon-Bibb County employee, it shall be the duty of that employee to make the required report. If the same be observed by more than one Macon-Bibb County employee, it shall be the duty of the senior Macon-Bibb County employee present and physically able to do so, to make the required report. 
(c)  Reports shall be completed and filed as herein prescribed as soon as possible, but in any event within 24 hours. 
Sec. 18-143. - Same—Form and contents. 
Reports shall be in writing and shall consist of: 
(1)  All reports required by the laws of the state for reporting motor vehicle accidents and occurrences. 
(2)  Such reports as may be required by any insurance company with which Macon-Bibb County or any of its employees is an insured. 
(3)  Such other reports as may be required by the governing authority of Macon-Bibb County. 
Sec. 18-144. - Same—Where filed; forwarding. 
Any person required by the terms hereof to make reports shall file the same with the county clerk. It will be the duty of the county clerk to distribute the same as follows: 
(1)  Reports required by the state shall be forwarded by the department to the appropriate state agency, and a copy sent to the appropriate department head. 
(2)  Reports required by an insurance company shall be forwarded to the risk management department for handling with the appropriate company, and a copy furnished to the appropriate department head. 
(3)  The county clerk, in every case, shall furnish copies of all other reports to the head of the department involved. 
Sec. 18-145. - Responsibility of person filing report. 
It shall be the duty of any person charged with filing reports to see that the same are completely filled out, and that the information required is accurate in every detail and is legible. 
Sec. 18-146. - Responsibility of department heads. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of each department head to insure that all employees of that department become familiar with the reporting mandates, the place of filing reports, and the other requirements of this article. 
(b)  Department heads shall further have the duty of seeing that new employees are similarly indoctrinated, and it shall be further the duty of each department head to ensure compliance by department employees with the provisions hereof. 
Secs. 18-147—18-149. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CLAIMS AGAINST EMPLOYEES 

Sec. 18-150. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Claim includes all claims presented against an employee prior to institution of a proceeding. 
Employee means the members of the governing body of Macon-Bibb County, supervisors, employees, and other elected or appointed officers and their appointees and employees, past and present and future. For the purpose of this article "employee" shall include the members of the Macon-Bibb County Board of Elections, the members of the Macon-Bibb County Board of Tax Assessors, the superintendent of elections, the chief appraiser of assessors, the employees of the Macon-Bibb County Board of Elections, and the employees of the Macon-Bibb County Board of Tax Assessors. 
(1)  The word "employee" does not include officers and employees of the Macon-Bibb County Board of Health; the Bibb County Department of Family and Children Services; the Macon-Bibb County Planning and Zoning Commission; the Macon-Bibb County Hospital Authority; the Macon-Bibb County Economic Opportunity Council; the Macon-Bibb County Transit Authority; the Board of Public Education for Bibb County; the Macon-Bibb County Industrial Authority; the Macon-Bibb County Urban Development Authority; the Development Authority of Bibb County; and other similar agencies; nor does the term include the agricultural agent, the home demonstration agent and the employees of either. Proceeding includes any matter of a civil nature in or before any court or agency of this state or of any other state or of the United States. 
( Ord. No. O-14-0043, § 1, 8-5-2014 ) 
Sec. 18-151. - Exclusions. 
There is excluded further from the operation of this article any claim or proceeding as to which insurance is provided by Macon-Bibb County. 
Sec. 18-152. - Construction. 
(a)  Nothing contained in this division shall be deemed to constitute any waiver of any immunity, including governmental immunity, afforded by law. 
(b)  Nothing herein shall be deemed to constitute the elected or appointed officers and their appointees and employees as employees of Macon-Bibb County except for the purposes of this article. 
Sec. 18-153. - Defense of employees. 
Whenever any claim is made or proceeding is brought against any employee, either against him asserting personal liability for damages arising out of the performance of his duties or in any way connected therewith, whether based on negligence, violation of contract rights or violation of civil, constitutional, common law or other statutory rights, whether federal, state or local, Macon-Bibb County shall, upon his written request, provide for his defense by an attorney selected by Macon-Bibb County unless otherwise limited by the terms of this article. Macon-Bibb County may decline defense of an employee or decline payment of a claim against an employee if the employee has failed to give notice in writing of any claim or proceeding to the board within 30 days after the employee has notice of a claim or if the employee has failed to give such notice within five days after service of a proceeding. 
Sec. 18-154. - Grounds for refusal of defense. 
(a)  Macon-Bibb County shall refuse to provide for the defense of a claim or proceeding brought against an employee if it determines that: 
(1)  The act or omission did not arise out of and in the course of his employment; 
(2)  The employee acted or failed to act because of actual fraud, corruption, or actual malice on his part; 
(3)  Defense of the claim or proceeding by Macon-Bibb County would create a conflict of interest between Macon-Bibb County and the employee; 
(4)  Provision of a defense against the claim or proceeding would not be in the best interests of Macon-Bibb County; 
(5)  The proceeding is a criminal prosecution; or 
(6)  The employee acts or fails to act as a result of, or at a time when, his own self-indulgence substantially impaired his judgment, as, for example, the act or omission occurs while the employee is intoxicated or under the influence of drugs. 
(7)  The employee fails to cooperate in the defense of the claim or proceeding. 
(b)  Subsection (a)(3) to the contrary notwithstanding, Macon-Bibb County may nevertheless provide a defense against a claim or proceeding where there is a conflict of interest between one employee or group of employees of Macon-Bibb County as compared with another employee or group of employees. 
Sec. 18-155. - Payment of judgments; compromise and settlement of claims. 
(a)  Where defense of a claim or proceeding against an employee is provided by this division, all final judgments awarded in courts of competent jurisdiction against employees in proceedings to which this division applies or any amount payable under any settlement of such proceeding or of claims in accordance with this division shall be paid by Macon-Bibb County as hereafter provided. All compromises of claims or proceedings governed by this article shall be submitted to the commission for its prior approval. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the forgoing, payment of judgments and claims shall be limited as follows: 
(1)  No sum will be paid where the employee's alleged liability is based on a discretionary act or omission. Payment of judgments and claims pursuant to this section shall be made only where liability is based upon a ministerial act of the employee. It is the intent of this section to provide for the payment of claims or judgments only where the defense of sovereign or governmental immunity is not available as a defense to the claim or proceeding. There is, however, excluded from this section payment of any claim against Macon-Bibb County for money for a loss caused by negligence of a Macon-Bibb County officer or employee using a vehicle owned, leased or rented by the county while carrying out his or her official duties or employment pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 36-92-1 et seq. 
(2)  No sum will be paid on behalf of any employee in excess of $50,000.00 for any one claimant, regardless of the number of claims that claimant may have arising from any one occurrence. In the event of multiple claimants as a result of one occurrence, no sum will be paid in excess of $100,000.00, regardless of the number of claimants or claims. Derivative claims, such as claims for loss of consortium or services, shall not be considered separate claims. 
(3)  No sum will be paid for punitive or exemplary damages. 
(4)  No sum will be paid unless the claimant unconditionally releases the employee and Macon-Bibb County from any and all claims, causes of action or judgments arising out of the subject claim or proceeding. 
(5)  No sum will be paid if Macon-Bibb County has reserved the right not to pay a claim or judgment notwithstanding the acceptance of the defense and if Macon-Bibb County later determines that the claim or proceeding meets one or more of the grounds for refusal of defense enumerated in this section. If Macon-Bibb County reserves the right not to pay a claim or judgment, Macon-Bibb County shall give the employee written notice that Macon-Bibb County has accepted the defense under a reservation of rights. 
(6)  Notwithstanding the forgoing, the commission may, in its discretion, indemnify an employee for a claim or judgment in excess of $50,000.00 if the commission determines that the best interests of Macon-Bibb County will be served by such additional indemnification. This authority to provide additional indemnification shall not extend to claims arising from the operation or use of a motor vehicle or claims based on simple negligence. 
Chapter 19 - PURCHASING, CONTRACTS AND DISPOSITION OF PROPERTY 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 19-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Asset means a non-expendable supply item with a probable useful life of more than one (1) year. 
Authorized elected official means an elected official designated by public vote of the Board of Commission to receive a county issued government purchasing card or credit card. 
Budget officer means the person, other than the finance office or buyer, designated as the budget officer or budget management officer of Macon-Bibb County. 
Buyer means the person, other than the finance officer or budget officer, designated as the buyer, buyer/purchaser, or purchasing agent for Macon-Bibb County. 
Card administrator means the purchasing card and credit card administrator designated by the Macon-Bibb County Board of Commission. 
Contractor means any person having or seeking a contract with Macon-Bibb County. 
Contractual services means and includes all telephone, internet, cable, gas, water, electric light and power service; cleaning service; insurance; leases for all grounds, buildings, office or other space required by the using departments; rental, repair or maintenance of equipment, machinery and other personal property; and other services except professional services. 
County purchase card, county p-card or county credit card means a financial transaction card issued by any business organization, financial institution, or any duly authorized agent of such organization or institution, used by a Macon-Bibb County official to purchase goods, services and other things of value on behalf of Macon-Bibb County. 
Financial transaction card means an instrument or device as the term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-9-30(5). 
Fixed asset means an asset having an original acquisition cost of over five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) per unit. 
Local labor, non-labor and administrative personnel means individuals who reside in Macon-Bibb County. 
Local offeror means any offeror whose principal place of business is within Macon-Bibb County. 
Local vendor means any vendor or bidder whose principal placed of business is within Macon-Bibb County. 
Offeror means any contractor responding to a request for proposals from Macon-Bibb County. 
Procurement means the buying, purchasing, renting, leasing or otherwise acquiring of any supplies, services or construction. It also includes all functions that pertain to the obtaining of any supply, service, or construction, including description of requirements, selection and solicitation of sources, preparation and award of contract, and all phases of contract administration. 
Professional services means those services within the scope of the practices of architecture, investment banking, professional engineering, planning, landscape architecture, land surveying, the medical arts, management analysis, account or auditing, law, psychology or any other similar kind or type of professional practice which is by its nature unique and for which competitive bidding or proposals are not feasible. 
Proposal means a solicited submission of information from a prospective offeror including how that offeror intends to perform certain work; the offeror's technical and business qualifications; the proposed delivery, warranty, other terms and conditions as those might differ from or supplement Macon-Bibb County's solicitation requirements; and any other information requested by Macon-Bibb County's solicitation. It shall also include such pricing information as may be required. 
Purchase order means an order for the procurement of supplies or services, and which is issued for a specific need, and includes data contained in the requisition. A purchase order may include, but not be limited to, the description of the requested item, delivery schedule, transportation data, price and any other terms and conditions which may be incidental to the desired purchase. 
Request for proposals means all documents, whether attached or incorporated by reference, utilized for soliciting proposals from prospective offerors. 
Requisition means that document whereby a using department requests that a purchase order or contract be entered into for a specific need and may include but is not limited to the description of the requested item, delivery schedule, transportation data, criteria for evaluation, suggested sources of supply and information supplied for the making of any written determination required by this article. 
Responsible bidder or offeror means a person who has the technical and financial capability in all respects to perform fully the contract requirements, and the experience, integrity, reliability, capacity, facilities, equipment,, and credit which will assure good faith performance; or means a person who has submitted a bid or proposal which conforms in all material respects to the requirements set forth in the invitation for bids or request for proposals. 
Services means the furnishing of labor, time, or effort by a contractor not involving the delivery of a specific end product other than reports which are merely incidental to the required performance. This term shall not include employment agreements. 
Sole source means there is only one (1) source for the required supply, service or construction item. 
Solicitation means an invitation for bids, a request for proposals, a request for quotations or any other documents or request issued by Macon-Bibb County for the purpose of soliciting bids or proposals to perform a Macon-Bibb Count contract. 
Specification means any description of the physical or functional characteristics or of the nature of a supply, service, or construction item. It may include a description of any requirement for inspecting, testing, or preparing a supply, service, or construction item for delivery. 
Supplies means all personal property owned by Macon-Bibb County, including but not limited to equipment and materials, excluding land or a permanent interest in land and leases of real property. 
Surplus supplies means any supplies no longer having any use to the using agency. This term may include supplies that are worn out, scrap or obsolete. 
User agreement means the required agreement between the Board of Commission and the authorized elected officials which restricts the use of a county purchasing card or credit card. 
Using department means any department, agency, office, commission or other unit in Macon-Bibb County government using supplies or procuring contractual services unless otherwise provided by law. 
( Ord. No. O-15-0060, § 1, 12-15-2015 ) 
Sec. 19-2. - Applicability and policy. 
This chapter shall apply to all contracts for procurement and for disposition of real and personal property entered into on behalf of Macon-Bibb County regardless of the source of funds, except this chapter shall not apply were superseded by federal or state law, or, with respect to federal or state grant funds, where superseded by federal or state requirements relating to such funds. The governing authority of Macon-Bibb County believes that it is in the public interest of Macon-Bibb County to purchase or procure supplies and services of a high quality from local businesses and vendors whose principal place of business is within Macon-Bibb County, and providing a local preference for Macon-Bibb County businesses, vendors and merchants will benefit the Macon-Bibb County's economy and potentially generate additional tax revenue for Macon-Bibb County. 
( Ord. No. O-15-0060, § 1, 12-15-2015 ) 
Sec. 19-3. - Unauthorized purchases. 
(a)  Except as provided in this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any person to order the procurement of any supplies or contractual services other than through the finance department, and any purchase order or contract made contrary to the provisions hereof shall not be approved by Macon-Bibb County officials, and Macon-Bibb County shall not be bound thereby. 
(b)  No purchases of materials, supplies, equipment and services shall be made in the name of Macon-Bibb County or one of its departments, or through its procurement department, except such as are required for official use by Macon-Bibb County or one of its departments. Purchases in the name of Macon-Bibb County or a department for personal use by an individual or for other than official use are prohibited, and no Macon-Bibb County funds will be expended or advanced therefor. 
(c)  Macon-Bibb County shall refuse to pay for any material, supplies, equipment or premiums hereafter purchased by any individual, committee or board from any person or business in which an elected or appointed employee of Macon-Bibb County has a significant financial interest. 
( Ord. No. O-15-0060, § 1, 12-15-2015 ) 
Sec. 19-4. - Ordering procedure. 
(a)  Except as provided in section 19-5.3 or otherwise provided in this chapter, all using departments, either by or with the authorization of the head of the using department shall file with the buyer detailed requisitions or estimates of their requirements in supplies and contractual services in such a manner, at such times, and for such future periods as the buyer shall prescribe.. 
(b)  A using department shall not be prevented from filing, in the same manner, with the buyer at any time a requisition or estimate for any supplies and contractual services, the need for which was not foreseen when the detailed estimates were filed. 
(c)  The buyer shall examine each requisition or estimate and shall have the authority to revise it as to quantity, quality, or estimated cost, in consultation with the using agency. 
(d)  Completed requisitions must be forwarded to the budget officer who will ascertain whether sufficient appropriated funds are available to make the purchase and that the correct account has been used, the buyer is authorized to issue a purchase order fulfilling the requisition. 
(e)  If the budget officer confirms in writing that sufficient appropriated funds are available to make the purchase and that the correct account has been used, the buyer is authorized to issue a purchase order fulfilling the requisition. 
(f)  Except as provided in section 19-5.5 of this chapter, regarding emergency procurement, it shall be a violation of Macon-Bibb County policy for the head of any department or office to permit expenditures by their respective department or office that exceed amounts appropriated for the specific line item. Failure to comply with this subsection shall subject the head of the department or office to progressive discipline up to and including termination of employment. Copies of disciplinary actions shall be placed in the employee's personnel file and submitted to the mayor, county manager, mayor pro tem, and appropriations committee chair. 
(g)  It shall be the duty of the head of a department or office who determines that funds appropriated in a specific line item will be insufficient to meet needs during the budget year to officially notify the mayor and finance officer in writing, including the reasons for the insufficiency. 
( Ord. No. O-15-0060, § 1, 12-15-2015 ) 
Sec. 19-5. - Methods of procurement. 
All Macon-Bibb County procurement of supplies, construction and contractual services shall be awarded by competitive sealed bidding, pursuant to section 19-5.1, except as provided in the following: 
(1)  Section 19-5.2 (competitive sealed proposals); 
(2)  Section 19-5.3 (small purchases); 
(3)  Section 19-5.4 (sole source procurement); 
(4)  Section 19-5.5 (emergency procurement); and 
(5)  Section 19-5.6 (contracts with or obtained through other governmental entities). 
( Ord. No. O-15-0060, § 1, 12-15-2015 ) 
Sec. 19-5.1. - Competitive sealed bidding. 
(a)  Invitations for bids. An invitation for bids shall be issued and shall include specifications and contractual terms and conditions applicable to the procurement. The invitation for bids shall also set forth the evaluation criteria to be used. 
(b)  Public notice. An advertisement inviting bids shall be published on the Macon-Bibb County web site and/or at least once in at least one (1) newspaper of general circulation in Macon-Bibb County. When appropriate, such an advertisement may also be published in a trade journal, a specialized industry publication or other publication. 
(c)  Contents of notice. The public notice shall contain a general description of the supplies or services to be procured, the location where appropriate solicitation documents may be obtained, and the time and place of opening of solicitation documents. 
(d)  Receipt of competitive sealed bids. All bids must be delivered to and received by the buyer on or before the date and time for opening of solicitation documents. 
(e)  Bid opening. Bids shall be opened publically in the presence of one (1) or more witnesses at the time and place designated in the invitation for bids. The name of each bidder, the amount of each bid and such other relevant information as the buyer deems appropriate shall be recorded. 
(f)  Bid evaluation. Bids shall be evaluated based on the requirements set forth in the invitation for bids. 
(g)  Award. The contract shall be awarded by the buyer to the lowest responsible and responsive bidder provided that where a non-local vendor has submitted the lowest bid, a local vendor whose price is within five (5) percent of the lowest bid, and whose price is lower than other local vendors, shall be treated as the lowest bidder, and provided further that, after consultation with the using department and approval by the county manager or the mayor, the buyer may award a contract to other than the lowest responsible and responsive bidder based on "best value" to Macon-Bibb County. The basis for any award based on best value shall be documented in writing by the buyer. Best value shall be documented in writing by the buyer. Best value shall be determined based on the following criteria: 
(1)  The ability, capacity and skill of the bidder or firm to perform the contract or provide the services required; 
(2)  The capability of the bidder or firm to perform the contract or provide the service promptly or within the time specified without delay or interference; 
(3)  The character, integrity, reputation, judgment, experience and efficiency of the bidder or firm; 
(4)  The quality of performance of previous contracts or services; 
(5)  The previous and existing compliance by the bidder or firm with laws and ordinances relating to the contract or services; 
(6)  The sufficiency of the financial resources and ability of the bidder or firm to perform the contract or provide the services; 
(7)  The quality, availability and adaptability of the supplies or services to the particular use required; 
(8)  The number and scope of conditions attached to the bid by the bidder or firm, in any; 
(9)  Price, provided that where a non-local vendor has submitted the lowest bid, a local vendor whose price is within five (5) percent of the lowest bid, and whose price is lower than other local vendors, shall be treated as having submitted the lowest bid; and 
(10)  Preference shall be granted to local vendors as against non-local vendors that are otherwise equal with respect to the above criteria. 
(11)  For contracts involving the use of S.P.L.O.S.T. funding, the degree and manner to which a bidder or firm intends to utilize local labor, non-labor, and administrative personnel. 
(h)  Exceeding available funds. If all bids exceed available funds as certified by the budget officer and the lowest and/or best bid does not exceed such funds by more than five (5) percent, the buyer, with approval of the mayor or county manager, may negotiate an adjustment of the bid price, including changes in the bid requirements with the winning bidder in order to bring the bid within the amount of available funds. 
( Ord. No. O-15-0060, § 1, 12-15-2015 ) 
Sec. 19-5.2. - Competitive sealed proposals. 
(a)  Conditions for use. When the use of competitive sealed bidding is either not practicable or not advantageous to Macon-Bibb County, a contract may be entered into by the use of competitive sealed proposals. 
(b)  Request for proposals. Proposals shall be solicited through a request for proposals. 
(c)  Public notice. The buyer shall issue public notice for a request for proposals as provided in section 19-5.1(b). The public notice for a request for proposals shall describe the services required and list the type of information and data required of each offeror. 
(d)  Selection and award. Award shall be made by the buyer, upon the recommendation of the head of the using department or a selection committee chosen by the mayor, based upon criteria established and published in the solicitation, to the responsible and responsive offeror whose proposal is determined in writing to be the most advantageous to Macon-Bibb County. The selection criteria shall include but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Previous experience demonstrating competence to perform work involved in the project; 
(2)  Past performance of previous contracts with respect to time of completion and quality of work and compliance with applicable laws and regulations: 
(3)  The fee or compensation demanded for the work or services, provided that where a non-local offeror has submitted the lowest such demand, a local offeror whose demand is within five (5) percent of the lowest demand, and whose demand is lower than other local offerors, shall be treated as having submitted the lowest demand; 
(4)  The ability to comply with the schedule of the commencement and completion of the work or services as required by Macon-Bibb County; 
(5)  The financial ability to furnish any necessary bonds or other security; 
(6)  The financial condition of the offeror; 
(7)  The ability to provide staffing personnel for the project, satisfactory to Macon-Bibb County; 
(8)  The relative advantage and value of the proposal to Macon-Bibb County; 
(9)  For contracts involving the use of S.P.L.O.S.T. funding, the degree and manner to which a bidder or firm intends to utilize local labor, non-labor, and administrative personnel; and 
(10)  Preference shall be granted to local offerors as against non-local offerors that are otherwise equal with respect to the above criteria. 
( Ord. No. O-15-0060, § 1, 12-15-2015 ) 
Sec. 19-5.3. - Small purchases. 
(a)  Heads of all using departments may, in their discretion, make small purchases for expendable supplies and services without the assistance of the buyer in the following circumstances: 
(1)  The purchase is paid for out of petty cash. Upon approval of the finance officer, an audited petty cash account not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) for incidental supplies may be established under any using department head. Upon prior written approval of the county manager, an audited petty cash account may exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00), but in no event shall any account exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), or 
(2)  The purchase is for a service or supply costing up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). Such purchases shall not include any items that the finance department has contracted to buy. 
(b)  For purchases over one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), but not more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), at least three (3) quotes shall be obtained and documented unless, after consultation with the buyer, it is determined that there are less than three (3) sources reasonably available for the supply or service being sought. In such cases, as many quotes as reasonably possible shall be obtained. For purchases up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), reasonable best efforts shall be used to obtain the best practice and value for Macon-Bibb County. 
(c)  Contracts shall not be artificially divided in order to fall under this section. 
( Ord. No. O-15-0060, § 1, 12-15-2015 ) 
Sec. 19-5.4. - Sole source procurement. 
A contract or purchase order may be awarded without competitive solicitation when the buyer determines in writing, after conducting a good-faith review of available sources and with the approval of the county manager, that there is only one (1) source for the required supply or contractual service. The buyer shall conduct negotiations, as appropriate, as to price, delivery and terms. The buyer shall maintain a record of sole source procurements which lists each contractor's name, the name and type of each contract, and a listing of the item procured under each contract. 
( Ord. No. O-15-0060, § 1, 12-15-2015 ) 
Sec. 19-5.5. - Emergency procurement. 
Notwithstanding any other section of this chapter, when the county manager or the mayor determines that an emergency exists, such person may make or authorize others to make emergency procurements for suppliers or contractual services. The mayor or the county manager shall make such determination when there exists a threat to public health, welfare or safety under emergency conditions. Such emergency procurements shall be made with as much competition as is practicable under the circumstances. A written determination of the basis for the emergency and for the selection of the particular contractor shall be included in the contract file by the buyer. As soon as practicable, the buyer shall make a record of each emergency procurement, shall set forth the basis for the emergency, the selection of the particular contractor, the contractor's name, the amount and type of the contract, a listing of the supplies or services procured under the contract, and submit a written report with such information to the clerk of the commission. 
( Ord. No. O-15-0060, § 1, 12-15-2015 ) 
Sec. 19-5.6. - Contracts with or through other governmental entities. 
Competitive solicitation shall not be required where Macon-Bibb County is contracting with other governmental entities, whether state, local or federal, and shall also not be required with respect to procurements through the state, as authorized by state law. 
( Ord. No. O-15-0060, § 1, 12-15-2015 ) 
Sec. 19-6. - Monthly report to the Macon-Bibb County Commission. 
The buyer shall submit to the clerk of the commission, before the fifteenth (15 th ) of each month, a report listing for the previous month the following information: 
(1)  The titles of all requests for proposals and the method of source selections to be used: 
(2)  All contracts authorized by the commission, the method of source selection used, and the total dollar amount; 
(3)  All contracts authorized for procurement and the method of source selection used; 
(4)  All change orders or contract modifications authorized, the dollar amount, and the reason. 
( Ord. No. O-15-0060, § 1, 12-15-2015 ) 
Sec. 19-7. - Right to reject all bids or proposals. 
With respect to all solicitations, Macon-Bibb County shall retain the right, in its sole discretion, to reject any and all bids or proposals and waive any formalities and shall not reimburse any bidder or offeror for its costs in responding or preparing to respond to any such solicitation by Macon-Bibb County. Each solicitation issued by Macon-Bibb County shall so state. 
( Ord. No. O-15-0060, § 1, 12-15-2015 ) 
Sec. 19-8. - Cooperative purchasing. 
The buyer shall have the authority to join with other unites of government in cooperative purchasing plans when the best interests of Macon-Bibb County would be served thereby. 
( Ord. No. O-15-0060, § 1, 12-15-2015 ) 
Sec. 19-9. - Surplus supplies. 
(a)  All using agencies shall submit to the buyer, at such times and in such form as he shall prescribe, reports of all surplus supplies. 
(b)  The buyer shall have the authority to transfer surplus supplies to other using departments and shall do so where warranted. 
(c)  The buyer shall have the authority to sell all surplus supplies that have become unsuitable for use by any using department of Macon-Bibb County. 
(d)  If the buyer determines that a surplus supply is unserviceable and beyond repair, and that the estimated market value of the surplus supply is less than Macon-Bibb County's estimated total cost to attempt to sell the surplus supply, including storage and transportation costs, the buyer shall have the authority to discard such supply, or, where feasible, to provide for recycling of such supply. 
( Ord. No. O-15-0060, § 1, 12-15-2015 ) 
Sec. 19-10. - Macon-Bibb County contracts; authority to sign; procedure. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, no contract with Macon-Bibb County shall be binding on Macon-Bibb County unless, at a minimum, the following requirements are fulfilled: 
(1)  All contracts must be signed by an authorized individual: 
(i)  The mayor shall have authority to sign all contracts. If authorized by the mayor, the county manager shall have the authority to sign contracts for procurement of supplies or contractual services. 
(ii)  All other contracts shall be negotiated at the direction of the mayor, and the mayor shall authorize and sign all such contracts unless the mayor in writing delegates the authorizing and signing responsibility to another Macon-Bibb County official, provided the delegation is for a specific contract or subject. 
(2)  All contracts shall be in writing and approved by the Macon-Bibb County attorney as to form. 
(3)  All contracts must be in compliance with state and federal law. 
(4)  No contract for the sale, exchange, lease or purchase of real estate shall be valid without approval by resolution of mayor and commission unless otherwise provided in this Code. 
(5)  No contract in excess of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) in either revenue or expense to Macon-Bibb County (directly or indirectly and regardless of the source of the funds) shall be valid unless approved by resolution or ordinance of mayor and commission. Contracts shall not be artificially divided in an effort to avoid this requirement. Contracts for fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) or less shall be approved as follows: 
(i)  Contracts for less than or equal to twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) may be approved by the purchasing director; 
(ii)  Contracts for more than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) up to fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) must be approved by the Macon-Bibb County manager. 
(b)  All procurements of consultants, regardless of dollar amount, must be approved by resolution of mayor and commission after a review of the experience and qualifications of the proposed consultant to successfully perform the tasks for which the contract, procurement or appointment is made. Competitive procurement for such consultants shall be made when required by the mayor or resolution of mayor and commission. For purposes of this section, consultant shall include professionals and advisors (other than Macon-Bibb County employees and attorneys) whose services are procured to give advice or provide professional services or to develop specific programs or design specific guidelines or policies. In the procurement of consulting services, preference shall be given to qualified Macon-Bibb County persons, firms, or corporations whenever practicable provided that the local preference established in this section shall in no way be construed to inhibit, limit or restrict the right and obligation of Macon-Bibb County to consider costs and to compare the experience and qualifications of the proposed consultant to successfully perform the tasks for which the contract, procurement, or appointment is made. 
(c)  Any contract entered into by Macon-Bibb County may be cancelled or terminated pursuant to its terms by either the official who executed the contract, the mayor or by resolution of mayor and commission. 
(d)  The clerk of commission shall authenticate all contracts and shall maintain a permanent, indexed file of originals on all Macon-Bibb County contracts. 
(e)  Before entering into a contract with any vendor, Macon-Bibb County shall require such vendor to provide proof of current payment of any undisputed taxes, fees, penalties, fines or other revenue due Macon-Bibb County. 
( Ord. No. O-2014-24, § 1, 4-1-2014 ; Ord. No. O-15-0060, § 1, 12-15-2015 ) 
Sec. 19-11. - Leasing municipal property. 
There shall be no entry into possession of any Macon-Bibb County owned premises which is the subject of any proposed lease with Macon-Bibb County until such lease is fully authorized and executed as required by this Code. All tenants of leased Macon-Bibb County-owned real estate shall abide by all terms, conditions and covenants contained in the lease agreement. Upon first knowledge by Macon-Bibb County of the failure of any tenant to abide by such terms, conditions or covenants, Macon-Bibb County shall give a written notice to the tenant of the lease agreement violation and that the tenant must cease and desist from committing the lease agreement violations within a period of ten (10) days or any longer period which may be specified by the applicable lease agreement. Upon the tenant's failure to present evidence that no provision of the lease agreement has been violated or, alternatively, to cease and desist from continuous violations of the lease agreement, the mayor shall initiate the appropriate legal process to terminate the lease agreement and remove the tenant from the premises. If the tenant takes corrective action acceptable to Macon-Bibb County within the grace period, then the possession of the leased premises shall continue, per the terms of the lease agreement. However, a second violation of the same lease provision during the balance of the lease period shall not be curable, but shall result in the initiation of the appropriate legal process to terminate the lease agreement and remove the tenant from the premises. No exceptions to the provisions of this subsection shall be permitted without the approval of Macon-Bibb County commission by resolution. After the effective date of the ordinance from which the subsection is derived, all new lease agreements entered into by Macon-Bibb County shall contain a paragraph adopting by reference the provisions of this subsection. 
( Ord. No. O-15-0060, § 1, 12-15-2015 ) 
Sec. 19-12. - Selling municipal property. 
(a)  All real and personal property of Macon-Bibb County shall be disposed of by the buyer upon order of the mayor pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 36-37-6, and any other applicable state law, and as provided in this Code. The buyer shall be the designated agent of Macon-Bibb County for purposes of such disposal.
