All litter from construction and related activities shall be containerized and shall be picked up and placed in containers at the end of each work day. 
(b)  Rock, waste building materials, or other refuse resulting from building or remodeling operations or resulting from a general cleanup of vacant or improved property just prior to its occupancy, shall not be removed by the solid waste division. Such waste shall be removed by the building contractor, owner, or occupant of the building at his own expense. 
Sec. 22-66. - Duty of owners with respect to litter. 
The owner, occupant and lessee of all property, jointly and severally, are required to remove all litter and place the same in proper containers. Vacant lots, borders, parking lots, embankments, fences, walls and sidewalks shall be kept free of litter. Parking lots, shopping centers, convenience stores, drive-in restaurants and all other commercial and industrial enterprises shall see to it that their respective properties are kept litter-free. 
Sec. 22-67. - Cleaning of property at owners' expense. 
In cases where litter has remained on private property for a period of 30 days following written notice by the director of public works to the owner of such property to remove the same, the director of public works is authorized but not required to cause such litter to be removed and to bill the owner for the cost thereof. If the owner fails or refuses to pay the bill for the cleanup service within 30 days from the date of billing, then execution may be issued against the property upon which such service is rendered for the amount of the cleanup service charge; and from and after the recording of such execution on the general execution docket in the office of the clerk of the superior court of the county, such execution shall constitute a lien on the property on which the service is rendered until the same shall have been fully paid and satisfied. Such executions may be enforced in the same manner and with the addition of interest and costs as provided by law for the enforcement of executions for ad valorem taxes of the county. Action by the director of public works shall not preclude prosecution for a violation of this article. 
Sec. 22-68. - Complaint; trial; order; failure to comply; assessment; collection. 
(a)  When it becomes necessary to issue a citation to an owner or occupant of lands subject to the provisions of this division, said citation shall be in the form of a written complaint setting forth, particularly, the nature and location of the nuisance and the identity of the person complained against. If the court determines that the conditions do in fact constitute a nuisance, the court shall issue an order specifying the time within which such nuisance must be abated. 
(b)  The failure of the owner or occupant to comply with the court's order to abate the nuisance shall constitute an offense and shall subject the person to prosecution and penalties as provided in section 1-6, including: 
(1)  Fines not to exceed $300.00 per violation. 
(2)  Imprisonment, not to exceed 60 days. 
(3)  Community service to be performed with any private, nonprofit community service organization or any public agency willing to participate and approved by the state court of Bibb County. Violators shall not be used for any purpose resulting in private gain to any person, except in accordance with state law. The role of the county in the supervision of violators performing community service shall be a governmental function. 
Secs. 22-69—22-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - JUNKED HOUSEHOLD APPLIANCES 

Sec. 22-81. - Finding. 
The commission finds that old household appliances which are discarded, dismantled, scrapped, ruined or junked, when stored on property in Macon-Bibb County constitute health hazards through the breeding of mosquitoes and other insects and unsightly nuisances. This article is adopted pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 36-60-4. 
Sec. 22-82. - Penalty for violations. 
Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof in the Macon-Bibb County Municipal Court or State Court of Bibb County, shall be punished as provided in section 22-256. 
Sec. 22-83. - Keeping old household appliances restricted. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person in charge or control of any property within the area of Macon-Bibb County, whether as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee or agent thereof, to store or permit to be stored on such property any old discarded, dismantled, scrapped, ruined or junked household appliances. 
(b)  As used in this section, the terms "discarded, dismantled, scrapped, ruined or junked household appliance" shall mean any appliance which is inoperable because of missing parts necessary to make the appliance operable. 
Sec. 22-84. - Notice to remove from lot, property or premises; service, contents. 
When any such old household appliance is abandoned, stored, or left on any lot, property or premises within Macon-Bibb County for a period of more than 30 days, notice shall be served personally by the sheriff of the county or other authorized official designated by the commission upon the owner or person in charge of the property or premises if occupied, or if unoccupied by certified U.S. mail to the owner or person in charge of the property or premises, with an additional notice posted on the old household appliance to remove, store or dispose of the old household appliance within 30 days from the date of the notice. The notice shall set forth the fact that the old household appliance is abandoned or stored in violation of this article and that upon failure to remove, properly store, house or otherwise dispose of the same, as provided in this article, that it will be removed, sold or disposed of by Macon-Bibb County and that any proceeds arising from the sale thereof will be applied first to payment of expenses incurred in connection with the removal and sale of the old household appliance and any remaining balance paid to the owner thereof. If such old household appliance is not removed, stored or disposed of within such 60-day period, the sheriff or other official authorized by Macon-Bibb County shall remove and store the same pending disposition. 
Secs. 22-85—22-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - LANDFILLS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-101. - Unauthorized use prohibited. 
No person shall dump or otherwise dispose of garbage, solid waste or refuse in any landfill within the limits of Macon-Bibb County and owned by another person or entity than the one dumping or disposing of such materials without the prior consent of such other person or entity and without having made arrangements for the payment of charges, if any, which may be imposed by such other person or entity. 
Sec. 22-102. - Landfill—Fees. 
(a)  Computation of tipping fee; special wastes; environmental protection division surcharge. The tipping fee charged for hauling refuse to the landfill for disposal shall be computed annually with the new rate to be effective beginning on July 1 of each year. The tipping fee shall be that amount computed by totaling all budgeted operating costs of waste disposal programs, including the operations of the landfill and mulching sites, less revenues generated from interest income (earned on the reserve fund) and the sale of methane gas for the upcoming fiscal year, and dividing the result by the total tonnage projected for the fiscal year. The calculated tipping fee shall be $27.00 per ton, for all tons disposed with exception of those covered by separate contracts as approved by the mayor. The tipping fee shall be multiplied by the total tonnage disposed of by the landfill customers at the end of each month, and this amount shall be billed to each individual customer. The director of solid waste, with the approval of the county manager, is authorized to charge additional fees for special wastes over and above the tipping fee. Said additional fees shall be based upon the actual costs incurred for handling the special wastes. The term "special wastes" as used herein shall be defined as any waste that requires additional handling in order to be disposed of at the landfill over and above the handling required for normal refuse, including, but not limited to: tires, sludges and semi-solids. 
In addition to the tipping fee set forth above and other fees charged for disposing of solid waste at the Macon-Bibb County landfill, each disposer of solid waste at the landfill shall pay to Macon-Bibb County any surcharge imposed by the state environmental protection division; said surcharge shall be increased from time to time as necessary to reflect future increases in such surcharges levied by the division. Said funds are collected by the city on behalf of the state environmental protection division pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 12-8-39(e). 
(b)  Disposition of revenue. All tipping fees received in the course of operating the landfill shall be paid into the solid waste management fund. The operating expenses of the waste disposal programs (as defined above) shall be paid from said fund and shall include all costs, direct and indirect, except depreciation. All operating revenue which exceeds the operating expenses shall be deposited in the solid waste management reserve. All revenues contributed by the city for solid waste disposal except for that portion of revenues representing payment of the surcharge provided in subsection (a), shall be used to support the operating and capital needs of Macon-Bibb County's solid waste management programs. Additionally, all interest earned on solid waste reserve shall be retained in and become a part of the solid waste management fund. All solid waste reserve monies shall be available for capital and operating expenses and waste management, including but not limited to heavy equipment recycling-related capital expenditure, landfill property, engineering fees, cover material and landfill property. 
(c)  Exemptions. Urban solid waste district residents who personally haul refuse, not including garbage, from their places of residence to the landfill shall be permitted to dispose of such refuse at the landfill once per month per household free of charge; provided, however, the total load per visit weighs 500 pounds or less. All others who dispose of refuse at the landfill are required to pay the tipping fees and surcharges set forth in this section. District residents who dispose of loads weighing more than 500 pounds, or who deposit more than one load per month, are required to pay the tipping fees and surcharges set forth in this section for such excess amounts and additional loads. 
(d)  Holidays. The landfill will normally be closed on all observed city holidays. The landfill may be opened at the discretion of the director of solid waste or the mayor. If the landfill is opened on a holiday the tipping fee for that day shall be one and twenty-five-one-hundredths (1.25) times the tipping fee in effect on regular workdays. 
Sec. 22-103. - Same—User permit. 
(a)  Required. No person shall be permitted to dispose of any type of refuse at the sanitary landfill without first obtaining a landfill user permit from the finance officer. This section shall not apply to homeowners and residential tenants who personally haul household refuse from their own places of residence to the landfill. 
(b)  Application; contents. Any person who wishes to obtain a landfill user permit shall, in addition to the general business license requirements, submit the following information on an application form furnished by the finance officer: 
(1)  A description of the type of business in which the applicant is engaged; 
(2)  The applicant's anticipated frequency of landfill use; 
(3)  The make, model, VIN number and tag number of each vehicle to be used at the landfill; 
(4)  Permit applicants with more than three (3) vehicles shall furnish proof of motor vehicle liability insurance (or self-insurance) in a minimum amount of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) total aggregate limits and proof of general liability insurance in a minimum amount of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00). Applicants with three (3) or less vehicles shall furnish proof of motor vehicle liability insurance (or self-insurance) in a minimum amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) total aggregate limits and proof of general liability insurance in a minimum amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). The state, county and all municipalities, governmental units and authorities with Macon-Bibb County shall be exempted from the provisions of subsection; 
(5)  A signed affidavit affirming that the refuse to be deposited in the sanitary landfill will originate in the county, unless prior approval is obtained as required by law. 
(c)  Grounds for denial; approval of qualified applicants. No permit may be issued to any person if the person, owner or majority stockholder has, in the past five (5) years, been convicted in state or federal court of any offense involving illegal dumping or the mishandling or dumping of toxic or hazardous wastes. 
(d)  Suspension, revocation. Any permit issued under this section may be suspended or revoked by the judge of the municipal court, after giving the permit holder notice and an opportunity to be heard, upon the finding by the court that the permittee has done one (1) of the following: 
(1)  Violated any terms of this Code or committed any act made unlawful hereunder; 
(2)  Made any false statement or misrepresentation on the application for the permit; 
(3)  Violated any of the rules and regulations pertaining to landfill use established by Macon-Bibb County; 
(4)  Failed to pay proper permit fees, landfill user fees, or license fees due to Macon-Bibb County within thirty (30) days of their due date. 
The mayor may suspend a permit for up to thirty (30) days pending a hearing to be held in municipal court as provided above. 
(e)  Issuance; renewal; transferability; vehicle decal. Once an applicant has completed the application, furnished all required information, received approval of the Sheriff and paid the required fee, the city finance officer is authorized to issue a landfill user permit to the applicant. The permit issued hereunder shall be effective for each calendar year and shall be renewed each year thereafter as all other privileged licenses. The ownership of this permit is nontransferable. A permit shall be issued to each person who meets the qualifications set out above, along with a decal for each vehicle. The decal shall be permanently affixed to the lower right corner of the front windshield of each of the permittee's vehicles. This decal must be displayed in order for a vehicle (other than homeowners' and tenants') to be admitted to the landfill. 
(f)  Inspection of vehicles. The director of solid waste and the Sheriff are authorized to make inspection, from time to time, of all vehicles which are permitted to use the landfill, including their load, to ensure compliance with all local, state and federal laws, rules and regulations. 
(g)  Single-use permit. Upon completion of a single-use permit application and payment of the applicable fees shown thereon, an individual, not otherwise eligible to enter the landfill, shall be issued a single-use permit for access to the transfer station located at the landfill. 
( Ord. No. O-2014-0050, § 1, 9-2-2014 ) 
Sec. 22-104. - Service charges—Collection; lien for unpaid charges; change in rates; exemptions from payment. 
(a)  The service charges, specified in section 22-67 and costs specified in section 22-103 are levied against both the owner and occupant of the premises served, jointly and severally, but collection from one shall relieve the other. The service charges shall be collected in the manner and at such intervals as may be prescribed by resolution of the commission and shall be paid into the treasury. All uncollected service charges shall constitute a continuing lien against the property served to the same and as full an extent and subject to addition of interest and costs as provided by law with respect to city ad valorem taxes, and may be enforced in the same manner. 
(b)  With respect to the calendar year 2014 and subsequent years, the issuance by Macon-Bibb County of a business license to transact any business in Macon-Bibb County is conditioned upon the applicant for the license having fully paid all garbage service charges for which the applicant may have become liable for all prior years. 
Sec. 22-105. - Same—Executions; satisfaction and cancellation of record. 
There shall be entered upon each execution for unpaid garbage service charges and collected with the principal, interest and other costs thereof the cost charged by the clerk of the superior court of Bibb County, Georgia, for satisfying and cancelling each execution of record upon the general execution docket in his office. Upon full payment of each execution, the Macon-Bibb County clerk shall cause the execution to be delivered to the superior court clerk's office for satisfaction and cancellation of the execution of record and shall thereafter forward the satisfied and cancelled execution to the person which paid off the execution. Macon-Bibb County shall pay to the superior court clerk his charge for each execution satisfied and cancelled of record as provided in this section. 
Sec. 22-106. - Legislative determination; waste management fees; billing and collection of waste management fees; exemptions; nonpayment. 
(a)  The mayor and commission find and determine that there exists insufficient funding to accomplish the mandates imposed by the federal and state governments relating to solid waste management and that as a result of such mandates, a new source of funding is required for the purpose of funding recycling and composting programs in Macon-Bibb County, for the purpose of funding the $0.50 per ton surcharge upon solid waste disposal required by state law, for the purpose of offsetting the cost of collecting, removing and disposing of garbage and other refuse, and for the purpose of recovering the costs associated with collecting charges for such services. 
(b)  In accordance with the findings hereinabove set forth, there is hereby levied upon each owner of property to which waste collection services are provided a quarterly waste management fee as follows: 
Fees 
Residential units, including single-family dwellings, mobile homes, duplexes, triplexes and quadraplexes, with existing container collection, for each unit thereof\$45.00 
Residential units of the Macon housing authority, for each unit thereof\$30.00 
Household units for which collection services are provided under subsection (c), for each unit thereof\$45.00 
(c)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (b), the director of the division of solid waste shall have the discretion to designate other properties to which waste collection services will be provided, the owners of which shall be charged in accordance with the per unit fees set forth in said subsection and billed and collected in accordance with the provisions of this section. In considering whether to designate other properties to which waste collection services will be provided by Macon-Bibb County, the Director of Solid Waste shall take into consideration the location of the establishment, the applicable collection routes, the available manpower, the equipment and manpower necessary for such additional service, and all such other factors as may be necessary and proper to determine whether collection services will be economically and practicably feasible. 
(d)  The household waste management fee set forth in subsection (b), shall be billed and collected quarterly in advance by Macon-Bibb County pursuant to a contract as determined by the mayor. Such fees shall be charged to the owners of all of the properties designated in subsection (b), on or after July 1, 1996, and for each quarterly period thereafter, at the rate set forth in said subsection. 
(e)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, persons who are financially unable to pay in whole or in part the waste management fees applicable to them under the provisions of this section, may be relieved wholly or partially from payment of such fees. Guidelines for determining financial inability to pay shall be established by the mayor with the approval of the commission, provided that no relief from whole or partial payment shall continue for a period of more than one-year from the date granted except upon further application and approval thereof extending such relief for an additional period of time not to exceed one-year from the date of the grant of such extended relief from payment. All applications for initial and extended relief from payment of such fees shall be in writing, filed with the finance officer on or before February 1 for each year for which the exemption is sought. In instances in which an applicant for relief from whole or partial payment of waste management fees does not show financial inability to pay according to the guidelines established by the mayor and commission, such application shall be denied. 
(f)  All uncollected waste management fees shall constitute a continuing lien against the property served to the same extent and subject to the addition of interest and cost as provided by law with respect to city ad valorem taxes and may be enforced in the same manner. 
Sec. 22-107. - Private collection and disposal regulated; responsibility of franchisees. 
(a)  No person shall engage in the business of collecting, transporting, delivering or disposing of solid waste, other than industrial waste, generated by another person within Macon-Bibb County without first obtaining a franchise. 
(b)  Every person desiring to engage in the collecting, transporting, delivering or disposing of solid waste, other than industrial waste, generated by another person within Macon-Bibb County shall make written application to the Director of Solid Waste on forms prescribed by the director. 
(c)  Macon-Bibb County shall have the authority to determine that franchises will not be granted for certain classes of solid waste collection, such as residential solid waste, or in designated areas of Macon-Bibb County. 
(d)  Franchisees must comply with this chapter as well as any policies or regulations of Macon-Bibb County concerning solid waste collection to include recycling collection. 
(e)  In addition to any other permit required by Macon-Bibb County, all persons now or hereafter engaged in the business of the collection or transportation of solid waste, other than industrial waste, shall annually apply for a franchise to operate such business. The application shall be filed with the Director of Solid Waste and a franchise shall not be issued until the director has approved the application in writing. 
(f)  No franchise shall be issued or renewed except upon a written application available from the division of solid waste in a form prescribed by Macon-Bibb County and setting forth such facts as it may deem appropriate, including, but not limited to the franchise application information outlined in established policies and procedures. 
Sec. 22-108. - Franchisees; billing and fees. 
(a)  At the time of initial application for a franchise, a franchise application fee of $300.00 shall be paid to Macon-Bibb County. Said franchise application fee shall be nonrefundable. 
(b)  At the time of application for the renewal of the franchise, a franchise renewal fee of $300.00 shall be paid to Macon-Bibb County. 
Sec. 22-109. - Requirements. 
(a)  Condition for franchise. It shall be a condition of each franchise that the franchisee shall comply with all of the following: 
(1)  All provisions of this chapter, and the policies and/or procedures promulgated under authority of this chapter. 
(2)  All applicable federal, state, county and local laws, statutes, rules and regulations, including but not limited to those pertaining to the collection, transport, delivery or disposal of solid waste generated within Macon-Bibb County. 
(3)  Reasonable requirements for quarterly and annual reports which may be established by the director of solid waste. 
(b)  Denial of franchise. The director of solid waste may deny the issuance of the franchise for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Failure of the applicant to comply with this chapter. 
(2)  Violations of this chapter or any other applicable federal, county and local laws, statutes, rules and regulations, including, but not limited to, those pertaining to the collecting, transporting, delivering or disposing of solid waste generated within Macon-Bibb County. 
(3)  Prior criminal convictions in connection with solid waste collection, processing and disposal activities in the last ten years (other than minor traffic offenses) by the applicant, its subsidiaries or its parent company or prior license revocation(s) by the applicant, its subsidiaries or its parent company. 
(4)  Failure to pay any money due Macon-Bibb County. 
(5)  Misrepresentations of any material fact in the application for the franchise. 
Sec. 22-110. - Franchisees—Termination of franchise. 
(a)  Franchises may be terminated by mutual agreement of Macon-Bibb County and the franchisee at any time. Franchisees may terminate franchises by giving 60 days' notice to the director of the division of solid waste. 
(b)  Franchises are nontransferable. 
Sec. 22-111. - Revocation of franchise. 
Macon-Bibb County shall have the right to revoke the franchise of any person that fails to abide by any provision of this chapter and any policies and procedures authorized hereunder. Before revocation of a franchise, the director of solid waste shall inform the applicant of its intention and the applicant shall have the opportunity to be heard before the judge of the municipal court who shall make the final decision regarding the application. Prior revocation of a franchise shall be sufficient grounds for refusal to certify any future application by such franchisee. 
Secs. 22-112—22-119. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DRY SOLID WASTE 

Sec. 22-120. - Definition. 
As used in this division, the term "solid waste" shall have the meaning attributed to it by O.C.G.A. § 12-8-22, except that it shall not include putrescible waste, as such term is defined in section 22-140, or biomedical waste, as such term is defined in section 22-210. 
Sec. 22-121. - Compliance with Code required. 
No putrescible waste shall be deposited in a landfill in Macon-Bibb County unless the landfill operator complies with the provisions of this Code relating to the payment of a license fee and further complies with the provisions of sections 22-140 through 22-143. No biomedical waste shall be deposited in any landfill or incinerated unless the incinerator operator complies with the provisions of this Code relating to the payment of a license fee and further complies with the applicable provisions of sections 22-210 through 22-220. 
Sec. 22-122. - Requirements for license issuance. 
No person, firm or corporation shall commence or continue the operation of a landfill for the disposal of solid waste except upon payment of the fee above prescribed and the fact that a license has been issued, and no license shall be issued or continued in force except upon compliance with the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  The site of the landfill shall have been and shall remain approved by the Macon-Bibb County planning and zoning commission. 
(2)  The operator shall have obtained and shall maintain in force valid permits from the appropriate federal and state regulatory agencies. 
(3)  The landfill shall be operated at all times in full compliance with the terms of any permit from regulatory agencies and the planning and zoning commission. 
(4)  The landfill shall be operated in an efficient and workmanlike manner and in such fashion that it does not constitute a nuisance to others. 
(5)  The landfill operator shall permit to be placed in the landfill only those materials which are authorized by appropriate permits. Specifically, and without limiting the foregoing, there shall be no disposition in any landfill of solid waste or of nonsolid waste which would be classified as "hazardous" material. 
(6)  Liquid or nonsolid waste shall not be disposed of in a landfill. 
(7)  The operator of a landfill shall obtain and maintain in force throughout the period of time that the operator holds a license for the landfill a performance bond with good and sufficient security payable to Macon-Bibb County in the penal amount of $75,000.00 and conditioned upon compliance by the operator of the landfill with federal and state law and county ordinances respecting the operations of landfills. 
The requirement for furnishing good and sufficient security shall be deemed to have been satisfied if: 
a.  The bond which is furnished is secured by a corporate surety engaged in that business and authorized to do business in the state; 
b.  The bond is accompanied by the deposit in a federally insured bank in the sum of $75,000.00 evidenced by a certificate of deposit issued jointly in the name of the principal and the county; or 
c.  The bond is accompanied by a letter of credit from a federally-insured bank in the amount of $75,000.00. 
If a cash deposit is made and certificate of deposit issued, the terms of the deposit shall be such that the principal may not withdraw the amount so long as the principal is engaged in the landfill business in Macon-Bibb County without the consent of Macon-Bibb County, but may be drawn against by Macon-Bibb County at any time upon presentation of a resolution of the commission that the sum to be withdrawn has been determined by the commission to be necessary to cure a breach of the bond. Until otherwise ordered by the commission, interest on a bond shall be paid to the other joint owner. If a letter of credit is furnished, Macon-Bibb County shall be entitled to draw upon the letter of credit in the same manner as it might draw upon a cash deposit. In the event of cancellation or withdrawal of the letter of credit, the license of the principal to conduct a landfill operation shall automatically be suspended. 
(8)  The operator of the landfill shall obtain and maintain in force at all times a general public liability policy which will insure against injury or death to persons and injury or damage to property in the amounts, respectively, of $1,000,000.00 and $50,000.00. 
(9)  The operator of the landfill shall maintain records which will reflect, at a minimum, the date and hour of the deposit of each load of solid waste, the name and address of the owner of the truck in which the waste was delivered, and a general description of the waste which is deposited. The operator of the landfill shall file in the office of the Macon-Bibb County engineer a copy of such records by the tenth day of the following month reflecting landfill operations for the preceding calendar month. The landfill operator shall likewise furnish such other and further information to the engineer as he may require in order to verify the actual landfill operation. 
(10)  Every operator shall make the landfill and the records maintained in connection therewith available for inspection at reasonable times by the engineer or other person designated by the governing authority so as to enable Macon-Bibb County to determine whether the landfill is being operated properly. 
(11)  In addition to other remedies, if Macon-Bibb County shall determine that a landfill is being operated in violation of the provisions hereof, the commission may order the landfill closed or its operation suspended and in default of compliance with such order, the commission may seek an injunction to restrain further operations either on a permanent basis or until violations hereof are corrected. 
(12)  In determining whether Macon-Bibb County will issue a permit for the operation of a landfill, the commission may take into consideration the density of the population in the area which might be affected by the landfill. 
Secs. 22-123—22-139. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PUTRESCIBLE WASTE 

Sec. 22-140. - Definition. 
Putrescible waste shall mean those wastes which are capable of being quickly decomposed by microorganisms. Examples of putrescible wastes include, but are not necessarily limited to, kitchen wastes, animal manure, offal, hatchery and poultry processing plant wastes, dead animals, garbage and waste which are contaminated by such wastes. 
Sec. 22-141. - Application for landfill license. 
(a)  No person, firm or corporation shall commence or continue the operation of a landfill or the disposal of putrescible waste except upon the filing and approval of an application, payment of the license fee prescribed in exhibit A hereto, and compliance with the provisions set forth in this division. Provided however, no person, firm or corporation shall be denied or refused issuance of a permit for the commencement or continuance of the operation of a landfill for the disposal of putrescible waste if said person, firm or corporation completes and files the required application, tenders payment of the prescribed license fee, complies with the provisions set forth in this division and provides satisfactory evidence that such landfill has been duly permitted by the environmental protection division of the state department of natural resources. The license issued pursuant to this section shall be renewed upon the submission of a renewal application and the payment of a $5,000.00 license fee once every three years. The application and license fee required under this section shall be in addition to, and not a substitute for, any business license application or fee required by any other ordinance or provision of this Code or any applicable state law, rule or regulation. 
(b)  The application for the operation of a landfill under the provisions of this division shall show the name of the applicant. If the applicant is a corporation, it shall show the names and addresses of the officers, directors and the owners of a majority of the outstanding stock. If the applicant is a partnership, the application shall reflect the names and addresses of the partners. The application shall further reflect: 
(1)  The experience of the applicant in operating, maintaining and closing landfills. 
(2)  Whether the applicant, if an individual, or any officer, director or shareholder, if a corporation, or any partner, if a partnership, has been convicted of or pled guilty to any crime involving moral turpitude or any offense involving the violation of any law regulating the disposition of garbage or solid waste. 
(3)  Whether a certified landfill operator will be in charge of the day-to-day operations and if so, the name, address and license number of the operator. 
(4)  Such other information as may be reasonably necessary to determine fitness for operating and closing of landfill sites. Such information shall include audited comprehensive financial statements for the five years immediately preceding the year in which application is made under this division for the entity or individual(s) making application under this division, and any parent or subsidiary entity with which the applicant files a consolidated tax return for federal or state income tax purposes. Except for the information required by subsections (1), (2) and (3), and the audited comprehensive financial statements required by the preceding sentence, any other information which is required to be provided by the application shall not be unduly burdensome for the applicant, and such requested information shall not be duplicative of information provided by the applicant in response to the permitting process required by state law, or the rules and regulations promulgated pursuant thereto. 
Sec. 22-142. - Findings. 
Macon-Bibb County has legitimate legislative interests in protecting its residents, resources and environment from the adverse effects of disposing of putrescible waste in landfills located or to be located in the county. In furtherance of those interests, the commission has determined to take reasonable, lawful and appropriate measures, including the enactment of this division, to insure that the disposal of putrescible waste within the unincorporated areas of the county, including the location, operation and closure of landfills licensed hereunder, does not adversely affect the health or well-being of residents, does not diminish or degrade the quality of the air, soil, water and other natural resources and environment; does not unreasonably adversely affect the economic viability of any particular geographic area or region of the jurisdiction; does not conflict with Macon-Bibb County's short term and long term land use plans; and does not place an unreasonable or disproportionate burden on road maintenance and other public services. 
Sec. 22-143. - Requirements for license issuance. 
In furtherance of the findings and policies set forth in section 22-142, no license shall be issued under this division or continued of force except upon compliance with the following provisions: 
(1)  Reserved. 
(2)  The licensee and the landfill shall be subject to and shall comply with all of the provisions set out in section 22-122(1) through (12), except that: 
a.  Reserved. 
b.  The amounts of the general public liability policy described in subsection [22-122](8) shall be $10,000,000.00 for injury or death to persons and $5,000,000.00 for injury or damage to property. The term "general public liability policy" shall also include environmental impairment liability coverage in the amounts stated. 
(3)  The licensee shall provide, construct and maintain an asphalt or concrete exit roadway from the right-of-way of the state or county highway on which egress from the landfill occurs back to the landfill operation. The licensee shall maintain said exit roadway in a clean condition. 
(4)  The licensee shall take such action as is reasonably necessary to prevent scavenging. 
(5)  Burning or other incineration at the landfill is prohibited. 
(6)  Each licensee shall take such measures as are necessary to prevent the harboring and feeding of wild dogs or other animals at the landfill site. 
(7)  The licensee shall take such measures as will prevent scavenging and scattering of any windblown litter and will keep the premises in a sightly condition. 
(8)  Landfill sites shall be enclosed with a minimum four foot "red page wire" fence and topped with two strands of barbed wire. Entrances and exits shall be only through gates monitored by the licensee. 
(9)  The operating hours for the landfill site shall be as stated and required in the permit issued by the environmental protection division of the state department of natural resources, a copy of which shall be provided to the Macon-Bibb County engineer. Provided however, in the event that the operating hours are not stated in such permit, then the landfill shall be opened and operated only between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m., current time. The hours of operation of the landfill site for any given day may be extended under exigent circumstances with the prior approval of the engineer or the mayor. 
(10)  Reserved. 
(11)  The licensee shall be responsible for the control and proper disposal of incidental litter by policing the landfill site. 
(12)  The licensee shall prepare a fire prevention control plan which shall be submitted to and approved by the engineer. Such fire prevention control plan shall demonstrate the procedures and safeguards implemented by the licensee for preventing and controlling fires at the landfill site. 
(13)  The landfill site shall be subject to periodic inspections by the engineer or his designee at any time upon the providing of at least 24 hours advanced notice to the licensee or its on-site designee. 
(14)  The license issued hereunder shall be transferable, subject to the transferee completing and submitting the application required by section 22-141 and upon evidencing compliance with all other requirements set forth in this division in the same manner as required of the transferor. In addition thereto, no transfer of the license issued hereunder shall be valid without the transferee first having been issued the required permit by the environmental protection division of the state department of natural resources. Evidence of the issuance of such permit shall be submitted as part of the application required by section 22-141. Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, the transfer of a license issued in accordance with this division shall not be effective any sooner than 90 days after the transferor has given written notice to the Macon-Bibb County engineer of the transferor's intent to transfer the license to another person, firm or corporation. The identity of the transferee shall be stated in the written notice required by the preceding sentence. 
Excepted from the provisions of this division are landfills owned and operated by Macon-Bibb County which began operations prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives; provided, however, that any expansion of its landfill operation beyond its present permitted capacity shall require Macon-Bibb County to comply with the terms of this division. 
Secs. 22-144—22-159. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SURCHARGE ON CERTAIN DISPOSAL FACILITIES 

Sec. 22-160. - Definition. 
Municipal solid waste disposal facility shall have the same meaning as defined in O.C.G.A. § 12-8-22(19). 
Sec. 22-161. - Levied. 
There is hereby levied upon every municipal solid waste disposal facility operated by private enterprise and upon the operators thereof, a surcharge of $1.00 per ton or a volume equivalent thereto received by the facility, in addition to any other charges or fees which are now or which may hereafter be imposed by Macon-Bibb County for the facility. 
Sec. 22-162. - Determination of tonnage. 
The tonnage or volume equivalent thereto with respect to which the surcharge is hereby levied shall be such as is finally determined by the environmental protection division of the state department of natural resources. When the periodic report of tonnage is prepared by the environmental protection division of the state department of natural resources, whether monthly or otherwise, each operator affected hereby shall be advised either by the environmental protection division or Macon-Bibb County of the tonnage or equivalency thereof as determined, and each operator of a municipal solid waste disposal facility shall remit to Macon-Bibb County the amount of the surcharge determined as provided in section 22-161 within ten days. If the environmental protection division shall fail to make the determination, it shall be made by Macon-Bibb County. 
Sec. 22-163. - Appropriations. 
Upon receipt of the surcharge from a municipal solid waste disposal facility, the finance director shall cause the same to be deposited into a separate account and the funds so collected and deposited are hereby appropriated to offset the impact of the facility, public education efforts for waste management, the cost of solid waste management, and the administration of local or regional solid waste management plans as determined from time to time by the governing authority of Macon-Bibb County. 
Sec. 22-164. - Penalty. 
Any person who shall violate the provisions of this article or who shall fail to make timely payments of the surcharge levied in section 22-161 shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in article X. 
Secs. 22-165—22-179. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - RESERVED 

Secs. 22-180—22-209. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - INCINERATION OF WASTE 

Sec. 22-210. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Biomedical waste means and includes the following: 
(1)  Pathological waste, which means all recognizable human tissues and body parts which are removed during surgery, obstetrical procedures, autopsy, and laboratory procedures. 
(2)  Biological waste, which means bulk blood and blood products, exudates, secretions, suctionings, and other bulk body fluids which cannot or are not directly discarded into a municipal sewer system. 
(3)  Cultures and stocks of infectious agents and associated biologicals including cultures from medical and pathological laboratories, cultures and stocks of infectious agents from research and industrial laboratories, wastes from the production of biologicals, discarded live and attenuated vaccines, and culture dishes and devices used to transfer, inoculate and mix cultures. 
(4)  Contaminated animal carcasses, body parts, and their bedding, and other wastes from such animals which have been exposed to infectious agents, capable of causing disease in man, during research, production of biologicals or testing of pharmaceuticals. 
(5)  Sharps, which means any discarded article which may cause punctures or cuts. Such waste includes, but is not limited to, items such as needles, IV tubing and syringes and needles attached, and scalpel blades. 
(6)  Chemotherapy waste, which means any disposable material which has come in contact with cytotoxic/antineoplastic agents (agents toxic to cells) and/or antineoplastic agents (agents that inhibit or prevent the growth and spread of tumors or malignant cells) during the preparation, handling and administration of such agents. Such waste includes, but is not limited to, masks, gloves, gowns, empty IV tubing, bags and vials, and other contaminated materials. The above waste must first be classified as empty which means such quantity that it is not subject to other federal or state waste management regulations prior to being handled as biomedical waste. 
(7)  Discarded medical equipment and parts, not including expendable supplies and materials which have not been contaminated, that were in contact with infectious agents. 
The term "biomedical waste" shall not include low level radioactive waste and laboratory hazardous waste, the incineration and/or disposal of which is expressly prohibited, except as provided by federal and state law. 
Biomedical waste incinerator facility means an incinerator or incinerators at a single location which accept biomedical waste for purposes of incineration. 
Commission means the Macon-Bibb County commission. 
Environmental quality board (EQB) means a board of five citizens appointed by the commission to assist in the administration of this article. The EQB shall only function when members are named and appointed by the commission following a request for a permit to construct and/or operate a principal use incinerator facility or a biomedical waste incinerator. Unless otherwise directed by the commission, the terms of service of the members appointed to the EQB shall end upon the approval or denial of such permit application. 
Incineration means a controlled process by which solid, liquid and gaseous combustible wastes are burned and changed into gases and a residue produced which is relatively free of combustible materials. 
Incineration facility means the combined incinerators under one ownership at a single location. 
Incinerator means all devices intended or used for the reduction or destruction of solid, liquid or gaseous wastes by burning. 
Incinerator ash means the residue remaining after the incineration of solid waste. 
Operator means the person having the direct supervision of daily field operations of an incineration facility to ensure that the site operates in compliance with the permit. 
Person means the state of Georgia or any other state or any agency or institution thereof, and any municipality, political subdivision, public or private corporation, special district, partnership association or other entity in Georgia or any other state. The term also includes any officer or governing or managing body of any municipality, political subdivision, special district empowered in solid waste activities, or public or private corporation in Georgia or any other state. This term also includes employees, departments and agencies of the federal government. 
Principal use incinerator facility is an incinerator or incinerators at a single location where the incineration process is a primary business and where the facility has the total capacity of burning greater than 250 pounds per hour. 
Sec. 22-211. - Findings. 
Macon-Bibb County is confronted with increasing quantities of solid wastes and the decreasing availability of landfill space, and there is an urgent need to regulate the handling of solid waste. The incineration of solid waste is increasingly proposed as a partial alternative to land disposal, however incineration of waste poses certain hazards to the environment and creates special problems of residue disposal in landfills. The handling and disposal of biomedical waste poses certain unique hazards and is of special public concern. Under article 9, section 2, paragraph 3 of the state constitution and under the provisions of the Georgia Solid Waste Management Act (O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20—12-8-41) local governments are empowered with the responsibility to regulate solid waste handling and air quality in such manner as to assure the public health, safety and welfare. 
Sec. 22-212. - Purpose. 
The purposes of this article are to: 
(1)  Regulate the location, operation and management of incineration facilities dealing with the storage, transfer, treatment or disposal of waste where the total incinerator capacity is of greater than 250 pounds per hour. 
(2)  Regulate the disposal of biomedical wastes which require special handling in order to protect the public health, safety and welfare of the citizens of Macon-Bibb County. 
Sec. 22-213. - Permits required. 
(a)  Owners and operators of incinerators applying for a permit under this article shall be permitted as required by the rules and regulations of the environmental protection division of the state department of natural resources and the United States Environmental Protection Agency. Any violation of the conditions of the permit issued by the environmental protection division of the state department of natural resources and/or the United States Environmental Protection Agency, and any violation of the rules and regulations of the environmental protection division of the state department of natural resources, United States Environmental Protection Agency, the state department of transportation, the United States Department of Transportation, and rules and regulations promulgated under the Occupation Safety and Health Act shall also be a violation of the conditions of the permit issued pursuant to this article. 
(b)  No person shall engage in the operation of a principal use incinerator and no person shall construct or operate a principal use incinerator facility without having a permit issued by the board pursuant to this article. 
(c)  No person shall operate a biomedical waste incinerator or shall construct or operate a biomedical waste incinerator facility without having a valid biomedical incinerator permit issued by the board pursuant to this article. 
(d)  Any person who began operation of a principal use incinerator facility or a biomedical waste incinerator facility prior to the adoption of the ordinance from which this section derives, and who would otherwise be subject to its terms shall be permitted to continue the operation of such facility but the person shall be strictly prohibited from transferring ownership or operation of or expanding its incinerator operation in any way, unless the person first makes application to the commission in accordance with this article and complies with the applicable provisions hereof. The term "expanding its incinerator operation" shall mean any action taken by such person after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives to increase its present state permitted volume of waste incineration and disposal of the facility. 
Sec. 22-213.1. - Notification/permit modification requirements. 
(a)  The holder of a permit issued pursuant to this article shall be required to make application to the commission for a modification of its existing permit issued pursuant to this article in the event that any of the following changes or modifications shall occur after the date upon which the permit is originally issued: 
(1)  Any modification of equipment or operation of the incineration facility; 
(2)  Any change of ownership or operator of the incineration facility; 
(3)  Any change in hours of operation of the incineration facility; 
(4)  Any increase in waste throughput at the incineration facility; 
(5)  Any change in the types of waste being treated at the incineration facility; 
(6)  Any change in residue disposal practices; and/or 
(7)  Any changes in the incineration facility's ash management plan. 
(b)  The commission, or its designee, shall establish a short form application for the purpose of reviewing and facilitating the processing of permit modification requests under this section. 
(c)  The application procedure for permit modification requests shall be the same as required for initial permit applications under section 22-216. 
Sec. 22-214. - Contents of permit application. 
A permit applicant shall prepare and file an incineration permit application with the commission. The permit application shall include all related documents submitted to the United States government and to the state. 
(1)  An application shall contain the following information: 
a.  A description of the company, information on its financial capability, and a detailed history of all its past activities in the field of incineration, including a synopsis of every other facility it has operated, and including a detailed account of all past and pending litigation, favorable and unfavorable. The applicant shall include the record of any subsidiary or parent corporation having an interest greater than five percent of the outstanding shares of the applicant corporation. The applicant shall also include a list of all past and present litigation, favorable and unfavorable, the subsidiary or parent corporation has been involved in. 
1.  The identity of whom the applicant purchased the incinerator from, its manufacturer, and the contractor(s) responsible for the installation and/or modification of the incinerator and air pollution control devices. 
b.  The applicant shall provide a history of any claims, charges and/or assessments against the applicant concerning or arising out of the violation of any state or federal rule or regulation relating in any way to any incineration facility, now or formerly owned/operated by the applicant, including any incineration facility now or formerly owned/operated by any subsidiary or parent corporation of the applicant. 
c.  Justification for and anticipated benefits from the project. 
d.  A description of the scope of the proposed project, including an estimated schedule of how much and what kinds of waste the facility would accept, where the material would come from, what pretreatment will be required of wastes unacceptable to the facility without such pretreatment, and how long the facility is expected to operate. 
e.  Yearly site operation expenses and an estimate of the costs for the lifetime of the project. 
f.  The proposed method of financing the project, including development, operation and closure stages. Include a list of the financial institution names which will be funding construction. 
g.  Resumes of management personnel and the proposed number of employees and types of positions, including information on the training and experience required for each position, and safety precautions undertaken for the protection of personnel. 
h.  The anticipated date to begin construction. 
i.  The anticipated date to begin operation. 
j.  A detailed estimate of the types and amount of local government services required by the operator in each year. 
k.  A description of emergency procedures and safety and security precautions that will be in use at the facility. This information should include details on emergency assistance and emergency medical treatment that will be required from the area's medical facilities and fire departments. 
l.  A description of the environmental protection measures to be taken by the applicant to prevent contamination in and around the facility site and the description of planned monitoring systems, with an estimated budget for each of these items. 
m.  A description of the environmental protection measures to be used during transportation of materials to and from the facility, with an estimated annual budget for these arrangements and an estimate of the volume of material to be transported during each year of operation. 
n.  A description of the site closure plan for the facility, the anticipated date of closure, and the estimated cost of closure, including post closure costs, if applicable. 
o.  A description of anticipated need for postclosure care. 
p.  A description of the means or method by which to capture any leachate or runoff from waste feed and ash storage areas, and areas in which trucks, equipment, containers and tools that have come into contact with the waste are decontaminated and processed for disposal. 
(2)  A map or other written material attached to the application shall include the following information: 
a.  Ownership. 
1.  Name, address and telephone number of legal owner (and/or agent) of the subject property. 
2.  Name, address and telephone number of professional persons responsible for plat of survey. 
3.  Description of any existing rights-of-way or easements affecting the property. 
4.  Reference to any existing restrictive covenants to the property. 
b.  Description. Location of property tax map parcel number. This description should include a reference to the deed book and page or other evidence of title the current property owner may have. 
c.  Features. Each map shall contain the following information: 
1.  Drawn to scale of not less than 160 feet to an inch. 
2.  Location sketch map showing relationship of the project to the surrounding area. 
3.  Graphic scale, date, north arrow and legend. 
4.  Location of property with respect to surrounding property and roads, and the names and addresses of adjacent property owners according to county tax records. 
5.  Zoning classification of proposed project and adjacent property. 
6.  The location of all boundary lines of the property. 
7.  The total acreage of land in the project. 
8.  The location of existing and/or platted streets, easements, buildings, railroads, cemeteries, bridges, sewers, water mains, culverts, wells and gas and electric transmissions lines. 
9.  The location of water bodies, watercourses, groundwater aquifers, springs and other pertinent features. 
10.  The location, dimensions and acreage of all property proposed to be set aside for various uses on the applicant's property. 
11.  The location of all test wells and/or borings. 
12.  The location of the 500-year and 100-year floodplain, and records of flood, including inundation due to dam break. 
d.  Reserved. 
e.  Topographic map. A topographic map with contours at vertical intervals of not more than ten feet at the same scale as to the project site map shall be included. Date, method of preparation and preparer of such survey shall be stated. 
f.  Transportation route map. A map showing proposed transportation routes to and from the facility site, including location of towns and emergency and safety facilities. An estimate of the volume of material to travel on each route shall be included. 
(3)  The application shall address the following factors with regard to, but not limited to, on-site storage and/or disposal: 
a.  Possibility of site flooding; planned special facility design. 
b.  Potential human exposure to incinerator ash and wastewater, including planned safety procedures, clothing, instruction, and practice for employees; planned oversized or redundant treatment capacity, effluent monitoring and automatic shutdown systems. 
c.  The nature and predictability of pollution movement, including planned stack height for incinerators, with continuous stack monitoring and recording, until emission levels are predictable; and planned segregation of incompatible wastes. 
Sec. 22-215. - Application and processing fees. 
The commission shall require a permit application fee in the amount of $50,000.00 to reimburse Macon-Bibb County for the costs of any needed professional assistance that may be required to evaluate the permit application and amendments, verify its contents and evaluate the impact of such a permit on the community, public health and environment. This assistance may include, but shall not be limited to, the assistance of lawyers, biologists, geologists, engineers, chemists, hydrologists, emergency response, transportation and public health experts, land appraisers and professional testing laboratories. Funds not so expended in the legitimate review of the permit application shall be returned to the applicant. 
Sec. 22-216. - Application procedure. 
(a)  The permit applicant shall submit to the commission six copies of all information required by federal and state agencies for the facility for which it requests a permit at the time such information is submitted to the state and federal government. The review procedure shall not begin nor shall the application be designated as complete until such time as all required data are submitted and the appropriate fees are paid, or suitable arrangements for payment have been approved by the commission. 
(b)  A designee of the commission shall compile copies of all reports, applications, minutes of the EQB meetings, reports by consultants and similar materials. These shall be placed in one location with free access by the public and availability of copying any portion of any document at cost. 
(c)  Within 45 days of the submission of the application, the commission shall set a time for a public hearing so that the applicant can present its plans to the EQB and answer questions regarding the same. 
(d)  After the hearing, the board after consultation with the EQB, shall have 60 days in which to determine if the application is complete and shall mail notice of its determination to the applicant. If it is not complete, the applicant will have six months to complete the application. However, the applicant may at the end of six months upon making a showing of good cause to the commission, be granted a maximum three-month extension. 
(e)  Each application shall require an analysis conducted by the Macon-Bibb County staff and a consultant or consultants selected by the commission upon the recommendation of the EQB. The analysis shall be completed within 90 days from the day the application is determined to be complete. In certain instances where the complexity of the application requires more than the usual 90 days, the Macon-Bibb County staff and/or consultant may request an additional 60 days from the board, and the applicant, likewise, has the option of requesting the commission to extend the analysis period to allow time for responding to staff and/or consultant request for additional information on a completed application. 
(f)  The Macon-Bibb County staff and each consultant shall make reports on the application to the EQB at its meetings. 
(g)  The EQB shall call a public meeting for public comment on the completed application along with the analysis of Macon-Bibb County staff and consultants. The purpose of this meeting shall be for public review of the application. The staff shall give notice by regular mail of the time and place of the public meeting to the owner and adjacent property owners as specified on the map. Such notice shall be mailed not less than 14 days prior to the date specified thereon. Notice of a public meeting in a form prescribed by the EQB shall be posted by the applicant on the proposed facility property on each and every street of access not less than 14 days prior to the date specified thereon. The posted notice shall be at intervals of not greater than 1,500 feet. Notice shall also be placed by the applicant in the local newspaper of general circulation not less than 14 days prior to the dates specified thereon. 
(h)  Within 45 days after receipt of the final analysis, complete application and public comment, the EQB shall make a recommendation to the commission at a public meeting whether to accept the application, deny it, or accept it with modifications. This recommendation shall be made to the full commission at a public meeting whether to accept the application, deny it, or accept it with modifications. This recommendation shall be made to the full commission; however, before making a recommendation to the commission to accept the proposal or accept it with modifications, the EQB shall make the following determinations: 
(1)  That there is a bona fide need for the facility and there is no reasonable alternative facility which will pose a lesser threat to the environment. 
(2)  That the construction and operation of the facility will not pose an unreasonable health or environmental risk to the surrounding locality. 
(3)  That the applicant (or facility operator) has the capability and financial resources to construct, operate and maintain the facility. 
(4)  That the applicant or operator has taken or consented in writing to take any and all reasonable measures to comply with the applicable federal, state and local regulations and ordinances. 
(5)  That the applicant's plan represents the best available technology for handling the waste for which the applicant has demonstrated that it will employ the best management practices in handling the waste at the proposed facility. 
(6)  That the incineration facility is compatible with an integrated long range solid waste management plan, taking into account alternative methods of management such as recycling. 
(7)  That the applicant has a valid contract with the operator of a state licensed landfill for the disposal of the projected ash production of the incineration facility for a three-year period. 
(i)  At its next scheduled meeting, the commission shall make its decision to grant the permit, deny it, or grant it with specified conditions. 
(j)  A permit shall be valid for 36 months from the date it is granted by the commission. 
Sec. 22-216.1. - Record keeping, reporting requirements and inspections. 
(a)  The holder of a permit issued pursuant to this article shall be required to perform such monitoring and recording of process and operational parameters as deemed necessary and appropriate by the commission with the advice of the EQB. Monitored parameters and required measuring and recording frequencies may include, but not limited to, one or more of the following: 
(1)  Frequency and mass of waste charging (continuous). 
(2)  Ash generation rate (weekly). 
(3)  Primary and secondary chamber temperatures (continuous). 
(4)  Flue gas opacity (continuous). 
(5)  Auxiliary fuel usage (weekly). 
(6)  Primary and secondary combustion air flow rates (weekly). 
(7)  L.D. fan motor current (weekly). 
(8)  Wet scrubbers (weekly): 
a.  Scrubber liquid header pressure. 
b.  Scrubber liquid flow rate. 
c.  Scrubber liquid pH (daily). 
d.  Scrubber static pressure drop. 
e.  Demister static pressure drop. 
(9)  Dry scrubbers and spray dry absorbers: 
a.  Reagent flow rate (daily). 
b.  Slaker slurry outlet temperature (weekly). 
c.  Solids recycle rate (weekly). 
d.  Nozzle air and slurry pressures (weekly). 
e.  Wet and dry bulb temperatures (weekly). 
(10)  Fabric filters: 
a.  Bag failure records (continuous). 
b.  Static pressure drop (weekly). 
c.  Baghouse inlet and outlet temperatures (weekly). 
(11)  Flue gas concentrations: 
a.  Acid gases. 
b.  CO. 
c.  O 2 , CO 2 . 
d.  Opacity. 
(b)  The holder of a permit issued pursuant to this article shall be required to perform a TCLP ash sampling based upon a schedule to be determined by the commission or its designee, which may include the taking of daily grab samples, the analysis of composite grab samples, the analysis of composite grab samples at such frequency as determined by the commission or its designee. 
(c)  The holder of a permit issued pursuant to this article may be required by the commission or its designee to engage in performance testing of the incineration facility at one or more of the following times: the initial startup of a new incineration facility, the startup of an existing incineration facility after significant modification or operational changes, prior to the issuance of an initial permit, and/or the renewal of an existing county permit. Such testing may include, but shall not be limited to, the following: TCLP testing of ash, combustibility testing of ash, putrescility testing of ash, stack testing for acid gases, metals, CO, VOC's, dioxins/furans, PM, etc., and biologic tracer test. 
(d)  The holder of a permit issued pursuant to this article shall be required to provide the commission or its designee, the Macon-Bibb County health department, environmental section, copies of all semi-annual reports submitted to the environmental protection division of the state (EPD), all notices of violation from EPD and responses thereto, EPD reports of no-notice site inspections, and all other correspondence with and submissions to the state EPD. Additionally, Macon-Bibb County shall be promptly notified of any occurrence of a serious nature likely to cause public concern, including but not limited to, fire, explosion, or extensive uncontrolled emissions. 
(e)  The holder of a permit issued pursuant to this article shall be required to provide to the commission or its designee, on an annual basis, the resumes of supervisory and management personnel responsible for the supervision and management of the incineration facility, and all records of training and certification relating to any employee of the incineration facility. 
(f)  The holder of a permit issued pursuant to this article shall be required to present an ash management plan to the commission or its designee at the time that the holder of a permit first makes application for an initial permit pursuant to this article, and annually thereafter following the issuance of the permit for the operation of the incineration facility. Such plan shall include a description of the estimated quantity of ash to be disposed of during the upcoming year, and the names, addresses and telephone numbers of all landfills where such ash will be disposed. 
(g)  The commission or its designee shall have the right to perform inspections of the incineration facility during normal operating hours without prior notice to the owner/operator of such facility. The commission's or its designee's right to perform inspections under this subsection shall include the authority to perform independent testing on any aspect of the performance of the incineration facility for purposes of monitoring the facility's compliance with this article. The commission or its designee, shall have the authority to require that the holder of a county permit issued pursuant to this article be required to install auxiliary sampling ports as a condition of its permit for the purpose of supporting inspections and independent testing. 
Sec. 22-216.2. - Insurance requirements. 
A condition of every permit issued pursuant to this article shall be the requirement that the holder of said permit maintain environmental impairment liability insurance and general public liability insurance in such amounts to be determined by the commission or its designee based upon such objective factors as the board deems appropriate to provide for the protection of its citizens and the environment, including but not by way of limitation: the permitted capacity of the incineration facility, the cost of the incineration facility, the environmental safety record and history of the type of equipment installed at the incineration facility, the environmental safety record and history of the manufacturer of the incineration facility, the environmental safety record and history of the owner/operator of the incineration facility, and the estimated cost of closure and post closure. The amount of environmental impairment liability insurance and general public liability insurance required by the commission, or its designee, shall not exceed $10,000,000.00 actual coverage nor be less than a minimum of $1,000,000.00 actual coverage. The amount of environmental impairment liability coverage established by the commission, or its designee, shall be required to remain in force for five years subsequent to the closure of the incineration facility. Once the amount of actual coverage required by the commission, or its designee, is established for the incineration facility, the applicant shall provide the commission, or its designee, evidence of such insurance coverage prior to the issuance of the permit. 
Sec. 22-216.3. - Packing and refrigeration. 
(a)  All biomedical waste transported to the biomedical waste incineration facility and accepted for incineration at such facility shall be packaged in containers which meet or exceed the requirements of 49 CFR 173.196 and 197, or such federal or state regulations which may be adopted in the future setting forth the minimum packaging requirements for biomedical waste. 
(b)  The holder of a permit issued pursuant to this article shall be required to provide refrigerated transportation and storage of biomedical waste that has been or is expected to be held for longer than 72 hours after being discarded at its point of origin. 
Sec. 22-217. - Control of emissions. 
Emissions from all principal use incinerator facilities and all biomedical waste incinerator facilities shall not cause ambient pollution concentrations to exceed levels established by the environmental protection division of the state department of natural resources (EPD/DNR) or levels established by the commission or its designee, if such levels, as established, are more stringent than those established by EPD/DNR. The commission, or its designee, may be required as a condition of any initial permit, renewal and/or modification thereof, that ambient pollution concentrations not exceed specific levels as established pursuant to this section. 
Sec. 22-218. - Certification of operator. 
No person shall operate a principal use medical waste incinerator unless such individual who operates or maintains the incinerator obtains a certificate of training in medical waste incinerators issued by the American Society of Mechanical engineers within nine months of the commencement of the training program. Copies of the training certificates for the operators and maintenance engineers shall be submitted to the EQB and shall be available for inspection at the facility along with the permit to operate. 
Sec. 22-219. - Issuance of permit and fee. 
Should the commission grant a principal use incinerator facility permit or a biomedical waste incinerator facility permit in accordance with the terms of this article, the permit shall not be issued by Macon-Bibb County until the person to whom the permit is granted complies with the provisions of this Code relating to the payment of a license fee. 
Sec. 22-220. - Penalty. 
Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate the provisions of this article shall, on conviction, be punished as provided in article X. In addition thereto, the commission shall be authorized to seek injunctive relief to restrain further violation of this article. 
Secs. 22-221—22-229. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - STORAGE OF USED OR DISCARDED MATERIALS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 22-230—22-250. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OUTSIDE STORAGE OF DISCARDED APPLIANCES 

Sec. 22-251. - Definition. 
For the purposes of this division, the word "appliance" or "appliances" refers to stoves, refrigerators, hot water heaters, air conditioning equipment, furnaces, washers, dryers and similar items falling under the general classification of household appliances. 
Sec. 22-252. - Finding. 
This body finds that the outside storage of discarded appliances renders the property whereon appliances are stored unsightly and unattractive, attracts rodents and insects, devalues neighboring property and constitutes a nuisance. 
Sec. 22-253. - Outside or uncovered storage of appliances prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, organization or association of any kind in charge or control of any property within the area of Macon-Bibb County, whether as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee, agent or otherwise, to store or permit the storage of appliances in the open. An appliance shall be deemed to have been stored in the open if it is visible from the street or streets upon which the property may front and when viewed from adjoining property or uncovered. 
Sec. 22-254. - Planning and zoning regulations not affected. 
Nothing contained herein shall be deemed to authorize any outside storage when it is prohibited by regulations of the Macon-Bibb County planning and zoning commission. 
Sec. 22-255. - Division to carry out terms of article. 
The environmental health division and the environmental education and enforcement officer are authorized and empowered to carry out the provision of this article and each employee of the division and the environmental education and enforcement officer are authorized and empowered to issue citations for violations hereof. 
ARTICLE X. - ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 22-256. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  Any person(s), firm or corporation violating any provision of article IX where such violation occurs within Macon-Bibb County, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof in the Macon-Bibb County Municipal Court or magistrate court of Bibb County, shall be punished as follows: 
(1)  For the first offense. By a fine of not less than $100.00 and not more than $1,000.00, or up to 30 days imprisonment, or both. Each day the violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. However this section shall not preclude Macon-Bibb County from choosing to seek civil redress in a court of competent jurisdiction in addition to the criminal prosecution, it being the intent of the jurisdiction to have both the civil and criminal rights of prosecution in this area; 
(2)  For the second or more offense(s). The violator shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of high and aggravated nature punishable by a fine of not less than $750.00 and not more than $1,000.00, or up to 60 days imprisonment, or both. Each day the violation continues shall constitute a separate offense; and/or 
(b)  In the sound discretion of the judge of the court with jurisdiction, the person may also be directed to pick up and remove from any public street or highway and/or other public right of way for a distance not to exceed one-mile, any litter the person has deposited, and any and all litter deposited thereon by anyone else prior to the date of execution of sentence; and/or
