(a)  Whenever personal property is acquired by Macon-Bibb County at a sale for taxes, in view of the fact that under state law, title vests absolutely in Macon-Bibb County at the time of sale, the mayor shall, upon report from the tax commissioner that the property has been acquired, determine whether the property or any part thereof is useful to any department or agency of Macon-Bibb County and, if it is found to be useful, the property may be transferred to such department or agency. 
(b)  If the property or part thereof is not useful to Macon-Bibb County or an agency thereof, the mayor is authorized to declare the same surplus and dispose of it in accordance with state law. 
Secs. 26-51—26-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REFUNDS 

Sec. 26-61. - Refunds not favored. 
In recognition of the general rule that taxes voluntarily paid are not to be recovered by the payor, applications for refunds of taxes paid to Macon-Bibb County are not favored. Since the law of the state authorizes the making of refunds of taxes under certain circumstances, and in view of the obvious equity in favor of a taxpayer which may exist in certain cases, applications for tax refunds may be granted upon terms and conditions set out in this division. 
Sec. 26-62. - General rules. 
Applications for refund of taxes will not be favorably considered if the taxpayer has made a voluntary payment of taxes and no public officer or employee of Macon-Bibb County has done any negligent act which would mislead the taxpayer in making payment of taxes which he subsequently claims he did not owe. 
Sec. 26-63. - Duplication ordinarily required. 
Ordinarily, no claim for tax refunds will be approved unless the tax sought to be refunded is duplicative of other taxes paid with respect to the same property by some other person. 
Sec. 26-64. - Joint negligence or action. 
Even if the negligent act of a public employee contributed to the payment of taxes alleged not to be due, but the governing authority of Macon-Bibb County finds that, under all the circumstances, the negligence of the claimant was equal to or greater than the negligence act of the public officer or employee, the application for refund will be denied. 
Sec. 26-65. - Monetary limitation. 
If a tax refund is granted, the amount to be refunded shall not exceed the actual amount paid by the taxpayer, without interest thereon. 
Sec. 26-66. - Surrender of documents or reconveyance. 
If an applicant for a tax refund is the transferee of tax fi. fa. or has acquired the property by tax deed, it shall be a condition precedent to the payment of any refund which may be approved that the taxpayer retransfer the tax fi. fa. to Macon-Bibb County or quitclaim the property to Macon-Bibb County, as may be appropriate. 
Sec. 26-67. - Time limitation. 
No claim for tax refund shall be approved where the taxes alleged to have been erroneously paid or collected were paid more than three years prior to the date of filing of the application for refund with the governing authority, nor shall any refund be granted with respect to any taxes for any tax year, regardless of the date of payment, which is more than seven years prior to the date of filing the application for refund. 
Sec. 26-68. - Other factors may be considered. 
The enumeration of factors to be considered in determining whether or not the Macon-Bibb County will approve a refund of taxes is illustrative and not exclusive, the restructured government reserving the right to make in the exercise of sound discretion, a determination to approve or deny such applications on sound equitable principles whether or not expressly set forth elsewhere in this division. 
Secs. 26-69—26-71. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - IN REM TAX FORECLOSURES PER O.C.G.A. § 48-4-75 et seq. 

Sec. 26-72. - Scope. 
This article is enacted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-4-75 et seq. in addition to and as an alternative to non-judicial tax foreclosure. The tax commissioner is authorized to undertake judicial in rem foreclosure of delinquent ad valorem tax executions. 
Sec. 26-73. - Conflict with state law. 
Should any portion of this division conflict with state law, the applicable state law will control. State law only controls the conflicting portion of the division; the non-conflicting portions remain unaffected. 
Sec. 26-74. - Definitions. 
Clerk means the clerk of the superior court of Macon-Bibb County, Georgia. 
Court means the superior court of Macon-Bibb County, Georgia. 
Interested party means: 
(1)  Those parties having an interest in the property as revealed by a certification of title to the property conducted in accordance with the title standards of the state bar; 
(2)  Those parties having filed a notice in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-3-9; 
(3)  Any other party having an interest in the property whose identity and address are reasonably ascertainable from the records maintained by the tax commissioner, clerk, or other records maintained in the Macon-Bibb County courthouse. "Interested party" shall not include the holder of the benefit or burden of any easement or right-of-way whose interest is properly recorded, which interest shall remain unaffected. 
Redemption amount means the full amount of the delinquent ad valorem taxes, accrued interest at the rate specified in O.C.G.A. § 48-2-40, penalties as determined in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-2-44, and costs incurred by Macon-Bibb County in collecting such taxes as allocated in its discretion, including without limitation the cost of title examination, attorney's fees, and publication of notice. 
Sec. 26-75. - The petition. 
(a)  After an ad valorem tax lien based upon an approved digest has been delinquent for 12 months, the tax commissioner may commence tax foreclosure in accordance with this article. 
(b)  The tax commissioner may commence tax foreclosure by filing a petition in the court. Said petition must include: 
(1)  The tax commissioner as the petitioner; 
(2)  The property address; 
(3)  A legal description of the property; 
(4)  The tax identification number and/or the property and parcel number of the property; 
(5)  The calendar year(s) for which the taxes are delinquent; 
(6)  The principal amount of the delinquent taxes together with interest and penalties; and 
(7)  The names and addresses of parties to whom copies of the petition are to be sent in accordance with subsection (c). 
(c)  The tax commissioner shall mail copies of the petition by certified mail, return receipt requested, to all interested parties whose identity and address are reasonably ascertainable. Copies of the petition shall also be mailed by first-class mail to the property address to the attention of the occupants, if any, and shall be posted on the property. 
(d)  Contemporaneously with the filing of the petition, the tax commissioner shall file a lis pendens notice at the office of the clerk. 
(e)  Within 30 days of the filing of the petition, a notice shall be published twice in the official organ. Said notice shall specify: 
(1)  The tax commissioner as the petitioner and as the person responsible for collecting the delinquent taxes; 
(2)  The property address; 
(3)  A description of the property; 
(4)  The tax identification number and/or property and parcel number of the property; 
(5)  The applicable period of tax delinquency; 
(6)  The principal amount of the delinquent taxes together with interest and penalties; 
(7)  The date and place of the filing of the petition. 
Sec. 26-76. - The hearing. 
(a)  The tax commissioner shall request a judicial hearing not earlier than 30 days after the filing of the petition. At such hearing any interested party has the right to be heard and to contest the delinquency of the taxes or the adequacy of the proceedings. If the court determines that the information set forth in the petition is accurate, the court may render its judgment and issue an order finding and ordering as follows: 
(1)  The taxes are delinquent; 
(2)  Proper notice has been given to all interested parties; 
(3)  The property as described in the petition shall be sold in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-4-75 et seq.; 
(4)  The property shall be sold free and clear of all liens, claims and encumbrances other than: 
a.  Rights of redemption provided under federal law; 
b.  Tax liens in favor of the state governmental entities other than the petitioner which are superior to the ad valorem taxes identified in the petition by virtue of O.C.G.A. § 48-2-56; 
c.  The holders of easements and rights-of-way described in O.C.G.A. § 48-4-77(1)(c); and 
d.  The holders of the benefits or burdens of any real covenants filed of record as of the date of filing of the petition. 
(5)  The sale shall become final and binding 60 days after the date thereof in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-4-81. 
(b)  If, upon production of evidence, the court determines that any interested party died within the six-month period of time immediately preceding the filing of the petition, the court may postpone the hearing for a period of up to six months, to allow the administrator or executor adequate time to close the estate. 
Sec. 26-77. - The sale. 
(a)  At any time prior to sale, any interested party may redeem the property by payment of the redemption amount to the petitioner, whereupon the petitioner shall dismiss the proceedings. 
(b)  Following the hearing and order of the court in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-4-79, a sale of the property shall be advertised and conducted on the date, time, place and manner which are required by law of sheriff's sales. Such sale shall not occur earlier than 45 days following the date of the order. 
(c)  Except as otherwise authorized by law, the minimum bid price shall be the redemption amount. In the absence of a higher bid, the petitioner may continue the sale to a specific advertised time on the same sale date or may resubmit advertisement to sell the following month. The commission may designate a department head to bid in an amount equal to the minimum bid price and thereby become the purchaser on behalf of Macon-Bibb County. 
(d)  From and after the moment of the sale and tender of the successful bid price, the sale shall be final and binding, subject only to the right of the owner of the property to redeem the property upon payment into the court of the full amount of the minimum bid price. Such right of redemption of the owner shall exist for a period of 60 days from and after the date of the sale and shall be in accordance with the following provisions: 
(1)  Redemption by an owner shall result in a dismissal of the proceedings, and the petitioner shall refund to the purchaser the full amount paid by the purchaser at the sale; 
(2)  For purpose of redemption, "owner" shall mean the owner of record of fee simple interest in the property as of the date of filing of the petition, together with such owner's successors in interest by death or operation of law. This right of redemption shall not otherwise be transferable; and 
(3)  This right of redemption shall automatically terminate and expire upon failure to redeem within the 60-day period after the sale. 
(e)  If the property is not redeemed, then within 90 days after the sale, the tax commissioner shall cause to be executed and delivered to the purchaser a tax deed, together with a real estate transfer tax form. 
(f)  Within 90 days after the sale, the petitioner shall file a report of the sale with the court, stating whether a sale took place, the sale price, and the identity of the purchaser. 
(g)  If the sale price exceeds the minimum bid amount, the petitioner shall deposit the surplus into the registry of the court. Such surplus shall be distributed by the court to the interested parties, including the owner, as their interests appear and in the priority in which their interests exist. 
Secs. 26-78—26-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - HOTEL AND MOTEL EXCISE TAX 

Sec. 26-81. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Due date means from the 20th day after the close of the monthly period for which tax is to be computed. 
Guest room means a room occupied, or intended, arranged or designed for occupancy, by one or more occupants for the purpose of living quarters or residential use. 
Hotel means any structure or any portion of a structure, including any lodginghouse, roominghouse, dormitory, Turkish bath, bachelor hotel, studio hotel, motel, motor hotel, auto court, inn, public club or private club containing guest rooms and which is occupied, or is intended or designed for occupancy, by guests, whether rent is paid in money, goods, labor or otherwise. It does not include any jail, hospital, asylum, sanitarium, orphanage, prison, detention or other building in which human beings are housed and detained under legal restraint. 
Monthly period means the calendar months of any year. 
Occupancy means the use or possession, or the right to the use or possession of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use and possession of the room. 
Occupant means any person who, for a consideration, uses, possesses, or has the right to use or possess any room in a hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license to use or other agreement, or otherwise. 
Operator means any person operating a hotel in Macon-Bibb County including, but not limited to, the owner or proprietor of such premises, lessee, sublessee, lender in possession, licensee or any other person otherwise operating such hotel. 
Permanent resident means any occupant as of a given date who has or shall have occupied or has or shall have the right of occupancy of any guest room in a hotel for at least ten consecutive days next preceding such date. 
Person means an individual, firm, partnership, joint association, social club, fraternal organization, joint stock company, corporation, nonprofit corporation or cooperative nonprofit membership, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate, or any other group or combination acting as a unit, the plural as well as the singular number, excepting the United States of America, the state, and any political subdivision of either, upon which Macon-Bibb County is without power to impose the tax provided in this article. 
Rent means the consideration received for occupancy valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits, and property or services of any kind or nature, and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the operator to the occupant, without any deduction therefrom whatsoever. 
Return means any return filed or required to be filed as provided in this article. 
Tax means the tax imposed by this article. 
Sec. 26-82. - Administration. 
(a)  Authority of tax commissioner. The tax commissioner shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the collection of the tax imposed by this article. 
(b)  Records required from operators, etc.; form. Every operator renting guest rooms in Macon-Bibb County to a person shall keep such records, receipts, invoices, and other pertinent papers in such form as the tax commissioner may require. 
(c)  Examination of records; audits. The tax commissioner or any person authorized in writing by the tax commissioner may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any operator renting guest rooms to a person and any operator liable for the tax, in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return is made by the operator, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid. 
(d)  Authority to require reports; contents. In administration of the provisions of this article, the tax commissioner may require the filing of reports by any person or class of persons having in such person's possession or custody information relating to rentals of guest rooms which are subject to the tax. The reports shall be filed with the tax commissioner when required by the tax commissioner, and shall set forth the rental charged for each occupancy, the date or dates of occupancy, and such other information as the tax commissioner may require. 
Sec. 26-83. - Purpose. 
(a)  The commission hereby finds, determines and declares that: 
(1)  The encouragement, development, growth and expansion of tourism and conventions within Macon-Bibb County are important to the economy of Macon-Bibb County and to the general welfare of its citizens; 
(2)  Macon-Bibb County should be a tourism and convention center of the state and should have the financial ability to attract and promote tourism and conventions, and to provide the necessary public facilities to compete in the domestic and international travel and convention markets; and 
(3)  The tourism and convention industry should pay for the delivery of the services and facilities requested by them to promote and attract visitors and convention delegates. 
(b)  The Macon-Bibb County Convention and Visitor Bureau, Inc. and the Macon, Georgia, Cherry Blossom Festival, Inc., are entities which encourage, develop and expand tourism and conventions within Macon-Bibb County to the benefit of the economy of Macon-Bibb County and the general welfare of its citizens and promote Macon-Bibb County as a tourism and convention center of the state and are essential to allow Macon-Bibb County to compete in the domestic and international travel and convention industry and also to promote and attract visitors and convention delegates to Macon-Bibb County. Such activities constitute promoting tourism, conventions and trade shows within the meaning of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50.2(4). Tobosofkee Recreation Area, the Macon Centreplex, the Georgia Sports Hall of Fame and the Douglass Theatre are facilities and physical attractions which are available and open to the public and which improve destination appeal to visitors, support visitors' experience, and are used by visitors, the support of which constitutes tourism product development pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50.2(6), as well as, to the extent applicable, promoting tourism, conventions and trade shows within the meaning of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50.2(4). 
Sec. 26-84. - Imposition and rate of tax; distribution. 
(a)  There is hereby levied and there shall be paid a tax of seven percent of the rent for every occupancy of a guest room in a hotel in Macon-Bibb County. The tax imposed by this section shall be paid upon any occupancy on and after January 1, 2014, although such occupancy is had pursuant to a contract, lease or other arrangement made prior to such date. 
(b)  The proceeds of said tax shall, upon payment to Macon-Bibb County be distributed in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(b)(1) as follows: 
(1)  An amount equal to 2.125 percent of the total taxes collected, subject to the budgetary process and requirements of Macon-Bibb County, to defray the cost of administration or any other lawful purpose or both. 
(2)  An amount equal to 9.513 percent of the total taxes collected, subject to the budgetary process and requirements of Macon-Bibb County, for supporting the Tobesofkee Recreation Area or for any other lawful purpose or both. 
(3)  An amount equal to 13.252 percent of the total taxes collected, subject to the budgetary process and requirements of Macon-Bibb County, for supporting the Macon Centreplex and/or the associated lodging facility or for any other lawful purpose or both. 
(4)  An amount equal to 60.825 percent of the total taxes collected, subject to the budgetary process and requirements of Macon-Bibb County, for promoting tourism, conventions, and trade shows, as defined by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50.2, allocated as follows: 
a.  53.775 percent to the Macon-Bibb County Convention and Visitors' Bureau, Inc., of which 39.489 percent is pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(3); and 14.286 percent is pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(b)(5). 
b.  7.050 percent to the Macon, Georgia, Cherry Blossom Festival, Inc. 
(5)  An amount equal to 14.286 percent of the total taxes collected, subject to the budgetary process and requirements of Macon-Bibb County, for tourism product development, as defined by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50.2, allocated as follows: 
a.  5.354 percent to the Georgia Sports Hall of Fame, provided it remains in Macon, Georgia. 
b.  3.576 percent to the Tobosofkee Recreation Area. 
c.  5.355 percent to the Douglass Theatre. 
(6)  Some other lawful purpose or combination of purposes permitted under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(b)(1). 
Sec. 26-85. - Collection of tax by operator. 
Every operator maintaining a hotel in Macon-Bibb County and renting guest rooms in Macon-Bibb County, not exempted under section 26-86, shall collect the tax from the occupant. 
Sec. 26-86. - Exemptions. 
No tax shall be imposed under this article with respect to occupancy by a permanent resident. 
Sec. 26-87. - Registration of operator; form and contents; execution certificate of authority. 
Every person engaging or about to engage in business as an operator of a hotel in Macon-Bibb County shall immediately register with the tax commissioner, on a form provided by the tax commissioner. Such registration shall set forth the name under which such person transacts business or intends to transact business, the location of the place or places of business and such other information which would facilitate the collection of the tax as the tax commissioner may require. The registration shall be signed by the owner, if a natural person; in case of ownership by an association or partnership, by a member or a partner; in the case of ownership by a corporation, by an officer thereof. The tax commissioner shall, after such registration, issue without charge a certificate of authority to each operator to collect the tax from the occupant. A separate registration shall be required for each place of business of an operator. Each certificate shall state the name and location of the business to which it is applicable. 
Sec. 26-88. - Determination, returns and payments. 
(a)  Due date of taxes. All amounts of such taxes shall be due and payable to the tax commissioner monthly on or before the 20th day of every month next succeeding each respective monthly period as set forth in section 26-81. 
(b)  Return; time of filing; persons required to file; contents. On or before the 20th day of the month following each monthly period, a return for the preceding monthly period shall be filed with the tax commissioner showing the gross rent, rent from permanent residents, taxable rent, amount of tax collected or otherwise due for the related period, and such other information as may be required by the tax commissioner. 
(c)  Collection fee allowed operators. Operators collecting the tax shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting and payment of the amount due, if that amount is not delinquent at the time of payment, pursuant to, and at the rate authorized under, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-52. 
Sec. 26-89. - Deficiency determinations. 
(a)  Recomputation of tax; authority to make; basis of recomputation. If the tax commissioner is not satisfied with the return or returns of the tax or the amount of the tax required to be paid to Macon-Bibb County by any person, the tax commissioner may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information within his possession or that may come into his possession. One or more deficiency determinations may be made of the account due for one or more monthly periods. 
(b)  Interest of deficiency. The amount of the determination shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month, or fraction thereof from the due date of taxes. 
(c)  Notice of determination; service of. The tax commissioner shall give to the operator written notice of his determination. The notice may be served personally or by mail; if by mail, such service shall be addressed to the operator at his address as it appears in the records of the tax commissioner. Service by mail is complete when delivered by certified mail with a receipt signed by addressee. 
(d)  Time within which notice of deficiency determination to be mailed. Except in the case of failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination shall be mailed within three years after the 20th day of the calendar month following the monthly period for which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period should last expire. 
Sec. 26-90. - Determination if no return made. 
(a)  Estimate of gross receipts. If any person fails to make a return, the tax commissioner shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the person, or as the case may be, of the amount of the total rentals in Macon-Bibb County which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period or periods in respect to which the person failed to make the return and shall be based upon any information which is or may come into the possession of the tax commissioner. Written notice shall be given in the manner prescribed in section 26-89(c). 
(b)  Interest on amount found due. The amount of the determination shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the 20th day of the month following the monthly period, for which the amount or any portion thereof should have been returned, until the date of payment. 
Sec. 26-91. - Penalties. 
(a)  When any operator fails to make any return or to pay the full amount of the tax of five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, if the failure is for not more than 30 days, add an additional five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, for each additional 30 days or fraction of 30 days during which the failure continues. The penalty for any single violation shall not exceed 25 percent or $25.00 in the aggregate, whichever is greater. 
(b)  If the failure is due to providential cause shown to the satisfaction of the tax commissioner in affidavit form attached to the return and remittance is made within ten days of the due date, the return may be accepted exclusive of penalties. 
(c)  In the case of a false or fraudulent return or of a failure to file a return where willful intent exists to defraud Macon-Bibb County of any tax due under this article, a penalty of 50 percent of the tax due shall be assessed. 
(d)  The penalty authorized by this section shall be in addition in and not in lieu of any other penalties provided by law, including, but not limited to, the criminal penalties authorized by O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-58 through 48-13-63, inclusive. 
Sec. 26-92. - Sale or discontinuance of business. 
(a)  Final return. If any operator liable for any tax, interest, or penalty imposed by this article sells or quits the business, he or she shall make a final return and payment within 15 days after the date of selling or quitting the business. 
(b)  Successor to withhold amount due. The operator's successor or assigns, if any, shall withhold a sufficient amount of the purchase money to cover the amount of the taxes, interest, and penalties due under this article and unpaid until the former owner produces either a receipt from the tax commissioner showing that the taxes, interest, and penalties due under this article have been paid or a certificate from the tax commissioner stating that no tax, interest, or penalty is due under this article. 
(c)  Liability of successor. If the purchaser of the business fails to withhold the purchase money as required by this section, he or she shall be personally liable for the payment of any taxes, interest, and penalties accruing under this article and unpaid by any former owner or assignor. The personal liability of the purchaser in such case shall not exceed the amount of the total purchase money, but the property being transferred shall in all cases be subject to the full amount of the tax lien arising from the delinquencies of the former owner. Paid executions may be transferred and enforced as otherwise provided by law. 
Sec. 26-93. - Collection of tax. 
(a)  Action for tax; time for. At any time within three years after any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected becomes due and payable and at any time within three years after the delinquency of any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected, the tax commissioner may bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction in the name of Macon-Bibb County to collect the amount delinquent together with interest, penalties, court fees, filing fees, attorneys' fees and other legal fees incident thereto. Such amounts and fees shall constitute a lien against the property in the same manner as ad valorem taxes as set forth in section 26-31. 
(b)  Duty of successors or assignees of operator to withhold tax from purchase money. If any operator liable for any amount under this article sells out his business or quits the business, his successors or assigns shall withhold sufficient of the purchase price to cover such amount until the former owner produces a receipt from the tax commissioner showing that he or she has been paid or a certificate stating that no amount is due. 
(c)  Liability for failure to withhold; certificate of notice of amount due; time to enforce successor's liability. If the purchase of a business fails to withhold purchase price as required, he or she shall be personally liable for the payment of the amount required to be withheld by him or her to the extent of the purchase price. 
(d)  Tax credit, or interest paid more than once, or erroneously or illegally collected. Whenever the amount of any tax or interest has been paid more than once, or has been erroneously or illegally collected or received by Macon-Bibb County under this chapter, it may be offset by the tax commissioner. If the operator or person determines that he or she has overpaid or paid more than once, which fact has not been determined by the tax commissioner, he or she will have three years from the date of payment to file claim in writing stating the specific ground upon which claim is founded. The claim shall be audited. If the claim is approved by the tax commissioner, the excess amount paid Macon-Bibb County may be credited on any amounts then due and payable from the person by whom it was paid, or his administrators or executors. 
Secs. 26-94—26-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - LOCAL OPTION SALES TAX 

Sec. 26-111. - Imposed. 
Pursuant to the provisions of House Bill 281, as the same was adopted by the general assembly of the state at its 1979 regular session, and pursuant to the provisions of Georgia Retailers and Consumers Sales and Use Tax, as amended by such bill, and pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-8-80 et seq., as revised by such bill, the joint county and municipal sales and use tax contemplated by House Bill 281 is hereby imposed effective April 1, 1979, and reimposed effective January 1, 1980. 
Secs. 26-112—26-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - LICENSE FEES AND TAXES ON INSURANCE COMPANIES AND PREMIUMS 

Sec. 26-131. - Insurers' license fees. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8, there is hereby levied an annual license fee upon each insurer doing business within Macon-Bibb County in the amount of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). For each separate business location in excess of one (1) not covered by section 26-132, which is operating on behalf of such insurers within Macon-Bibb County, there is hereby levied a license fee in the amount of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). For the purposes of this article, the term "insurer" means a company which is authorized to transact business in any of the classes of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5. 
( Ord. No. O-14-0064, § 1, 12-9-2014 ) 
Sec. 26-132. - License fee for insurers insuring certain risks at additional business locations. 
For each separate business location, not otherwise subject to a license fee hereunder, operated and maintained by a business organization which is engaged in the business of lending money or transacting sales involving term financing and, in connection with such loans or sales, offers, solicits or takes applications for insurance through a licensed agent of an insurer for insurance, such insurer shall pay an additional license fee of fifty-two dollars and 50/100s ($52.50) per location. 
( Ord. No. O-14-0064, § 1, 12-9-2014 ) 
Sec. 26-133. - Insurance agency license fees; independent insurance agencies, brokers, etc., not otherwise licensed. 
There is hereby levied an annual license fee upon independent agencies and brokers for each separate business location from which an insurance business is conducted and which is not subject to the company license fee imposed by section 26-131, in the amount of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for each such location within Macon-Bibb County. 
( Ord. No. O-14-0064, § 1, 12-9-2014 ) 
Sec. 26-134. - Gross premiums tax—Imposed on life insurers. 
There is hereby levied, for the year 2015 and each subsequent year, an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer writing life, accident and sickness insurance, designated as class (1) insurance in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5, within the State of Georgia in an amount equal to one (1) percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1. "Gross direct premiums," as used in this section, shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by section 26-131. 
( Ord. No. O-14-0064, § 1, 12-9-2014 ) 
Sec. 26-135. - Same—On all other insurers. 
There is hereby levied, for the year 2015 and for each year thereafter, an annual tax based upon the gross direct premiums on each insurer doing business within the State of Georgia at the rate of two and one half (2.5) percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2. Insurer, as used in this section, shall mean any insurer other than an insurer transacting business in the class of insurance designated as class (1) of O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5. As used in this section, "gross direct premiums" shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by section 26-131. 
( Ord. No. O-14-0064, § 1, 12-9-2014 ) 
Sec. 26-136. - Due date for license fees. 
License fees imposed in sections 26-131 through 26-133 shall be due and payable on the first day of January, 2015, and on January first of each subsequent year. Payment shall be made in the office of the Macon-Bibb County clerk. 
( Ord. No. O-14-0064, § 1, 12-9-2014 ) 
Secs. 26-137—26-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - BUSINESS LICENSE TAX ON DEPOSITORY FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS 

Sec. 26-151. - Purpose and interpretation. 
It is the purpose of this article to exercise the powers granted to the commission to levy a business license tax upon all depository financial institutions located within Macon-Bibb County in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. The terms used in this article shall have the same meanings as similar language contained in such statute. 
Sec. 26-152. - Levy of tax. 
For each year there is hereby levied an annual business license tax upon all depository financial institutions located within Macon-Bibb County. 
Sec. 26-153. - Rate of tax. 
The tax hereby levied shall be at the rate of one-quarter of a percent of gross receipts. 
Sec. 26-154. - Minimum tax. 
Notwithstanding the foregoing, the minimum amount hereby levied upon each depository financial institution for any year shall be $1,000.00. 
Sec. 26-155. - Returns. 
Each depository financial institution shall file an annual return of its gross receipts with the tax commissioner on or before March 1 of the year following the year in which such gross receipts are measured. Such return shall be in the manner and in the form prescribed by the commissioner of the department of revenue and shall be based upon the allocation method prescribed by law. The tax hereby levied shall be assessed and collected based upon the information provided in the return; provided, however, that if otherwise authorized by law, nothing contained in this article shall prohibit Macon-Bibb County or the tax commissioner from taking reasonable steps to confirm the information set out in the returns, and to make such adjustments in the tax reported to be due as the circumstances warrant. 
Sec. 26-156. - When tax payable. 
The tax levied hereby shall be due and payable on or before 30 days after the filing of the return to the tax commissioner. Taxes which are not timely paid shall be in default, and shall bear interest and be subject to such costs as are from time to time provided by this Code for delinquent ad valorem taxes. Taxes delinquent under the provisions of this article shall be subject to fi. fa. and collected in the same manner as ad valorem taxes in Macon-Bibb County. 
Secs. 26-157—26-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - OCCUPATION TAXES 

Sec. 26-201. - Occupation tax required; occupation tax required for business dealings in Macon-Bibb County, Georgia. 
For the year 1996 and succeeding years thereafter, each person who is engaged in any business, trade, profession, or occupation in Macon-Bibb County, or, to the extent required pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7 and § 26-209 herein, in the case of an out-of-state business with no location in the state, shall pay an occupation tax for said business, trade, profession, or occupation. A business registration certificate shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in the place of business if the taxpayer has a permanent business location in Macon-Bibb County. If the taxpayer has no permanent business location in Macon-Bibb County, such business tax registration shall be shown to the department of business development services of Macon-Bibb County, or their agents, upon request. 
Sec. 26-202. - Purpose and scope of tax. 
The occupation tax levied herein is for revenue purposes only and is not for regulatory purposes, nor is the payment of the tax made a condition precedent to the practice of any such profession, trade, or calling. The occupation tax applies to all businesses and occupations not specifically excluded by the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-5 to 48-13-26. All other applicable businesses and occupations are taxed by the local government pursuant to the pertinent general and/or local law and ordinance. 
Sec. 26-203. - When occupation tax due and payable. 
The amount of occupation tax shall be due and payable to Macon-Bibb County, at the office of the department of business development services, on January 1 each year and delinquent if not paid on or before April 1 of each year. 
Sec. 26-204. - Construction of terms; definitions. 
(a)  Where the term "Macon-Bibb County" is used herein in a geographic sense, such term shall be construed to mean the area or territory of Macon-Bibb County, Georgia. The term, when used in a corporate sense, shall be construed to mean Macon-Bibb County, Georgia, or its governing body. 
(b)  As used in this article, the term: 
Administrative fee means a component of an occupation tax which approximates the reasonable cost of handling and processing the occupation tax. 
Business registration certificate means the document issued by the department of business development services to a business, occupation or profession which gives evidence of registration required hereby. 
Employee means an individual whose work is performed under the direction and supervision of the employer and whose employer withholds FICA, federal income tax or state income tax from such individual's compensation, or whose employer issues to such individual for purposes of documenting compensation an IRS Form W-2, but not an IRS Form 1099. 
Location of office shall include any structure or vehicle where a business, profession, or occupation is conducted, but shall not include a temporary or construction work site which serves a single customer or project. 
Occupation tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations, or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession, or business for revenue raising purposes. 
Person shall be deemed to include any individual, firm, joint venture, association, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, syndicate, sole proprietor, corporation, and partnership or any other form of business organization or combination acting as a unit. 
Practitioner of profession or occupation means one who by state law requires state licensure regulating such profession or occupation. 
Practitioner of professions and occupations shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business, if the business pays an occupation tax. 
Privilege license means any license or permit requiring approval of the sheriff and any license or permit wherein the business, trade or occupation is regulated and controlled by ordinance of Macon-Bibb County. Every person receiving a license for any business, trade or occupation, set forth as a privilege license, shall take such license subject to the continuing compliance with the conditions set forth in this Code, and the failure of any business, trade or occupation to comply therewith at any time may result in the automatic suspension of such license until such business, trade or occupation has complied therewith. Privilege licenses specifically include, but are not limited to the following: 
(1)  Adult entertainer permit; 
(2)  Adult entertainment establishment; 
(3)  Reserved. 
(4)  Bail bondsman; 
(5)  Beer or malt beverages, retail (consumed on premises or packaged to go or both); 
(6)  Beer or malt beverages, wholesaler; 
(7)  Billiard or pool hall; 
(8)  Brown bagging permit; 
(9)  Dealers in precious metals and gems; 
(10)  Landfill user; 
(11)  Liquor, retail (packaged to go); 
(12)  Liquor, retail (sales by the drink/consumed on premises); 
(13)  Liquor, wholesale; 
(14)  Massage parlor; 
(15)  Pawnbroker; 
(16)  Private detective; 
(17)  Shooting range (indoor); 
(18)  Sunday sales permit; 
(19)  Taxicab company; 
(20)  Taxicab driver permit; 
(21)  Wine, retail (consumed on premises/packaged to go); and 
(22)  Wine, wholesale. 
Regulatory fees means payments, whether designated as license fees, permit fees, or by another name, which are required by a local government as an exercise of its police power and as a part of or an aid to regulation of an occupation, profession, or business. The amount of a regulatory fee shall approximate the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity performed by Macon-Bibb County. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee. Development impact or permit fees as defined by O.C.G.A. § 36-71-2(8) or other costs or conditions of zoning or land development are not regulatory fees. 
Sec. 26-205. - Administrative and regulatory fee structure; occupation tax structure. 
(a)  A nonprorated, nonrefundable administrative fee of $65.00 shall be required on all business occupation tax accounts for the initial start-up, renewal, or reopening of those accounts. 
(b)  A regulatory fee will be imposed as provided under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9 on those applicable businesses. 
(c)  The regulatory fee schedule for persons in occupations and professions is set forth in another ordinance and is not comprehended hereby. 
(d)  No administrative or processing fee shall be imposed upon a business or practitioner for the cost of ascertaining whether such a business or practitioner has paid occupation tax to another local government. 
Sec. 26-206. - Occupation tax levied; restrictions. 
(a)  An occupation tax is hereby levied upon those businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations with one or more offices located in Macon-Bibb County, and/or upon the application out-of-state business with no location or office in the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7 based upon the average number of employees of the business or practitioner as computed on a full time position basis or a full time position equivalent basis. For the purposes of this computation, an employee who works 40 hours or more weekly shall be considered a full time employee. The average weekly hours of employees who work less than 40 hours shall be determined and aggregated and divided by 40 to produce full time equivalent employees. 
(b)  If as a result of the computation described next above, the result is a fractional number, any fraction less than one-half shall be disregarded and fractions of one-half or more shall be rounded up to the next whole number. 
(c)  The average weekly hours shall be determined upon an annual basis by computing the average number of full time employees and full time equivalent employees based upon the preceding calendar year. Businesses which have been in business for less than 12 months during such preceding calendar year shall compute their average weekly number of employees annualized to a full year. Businesses or practitioners having no operations in a prior year and which commence business on or after January 1st in each year shall pay the business occupation tax, based upon a bona fide estimate of the number of employees expected to be employed on a full time and full time equivalent basis. 
(d)  Where the estimated business occupation tax for any year proves to be inaccurate, then no later than April 1st of the next succeeding year, the business or practitioner shall file an amended return indicating the actual number of full time and full time equivalent employees. Any over payment of the occupation tax may be credited to the business' or practitioner's account for future liability, offset against other amounts due and owing Macon-Bibb County for any reason or refunded to the business or practitioner at the discretion of the department of business development services. 
(e)  If a business or practitioner commences business in Macon-Bibb County on or after July 1st in any year, the occupation tax for the remaining portion of the year shall be 50 percent of the tax imposed for the entire year, calculated as herein otherwise provided, plus the administrative fee of $50.00. 
Sec. 26-207. - Levy based on number of employees. 
The business occupation tax hereby levied shall be that amount determined by multiplying the average number of employees for a calendar year by $39.00 and plus the administrative fee levied by this article. 
Sec. 26-208. - Limitations on levy of tax; exceptions. 
(a)  No business or practitioner shall be required to pay more than one occupation tax for each of its locations. 
(b)  No occupation tax shall be required from real estate brokers, agents, or companies whose offices are located outside the taxing jurisdiction and who sell property inside the taxing jurisdiction. 
(c)  The maximum number of employees for which any business or practitioner shall be liable to pay under the provisions of this article shall be 250. 
Sec. 26-209. - Paying occupation tax of business with no location in the state. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, registration and assessment of an occupation tax is hereby imposed on those businesses and practitioners of professions with no location or office in the state if the business's largest dollar volume of business in the state is in Macon-Bibb County and the business or practitioner has one or more employees or agents who exert substantial efforts within the jurisdiction of Macon-Bibb County for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients or if the business or practitioner owns personal or real property which generates income and which is located within Macon-Bibb County. 
Sec. 26-210. - The number of businesses considered to be operating in Macon-Bibb County. 
Where a person conducts business at more than one fixed location, each location or place shall be considered a separate business for the purpose of occupation tax. 
Sec. 26-211. - Professionals as classified in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c)(1) through (18). 
Practitioners of professions as described in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c)(1) through (18) shall elect as their entire occupation tax either: 
(1)  The occupation tax based on the number of full time and full time equivalent employees as set forth in this article; or 
(2)  A fee of $400.00 per practitioner who is licensed to provide the service. The per-practitioner fee applies to each person in the business who qualifies as a practitioner under the state's regulatory guidelines and framework. 
(3)  The election and payment of the occupation tax shall be made on an annual basis and must be done on or before April 1 in each year. 
(4)  A practitioner who fails to make an election on a timely basis shall be deemed to have elected to pay the business occupation tax based upon $400.00 per practitioner. 
Sec. 26-212. - Practitioners exclusively practicing for a government. 
Any practitioner whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the United States, the state, a municipality or county of the state, instrumentalities of the United States, the state, or a municipality or county of the state shall not be required to obtain a license or pay an occupation tax for that practice. 
Sec. 26-213. - When tax due and payable; effect of transacting business when tax delinquent. 
(a)  Each such occupation tax shall be for the calendar year 1996 and succeeding calendar years thereafter. The administrative fee and business occupation tax shall be payable January 1 of each year and shall, if not paid by April 1 of each year, be subject to penalties for delinquency as prescribed in this article. On any new profession, trade, or calling begun in Macon-Bibb County in 1996 or succeeding years thereafter, the registration fee and tax shall be delinquent if not obtained immediately upon beginning business and a ten percent penalty shall be imposed. In addition to said penalty, the department of business development services shall impose interest on delinquent occupation taxes and administrative fees at a rate of one and one-half percent per month or fraction thereof. The business registration certificate herein provided for shall be issued by the department of business development services and if any person, firm, or corporation whose duty it is to obtain a registration certificate shall, after said registration or occupation tax becomes delinquent, transact or offer to transact, in Macon-Bibb County any of the kind of profession, trade, or calling subject to this article without having first obtain said registration certificate, such offender shall, upon conviction in the municipal court of Macon-Bibb County, be punished as provided by section 1-6. 
(b)  Attorneys engaged in the practice of law shall not be required to pay the occupation tax in any calendar year beginning with and including the year 2014 until January 1 of the year following. In the event that any such attorneys commence business on any date after January 1, occupation tax and registration shall be due and payable 30 days following the commencement of the business or January 1 of the following year, whichever is later. 
(c)  In addition to the above remedies, the department of business development services or its agents may proceed to collect in the same manner as provided by law for tax executions. 
Sec. 26-214. - Allocation of number of employees of business with multiple intra- or interstate locations. 
For those businesses and practitioners that have multiple locations inside and outside of Macon-Bibb County, the number of employees shall be allocated to each location, number of employees used to determine the occupation tax due will be the number of employees attributed to each Macon-Bibb County location. 
Sec. 26-215. - Exemption on grounds that business is operated for charitable purpose. 
No business on which a business registration certificate is required or occupation tax is levied by this article shall be exempt from said registration or tax on the ground that such business is operated for a charitable purpose, unless said business shall provide a copy of a determination letter from the U.S. Internal Revenue Service granting nonprofit or charitable status or similar documentation. 
Sec. 26-216. - Evidence of state registration required if applicable; state registration to be displayed. 
(a)  Each person who is licensed by the secretary of state pursuant to O.C.G.A. tit. 43 shall provide evidence of proper and current state licensure before Macon-Bibb County registration may be issued. 
(b)  Each such person who is licensed by the state shall post the state license in a conspicuous place in the licensee's place of business and shall keep the license there at all times while the license remains valid. 
Sec. 26-217. - Evidence of compliance required if applicable. 
Any business required to obtain planning and zoning permits, building inspection permits, health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency, or comply with any other regulatory matter shall first, before the issuance of a Macon-Bibb County business registration, show evidence that such requirements have been met. 
Sec. 26-218. - Liability of officers and agents; registration required; failure to obtain. 
All persons subject to the occupation tax levy pursuant to this article shall be required to obtain the necessary business registration certificate for a business described in this article, and in default thereof the officer or agent soliciting for or representing such persons shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons who fail to obtain a registration. Every person commencing business in Macon-Bibb County after January 1 of each year shall likewise obtain the registration herein provided for before commencing the same; and any person transacting, or offering to transact in Macon-Bibb County, any of the kinds of business, trade, profession, or occupation without first having obtain such registration, shall be subject to penalties provided in this article. 
Sec. 26-219. - Department of business development services; citation powers. 
The department of business development services and their agents shall have authority to issue citations for any violations of this article. 
Sec. 26-220. - Businesses not covered by this article. 
(a)  The following businesses are not covered by the provisions of this article but may be assessed an occupation tax or other type of tax pursuant to the provisions of other general laws of the state or by local law: 
(1)  Those businesses regulated by the state public service commission. 
(2)  Those electrical service businesses organized under O.C.G.A. tit. 46, ch. 3. 
(3)  Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including agribusiness. 
(4)  Cooperative marketing associations governed by O.C.G.A. § 2-10-105. 
(5)  Insurance companies governed by O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8 et seq. 
(6)  Motor common carriers governed by O.C.G.A. § 46-7-15. 
(7)  Those businesses governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-355. (Businesses that purchase carload lots of guano, meats, meal, flour, bran, cottonseed, or cottonseed meal and hulls.) 
(8)  Agricultural products and livestock raised in the state governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-356. 
(9)  Depository financial institutions governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. 
(10)  Facilities operated by a charitable trust governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-55. 
(11)  Any person engaged in casual or isolated activity and commercial transactions where such involve personal assets and are not the principal occupation of the individual. 
(b)  The exemptions and limitations contained in this article shall not be construed to repeal or otherwise affect any license fees, franchise fees, business taxes or other fees or taxes otherwise allowed by law. 
Sec. 26-221. - Occupation tax inapplicable where prohibited by law or provided for pursuant to other existing law. 
An occupation tax shall not apply to any business where such levy is prohibited or exempted by the laws of the state or of the United States. 
Sec. 26-222. - More than one place. 
Where a business is operated at more than one place, said business will pay an occupation tax for each location according to the number of employees engaged at such location. 
Sec. 26-223. - Reserved. 
Sec. 26-224. - Inspections of books and records. 
In any case the department of business development services, through it officers, agents, employees, or representatives, may inspect the books of the business for which the returns are made for the purpose of the number of employees. The department of business development services shall have the right to inspect the books or records for the business of which the return was made in Macon-Bibb County, and upon demand of the department of business development services such books or records shall be submitted for inspection by a representative of Macon-Bibb County within 30 days. Failure of submission of such books or records within 30 days shall be grounds for revocation of the tax registration currently existing to do business in Macon-Bibb County. Adequate records shall be kept in Macon-Bibb County, for examination by the department of business development services at that officer's discretion. If, after examination of the books or records, it is determined that a deficiency occurs as a result of under-reporting, a penalty of one and one-half percent per month or fraction thereof times the amount deficient will be assessed for the period delinquent. 
Sec. 26-225. - Business registration certificate to be revoked for failure to pay tax, file returns, permit inspection of books. 
Upon the failure of any business to pay said occupation tax or any part thereof before it becomes delinquent, or upon failure to make any of said returns within the time required herein, or upon failure to make a true return, or upon failure to amend a return to set forth the truth, or upon failure to permit inspection of its books as above provided, any business registration certificate granted by Macon-Bibb County under this article shall be, ipso facto, revoked. No new business tax registration shall be issued by Macon-Bibb County for the operation of a business for which any part of the occupation tax herein provided for is at that time unpaid, or to an individual, firm, or corporation who has failed to submit adequate records as requested by the department of business development services in accordance with the provisions of this article. Businesses whose business registration certificate has been revoked shall not be authorized to do business until the default is cured. This section shall not apply in the case of those practitioners where the local government cannot suspend the right of the practitioner to conduct business, but the imposition of civil penalties shall be permitted and pursued by Macon-Bibb County as in the case of delinquent occupation tax. 
Sec. 26-226. - Effect of failure to comply with article provisions; continuing in business after tax registration revocation. 
Any persons, their managers, agents, or employees, who do business in Macon-Bibb County after the registration for said business has been revoked as provided in the next preceding section, hereby required to make occupation tax returns, and who fail to make said returns within the time and in the manner herein provided, who refuse to amend such returns so as to set forth the truth, or who shall make false returns; and any persons, their managers, agents, or employees who refuse to permit an inspection of books in their charge when authorized officers, agents, employees, or representatives of Macon-Bibb County request such inspection, during business hours of the taxpayer, for the purpose of determining the accuracy of the returns herein provided for, shall be subject to penalties provided herein. 
Sec. 26-227. - Lien taken for delinquent occupation tax. 
In addition to the other remedies herein provided for the collection of the occupation tax herein levied, the department of business development services, upon any tax becoming delinquent and remaining unpaid, shall issue execution for the correct amount of said tax against the persons, partnership, or corporation liable for said tax, which said execution shall bear interest at the rate of one and one-half percent per month or fraction thereof from the date when such tax or installment becomes delinquent, and the lien shall cover the property in Macon-Bibb County of the person, partnership, or corporation liable for said tax, all as provided by the ordinances of Macon-Bibb County and the laws of the state. The lien of said occupation tax shall become fixed on and date from the time when such tax or any installment thereof becomes delinquent. The execution shall be levied by the department of business development services of Macon-Bibb County upon the property of defendant located in said jurisdiction, and sufficient property shall be advertised and sold to pay the amount of said execution, with interest and costs. All other proceedings in relation thereto shall be had as is provided by ordinances of Macon-Bibb County and the laws of the state, and the defendant in said execution shall have rights of defense, by affidavit of illegality and otherwise, which are provided by the applicable laws in regard to tax executions. 
Sec. 26-228. - Amendment, repeal of provisions. 
This article shall be subject to amendment or repeal, in whole or in part, at any time, and no such amendment or repeal shall be construed to deny the right of Macon-Bibb County to assess and collect any of the taxes or other charges prescribed. Said amendment may increase or lower the amounts and tax rates of any occupation and may change the classification thereof. The payment of any occupation tax provided for shall not be construed as prohibiting the levy or collection by Macon-Bibb County of other occupation taxes upon the same person, property, or business. 
Sec. 26-229. - Applications of provisions to prior ordinance. 
This article does not repeal or affect the force of any part of any ordinance heretofore passed where taxes levied under such prior ordinance have not been paid in full. So much and such parts of ordinances heretofore and hereinafter passed as provided for the issuing and enforcing of execution for any tax or assessment required by such ordinances, or that imposed fines or penalties for the nonpayment of such tax, or for failure to pay regulatory fees provided for in said ordinance or ordinances, or failure to comply with any other provisions hereof, shall continue and remain in force until such tax, regulatory fee, or assessment shall be fully paid. 
Sec. 26-230. - Enforcement of provisions. 
It is hereby made the duty of the department of business development services to see that the provisions of this article relating to occupation taxes are observed; and to summon all violators of the same to appear before the court. It is hereby made the further duty of the department of business development services and their agents to inspect all registrations issued by Macon-Bibb County as often as in their judgment it may seem necessary to determine whether the registration held is the proper one for the business sought to be transacted thereunder. 
Sec. 26-231. - Provisions to remain in full force and effect until changed by governing body. 
This article shall remain in full force and effect until changed by amendment adopted by the commission. All provisions hereto relating to any form of tax herein levied shall remain in full force and effect until such taxes have been paid in full. 
Sec. 26-232. - Requirement of public hearing. 
(a)  After the effective date of this article, the commission shall conduct at least one public hearing before adopting any ordinance or resolution regarding the occupation tax as set forth in this article. 
(b)  In any year when revenue from occupation taxes is greater than revenue from occupation taxes for the preceding year for Macon-Bibb County, the commission shall hold one or more public hearings as a part of the process of determining how to use the additional revenue. 
Sec. 26-233. - Conflicts between specific and general provisions. 
Where there is an apparent conflict in this article between specific and general provisions, it is the intention hereof that the specific shall control. 
Sec. 26-234. - Violations; revocation; suspensions and penalties. 
(a)  Violations. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for a person to engage in any business in Macon-Bibb County without having first registered such business and procured a business registration certificate therefor, or to engage in any such business in Macon-Bibb County after revocation or suspension of any business registration certificate previously issued therefor. Each day during which such business is so engaged in shall constitute a separate offense. The officers and agents listed for or representing any person engaged in business shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons who fail to procure a license. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any duly registered person to fail or refuse to comply with the provisions of this chapter relating to returns or affidavits, and each day such person engages in such business without compliance with such provisions shall constitute a separate offense. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any person to give, or cause to be given, submit or cause to be submitted, exhibit, or cause to be exhibited, or present, or cause to be presented to Macon-Bibb County any false, deceptive or misleading statement, affidavit, certificate, book or record of entry, or any other document or information relating to the number of employees of the business or practitioner, or any other data, records or information required by ordinance and applicable to such business. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful for any person transacting business in Macon-Bibb County to impede, hinder or obstruct the department of business development services in the performance of their duty to inspect from time to time, during reasonable business hours of the taxpayer, all records, books, tax returns or other papers or documents, stocks of goods and merchandise, as well as the place of business, for the purpose of ascertaining information necessary for a proper classification for occupation taxation and fixing the amount of such occupation tax or specific tax. 
(5)  It shall be unlawful for any person duly registered to transact any business within Macon-Bibb County to fail to have such business registration certificate posted in a conspicuous place in the place of business of such person as provided in this chapter and if such person has no fixed place of business within Macon-Bibb County, it shall be unlawful for such person to fail to exhibit to Macon-Bibb County's agents such business registration certificate after request for such business registration certificate during reasonable business hours. 
(6)  It shall be unlawful for any person to whom a business registration certificate shall be granted under the provisions of this chapter to do any of the acts forbidden by this chapter or to fail to do any of the things required to be done by the terms hereof, and it shall be unlawful for any person to whom a business registration certificate shall be granted to violate any of the terms, conditions and provisions under which such business registration certificate has been granted. Every registrant shall be responsible for and subject to the penalties provided in this chapter in the event of violation of this chapter by any employee or agent of such registrant. 
(b)  Revocation, suspensions and penalties. 
(1)  Any person transacting any business within Macon-Bibb County who shall violate any of the term of this Code or commit any offense made unlawful in this section, upon conviction in the municipal court of Macon-Bibb County, shall be punished as provided in section 1-6. The conviction and payment of a fine therefor or other punishment shall not relieve any person of the duty to comply with the requirements of any of the provisions of this chapter or to pay any tax or fee applicable to such business. 
(2)  The municipal court, after affording the registrant notice of the charges and opportunity to be heard with respect to any revocation proceedings, may, if it finds this article to have been violated by the registrant, his agents or employees in the operation of the business, revoke the business registration certificate in its entirety, suspend such business registration certificate for a specified period of time, place the registrant on probation, or place other conditions thereon as the municipal court judge may deem necessary in addition to any other lawful punishment for violation of this chapter. 
Sec. 26-235. - Administration, enforcement. 
(a)  The department of business development services shall administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter for the application for an issuance of business registration certificate and the regulation of businesses under this chapter. 
(b)  It is hereby made the duty of the department of business development services and the office of the sheriff to see that the provisions of this article relating to occupation taxes are observed; and to summon all violators of the same to appear before the court. It is hereby made the further duty of the department of business development services to inspect all registrations issued by Macon-Bibb County, as often as, in their judgment, it may seem necessary to determine whether the registration held is the proper one for the business sought to be transacted thereunder. Summons may issue to any business found to be in violation of this chapter to appear before the municipal court of Macon-Bibb County for a determination of the matter. 
(c)  Any summons to appear before the municipal court issued pursuant to this section shall provide a statement of alleged violations which may constitute grounds for the revocation of any court business registration certificate or privilege license. 
(d)  For the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this chapter, the judge of the municipal court shall have jurisdiction by appropriate process to compel the presence of witnesses and the production of books, papers, records, or memoranda to enforce compliance with the terms of this chapter. 
Sec. 26-236. - Severability. 
If any section, provision, or clause of any part of this article shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional, or if the provisions of any part of this article as applied to any particular situation or set of circumstances shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional, such invalidity shall not be construed to affect the portions of this article not so held to be invalid, or the application of this article to other circumstances not so held to be invalid. It is hereby declared as the intent that this article would have been adopted had such invalid portion not been included herein. 
Sec. 26-237. - Regulation of privileged business unaffected. 
Nothing herein contained shall be deemed to modify or repeal any provisions of the Macon-Bibb County Code or ordinances of the commission regulating holders of privileged licenses or levying taxes or fees with respect to the same. 
Secs. 26-238—26-299. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - ENTERPRISE ZONES 

Sec. 26-300. - Legislative findings and intent; construction. 
Macon-Bibb County finds and determines that there is a need for revitalization in many areas of Macon-Bibb County. Revitalization will improve geographic areas within Macon-Bibb County which are suffering from disinvestment, underdevelopment, and economic decline and will encourage private businesses to reinvest and rehabilitate such areas. Macon-Bibb County recognizes that increased employment opportunities for the citizens of Macon-Bibb County will assist in the implementation of the redevelopment of Macon-Bibb County. It is the intent of Macon-Bibb County that this article be liberally construed to accomplish these purposes. 
Sec. 26-301. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the term: 
Act means the Georgia Enterprise Zone Employment Act of 1997, codified at O.C.G.A. § 36-88-1 et seq. 
Ad valorem tax means property taxes levied for state, or local government operating purposes but does not include property taxes imposed by school districts or property taxes imposed for general obligation debt. 
Business enterprise means any business engaged primarily in retail, manufacturing, warehousing and distribution, processing, telecommunications, tourism, research and development industries, new residential construction, and residential rehabilitation. 
Department means the Macon-Bibb County department of business development services. 
Director means the director of the department of business development services. 
Enterprise zone means the geographic area(s) designated pursuant to section 26-302. 
Full-time job equivalent means a job or jobs with no predetermined end date, with a regular work week of 30 hours or more, and with the same benefits provided to similar employees. 
Low-income and moderate-income individual means a person currently: 
(1)  Unemployed or unemployed for three of the six months prior to the date of hire; 
(2)  Homeless; 
(3)  A resident of public housing; 
(4)  Receiving temporary assistance for needy families or who has received temporary assistance for needy families at any time during the 18 months previous to the date of hire; 
(5)  A participant in the Workforce Investment Act or who has participated in the Workforce Investment Act at any time during the 18 months previous to the date of hire; 
(6)  A participant in a job opportunity where basic skills are required or who has participated in such a job opportunity at any time during the 18 months previous to the date of hire; 
(7)  Receiving supplemental social security income; or 
(8)  Receiving food stamps. 
New job means employment for an individual created within an enterprise zone by a new or expanded qualified business or service enterprise at the time of the initial staffing of such new or expanded enterprise. 
Qualified or qualifying business means any business engaged primarily in retail, manufacturing, warehousing and distribution, processing, telecommunications, tourism, research and development industries, new residential construction, and residential rehabilitation. 
Service enterprise means an entity engaged primarily in finance, insurance, and real estate activity or activities listed under the Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) Codes 60 through 67 according to the Federal Office of Management and Budget Standard Industrial Classification Manual, 1987 edition, or engaged primarily in day-care activities. 
Urban redevelopment plan means the current plan prepared and adopted by Macon-Bibb County to the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 36-61-1 et seq. 
Sec. 26-302. - Designation of enterprise zone. 
(a)  Macon-Bibb County hereby designates the following areas as enterprise zones to be known collectively as the "Macon-Bibb County Enterprise Zone Area": 
(1)  Antioch road enterprise zone. Beginning at the intersection of Broadway and Eisenhower Parkway then heading west along Eisenhower to the intersection of Eisenhower and Houston Avenue then heading southwest along both sides of Houston Avenue to include frontage parcels on both the east and west sides of the road down to Guy Paine Road. Then at the intersection of Houston Avenue and Guy Paine Road heading east towards Broadway along Guy Paine then at the intersection of Broadway and Guy Paine heading northeast along Broadway including frontage parcels on both sides of Broadway to the point of beginning at the intersection of Broadway and Eisenhower Parkway. 
(2)  East Macon-Bibb County enterprise zone. Beginning at the intersection of Coliseum Drive and Clinton Street then heading north to Emery Highway then along Emery Highway to Jeffersonville Road heading northeast toward Millerfield Road then at the intersection of Millerfield and New Clinton Road heading north towards Shurling Drive. At the intersection of New Clinton Road and Shurling Drive heading west to Millerfield Road. Then heading northeast on Millerfield Road to the intersection of Millerfield Road and Fairway Drive then southeast on Fairway Drive to a point located at approximately 83°33'34.48" W and 32°51'41.86" N then south to follow the city limits of the previous City of Macon around the southern end of Bowden Golf Course to Recreation Road. At Recreation Road headed west to Masseyville Road then northeast at the intersection of Masseyville Road and Lakeshore Drive then following Lakeshore Drive to Recreation Road. Then heading west on Recreation Road to Jeffersonville Road to Emery Highway. Then at eastern boundary of the Ocmulgee National Monument, at a point located at approximately 83°36'15.81" W and 32°50'52.91" N, heading southwest and then south along the boundary of the Ocmulgee National Monument to Dunlap Street. Then heading south on Dunlap Street to the intersection of Dunlap and Fletcher Street then heading west on Fletcher then southwest on Fletcher to Clinton Street then heading northwest on Clinton to the point of beginning at the intersection of Clinton and Coliseum Drive. 
(b)  Macon-Bibb County finds the area(s) defined in subsection (a) meets the qualification of the Act by exhibiting the following factors: 
(1)  Pervasive poverty. The Macon-Bibb County enterprise zone area falls within several contiguous portions of census tracts block groups that have at least 15 percent poverty or greater. 
(2)  Underdevelopment. There is significant documentation of underdevelopment throughout Macon-Bibb County. Macon-Bibb County has identified many businesses closures and vacancies in both commercial and residential properties through the Macon-Bibb County enterprise zone area. 
(3)  General distress. Macon-Bibb County has documented significant general distress throughout the Macon-Bibb County enterprise zone area. Adverse conditions found in this area include code enforcement violations, crime, abandonment, dilapidated structures and infrastructure, all of which contributes to general distress. 
(4)  General blight. There is significant evidence of general blight in the Macon-Bibb County enterprise zone area and this has been documented, in part, through the adoption of the URP. 
(c)  Macon-Bibb County reserves the right to alter and amend this section so as to expand the geographic area of the existing enterprise zone or to create new enterprise zones if other geographic areas of Macon-Bibb County are found to meet the qualifications of the Act by exhibiting factors that will be outlined in the amendment of this section. 
Sec. 26-303. - Economic stimulus. 
By implementing this article, Macon-Bibb County intends that qualifying business provide "economic stimulus" by having each qualifying business or service enterprise provide increased employment of five or more new full-time job equivalents. The quality and quantity of such additional economic stimulus shall be determined, on a case-by-case basis, by Macon-Bibb County. Such business or service enterprise may be new, an expansion or reinvestment of an existing business or service enterprise, or a successor to such business or service enterprise. Whenever possible, ten percent of such new employees shall be low-income or moderate-income individuals.
